column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, combine flour, white sugar, cocoa powder, 3/4 teaspoon salt, and baking powder. Stir in 1 1/2 cups milk, eggs, 1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla, and shortening. Mix until smooth using an electric mixer. Drop batter by rounded teaspoons onto ungreased cookie sheets. Leave space, and only use a teaspoon; these spread.
column4: Bake in preheated oven for 7 to 8 minutes. Remove from pan immediately, and cool on wire rack.
column5: To make the filling, combine the butter, confectioners' sugar, 1/8 teaspoon salt, marshmallow creme, 1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla, and 1 tablespoon milk in a medium bowl. Beat with mixer until fluffy. Spread filling on one cookie, and top with another sandwich style.

column2: Whisk the eggs with the sugar and salt until light. Melt the butter and stir in.
column3: Sift together all the remaining ingredients except the hazelnuts and fold in.
column4: Stir in the hazelnuts last.
column5: Heat Pizzelle iron and place 1 teaspoon of batter on each imprint. Close iron and bake 30 seconds.
column6: Cool on racks. Sprinkle with powdered sugar.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column3: Combine shortening, salt, and peanut butter and mix well. Add sugars gradually and cream thoroughly. Add beaten eggs and milk. Mix well.
column4: Sift flour with soda and add to first mixture, blending well.
column5: Drop from teaspoon on greased baking sheet. Press with fork or fancy glass. Bake 15-20 minutes

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a medium mixing bowl, cream together butter, confectioners' sugar, and vanilla until smooth with electric mixer. Stir in flour and cornstarch. Pop dough into your cookie press, and away you go! Press cookies out onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or until the peaks are golden.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Grease 9 x 9 inch pan.
column3: Melt butter or margarine in saucepan, then mix with other ingredients. Toast sesame seeds in oven or grill, being very careful to avoid burning them. Mix with other ingredients and stir well. Press into greased tin, should be about a half inch thick.
column4: Bake for 20 minutes (until lightly brown). Cool in pan, cutting into slices after a minute or so cooling, then leaving in pan until completely cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column3: Beat together white and brown sugars, butter and shortening until light and fluffy. Beat in eggs, vanilla and lemon extract to mix well.
column4: Sift together nutmeg, flour, baking powder, cream of tartar, salt and soda. Add alternately with buttermilk to creamed mixture.
column5: Drop tablespoonfuls of dough 2 1/2 inches apart onto greased baking sheet. With the back of the spoon, spread round and round making the outer edge of the cookies a little thicker than the center. Sprinkle generously with the reserved white sugar and place a fat raisin in the center of each cookie.
column6: Bake about 10 minutes. For softer cookies, bake in hot oven (425 degrees F (220 degrees C)) for about 8 minutes or until no indentation remains when you touch the center of the cookie with your fingertip. Remove cookies and cool on racks.

column2: Cream together all ingredients except cornflakes and cherries. Chill dough for one hour.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column4: Roll into 1 inch balls, then roll balls into crumbs. Place on parchment-lined sheets, top each cookie with a cherry. Bake for 13 minutes; 6 minutes on middle rack, 7-8 minutes on top rack.

column2: In a large bowl, cream together butter and brown sugar. Beat in egg, vanilla and maple flavoring. Beat in salt and flour until a smooth dough is formed. Shape dough into a log 12 inches long, wrap in wax paper, and refrigerate overnight.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Line cookie sheet with parchment paper.
column4: Slice dough into 1/4 inch slices. Place slices on cookie sheet. Top each cookie with a pecan half. Bake for 10 minutes in preheated oven, or until golden brown.

column2: Cook all ingredients except confectioner's sugar in iron skillet until smooth. Remove and add sugar. Spoon/drizzle over cookies. Frosting will harden when cool!
Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: In medium skillet, over medium heat, heat butter until lightly browned. Be careful not to burn. Add oats; saute, stirring constantly, until golden -- about 5 minutes. Remove from heat; cool.
column4: Meanwhile, sift flour with cinnamon, salt, and soda; set aside.
column5: In large bowl, combine sugar, egg, and vanilla. With wooden spoon, or portable electric mixer at medium speed, beat until light.
column6: Stir in rolled oats and flour mixture until well combined.
column7: Drop by slightly rounded teaspoonfuls, 3 inches apart, onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column8: Bake 10 to 12 minutes, or until golden. Remove to wire rack. Cool.

column2: In a large bowl, cream together the butter and white sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the egg, then stir in the vanilla. Combine the flour and salt; stir into the sugar mixture. Cover dough, and chill for at least one hour. Chill cookie sheets.
column3: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Press dough out onto ungreased, chilled cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or until lightly golden at the edges. Remove from cookie sheets to cool on wire racks.

column2: Sift flour with baking powder. Set aside.
column3: Cream butter and gradually add sugar and beat until fluffy. Add egg yolk, brandy and vanilla. Beat again until very light. Stir in almonds.
column4: Blend in flour mixture, mix to form a soft, smooth dough. Chill 30 minutes or until it can be handled easily.
column5: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column6: Shape level tablespoonfuls of dough into crescent-shapes. Place 1 inch apart on ungreased cookie sheet. Insert whole clove into center of each. Bake for 25-30 minutes or until light...do not brown. Cool on rack. Dust generously with confectioners' sugar.

column2: Mix together flour, baking powder and salt and set aside.
column3: In large mixing bowl, beat butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Add eggs and beat well. Stir in milk and vanilla, then add flour mixture. Combine well. Add nuts, raisins and chopped cherries.
column4: Shape dough into balls using level tablespoon as measure. Roll in crushed cornflakes. Place two inches apart on greased cookie sheets. Top with cherry quarter.
column5: Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for approximately 10 minutes until lightly browned. Remove immediately from sheets and cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Coarsely chop the hazelnuts. In a bowl, combine the nuts, sugar, butter, liqueur and eggs; mix well. Stir in the flour, baking powder and salt.
column4: Turn the dough out onto a floured surface and knead briefly; then form into a long loaf about 2 inches wide. Place the loaf on a parchment-lined or lightly oiled cookie sheet and bake in the middle of the oven for 25 min. or until firm. The loaf will have a cakelike texture. Remove from the oven and cool.
column5: Cut the loaf diagonally into 1/4-1/2 inch slices and lay those out on a cookie sheet. Bake for 20 minutes more, turning them once until both sides are lightly browned and toasted. Cool and store in an airtight container.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Place butter in a large heavy skillet and cook over medium-low heat without stirring for about 15 minutes, or until butter is a light tan color. Pour into mixing bowl. Place over a bowl of cold water and chill until firm.
column4: Add sugar, baking powder, vanilla and cardamom; beat until combined. Stir in flour.
column5: Shape dough into 1-inch balls. Place 1 inch apart on an ungreased cookie sheet. Top each with an almond; press almond slightly into dough.
column6: Bake until golden brown, 12 to 15 minutes. Remove to wire rack and cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: To Make Cookies: In a large bowl cream 1/2 cup of shortening , 1 cup sugar and 2 egg yolks. (Set egg whites aside for filling.) NOTE: If you don't want to use raw egg white in the filling, leave it out. Substitute 1 whole egg for the 2 egg yolks in the cookie recipe so you don't end up with leftover whites!!
column4: In a separate bowl sift together 2 cups flour, 5 T cocoa, 1 t baking powder, 1/2 t salt, 1 t baking soda. Add to other mixture alternately with milk, beating well. Add vanilla at the end.
column5: Drop by large spoonful on greased pan. Bake for 10-15 minutes. Remove to wire rack and cool completely.
column6: To Make Filling: Beat together 3/4 cup shortening, 2 cups confectioners' sugar, 2 egg whites and dash of salt till light. Add 1 tsp. vanilla.
column7: To assemble: Spread the flat side of one cookie circle with a spoonful of filling. Top with another.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: To Make Cookie: Cream together 1 cup shortening, 2 cups sugar, 2 eggs, and 1 teaspoon vanilla.
column4: Sift together 4 cups flour, 1 cup cocoa, and 1 tsp salt. Add alternately to cream mixture with sour milk. Add 3 tsp baking soda to hot water and stir into mixture.
column5: Drop on cookie sheet and bake for about 7-10 minutes.
column6: To Make Filling: Cream together egg whites, 1 T vanilla, powdered sugar, 4 T flour, 4 T milk and 1 1/4 cup shortening.
column7: Beat together until fluffy. Spread between flat sides of cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: To Make Cookies: Cream 6 T butter, 1 cup sugar and egg in bowl.
column4: In a separate bowl, mix together 2 cups flour, 5 T cocoa, 1 1/2 t soda, and 1 t salt. Add to butter mixture alternately with 1 cup milk and 1 teaspoon vanilla, mixing well after each addition.
column5: Drop by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets. Bake for 10 minutes. Remove to wire rack to cook completely.
column6: To Make Filling: Cream 3/4 cup margarine and 3/4 cup confectioners' sugar in bowl until light and fluffy. Blend in 1/4 teaspoon vanilla, 1 cup marshmallow creme and 1 tablespoon milk. Spread on half the cooled cookies; top with remaining cookies.

column2: Melt butter or margarine over low heat. Add sugars, peanut butter and vanilla. Mix well.
column3: Press into a 9 x 13 inch pan.
column4: Melt chocolate chips and spread over the top. Cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line cookie sheets with parchment paper.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the shortening and white sugar until smooth. Beat in eggs one at a time, and stir in vanilla. Combine the flour, baking powder, and baking soda; stir into the creamed mixture alternately with the buttermilk until a soft dough forms. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto prepared cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 10 minutes in preheated oven, or until light brown. Cool on wire racks.
column5: In a medium bowl, blend together melted butter and confectioners' sugar until smooth. Gradually stir in milk until frosting reaches the desired consistency. Mix in food coloring, if desired. Spread onto cooled cookies, and place frosted cookies on waxed paper or cooling racks until frosting is set.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Mix flour, butter and powdered sugar thoroughly. Press evenly into an ungreased 8 x 8 x 2 inch or 9 x 9 x 2 inch square pan. Make a little rim up the edges to hold in the filling. A quarter inch or so will do it. Bake 20 minutes.
column4: Beat remaining ingredients about 3 minutes of until light and fluffy. Pour over the hot crust, spreading it out evenly.
column5: Bake about 25 minutes longer or until no imprint remains when touched lightly in the center. Remove from oven, sprinkle the extra powdered sugar on the top, if you like. Cool, cut into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Line 2 cookie sheets with foil; lightly grease foil.
column3: Mix almond paste and granulated sugar in food processor until smooth. Add confectioners' sugar and 2 egg whites; process until smooth.
column4: Whisk remaining 2 egg whites in small bowl. Place pine nuts on shallow plate. With lightly floured hands roll dough into 1 inch balls. Coat balls in egg whites, shaking off excess, then roll in pine nuts, pressing lightly to stick. Arrange balls on cookie sheets, and flatten slightly to form a 1 1/2 inch round.
column5: Bake 15 to 18 minutes in the preheated oven, or until lightly browned. Let stand on cookie sheet 1 minute. Transfer to wire rack to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the sugar and shortening until smooth. Stir in the molasses. Combine the baking soda, ginger,cinnamon and 3 3/4 cups of the flour; blend into the molasses mixture. Add more flour if necessary to make dough stiff enough to roll out. Use remaining flour to dust rolling surface. Roll dough out to 1/4 inch thickness and cut with cookie cutters.
column4: Bake for 5 to 7 minutes in the preheated oven. remove from baking sheets to cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter, brown sugar, and white sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs, one at a time, then stir in the vanilla and almond extracts. Combine the flour, baking soda, and salt; gradually stir into the creamed mixture. Mix in the macadamia nuts and white chocolate. Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or until golden brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: In a large mixing bowl, cream together the margarine and sugar. Add eggs and beat until fluffy.
column4: In a separate bowl, mix together the flour, baking powder, and salt. Dissolve the baking soda in the buttermilk and add alternately to the margarine mixture with flour mixture.
column5: Roll out dough and sprinkle with nutmeg. Cut with a biscuit cutter. Dough will be very soft and delicate.
column6: Bake until lightly browned around the edges. A really soft, chewy cookie.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Add the eggs one at a time, beating well with each addition, then stir in the vanilla.Combine the flour, baking powder and baking soda, stir into the creamed mixture alternately with the milk. Drop by rounded tablespoonfuls onto an unprepared cookie sheet.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven. Allow cookies to cool on baking sheet for 5 minutes before removing to a wire rack to cool completely. You may glaze with confectioners' sugar when cool.

column2: Cream butter and sugar, then add sour cream. Stir in the flour, baking soda and salt. . Blend well and chill 2 hours or overnight.
column3: Divide dough in half and roll into a rectangle. Brush rectangles with water and sprinkle each with 1/2 package flavored gelatin. Roll up. Chill 1 to 2 hours.
column4: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column5: Cut dough into 1/4 to 1/2 inch thick slices. Put on greased cookie sheets and bake for 10 to 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream together butter or margarine, white sugar, and brown sugar. Add eggs and vanilla.
column4: Mix together in a separate bowl: salt, baking powder, baking soda, flour and oatmeal (put small amounts of oatmeal in blender until it turns to powder. Measure out 5 cups of oatmeal and only "powderize" that, NOT 5 cups "powderized" oatmeal).
column5: Mix all of the above.
column6: Add: chocolate chips, grated chocolate bar, and chopped nuts (any kind).
column7: Bake on greased cookie sheet (make golf ball sized balls) and bake about two inches apart. Bake for 8 -10 minutes. Do not overbake.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Cream butter, shortening, both sugars, egg, and vanilla in an electric mixer until fluffy.
column4: Stir in sifted dry ingredients.
column5: Add chocolate chips and walnuts.
column6: Drop by teaspoonfuls, 2 inches apart onto greased cookie sheet. Bake for 10-12 minutes or until golden.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the shortening and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the egg, then stir in the pumpkin and vanilla. Combine the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, nutmeg, and cinnamon; gradually mix into the creamed mixture. Stir in the walnuts and chocolate chips. Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto the prepared cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 15 minutes in the preheated oven, or until light brown. Cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the shortening, butter, brown sugar, and white sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla and coffee liqueur. Combine the flour, baking soda, and salt; stir into the sugar mixture. Mix in the oats, chocolate chips, and walnuts. Roll tablespoonfuls of dough into balls, and place them 2 inches apart onto the prepared cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, or until golden. Cool on a wire rack for a few minutes before eating!

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Combine flour, baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon, nutmeg, ground cloves, and salt; set aside.
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together the 1/2 cup of butter and white sugar. Add pumpkin, egg, and 1 teaspoon vanilla to butter mixture, and beat until creamy. Mix in dry ingredients. Drop on cookie sheet by tablespoonfuls; flatten slightly.
column4: Bake for 15 to 20 minutes in the preheated oven. Cool cookies, then drizzle glaze with fork.
column5: To Make Glaze: Combine confectioners' sugar, milk, 1 tablespoon melted butter, and 1 teaspoon vanilla. Add milk as needed, to achieve drizzling consistency.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a medium size mixing bowl, mix together 3 teaspoons baking powder and 3 1/4 cups flour.
column4: Beat together brown sugar and shortening then add eggs, orange rind and vanilla. Mix in flour mixture, alternating the flour mixture and sour milk until all is blended. Drop dough by teaspoonful onto cookie sheets.
column5: Bake 12-15 minutes. Let cool and frost cookies.
column6: To Make Frosting: Mix together powdered sugar, 1 teaspoon butter and enough orange juice mixed in to make it able to spread over cooled cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Cream shortening and sugar, then add the eggs. Mix well. Add vanilla and pumpkin. Set aside.
column4: Sift dry ingredients, then blend into the "wet" ingredients. Fold in the nuts and raisins. Mix well.
column5: Drop by heaping teaspoons onto a greased cookie sheet, bake for 10 - 15 minutes. Cool. Best eaten if you let them "ripen" for a day. Store in a sealed container.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C) Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter and brown sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs and vanilla, then stir in the pumpkin puree until well blended. Combine the flour, baking soda, and pumpkin pie spice; stir into the pumpkin mixture. Fold in the white chocolate and pecans. Drop by heaping spoonfuls onto the prepared cookie sheets. Cookies should be at least 2 inches apart.
column4: Bake for 20 to 22 minutes in the preheated oven, until bottoms are lightly browned. Cool for 5 minutes on baking sheets before removing to cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheet.
column3: In a saucepan melt chocolate over low heat. Let cool.
column4: In a small bowl mix flour, baking powder and salt.
column5: In a medium bowl beat margarine on low speed until smooth. Add sugar and beat until creamy. Stir in egg, vanilla and chocolate. Add flour mixture and mix well, forming a stiff dough.
column6: To make spider, shape a 2 inch flat oval for the body. Make the spider's head by flattening a circle about 1/2 inch wide. Shape dough for legs each about 2 inches long and less than 1/4 inch wide.
column7: Attach the head and legs to body. Put two red candies into head for eyes. Bake for 5-8 minutes. Let spiders cool on baking sheet to avoid breaking when moving.

column2: Cream butter, slowly add cornstarch and 1/3 cup confectioners' sugar; beat til fluffy. Stir in flour with wooden spoon (very soft dough). Cover and chill 1 hour.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column4: Roll dough into 24, 1 inch balls. Place 1 and 1/2 inches apart on ungreased sheet. Press slight indentation on top of each cookie. Bake for 10-12 minutes until firm, not brown. Cool, top with icing.
column5: To Make Icing: Blend cream cheese and 1 cup powdered sugar til smooth. Mix in vanilla or 1/4 t. of another extract and a few drops of food coloring. Mix well.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Grease a 15 x 10 x 1 inch baking pan.
column3: To make base, cream 1/3 cup butter flavored shortening and 1/2 cup peanut butter in large bowl at medium speed in an electric mixer. Blend in brown sugar. Beat in eggs one at a time until creamy.
column4: Combine all-purpose flour, baking powder and salt in a small bowl. Set aside. Combine 1/4 cup milk and 1 tsp. vanilla in measuring cup. Add dry ingredients and milk alternately to creamed mixture. Mix at low speed. Scrape the sides of the bowl frequently and beat until blended.
column5: Spread batter into prepared pan and bake for 18 to 20 minutes. Let cool.
column6: For Frosting: Cream 1/4 cup butter flavored shortening and 2/3 cup peanut butter in large bowl at medium speed of electric mixer. Add 4 cups of confectioners' sugar and 1/2 cup milk. Beat until fluffy. Spread on cooled cookie base. For drizzle melt chocolate pieces on very low heat in small saucepan. Drizzle chocolate from end of spoon back and forth over frosting. Cut into 2 inch squares. Refrigerate 15 to 20 minutes until chocolate is firm.

column2: Mix 1/2 cup butter or margarine, white sugar, cocoa, egg and vanilla in a heavy sauce pan or double boiler. Stir over low heat until mixture is of custard like consistency.
column3: Combine graham crackers, coconut and walnuts and add to the melted mixture. Mix well and pack into buttered 9 inch square cake pan.
column4: Cream 1/4 cup butter, confectioners' sugar, vanilla custard powder and milk. Beat until creamy and spread over melted base.
column5: Refrigerate till hardened.
column6: Melt semi-sweet chocolate with 1 tablespoon butter and drizzle over custard icing. Refrigerate. When totally hard cut into square bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column3: Cream butter, and sugar continuing to beat. Beat in egg, then flour, and then vanilla.
column4: Drop 2 inches apart on a greased cookie sheet, and top with a raisin, chocolate chip, or nut.
column5: Bake for 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 450 degrees F (230 degrees C).
column3: Cream together 2 cups sugar, 1/2 cup shortening and eggs. Combine 1 cup milk plus 1 teaspoon vinegar. Add to mixture with vanilla, blending well. Set aside.
column4: Mix together flour, baking soda, salt, baking powder, and cocoa in a separate bowl. Gradually add to creamed mixture until well blended. Finally add the boiling water and mix well.
column5: Drop by rounded teaspoonful on to ungreased cookie sheets. Bake for 5 minutes. Remove to baking rack to cool.
column6: Cream margarine and shortening. Add 1 cup milk and 1 teaspoon vanilla, continuing to beat. Slowly add pudding mix and 1 cup confectioners' sugar.
column7: Assemble cookies by spreading filling on one side of cookie and then placing another on top.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Dissolve baking soda in persimmon pulp and set aside.
column4: Sift flour, spices and salt together, set aside.
column5: Cream together butter or margarine and sugar until fluffy, beat in egg and persimmon. Stir in dry ingredients. Stir in nuts and raisins.
column6: Drop by teaspoonfuls onto greased cookie sheet. Bake for 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter and brown sugar. Add eggs, one at a time, beating thoroughly after each addition, then stir in the almond extract. Sift flour, baking powder, and salt together; stir into the creamed mixture until well blended. Turn into a greased 15x10x1 inch jelly roll pan and spread evenly to edges.
column4: Sprinkle a mixture of almonds and cinnamon over batter, then sprinkle with a mixture of red and green sugars.
column5: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, until the edges start to pull away from the sides of the pan. Cut into bars while still warm.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream butter and both sugars. Add eggs and vanilla. In a blender or food processor, process the oats until finely chopped.
column4: Add the chopped oats, flour, baking soda, salt, baking powder into the creamed butter and sugar mixture and mix well. Stir in the chocolate and nuts.
column5: Roll dough into 1 1/2 - 2 inch balls (do not press) and place 2 inches apart on a cookie sheet. Bake for 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column3: Combine sugar, oil, milk, eggs, baking powder and vanilla in large bowl. Blend in enough flour to form a soft dough.
column4: Roll into walnut size balls. Place on ungreased cookie sheets
column5: Bake for 15-20 minutes. Cookies will be pale. Remove to rack to cool.
column6: Hollow out cookie center. Reserve crumbs. Combine 2 cups crumbs, preserves, almonds, cream cheese, instant tea powder, brandy and cinnamon. Mix to blend.
column7: Fill cookies with crumb mixture. Press 2 cookies together to form peach.
column8: Brush lightly with brandy or water and dip one spot in the red sugar for blush and roll entire cookie in orange sugar. Top with a icing leaf or purchase the plastic peach leaves.

column2: Cream butter and sugar until fluffy. Beat in egg and vanilla. Add baking powder and salt. Beat well. Add flour and mix until blended. Remove 2/3 of dough. Roll or pat dough out to form two 10 x 4 inch rectangles. Add cocoa to remaining 1/3 of dough. Mix until blended. Shape chocolate dough into two 10 inch long rolls. Place on rectangle and roll plain dough to cover chocolate dough completely, not including ends. Wrap in plastic wrap and chill at least 2 hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column4: Cut dough into 1/8 inch slices with a sharp knife. Place two slices side by side on a cookie sheet to resemble an owl's face. Pinch upper "corners" to resemble ears. Put chocolate chips in each dark circle for eyes and a cashew in the center for the beak.
column5: Bake for 8 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, or until lightly browned.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column3: Blend together butter, flour, white sugar, salt, and vanilla. Add black walnuts and mix well.
column4: Shape into 1 inch balls. Bake for 25 minutes on ungreased cookie sheet. Remove from oven and let cool.
column5: Roll in powdered sugar. Store flat - not stacked on top of each other.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column3: Cream the butter, sugar and eggs well. Add remaining ingredients and mix thoroughly.
column4: Pour batter into tart shells, no more than half full. Bake for 20 - 25 minutes. Watch carefully!!--they'll burn quickly. Filling will keep in the refrigerator for 2 weeks or so. Liquid coffee creamer can be used for cream. Use any good pie pastry for shells.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream butter or margarine and sugars. Add already beaten eggs and vanilla.
column4: Mix dry ingredients together and mix with creamed mixture. Add chocolate chips and nuts.
column5: Bake 8 to 10 minutes until done. These are not HOT HOT -- Just a little surprise, definitely a little kick, goes well with the chocolate.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Combine butter or margarine, baking soda, white sugar and your favorite extract flavor. Beat these ingredients together with an electric mixer until fluffy. Add self-rising flour Beat well.
column4: Roll dough into walnut sized balls. Place them two inches apart onto the cookie sheet and flatten slightly. Press ice cream stick into the flattened side of the cookie, and press down. This way, you know how large the cookie will be when baked. Add whatever topping to each cookie you like, OR, before pressing stick into the cookie, roll each cookie into sprinkles first, then flatten.
column5: Bake until edges are lightly golden.

column2: In a small saucepan combine 3/4 cup of the candies and milk. Melt over low heat, stirring until smooth. Remove from heat.
column3: Prepare cookie mixes according to package directions. Stir melted chocolate into half the dough. Form chocolate dough into two 12-inch long rolls about 1 inch in diameter. Wrap in wax paper or foil. Chill until firm, about 2 hours.
column4: Divide plain dough in half. On a well-floured surface, roll each plain half out to a 12 x 6 inch rectangle. Place a chocolate roll on long edge. Roll up, pressing doughs lightly together so plain dough encases chocolate roll. Repeat with remaining dough.
column5: Wrap each roll in wax paper or foil. Chill about 2 hours until firm. Preheat oven to 375 F (190 C).
column6: Cut each roll into 1/4 inch slices. Place 2 slices so they are touching on greased baking sheet. In the center of each chocolate circle, place one of the remaining candies for eye. Where the slices touch, place a cashew to form nose.
column7: Bake until the plain cookie is lightly browned, 8 to 10 minutes. Cool cookies on baking sheets 2 to 3 minutes. Remove and cool on wire racks.

column2: (Directions as written:) Cream fat and sugar, beat in whipped eggs, add baking powder and 1 cup flour, then water and spices; add remaining flour gradually, working in more flour until dough is stiff enough to roll.
column3: Sprinkle flour over pastry board. Make a ball of dough, lay it on the board. Rub rolling pin with flour and roll out dough into a sheet 1/4 inch thick. Cut in round cakes, sift granulated sugar over each, and bake quickly 400 - 450 F. (200 - 230 C).

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Mix 1 cup butter, 1 cup brown sugar and 2 eggs. Stir in 2 cups flour and 1/2 teaspoon salt. Press in ungreased 9 x 13 pan.
column4: Bake for 25 minutes. Let cool.
column5: Heat chocolate and 1/2 cup butter over low heat, stirring constantly until melted. Remove from heat.
column6: Stir in 2 cups powdered sugar and 2 eggs. Beat until smooth. Stir in marshmallows and pecans. Spread mixture over cookie-base. Refrigerate 2 hours. Cut into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Stir flour, baking powder and salt together. Beat eggs until light; add sugar gradually, beating well after each addition.
column4: Stir in almond flavoring, then dry ingredients. Fold in chocolate pieces, fruits, and nuts.
column5: Spread dough evenly in greased 9 x 13 inch pan. Bake 30 to 35 minutes. If desired, when cooled, frost with powdered sugar icing. Cut into bars and garnish each bar with a chocolate piece.

column2: Mix the butter or margarine, sugar, egg yolks and vanilla. Add the flour and mix by hand.
column3: Spoon into cookie press and press onto ungreased cookie sheets. Sprinkle with colored sugars.
column4: Bake in preheated 400 degrees F (200 degrees C) oven for 7-10 minutes.

column2: Mix shortening, sugar, egg and vanilla thoroughly. Blend flour, soda and salt; stir in.
column3: Form into roll 2 1/2" across. Wrap in waxed paper. Chill until firm.
column4: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column5: With a thin sharp knife, slice 1/8 inch thick. Place a little apart on ungreased baking sheet. Bake 8 to 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream together sugars and butter or margarine. Beat in eggs, add flour and baking soda, mix well.
column4: Fold in butterscotch chips and potato chips.
column5: Drop by tsp. on cookie sheet and bake for 8 to 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream butter and sugar with mixer. Add flour and mix with a wooden spoon. Use hands to thoroughly mix.
column4: Press into a jelly roll pan. Prick to bottom all over with a fork being sure the fork hits the bottom and the pricks are close together.
column5: Bake for 10 minutes. Reduce the heat to 300 and continue to bake for 40 minutes more. Wait 2 minutes then cut into finger size bars. Cool thoroughly in pan.

column2: In a large saucepan over medium heat, combine corn syrup and white sugar. Bring to a boil, boil for one minute, and remove from heat. Stir in peanut butter until well blended. Mix in cereal until evenly coated. Drop by spoonfuls onto waxed paper.
column3: In a glass bowl in the microwave, or using a double boiler, melt chocolate chips and butterscotch chips, stirring frequently until smooth. Drizzle on the top of the cookies.

column2: Grease 3 - 13 x 9 inch pans. Line with wax paper. Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Combine almond paste, sugar, butter, egg yolks and almond extract. Beat for 5 minutes until light and fluffy. Beat in flour and salt.
column4: In a separate bowl, beat egg whites until stiff peaks form. With a wooden spoon, fold into the almond mixture.
column5: Divide dough into 3 -1 1/2 cup portions. Add red coloring to one of the portions, and green to the another. Spread the batter in the 3 separate prepared pans (keeping the colors separate).
column6: Bake for 15 minutes, or until edges are golden brown. (Each layer will be 1/4 inch thick). Remove cakes from pan immediately. Cool thoroughly.
column7: Stack layers in a 9 x 13 inch pan, spreading apricot jam between layers (no jam on top layer). Place second 9 x 13 inch pan on top and weigh down with two 5 pound bags of sugar or flour. Refrigerate overnight.
column8: Melt chocolate over hot water and spread over cake. Allow to set. Trim edges and cup into 1 inch squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream sugar and shortening together. Add eggs and dry ingredients. Add the milk last.
column4: No need to chill this dough, simply roll out to 1/4 inch thickness, cut out and bake 10-12 minutes.

column2: Melt butter in top of double boiler over hot water. Add chocolate morsels; stir until melted, then remove from heat. Let cool. Add marshmallows; stir lightly.
column3: Spread half of the coconut in a greased 9x9x2 - inch pan. Spread chocolate mixture over coconut in pan. Top with remaining coconut. Press down with a spoon. Refrigerate until set. When well chilled, cut into small squares.

column2: In small bowl blend flour, cocoa and baking soda. Mix until well blended.
column3: In large bowl beat white and brown sugars, butter or margarine and 1/4 cup peanut butter, until light and fluffy. Add vanilla and egg, beat. Stir in flour mixture until blended. Set aside.
column4: To make Filling: Combine confectioner's sugar and 3/4 cup peanut butter. Blend well.
column5: Roll filling into 30 1-inch balls. For each cookie, with floured hands, shape about 1 tablespoon of dough around 1 peanut butter ball, covering completely. Place 2 inches apart on an ungreased cookie sheet. Flatten with glass dipped in white sugar.
column6: Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 7-9 minutes. When cookies are done, they should be set and slightly cracked.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease an 11x7 inch baking pan.
column3: In medium sauce pan, over low heat, combine butter or margarine, brown sugar and honey. Cook, stirring, until butter or margarine is melted and sugar is dissolved. Remove from heat. Add oats, nuts, coconut and sesame seeds. Mix with a wooden spoon until well combined. Press mixture evenly into the prepared baking pan.
column4: Bake for 15 to 18 minutes in the preheated oven, until the top is golden brown. Let cool in the pan and cut into bars.

column2: Combine raisins and water in small saucepan. Simmer over low heat 20 to 30 minutes, until raisins are plump. Drain liquid from raisins into measuring cup. If necessary, add enough additional water to raisin liquid to measure 1/2 cup. Set drained raisins and 1/2 cup raisin liquid aside to cool.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, beat shortening, sugar, eggs and vanilla with an electric mixer until smooth and creamy. Stir in reserved 1/2 cup raisin water.
column4: Sift the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon and cloves into a separate bowl. Stir flour mixture into shortening mixture with a spoon. Stir in oats, nuts and reserved raisins; mix well.
column5: Drop dough by rounded teaspoonfuls, about 2 inches apart, onto ungreased baking sheets. Bake in a preheated 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) oven 8 to 10 minutes, or until lightly browned. Note: These cookies freeze well.

column2: Cream together butter, margarine, cottage cheese, salt and 4 cups of flour. Shape into a large square, cover and chill overnight.
column3: Cut dough into 4 quarters. Roll each quarter out individually, about 1/8 inch thick. Cut into 8 inch strips, as wide as you like.
column4: Roll over tubes (I use clothespins covered with aluminum foil). Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) until brown.
column5: To make Filling: Cook milk and 4 tablespoons of flour until thick paste forms. Let cool completely.
column6: Beat shortening and confectioner's sugar until fluffy. Add marshmallow cream and vanilla. Then add COLD paste and beat.
column7: Fill tubes with cream filling. Sprinkle with confectioner's sugar just before serving.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Spray madeleine molds with non-stick spray.
column3: In a double boiler, heat eggs and sugar stirring constantly; whipping in as much air as possible. Remove from heat, let cool.
column4: Stir in flour add remaining ingredients.
column5: Fill madeleine molds with a generous amount of batter, but don't spread it out. Bake until lightly browned; approx. 15 minutes. Cool one minute, remove to racks to cool completely. *Extracts can be varied and spices changed to suit tastes. Sprinkle with powdered sugar or dip in chocolate.

column2: Microwave marshmallows and butter on High for 2 minutes. Stir, then microwave on High for 2 minutes more. Stir. (This can be done in a double boiler if one doesn't have a microwave.)
column3: Add and mix quickly the coloring, extracts, then cornflakes. Drop by spoonfuls in clumps on greased wax paper and decorate with 3 red hots each.
column4: Once cool, transfer to lightly greased serving/storage tray with lightly greased fingers.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Cream butter or margarine; gradually add sugar, beating well.
column4: Add flour, and mix well. Stir in peppermint extract.
column5: Divide dough in half and place in separate bowls. Tint half of dough with red food coloring and the other half with the green food coloring.
column6: Roll dough into balls using 1/2 teaspoon dough per ball. For each wreath shaped cookie, place six balls in a circle, alternating colors, on ungreased cookie sheets. Press together securely. Bake for 8 minutes. Let cool 10 minutes; then remove to racks. Cool completely.

column2: Cream together the butter with the sugar in a large mixing bowl. Beat in egg yolks and vanilla. Gradually beat in flour.
column3: Turn into a ball, cover and let stand at room temperature for 2 hours.
column4: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column5: To form the crescents, roll about 1 Tbsp of the dough in the palms of your hands. Then continue rolling to form a rope about 3 inches long and 1/2 inch thick. Bend rope to form crescent. Repeat with remaining dough, placing on ungreased cookie sheets about 1 inch apart.
column6: Bake for about 10 to 12 minutes. Cookies should be white in color. Let cool on cookie sheets for 5 minutes to prevent breaking. Then, while cookies are still warm, carefully roll in vanilla sugar. (May be found in bulk food stores). Repeat with remaining cookies. Cool cookies completely.
column7: Melt chocolate in a double boiler set over low heat. When cookies are cool, dip tips of each cookie in melted chocolate, then set on waxed paper to dry.

column2: In large bowl, beat together butter or margarine and cottage cheese til light and fluffy. Add flour until dough forms a ball.
column3: Divide dough into 3 equal portions. Wrap in plastic wrap and refrigerate until firm.
column4: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) and grease cookie sheets.
column5: To Make Filling: Combine egg whites, nuts, water, and ground cinammon. Mix well and set aside.
column6: On a floured surface roll 1 portion of dough into a 10 inch circle. Spread circle with 1/3 of the filling to within approximately 1/2 inch of the edge.
column7: Cut circle into 24 pie-shaped wedges. Beginning at outer edge roll up each wedge tightly. Place point side down on cookie sheet 1 1/2 inches apart. Bake 13-15 minutes or until golden (be sure to watch carefully as these cookies burn easily).
column8: Remove to rack to cool. Repeat process with each remaining portion of dough and filling.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl mix oil and 1 cup of sugar. Add egg, beat well. Stir in molasses, 2 cups flour, baking soda and spices. If necessary, add more flour to make a firm dough.
column4: Shape dough into 1 1/4 inch balls. Roll in 1/3 cup sugar. Place 3 inches apart on an ungreased baking sheet. Bake 12 to 14 minutes or until tops crack. Remove from baking sheet and cool on rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream together shortening and brown sugar. Add eggs and mix well.
column4: Dissolve baking soda in hot water. Stir into mixture. Add flour, salt and cinnamon. Mix well.
column5: Drop by spoonful onto cookie sheet. Bake 10 - 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the sugar, shortening and eggs. Add vanilla and mix well.
column4: In a separate bowl, mix together the flour, baking soda, and cream of tartar. Add to brown sugar mixture and stir until it is a soft dough.
column5: Roll out, cut with cookie cutters and bake for 8 to 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column3: Stir together the honey, oil, and eggs. Add the orange rind and salt. Mix in the oatmeal and stir well.
column4: Drop on cookie sheets and bake for 8 to 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter and sugar until smooth. Beat in the egg, vanilla, and ricotta cheese. Combine the flour and salt; blend into the ricotta mixture. Stir in the candied fruit and walnuts using a wooden spoon. Drop dough by rounded teaspoons onto ungreased cookie sheets. Top each cookie with a pecan half.
column4: Bake for 12 to 15 minutes in the preheated oven, or until sides begin to brown. Remove and cool cookies on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C.)
column3: Combine butter or margarine, flour and confectioner's sugar and beat for 10 minutes.
column4: Drop from teaspoon onto cookie sheet. Decorate with maraschino cherry pieces.
column5: Bake in preheated oven for 15 to 18 minutes, or until bottoms are lightly browned.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: To Make Dough: In a mixing bowl, cream 1 cup butter, 1 cup confectioner's sugar and 2 teaspoons vanilla. Combine 2 cups flour and 1/2 teaspoon salt. Gradually add to the creamed mixture and mix well.
column4: Shape into 1 inch balls; place 2 inches apart on ungreased baking sheets. Make a deep indentation in the center of each cookie.
column5: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes or until the edges just start to brown. Remove to wire racks to cool completely.
column6: To Make Filling: Beat cream cheese, 1 cup confectioner's sugar, 2 tablespoons flour, and 1 teaspoon vanilla in a mixing bowl. Add pecans and coconut; mix well.
column7: Spoon 1/2 teaspoon of the filling into each cookie.
column8: To Make Topping: Heat chocolate chips, 2 tablespoons butter or margarine and water in a small saucepan until melted. Stir in 1/2 cup confectioner's sugar. Drizzle over cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Beat all ingredients except flour and nuts in a large bowl with mixer on medium speed until blended (mixture will look curdled).
column4: With mixer on low speed beat in flour just until blended. Stir in walnuts.
column5: Drop by rounded tablespoon 2 inches apart on ungreased cookie sheet. Bake 10 to 12 minutes until tops look dry. Cool on cookie sheet 1 minute before removing to a wire rack to cool completely. Frost with Orange Cream Cheese Frosting (see footnote for link to recipe).

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Combine flour and brown sugar. Cut in butter and margarine until mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
column4: Press into a 9 x 13 inch pan and bake for 10 minutes.
column5: Combine remaining ingredients except pecans and blend well. Stir in pecans. Pour over baked crust.
column6: Reduce oven temperature to 275 degrees F (140 degrees C). Bake 50 minutes or until set. Cool in pan on wire rack. Cut into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column3: Cream butter or margarine and sugar. Add other ingredients. Drop by teaspoon on lightly greased cookie sheet.
column4: Bake for 18-20 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream together butter, powdered sugar and almond extract. Add flour in steps (not all at one time).
column4: Knead with hands, shape into crescents. Bake for 20 minutes or until light brown. While warm, roll in confectioner's sugar.

column2: Cream together shortening, 1 cup white sugar and 1 cup of brown sugar. Add eggs, vanilla and 1 tablespoon of water.
column3: Sift flour, soda, and saltTWICE and add to sugar mixture. Divide dough into 2 or 3 parts.
column4: Cook dates, 1/2 cup white sugar and 1 cup water over low heat, stirring constantly until it becomes a smooth paste. Let cool.
column5: Roll each section of dough into rectangles 1/4 - 1/2 inch thick.
column6: Spread filling over rectangles and roll up like a jelly roll. Cover and chill dough until firm; 2 - 3 hours.
column7: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Slice dough 1/4 to 1/2 inch thick. Bake for 10 to 12 minutes.

column2: Chop pitted dates in food chopper. Place dates into small saucepan and add 1/4 cup sugar, dash of salt, and 1 1/4 cups of water. Cook, stirring constantly until mixture is of a soft consistency. Remove from heat.
column3: Add grated lemon rind, lemon juice, and chopped nuts. Mix well and chill.
column4: Cream together 3/4 cup butter and gradually add 1/2 cup white sugar and 1cup lightly packed brown sugar. Beat well. Beat 2 eggs until thick and add to creamed mixture part at a time, beating well after each addition. Stir in 1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla.
column5: Measure into a sifter 3 1/2 cups flour, 1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder, 1/4 teaspoon baking soda, and 3/4 teaspoon of salt. Sift together twice. Sift dry ingredients into creamed mixture about 1/4 at a time. Combine thoroughly after each addition. Chill until firm.
column6: Divide dough into 3 parts. Roll out 1 part at a time into a rectangle. Spread with date filling. Roll up jelly roll fashion in waxed paper. Chill several hours.
column7: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column8: With sharp knife, slice 1/4 inch thick slices off of rolls and place on greased cookie sheets. Bake 10 - 13 minutes. Let cool.

column2: Cream the butter and brown sugar together in a mixing bowl until smooth. Add the eggs, one at a time, beating well after each addition. Stir in the vanilla. Sift the cinnamon, salt, baking soda, and flour together in a second mixing bowl. Slowly stir the flour mixture into the egg mixture until evenly blended.
column3: Divide the dough evenly into three portions and place each on a square of waxed paper. Wrap and refrigerate until firm, about 1 hour.
column4: Meanwhile, make the filling by combine the dates, pecans, water and white sugar in a saucepan set over low heat. Cook and stir until the filling has a paste-like consistency. Cool slightly.
column5: Working with one portion at a time, roll out the dough on a lightly floured surface to make a rectangle about 1/4 inch thick. Spread 1/3 of the filling evenly over the dough; roll up to make a log. Repeat the process with the remaining dough. Refrigerate until firm, about 1 hour.
column6: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Lightly grease two baking sheets.
column7: Using a sharp, serrated knife, cut the rolls into 1/4 inch slices. Place the slices on prepared baking sheets.
column8: Bake in preheated oven until set and lightly browned, about 15 minutes. Cool on racks.

column2: In a large bowl, beat sugar and 1/2 cup butter with mixer at high speed until light and fluffy. Add flour, vanilla, salt, and egg; beat on low speed until blended, occasionally scraping bowl.
column3: Shape dough into ball. Wrap and refrigerate 1 hour, until firm enough to handle.
column4: To Make Filling: Stir remaining ingredients and 4 Tablespoons butter untl mixed. Set aside.
column5: On waxed paper, roll half of dough into 10 by 8 inch rectangle. Spread dough with half of the poppy seed mixture. Starting at narrow side, roll jelly-roll fashion. Wrap and refrigerate 1 hour, until firm. Repeat with remaining dough and filling.
column6: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column7: Slice one roll cross-wise into 1/4 inch thick slices. Place 1/2 inch apart on ungreased cookie sheet. Bake 10 to 12 minutes, until lightly browned. Cool on wire rack and repeat with remaining dough.

column2: Cream butter, sugar, and egg yolks. Add flour, salt, poppy seeds and vanilla. Mix well. Chill dough for one hour.
column3: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column4: Form dough into teaspoon sized balls. Place on cookie sheet and dip the bottom of a juice glass into sugar and press balls flat. Bake 8 to 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Mix together sugar, shortening or margarine, vanilla extract and almond extract Cream these together until light. Add eggs and beat well.
column4: Combine flour, baking soda, baking powder and salt ( use 1/2 teas. if using margarine). Add to sugar mixture alternately with milk, ending with flour mixture. Dough will be quite stiff and may require mixing the last bit of flour in by hand.
column5: Roll out portions of dough on floured board and cut with your favorite cookie cutters.
column6: Place on greased cookie sheets and bake for 10 to 12 minutes . Test for doneness by touching lightly with your finger. If there is no dent, they're done. Cool and frost, decorate with colored sugars and colored frosting..
column7: Note: If you like crisp cookies, roll the dough thinner. For more cake-like dough roll thicker and use metal cookie cutters. Originally we used Anise oil to flavor the dough (5 to 6 drops) in place of the vanilla and almond extracts. But my children prefer the extracts.

column2: Cream butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat eggs until foamy, add to mixture. Sift flour with spices, cocoa and soda. Save out 1/2 cup of flour mixture. Add the rest of flour mixture to butter mixture. Stir in coffee.
column3: Cut fruits into small slivers and dredge fruit and chopped pecans lightly in flour saved out for this. Add to fruit and the rest of flour to batter, mixing thoroughly.
column4: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column5: Drop by teaspoon onto cookie sheet. Do not place too close together. Bake for 12 to 15 minutes. Do not over-brown. Store cookies in jars.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Cream butter or margarine and 1/4 cup white sugar until light and fluffy. Blend in almond extract. Add flour and salt; mix well.
column4: Shape rounded teaspoonfuls of dough into balls. Place on ungreased cookie sheet. Flatten middle of dough ball with thumb print. Bake 8 - 10 minutes or until golden brown around edges. Let cool.
column5: To make Frosting: combine confectioner's sugar and cocoa. Add water and vanilla and mix well. Place chocolate frosting into thumb print indention of cooled cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets or line with parchment paper.
column3: Melt unsweetened chocolate in top of double boiler or hot, not boiling water. Remove from heat; let cool.
column4: Cream butter, melted chocolate and sugar in large bowl until blended. Add egg and vanilla; beat until light. Blend in flour, baking soda, chocolate chips and macadamia nuts.
column5: Drop dough by rounded teaspoonfuls 2 inches apart onto prepared cookie sheets. Bake 10 to 12 minutes or until firm. DO NOT OVERBAKE. Remove to wire racks to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Mix well the shortening and butter, sugar, egg, almond and vanilla. In a separate bowl, mix flour and salt and add to shortening mixture. Divide dough in half.
column4: Blend red food coloring into one half. Roll 1 teaspoon of the red dough and 1 teaspoon of the white dough on lightly floured board into 4 inch strips. Place strips side by side and press lightly together and twist like a rope. Curve top of rope down to look like the handle of a candy cane.
column5: Bake 9 minutes or until lightly browned. Remove while still warm. Sprinkle with 1/2 cup crushed peppermint stick candy and 1/2 cup sugar (optional).

column2: Cook flour and milk over low heat until thick.
column3: Cream together sugar, butter and shortening until smooth. (Sounds greasy, but it is good and mixes in.)
column4: When the flour mixture is cool add a small amount to the sugar mixture and beat. Continue to add small amounts of the flour and milk mixture to the sugar mixture until it is all mixed in. Whip until it is has the texture of whipped cream. This is best when it is made a few hours or the day before. Enjoy!!

column2: Thoroughly cream shortening and sugar; add egg and beat well. Melt chocolate over low heat. Add chocolate and vanilla to shortening mixture. Mix well.
column3: Sift dry ingredients; add to creamed mixture alternately with milk. Stir in nuts.
column4: Shape into rolls. Wrap in waxed paper; chill thoroughly or overnight.
column5: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column6: Using a sharp knife, cut 1/4 inch thick slices off the rolls and place about 2 inches apart on cookie sheets. Bake 8 to 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, combine all the ingredients except the almonds; mix well with a spoon. Stir in the almonds until well blended; the dough will be thick and sticky.
column4: Place half of the dough on a 10 x 15 inch rimmed cookie sheet that has been coated with nonstick baking spray. Form a slightly rounded 4 x 12 inch loaf that is about 3/4 inch thick. Repeat with the remaining dough on a second cookie sheet and bake for 30 minutes.
column5: Remove from the oven and reduce the temperature to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C). Allow the loaves to cool for 20 to 25 minutes, then cut into 1/2 inch thick slices. Lay the slices cut side down on the cookie sheets and bake for 15 more minutes. Turn the cookies over and bake another 15 minutes or until very crisp. Allow to cool, then store in an airtight container. Will keep several weeks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Mix ingredients well in the order given.
column4: Drop by teaspoon on cookie sheet and bake for 10-12 minutes. Under bake for a chewy cookie.

column2: Lightly butter a 7 or 8 inch square pan.
column3: Put all ingredients (except chocolate squares) into mixing bowl: mix well together. Press into pan; smooth surface.
column4: Melt chocolate in double broiler; spread evenly over top of mixture. Score with fork. Refrigerate until firm. Cut into small bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column3: Cream margarine, sugar, oil, eggs, and vanilla. Beat well.
column4: Mix flour, salt, cocoa, and baking soda together. Add dry ingredients to first mixture alternately with sour milk. Fold in zucchini.
column5: Bake in a 9 x 13 inch pan for 35 minutes or until done. Frost with a chocolate frosting.

column2: Cream the butter and sugar together until light and fluffy. Blend in eggs and beat well. Sift together flour and baking powder; add to creamed mixture. Add milk and vanilla; mix well.
column3: Cover and chill for 1 to 2 hours.
column4: Roll very thin. Cut with cookie cutter dipped in flour. Place on greased cookie sheet. Bake at 400 degrees F (200 degrees C) for 6 to 8 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 250 degrees F (120 degrees C). Lightly grease a cookie sheet.
column3: In a large glass or metal mixing bowl, beat egg whites to soft peaks. Gradually add sugar, continuing to beat until whites form stiff peaks. Stir in vanilla and pecans. Drop mounded spoonfuls onto the prepared cookie sheet.
column4: Bake 1 hour in the preheated oven. Turn off heat, and allow to remain in oven at least another 30 minutes, or until the centers of cookies are dry.

column2: Soften yeast in 1/4 cup warm water. Heat milk, sugar, butter or margarine and salt until the sugar dissolves; cool to lukewarm. Stir in 2 eggs. Stir in yeast mixture and 2 cups of the flour, beat well. Stir in enough of the rest of the flour to make a moderately stiff dough.
column3: Knead on floured surface till smooth, and shape into a ball. Place dough into a greased bowl and cover with a towel. Let rise until doubled, then divide in half.
column4: To make Filling: Combine the poppy seeds with the lemon peel and lemon juice and mix well. Set aside.
column5: Roll each half of the risen dough into a 17 x 12 inch rectangle. Cut into 4 inch circles. Put about 1/2 Tablespoon of the filling on each circle. Moisten the edges, bring the sides together and pinch, forming a triangle. Place on a greased cookie sheet and cover. Let the dough rise again until doubled.
column6: Brush with egg yolk mixed with water, then bake at 350 degrees F (180 degrees C) for 15 to 20 minutes.

column2: Beat eggs, add oil and mix. Add the sugar, vanilla, baking powder and salt. Add the flour gradually and mix well.
column3: Refrigerate a few hours or overnight.
column4: Kneed dough until it becomes soft enough to roll. Cut dough with three inch cup or three inch round cookie cutters. Put about 1 tablespoon of pie filling into the middle of each circle. Fold up the edges of the circle into the middle and pinch together.
column5: Bake at 350 degrees F (180 degrees C) for 20 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Lightly grease a 9 x 9 inch baking pan.
column3: In a medium bowl, combine graham crackers, chocolate chips, walnuts and coconut.
column4: Pour melted butter over the dry ingredients and stir. Press into prepared baking pan. Drizzle the condensed milk over the top.
column5: Bake for 25 - 30 minutes, until lightly colored on top. Let cool before cutting into bars.

column2: Cream margarine or butter and sugar thoroughly; add eggs, vanilla, and 2 tablespoons of orange juice. Combine flour and baking powder and gradually add to creamed mixture.
column3: Knead dough on lightly floured board for about 5 minutes. Using tablespoonfuls of dough, roll in 6-inch lengths; press ends together to form rings. Let stand on ungreased cookie sheets at room temperature for 15 minutes.
column4: Bake 350 degrees F (180 degrees C) for 15-17 minutes or until lightly golden.
column5: To Make Icing: Combine 2 1/2 cups confectioner's sugar with enough orange juice to make a thin glaze. Dip each hot cookie into glaze; cool on racks. Decorate with confetti sprinkles, if desired.

column2: Cream shortening and sugar. Sift flour with salt, soda and spices. Blend flour mixture into creamed mixture alternately with molasses and water. Chill at least 1 hour.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column4: Roll dough to 1/4 inch thick. Cut with large 6-8 inch gingerbread men cookie cutters. Lift onto lightly greased cookie sheet with broad spatula.
column5: Bake above oven center for about 12 minutes or until cookies spring back lightly in center. Do not overcook, they won't stay soft. Remove from sheets. Cool on wire racks. Makes 10 men 6-8 inches tall.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Thoroughly butter the bottom and sides of a 13 x 9 inch baking pan.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, cream together the butter and sugar. Beat in the almond extract. Gradually mix in the arrowroot flour.
column4: In a separate bowl, beat the egg whites and cream of tartar until stiff peaks form. Gently fold the egg whites into the batter. Pour the batter into the baking pan and smooth the surface with a rubber spatula. Bake for 30 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Dust with confectioner's sugar.

column2: Sift flour, baking powder, and salt together, set aside. In a large bowl, cream together the margarine and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla. Gradually blend in the sifted ingredients until fully absorbed. Cover dough, and chill for 2 hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets. On a clean floured surface, roll out small portions of chilled dough to 1/4 inch thickness. Cut out shapes using cookie cutters.
column4: Bake 6 to 8 minutes in the preheated oven, or until edges are barely brown. Remove from cookie sheets to cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Grease a shallow (or, tea cake) pan.
column3: Cream butter; gradually add sugar and beat until fluffy. Add whole egg and egg yolk one at a time and beat until mixture is puffy light.
column4: Measure molasses into milk. Add vanilla. Sift dry ingredients. Add dry ingredients and liquid alternately to first mixture, mixing until smooth.
column5: Bake for 20 to 25 minutes. Frost with your favorite confectioner's icing. Cut into 1 x 2 inch slices.

column2: Using a double boiler method, melt the chocolate coatings over hot tap water for 15 - 20 minutes. Stir . Do not cook or get water into the chocolate.
column3: After it is melted, stir in a couple drops of peppermint flavor into the chocolate.
column4: Dip crackers into the melted chocolate and then place onto a cold cookie sheet and put into the refrigerator to set. (A freezing tray to rest the dipped cookies will keep the bottoms neat looking.)
column5: In a few minutes take them out and package in candy cups. The cookies are best kept at room temperature or a cool dry place away from any odors.

column2: Cut dates and prunes into small pieces. Boil dates, prunes, raisins, and water for 5 minutes. Add margarine. Mix and set aside to cool.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column4: Mix the eggs, vanilla and nuts. Add to the fruit mixture. Sift the flour, baking soda and salt and add to the fruit mixture. (If you want a spicy bar add 1/2 tsp. Cinnamon and 1/4 tsp. Nutmeg to the flour.)
column5: Spread in 7 x 11 inch pan and bake for 25-30 minutes.

column2: Cream the butter until light. Gradually beat in the white and brown sugar ( on low speed with a mixer if using one ) until creamy and light. Beat in the egg and vanilla.
column3: Melt the chocolate in a small, heavy saucepan over very low heat. Stir chocolate into the butter mixture.
column4: Slowly stir in the salt and flour. Combine thoroughly. Stir in walnuts, if desired.
column5: Shape into walnut-sized balls. Make an indentation with your thumb in each cookie. Bake at 350 degrees F (180 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes until just done. Cool on rack.

column2: Cut cold butter or margarine and cream cheese into bits. In food processor pulse flour, salt, butter or margarine, cream cheese and sour cream until crumbly.
column3: Shape crumbly mixture into four equal disks. Wrap each disk and chill 2 hours or up to 2 days.
column4: Combine sugar, cinnamon, chopped walnuts, and finely chopped raisins (may substitute miniature chocolate chips for raisins).
column5: Roll each disk into a 9 inch round keeping other disks chilled until ready to roll them. Sprinkle round with sugar/nut mixture. Press lightly into dough. With chefs knife or pizza cutter, cut each round into 12 wedges. Roll wedges from wide to narrow, you will end up with point on outside of cookie. Place on ungreased baking sheets and chill rugelach 20 minutes before baking.
column6: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column7: After rugelach are chilled, bake them in the center rack of your oven 22 minutes until lightly golden. Cool on wire racks. Store in airtight containers...they freeze very well.
column8: Variations: Before putting the filling on the dough, use a pastry brush to layer apricot jam as well as brown sugar. Then add the recommended filling. You may also make a mixture of cinnamon and sugar and roll the rugelach in this prior to putting them on the cookie sheets.

column2: Put ingredients together in a bowl. For each child's bowl, use 1 cup oatmeal, 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup butter or margarine, 1/2 cup of flour, and 1/2 teaspoon of baking soda.
column3: Then mash, knead, and squeeze with hands until there aren't any lumps of butter. Form into small balls not as big as a walnut. Put on ungreased cookie sheet. Butter the bottom of a small glass and dip in granulated sugar. Flatten each ball of dough, dipping glass in sugar each time.
column4: Bake at 350 degrees F (180 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes. Let cool on cookie rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Mix in a large bowl, pumpkin, sugar, vegetable oil, egg and vanilla. Blend well.
column4: In a separate bowl, combine flour, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg, and baking soda. Stir into pumpkin mixture, add the milk. Blend well. Stir in the chocolate chips and nuts.
column5: Use teaspoon to drop cookies on baking sheet. Bake 8 - 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line three 9x13 inch baking pans with parchment paper.
column3: In a large bowl, break apart almond paste with a fork, and cream together with butter, sugar, and egg yolks. When mixture is fluffy and smooth, stir in flour to form a dough. In a small bowl, beat egg whites until soft peaks form. Fold egg whites into the dough. Divide dough into 3 equal portions. Mix one portion with red food coloring, and one with green food coloring. Spread each portion into one of the prepared baking pans.
column4: Bake 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, until lightly browned. Carefully remove from pan and parchment paper, and cool completely on wire racks.
column5: Place green layer onto a piece of plastic wrap large enough to wrap all three layers. Spread green layer with raspberry jam, and top with uncolored layer. Spread with apricot jam, and top with pink layer. Transfer layers to a baking sheet, and enclose with plastic wrap. Place a heavy pan or cutting board on top of wrapped layers to compress. Chill in the refrigerator 8 hours, or overnight.
column6: Remove plastic wrap. Top with melted chocolate chips, and refrigerate 1 hour, or until chocolate is firm. Slice into small squares to serve.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: In a bowl, combine food coloring with a few drops of water. Add coconut and cover the container, shake until coconut is tinted. Set aside.
column4: Place 1/2 of the vanilla wafers, flat side up, in an ungreased cookie sheet. Top each wafer with a peppermint patty. Place in the oven about 1 minute or just until chocolate begins to soften.
column5: Remove cookies from oven and sprinkle each mint with 1/2 teaspoon coconut (for lettuce). Place another vanilla wafer on top and press gentle. With a clean paint brush, brush the top of each hamburger with just enough water to moisten so that the sesame seeds will stick when sprinkled on top of each cookie. NOTE: You can use canned chocolate frosting in place of peppermint patty, then eliminate the baking.

column2: In a large bowl, mix together the butter, salt and baking powder. Gradually stir in flour. Store in a covered container in the refrigerator for up to 4 weeks.
Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Mix sugar and almond flavoring and set aside. In a separate bowl mix butter, cheese and egg yolk. Stir in Make Ahead Cookie Mix.
column4: Roll onto flat surface. Cut in half. Place 1 half on greased cookie sheet. Spoon on almond and sugar mix. Place 2nd half on top. Brush with slightly beaten egg white.
column5: Bake 22 - 30 minutes. Let cool at least 30 minutes. Cut into 1/2 inch strips.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Grease a 9 x 13 inch pan.
column3: Combine Make Ahead Cookie Mix with brown sugar, butter, vanilla and egg. Mix well.
column4: Spread dough in pan. Bake 17 to 24 minutes until top springs back when touched.
column5: Immediately sprinkle with chocolate chips. Let stand 2-3 minutes to melt then spread chocolate over bars and sprinkle with nuts. Cut when cooled.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Combine Make Ahead Cookie Mix with sugar, butter, vanilla, egg and chopped nuts. Mix well.
column4: Shape dough into balls. Bake 11 to 16 minutes. Let cool. Roll in confectioners' sugar.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Combine Make Ahead Cookie Mix with white sugar, butter, vanilla, and egg.
column4: Shape dough into balls. Dip into an egg white. Roll dough in chopped nuts. Press deep hole into center of each ball. Fill hole with 1/4 teaspoon jam. Bake 11-16 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Combine 2 cups of Make Ahead Cookie Mix with white sugar, egg, butter, and vanilla. Add nuts if desired. Stir in raisins and chopped maraschino cherries.
column4: Shape dough into balls. Press half of a Maraschino cherry into each cookie and bake 11-16 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Combine 2 cups of Make Ahead Cookie Mix with brown sugar, shortening, peanut butter, vanilla, and egg.
column4: Shape dough into balls. Place dough on ungreased cookie sheets. Flatten with a fork. Bake 7-11 minutes.

column2: Bring sugar, milk and butter to boil. Boil for 2 minutes and remove from heat.
column3: Stir in cocoa and vanilla. Stir in remaining ingredients to coat well.
column4: Drop onto waxed paper by the tablespoonfuls. Cool and enjoy!

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the butter or margarine, confectioner's sugar, flour and peppermint extract. Mix well.
column4: Separate dough into two equal parts, put into separate bowls and tint with food-coloring. Roll dough into SMALL balls, approximately 1/2 tsp per cookie. Place six balls in a circle, alternating colors onto cookie sheet.
column5: Bake for 8 minutes. NOTE: I guess you could omit peppermint flavoring or substitute it, but we like peppermint, so I have not tried variations or substitutions .

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream the sugar and butter. Add flour, nuts, salt and vanilla. Mix well. Batter will be very crumbly.
column4: Shape into 1 inch balls. Bake for 15 minutes, remove from oven and allow to cool for 3 minutes. Roll in super fine sugar. When cool, roll again, if desired.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Beat six eggs. Add sugar, oil, and anise flavoring and mix well.
column4: Mix in the flour and baking powder. Beat well.
column5: Smooth batter into a 10 x 15 inch greased and floured pan. Bake for 25 - 30 minutes. Cool then cut in strips.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In medium bowl, cream together butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the egg, orange juice concentrate, and orange zest. Combine the flour and baking powder; mix into the fluffy mixture until blended. Stir in cereal. Drop by teaspoonfuls 2 inches apart on ungreased cookie sheet.
column4: Bake 10 to 12 minutes or until edges are golden. Remove from cookie sheet for cooling.

column2: Mix thoroughly sugar, shortening and egg. Stir in buttermilk and vanilla. Sift dry ingredients and stir in. Add nuts.
column3: Chill dough for 1 hour.
column4: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Drop by rounded spoonfuls onto the cookie sheet.
column5: Bake 8 to 10 minutes. Cool. Frost with chocolate or white icing. Enjoy!

column2: Sift together flour, sugar, and spices; stir in peel and almonds. Cut in margarine till mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Stir in egg and milk till mixture forms a ball; chill.
column3: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column4: Roll out to about 1/8-inch thickness. Cut into circles 1-3/4 inches in diameter. Place on ungreased cookie sheet; sprinkle with sugar. Bake for 6 to 8 minutes until edges are brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Thoroughly cream shortening, peanut butter, sugars, and vanilla extract. Add egg and beat well. Add peanuts and milk; blend. Add flour sifted with salt and baking powder.
column4: Drop from Tablespoons and greased cookie sheets. Let stand a few minutes; flatten by stamping with a greased glass. Bake for 12 to 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F(180 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets or line with parchment paper.
column3: Melt butter and chocolate in small heavy saucepan over low heat; stir to blend. Remove from heat; cool.
column4: Beat egg, brown sugar, vanilla and baking soda in large bowl until light and fluffy. Blend in chocolate mixture and flour until smooth. Slowly beat in milk to make light, cake-batter-like dough.
column5: Drop dough by teaspoonfuls 2 inches apart onto prepared cookie sheets. Bake 10 to 12 minutes or until firm in center. Cut marshmallows in half.
column6: Immediately place halved marshmallow, cut side down, onto each baked cookie. Return to oven 1 minute or just until marshmallow is warm enough to stick to cookie. Remove to wire racks to cool.

column2: Melt chocolate and butter in small heavy saucepan over low heat; stir to blend.
column3: Beat in powdered sugar. Beat in egg white and vanilla, adding a little water, if necessary, to make smooth, slightly soft frosting. Spoon over Chocolate Frosted Marshmallow Cookies cookies to cover marshmallows.

column2: Heat milk over low heat until just below boiling. Remove from heat;stir in butter, honey and salt. Set aside and let cool.
column3: In a large bowl, combine yeast and lukewarm water. Set aside 5 minutes for yeast to soften. Add cooled milk mixture to softened yeast and beat in 4 cups flour.
column4: Knead dough in a bowl, adding up to 1/2 cup more flour if necessary, until a smooth, soft dough forms. Divide dough into 8 balls 3 inches in diameter. Place balls 4 inches apart on lightly greased cookie sheets; pat into 4 inch rounds. Set aside, lightly covered with kitchen towels, about 1 hour, or until doubled in size.
column5: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column6: Bake raised rounds 30 minutes, or until golden brown. Remove from oven; leave oven on. Let cool on sheets 10-15 minutes, or until cool enough to handle.
column7: With a serrated knife, cut each round into six 1/2-inch slices. Place slices, cut sides down, on cookie sheets and return to oven 5 minutes. Turn slices and bake 5 to 7 min. longer, or until golden on both sides. Turn off heat and leave zwieback in unopened oven until cool, about 45 minutes. Store in a tightly covered container.

column2: Heat milk in a small saucepan until just starting to bubble. Remove from heat; stir in butter, honey and salt. Set aside and let cool. Set aside 2 teaspoons sugar. Stir remaining sugar into milk mixture. Let cool to room temp.
column3: In a large bowl, combine yeast and lukewarm water. Set aside 5 minutes for yeast to soften. Beat cooled milk mixture, egg, 4 cups flour, and nutmeg into yeast mixture.
column4: Knead dough in a bowl, adding up to 1/2 cup more flour if necessary, until a smooth, soft dough forms. Divide dough into 8 balls 3 inches in diameter. Place balls 4 inches apart on lightly greased cookie sheets; pat into 4 inch rounds. Brush tops of rounds with water and sprinkle with reserved sugar. Set aside, lightly covered with kitchen towels, about 1 hour, or until doubled in size.
column5: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Bake raised rounds 30 minutes, or until golden brown. Remove from oven; leave oven on. Let cool on sheets 10-15 minutes, or until cool enough to handle.
column6: With a serrated knife, cut each round into six 1/2-inch slices. Place slices, cut sides down, on cookie sheets and return to oven for 5 minutes. Turn slices and bake 5 to 7 minutes longer, or until golden on both sides. Turn off heat and leave in unopened oven until cool, about 45 minutes. Store in tightly covered container.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together the butter, white sugar and brown sugar until smooth. Stir in the peanut butter, vanilla and egg until well blended. Combine the flour, baking soda and salt; stir into the batter just until moistened. Mix in the oats and chocolate chips until evenly distributed. Drop by tablespoonfuls on to lightly greased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, until the edges start to brown. Cool on cookie sheets for about 5 minutes before transferring to wire racks to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Beat butter or margarine with an electric mixer on medium to high speed for 30 seconds. Add one cup of the flour, the sugar, eggs, baking powder, vanilla, cinnamon, soda, and cloves. Beat until thoroughly combined.
column4: Stir in the remaining flour. Beat in bananas and nuts. Drop by rounded teaspoons 2 inches apart onto a greased cookie sheet. Bake for 8 to 10 minutes or until edges are lightly browned. Cool cookies on a rack.

column2: In a bowl beat butter or margarine until fluffy. Gradually add 2 cups of the confectioners' sugar, beating well.
column3: Slowly beat in the milk and vanilla. Slowly beat in remaining sugar. Beat in additional milk, if needed, to make of spreading consistency. Tint with food color, if desired.

column2: Using a double boiler, heat butter, chopped dates, confectioner's sugar, eggs and salt. Stir constantly until very thick, about 20 minutes. Remove from heat and cool.
