column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, combine oats, pastry flour, salt, 1 cup brown sugar, and baking soda. Mix in the butter until crumbly. Press half of the mixture into the bottom of a 9 inch square baking pan.
column4: In a small saucepan over medium heat, combine the dates, water, and 1/3 cup brown sugar. Bring to a boil, and cook until thickened. Stir in lemon juice, and remove from heat. Spread the filling over the base, and pat the remaining crumb mixture on top.
column5: Bake for 20 to 25 minutes in preheated oven, or until top is lightly toasted. Cool before cutting into squares.

column2: In a medium bowl, cream together butter and 1 cup sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in egg, corn syrup, and lemon extract. Stir in flour, baking soda, and baking powder. Cover dough, and chill in the refrigerator at least 1 hour.
column3: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Line a cookie sheet with parchment paper. Roll chilled dough into walnut sized balls. Roll balls in remaining sugar, and place on the prepared cookie sheet.
column4: Bake 12 minutes in the preheated oven, or until lightly browned.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees). Line baking sheets with foil.
column3: Beat the egg whites until creamy. Gradually beat in the sugar and beat until stiff peaks form. Fold in the peanut butter chips, chocolate chips and walnuts. Fold in the vanilla. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheets.
column4: Put them in the preheat 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) oven, turn off oven and go to bed. Cookies will be ready in the morning. Happy Dreams!

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
column3: In the top half a double boiler melt the chocolate and condensed milk, stirring frequently.
column4: Pour the melted chocolate mixture over the coconut. Stir in the vanilla and salt. Mix well until the coconut is completely coated. Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheet. Press one whole almond into the top of each cookie.
column5: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes. Check at 8 minutes as the bottoms tend to burn easily. Remove from oven and cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column3: Beat the butter or margarine in a large mixing bowl at medium speed until very creamy. Gradually add the 1/2 cup confectioners' sugar, beating until light and fluffy.
column4: Combine the flour, nuts and salt add to the butter mixture and beat until just blended. Stir in the rum extract. Shape cookies into 1inch balls and place on ungreased cookie sheets. Flatten cookies down.
column5: Bake at 325 degrees F (165 degrees C) for 12 to 15 minutes. When cool spread with Rum Glaze.
column6: To Make Rum Glaze: Combine the 3/4 cup confectioners' sugar, milk and 1/8 teaspoon rum extract. Stir until smooth.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl beat the butter or margarine, white sugar and brown sugar together. Add the eggs and vanilla, beating well.
column4: Stir together the flour, baking soda, cinnamon and salt. Gradually add the flour mixture to the butter mixture and stir until blended. Stir in the oats and the butterscotch chips. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto an ungreased cookie sheet.
column5: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven, until the edges begin to brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease one 9 x 13 inch baking pan.
column3: Combine the cake mix and nuts. Stir in the evaporated milk and melted butter. Spread half of the cake mix mixture into the prepared pan.
column4: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 15 minutes. Remove from oven and immediately place Rolo pieces, cut side down, over hot crust. Drop remaining cake mix mixture by teaspoonfuls over Rolo pieces. Return to oven and bake for 25 to 30 minutes or until lightly browned. Cut into squares to serve.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Line one 9x13 inch pan with greased parchment paper.
column3: Combine the cocoa, melted butter, sugar, eggs, salt , flour and vanilla. Mix until well combined. It should be very thick and sticky.
column4: Spread mixture into the prepared pan. Bake at 300 degrees F (150 degrees C) for 30 minutes. Cool completely before cutting into squares.

column2: In a saucepan combine the sugar, butter or margarine and evaporated milk. Bring to a boil. Add the instant pudding and oats. Remove from heat and stir to mix.
column3: Drop by spoonfuls onto waxed paper. Let cool for 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease one 9 x13 inch baking pan.
column3: Reserve 2/3 cup of the cake mix and set aside. In a large bowl combine the remaining cake mix, melted butter and 1 egg. Mix until crumbly then press mixture into the prepared pan.
column4: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 15 to 20 minutes, until light golden brown.
column5: Combine the reserved 2/3 cup cake mix, brown sugar, corn syrup, vanilla and 3 eggs. Beat at medium speed for 1 to 2 minutes. Pour filling over the baked crust and sprinkle with pecans.
column6: Return to oven and bake for an additional 30 to 35 minutes, until the filling is set. Cool and cut into 36 bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a 9 x 13 inch baking pan melt the butter and sprinkle the graham cracker crumbs over the melted butter. Mix together and press onto bottom of pan.
column4: Layer coconut, nuts, chocolate chips and marshmallows over crust. Drizzle the condensed milk evenly over all.
column5: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 25 to 30 minutes or until golden brown. Remove from oven and drizzle with the melted chocolate. Cool completely and cut into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C).
column3: Combine the 3 tablespoons white sugar and the cinnamon in a small bowl and set aside.
column4: Blend dark brown sugar and white sugar in a large bowl with mixer on medium speed. Add butter and blend until grainy. Add eggs and vanilla extract, mixing until light and fluffy.
column5: Whisk flour, baking soda and salt together in a separate bowl. Add to sugar mixture, mixing at low speed just long enough to combine. Overmixing makes tough cookies!
column6: Roll dough into 1inch balls, then roll each ball into cinnamon-sugar to coat. Place cookies on ungreased cookie sheets and bake at 300 degrees F (150 degrees C) for 18 to 20 minutes. Remove from sheets and let cool on racks.

column2: Blend the condensed milk and the vanilla together in a bowl. Add the powdered sugar a little at a time, blending each time until smooth. Stir in the coconut. You should have a firm mixture. Pat the mixture into a greased 9 x 13 inch pan and chill until firm.
column3: Place the chocolate chips in a microwave-safe bowl and heat on high 1 minute at a time, stirring after each minute, until melted. Remove the pan from the refrigerator and cut the coconut mixture into 1 x 2 inch bars.
column4: Set each bar on a fork and dip into the chocolate, completely coating the bar. Let excess drip off, then set on waxed paper. Repeat for each bar. Bars will take several hours to air-dry; if you are in a hurry you can refrigerate the bars for about 30 minutes. Enjoy!

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Lightly grease your baking sheets.
column3: Beat the butter and 2/3 cup sugar together until creamy. Mix in the egg and lime extract. Blend well.
column4: In a separate bowl, combine the cornmeal, baking powder, salt and flour. Add the flour mixture to the butter mixture and mix well.
column5: Drop teaspoonfuls of the dough onto the prepared baking sheets. Dip the bottom of a glass, or similar round, flat object in the 1/4 cup sugar, and slightly flatten the balls of dough. Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes or until cookie bottoms are lightly browned.
column6: To Make Icing: Combine the lime zest, confectioners' sugar, and enough lime juice to make a spreadable glaze. Spread over the tops of cooled cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease one 8 inch square pan, and line with greased foil.
column3: Combine brown sugar, flour, baking soda, salt, and rolled oats. Rub in the butter using your hands or a pastry blender to form a crumbly mixture. Press 2 cups of the mixture into the bottom of the prepared pan. Spread the jam to within 1/4 inch of the edge. Sprinkle the remaining crumb mixture over the top, and lightly press it into the jam.
column4: Bake for 35 to 40 minutes in preheated oven, or until lightly browned. Allow to cool before cutting into bars.

column2: Place the eggs, vanilla, vegetable oil, 1 teaspoon of the sugar, and the flour and salt in the bowl of an electric mixer fitted with the paddle and blend on low speed until incorporated. Then beat on high speed for 5 minutes.
column3: Remove the paddle and scrape the batter down the sides of the bowl. Rest the dough in the bowl, covered, until soft and spongy outside, about 1 hour. Then remove it from the bowl, it will be sticky, and make a ball out of it.
column4: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) and grease 2 baking sheets.
column5: Sprinkle a work surface with the 1 cup sugar, about 1/8 inch deep. Place the dough in the center, flatten it slightly with a rolling pin and sprinkle the dough liberally with sugar.
column6: Roll the dough to a thickness of 1/8 inch, a rectangle about 18 by 12 inches. Then, using a pastry cutter or a dull knife, cut out the dough into strips 3/4 inch wide and 2 inches long. Lift each strip, twist in the middle to make a bow tie and place on the cookie sheets, leaving 1/2 inch between each strip.
column7: Bake the cookies for 25 to 30 minutes on the middle rack of the oven, until the cookies are hard to the touch on all corners and golden brown. (If using 1 oven, put the cookie sheets on the top and center racks, then switch them midway). To test for doneness, break a cookie in half. If it is doughy or too soft, it is not done yet. Return to the oven for a few minutes more.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease baking sheets.
column3: Cream the butter with the white sugar and brown sugar. Beat in the egg and vanilla.
column4: Mix the flour and baking powder together. Stir in the flour mixture into the butter mixture and combine.
column5: Form dough into 1 inch balls and place on the prepared baking sheet. Make an indentation in each cookie and fill with jam. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 12 to 15 minutes. Let cool completely and sprinkle with confectioners' sugar.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C).
column3: Place pecans in a resealable plastic baggie. Crush the pecans into small bits. Read John 19:1-3
column4: Put 1 teaspoon vinegar into a medium bowl. Read John 19:28-30
column5: Add egg whites to the vinegar. Read John 10:10-11
column6: Sprinkle salt into the egg whites. Read Luke 23:27
column7: So far, the mixture isn't very appetizing. Add 1cup sugar. Read Psalm 34:8 and John 3:16. Beat with mixer on high speed for 12 to 15 minutes until stiff peaks are formed. Read Isaiah 1:18 and John 3:1-3.
column8: Fold in broken nuts. Drop by teaspoons onto parchment paper lined baking sheet. Read Matthew 27:57-60.
column9: Place cookies in the oven close the door and turn the oven off. Read Matthew 27:65-66.
column10: Go to bed. Read John 16:20 and 22.
column11: In the morning open the oven and take out the cookies. Read Matthew 28:1-9.

column2: Preheat oven to 200 degrees F (100 degrees C).
column3: Combine the white sugar, ground walnuts, orange zest, orange juice and 2 egg whites. This mixture will become very sticky and paste-like.
column4: Form the paste into a long rectangle on a smooth surface sprinkled with sugar so that it won't stick. The rectangle should be about 16 x 4 inches.
column5: Make the frosting by mixing the remaining egg white with the confectioners' sugar. You don't need to beat the egg white first! You may need to add a little water, or a little more powdered sugar to form a paste that you can easily spread, but that isn't runny.
column6: Spread the frosting over your rectangle. Use a knife covered with sugar to cut the rectangle into small 1 x 2 inch bars and place them on an ungreased cookie sheet.
column7: Bake at 200 degrees F (100 degrees C) for about 35 minutes or until frosting is hard but still white. Enjoy with a big glass of milk!

column2: In a large bowl, cream butter and 1 1/4 cups of the sugar. Add eggs, one at a time, beating well after each.
column3: Sift flour and baking powder together. Add flour mix to the butter mixture alternately with the sour cream. Blend very well and add the orange zest. Wrap tightly and chill overnight.
column4: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column5: Turn chilled dough out on to a floured surface and roll out to 1/4 inch thick. Cut into desired shapes.
column6: Combine the 1/3 cup white sugar and the finely chopped almonds and sprinkle over the tops of the cookies. Place cookies on the prepared baking sheet and bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes. Remove from oven and let cookies cool on rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the shortening and the butter. Add the brown sugar and cream until light and fluffy. Beat in the eggs until well blended.
column4: Sift the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves over the creamed mixture. Mix in then stir in the raisins, nuts and dates.
column5: Drop cookies onto ungreased baking sheets and bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 8 to 10 minutes or until golden.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease one 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: Combine the oats, butter or margarine, white sugar and brown sugar and press into the bottom of the prepared pan.
column4: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes.
column5: Melt the chocolate chips and peanut butter together over low heat. Spread over the top of the baked oatmeal mixture. Cool and cut into squares.

column2: To Make The Dough: Sift the flour, baking powder, and salt together; set aside.
column3: Cream the butter with 3/4 cup of the brown sugar and the white sugar. Beat in the eggs, milk and vanilla. Mix at high speed for 2 minutes, then reduce speed and gradually blend in the flour mixture. Cover and refrigerate dough for at least 3 hours.
column4: To Make Raisin Filling: Grind the raisins. In a medium saucepan combine the ground raisins, 1 cup brown sugar, 1 cup water, salt and lemon juice. Bring to a boil, and simmer for 3 minutes.
column5: Combine the cornstarch and 2 tablespoons of the water and mix until smooth. Add to the raisin mixture and continue to simmer until thick. Remove from heat and let cool. Once cool, stir in the chopped nuts.
column6: Preheat Oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column7: On a floured surface, roll out the chilled dough to 1/8 inch thick. Cut into 2 3/4 inch rounds. Place rounds on the prepared baking sheet. Place a heaping teaspoon of the raisin filling on the cookie round and top with another round. Crimp the edges closed.
column8: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 8 minutes. Allow cookies to cool on sheet until just barely warm.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column3: Cream butter and sugar together until light. Beat in the vanilla. Mix in the flour, pecans and cocoa powder.
column4: Form dough into 1 inch balls and place onto the prepared baking sheets. Bake in the preheated oven for 20 to 25 minutes. Cool, then roll each cookie in confectioners' sugar.

column2: Soak almonds in water overnight.
column3: Soak raisins in boiling water for 5 minutes then drain. Dice raisins and strawberries.
column4: Coarsely grind the soaked almonds. Add them to the diced strawberry-raisin mixture and mix well.
column5: Drop batter by spoonfuls onto a dehydrator plastic tray. Dehydrate for 24 hours or until dry at 105 degrees F (40 degrees C). Turn cookies over in 8 to 12 hours or when you see that one side is dry enough.

column2: In large bowl, with mixer at low speed, beat margarine or butter with cream cheese until blended and smooth. Beat in vanilla extract, salt, 1 cup flour, and 1/4 cup sugar until blended.
column3: With spoon, stir in remaining flour. Divide dough into 4 equal pieces. Wrap each with plastic wrap and refrigerate until firm, at least 2 hours or overnight.
column4: To Prepare Filling: In medium bowl, with spoon, stir walnuts, apricots, brown sugar, 1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons white sugar, and 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon until well mixed.
column5: Line 2 large baking sheets with foil and grease foil.
column6: On lightly floured surface, with floured rolling pin, roll 1 piece of chilled dough into a 9-inch round, keeping remaining dough refrigerated. Spread dough with 2 tablespoons raspberry preserves. Sprinkle with about 1/2 cup apricot filling; gently press filling onto dough. With pastry wheel or sharp knife, cut dough into 12 equal wedges. Starting at curved edge, roll up each wedge, jelly-roll fashion. Place cookies on foil-lined cookie sheet, point-side down, about 1/2 inch apart. Repeat with remaining dough, one-fourth at a time.
column7: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column8: In cup, mix remaining 2 tablespoons sugar with 1 teaspoon cinnamon. With pastry brush, brush rugelach with milk. Sprinkle with cinnamon-sugar.
column9: Bake rugelach at 325 degrees F (165 degrees C) on 2 oven racks about 30 to 35 minutes until golden, rotating cookie sheets between upper and lower racks halfway through baking time. Immediately remove rugelach to wire racks to cool. Store in tightly covered container.

column2: Blend all ingredients together (preferably with hands). Roll into balls the size of large marbles and refrigerate. Optional: roll balls in powdered cocoa or roll balls info flaked coconut or dip into chocolate fondue. Eat and enjoy!
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly coat baking sheets with non-stick cooking spray.
column3: Combine the flour, baking soda and salt. Set aside.
column4: Cream the butter with the sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the egg and vanilla until well combined. Mix in the flour mixture. Stir in the cereal and chocolate chips. Drop by level tablespoons onto the prepared baking sheets.
column5: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 12 minutes or until lightly browned. Remove immediately from baking sheets and cool on wire racks. Store in an airtight container.

column2: Preheat oven 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: In a small bowl combine flour, baking soda and baking powder and set aside.
column4: In a large bowl, cream the butter and sugar together until light. Beat in the eggs and the vanilla. Gradually mix in the flour then add the cherry mixture. Cover and refrigerate for 10 to 15 minutes.
column5: Roll small round balls of dough and place on ungreased cookie sheet. Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 8 to 10 minutes or until golden brown. Remove and let cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column3: Combine the oil and brown sugar. Mix in the pumpkin and eggs, beating well. Add the flour, salt, baking powder, baking soda, 1 teaspoon vanilla, cinnamon, ginger and cloves. Mix well.
column4: Drop dough by heaping teaspoons onto the prepared baking sheets. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes. Let cookies cool then make sandwiches from two cookies filled with Whoopie Pie Filling.
column5: To Make Whoopie Pie Filling: Beat egg white and mix with the milk, 1 teaspoon vanilla and 1 cup of the confectioners' sugar. Mix well then beat in the shortening and the remaining cup of confectioners' sugar. Beat until light and fluffy.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column3: Cream butter or margarine with the brown sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the eggs and mix well. Stir in the salt, cinnamon, baking powder, boiling water, baking soda and flour. Mix to combine. Stir in the oats.
column4: Drop cookies onto the prepared baking sheets. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes. Let cookies cool then make sandwiches from two cookies filled with Whoopie Pie Filling.
column5: To Make Filling: Beat egg white. Mix in the milk, 1 teaspoon vanilla and 1 cup confectioners' sugar. Beat in the shortening and remaining 1 cup confectioners' sugar. Beat until light.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column3: Cream the butter and the brown and white sugars together until light and fluffy. Add the egg whites and beat well. Beat in the peanut butter and the vanilla.
column4: Combine the flour, baking soda and salt. Add to the creamed mixture and mix well. Stir in the chopped candy bars. Shape dough into 1 1/2 inch balls and place on the prepared baking sheets.
column5: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes or until golden brown. Let cookies cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Beat butter and sugars until fluffy. Slowly add oil and beat until oil is well incorporated. Add egg and vanilla, beat to mix.
column4: In a small bowl, combine flour, soda and salt. Add to butter mixture and stir just until mixed. Combine corn flakes, oatmeal, nuts and coconut and add to cookie mixture; mix just until combined.
column5: Use a cookie scoop to produce consistently sized cookies, but you can drop by rounded teaspoonfuls onto an ungreased cookie sheet, if you don't have a scoop. Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 12 minutes or until lightly browned. Since these are so rich, you can chill the individual balls of cookie dough and then freeze them in freezer bags. You can then take them directly from the freezer to the oven, just add a few minutes to the cooking time.

column2: In a large bowl, beat the butter or margarine, 1 1/2 cups sugar, eggs, and vanilla until fluffy.
column3: Sift flour with baking powder, baking soda and salt. At low speed, beat sour cream into the egg mixture, gradually beat in the flour until well mixed. Add raisins and mix by hand. Refrigerate dough for 1 hour.
column4: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column5: Mix the 1/2 cup white sugar with the ground cinnamon.
column6: Drop spoonfuls of dough 2 inches apart on the prepared baking sheets. Sprinkle cookies with the cinnamon sugar mixture. Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes or until golden brown. Remove to wire racks to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column3: Ina a bowl stir together the flour, baking soda and salt.
column4: In a large bowl beat the margarine and the sugar until light and fluffy. Mix in the eggs and vanilla and beat well. Stir in the flour mixture and mix thoroughly. Stir in the cereal.
column5: Drop dough by rounded teaspoons onto the prepared baking sheets. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes or until lightly browned. Let cookies cool on a wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease one 15x10 inch baking pan.
column3: Prepare pudding mix according to package directions using the 2 cups milk. Whisk in the cake mix. Stir in the chocolate chips. Pour batter into the prepared pan.
column4: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 30 to 35 minutes or until the top springs back when lightly touched. Dust with confectioners' sugar. Serve with ice cream if desired.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheet.
column3: Add the oil to the sugar gradually and mix well. Beat in the milk and the eggs. Stir in the whole wheat flour, baking powder, wheat germ and nutmeg and mix well.
column4: Drop teaspoonfuls of dough on the prepared baking sheets. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 5 minutes. Lower temperature to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C) and bake for an additional 7 minutes.

column2: Combine butter,1 cup confectioners' sugar, vanilla and almond extracts. Beat at medium speed and add remaining confectioners' sugar alternately with the heavy whipping cream. Beat until smooth.
Melt the chocolate chips and combine with the brown sugar and vegetable oil. Add the eggs one at a time and beat well. Stir in the vanilla.
column3: Combine the flour, baking powder and salt. Add flour mixture to the chocolate mixture. Stir in the chopped walnuts. Chill dough for a few hours.
column4: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease baking sheets.
column5: Drop teaspoonfuls of dough in confectioners' sugar and roll to coat. Place cookies on the prepared baking sheets. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes. Let cookies cool on racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column3: Cream butter and brown sugar. Add 3 to 3 3/4 cups flour. Mix well.
column4: Sprinkle board with the remaining flour. Knead for 5 minutes, adding enough flour to make a soft dough. Roll to 1/2 inch thickness. Cut into 3x1 inch strips. Prick with fork and place on ungreased baking sheets.
column5: Bake at 325 degrees F (165 degrees C) for 20 to 25 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease one 8 inch square baking pan.
column3: Melt butter over low heat.
column4: In a mixing bowl stir the cocoa and sugar together. Stir in the melted butter. Beat in the egg and vanilla.
column5: Stir in the flour and salt and mix until smooth. Stir in the walnuts. Pour mixture into the prepared pan and spread into an even layer.
column6: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 40 to 50 minutes or until brownies begin to pull away from the sides of the pan. Let cool before cutting.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together shortening, brown sugar, and white sugar until smooth. Blend in instant pudding, then beat in eggs until the batter is light and fluffy. Combine flour and baking soda; mix into the batter. Stir in oats and raisins. Dough will be stiff. Drop dough by spoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheets.
column4: Bake for 8 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, or until firm. Cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column3: Beat together the whipped topping and eggs together. Add the lemon cake mix and continue to mix. Dough will be thick.
column4: Drop by teaspoonfuls into a bowl of confectioners' sugar and roll to coat. Place cookies on the prepared baking sheets. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 8 minutes.

column2: In a large bowl mix the butter or margarine, confectioners' sugar, brown sugar, egg and vanilla together until light and well combined.
column3: In a medium bowl combine the flour, ground pecans and salt. Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix until a soft dough is formed. Wrap dough in plastic and refrigerate for 1 hour.
column4: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column5: Roll chilled dough to 1/4 inch thickness and cut into desired shapes.
column6: Place cookies on an ungreased baking sheet and bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 7 to 9 minutes or until light golden brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease one 8x8 inch baking pan.
column3: Cream butter, sugar, eggs and vanilla; beat well.
column4: Blend in cinnamon, flour, baking soda and salt; add raisins, nuts and applesauce. Mix well.
column5: Place batter into the prepared baking pan and bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 30 minutes. Cut into squares and serve.

column2: Cream together the shortening and sugar and beat in the egg until light.
column3: Sift together the flour, baking powder and salt and mix into the creamed mixture. Stir in the oatmeal and water until blended. Roll into a 2 inch roll and chill in the refrigerator for several hours or overnight.
column4: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column5: Slice cookie dough thinly and bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 6-8 minutes. Cool and put together in sandwiches with jam.

column2: Cream the butter or margarine until light and fluffy. Add the bananas and mix well. Beat in the eggs and vanilla.
column3: Sift together the flour, baking soda, salt, ground nutmeg and ground cinnamon. Add the dry mixture to the creamed mixture and mix well. Stir in the oats and the chopped nuts. Cover and chill dough for 1 hour.
column4: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column5: Drop chilled teaspoon-sized rounds of cookie dough onto the prepared baking sheet. Bake in the preheated oven for 10 to 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease and flour twenty-four 3-inch Madeleine molds.
column3: In a medium bowl beat eggs, vanilla and lemon zest with an electric mixer on high speed for 5 minutes. Gradually beat in the confectioners' sugar. Beat for 5 to 7 minutes or until thick and satiny.
column4: Sift together the flour and baking powder. Sift one-fourth of the flour mixture over the egg mixture, gently fold in. Fold in the remaining flour by fourths. Then fold in the melted and cooled butter. Spoon batter into the prepared molds, filling 3/4 full.
column5: Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes or until the edges are golden and the top s spring back. Cool in molds on a rack for 1 minute. Loosen cookies with a knife. Invert cookies onto a rack and cool. Sift confectioners' sugar over the tops or melt semi-sweet chocolate chips and dip the tips in the chocolate. Store in an airtight container.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (205 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Cream the butter and the sugar together until light and fluffy. Beat in the egg, milk and vanilla.
column4: Sift the flour, baking powder and salt together. Add the flour mixture the butter mixture and stir to combine.
column5: Drop teaspoonfuls of the dough on the prepared baking sheets and bake at 400 degrees F (205 degrees C) for 5 to 8 minutes or until just golden.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Combine the peanut butter, white sugar and egg. Mix until smooth.
column4: Drop spoonfuls of dough onto the prepared baking sheet. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 6 to 8 minutes. Do not overbake! These cookies are best when they are still soft and just barely brown on the bottoms.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column3: Cream butter or margarine, shortening, white sugar and confectioners' sugar together until light and fluffy. Beat in the egg and the vanilla.
column4: Sift the flour, baking soda, salt and cream of tartar together. Add the flour mixture to the sugar mixture and blend.
column5: Shape dough into walnut-sized balls and place on the prepared baking sheets. Dip a glass in white sugar and press balls flat. Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes or until lightly browned.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Cream the butter or margarine with the sugar. Beat in the pumpkin, egg and vanilla.
column4: Stir the flour, baking soda, baking powder, salt and ground cinnamon into the pumpkin mixture. Blend until combined.
column5: Drop teaspoonfuls of dough onto the prepared baking sheets. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 12 to 14 minutes. Let cookies cool completely then sandwich two cookies together with Vanilla Filling.
column6: To Make Vanilla Filling: Beat the shortening and 1 1/2 cups white sugar together for 10 minutes. Beat in the vanilla and the vanilla pudding. Beat until creamy.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Cream the shortening, brown sugar and white sugar together until light and fluffy. Beat in the vanilla salt and eggs.
column4: Sift the flour, baking soda and baking powder, add to the creamed mixture and stir to combine. Stir in the oats, rice cereal, coconut and nuts. Mix to combine.
column5: Form dough into walnut sized balls and place on the prepared baking sheets. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 10 minutes. These cookies should still be very soft when taken from the oven. Place on a cooling rack and let cool completely before storing in airtight containers.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Cream the shortening with 1/2 cup of the brown sugar. Add 1 cup of the flour, the salt and the oats and blend. Press into the bottom of one 8x12 inch baking dish.
column4: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 15 minutes.
column5: Beat eggs well. Then beat in the 1 cup brown sugar and the vanilla. Stir in the 2 tablespoons flour and baking powder, blending well. Stir in the coconut and pecans. Spread over the top of the baked bottom layer.
column6: Return dish to oven and bake for an additional 15 to 20 minutes at 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Let cool then cut into 2 inch bars and wrap in plastic wrap before storing in an airtight container.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column3: Cream the shortening with 2 cups of the white sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the eggs, vanilla and sour cream; mixing well.
column4: Stir in the flour, salt, baking powder and baking soda into the shortening mixture to make a stiff dough. Add the chopped black walnuts.
column5: Drop teaspoonfuls of dough onto the prepared baking sheets. Mix the 3 tablespoons with the ground cinnamon. Grease the bottom of a small glass. Dip it into the cinnamon-sugar mixture and gently press the cookies to flatten the balls of dough slightly.
column6: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 10 to 15 minutes or until centers are done.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Grease one 8 inch square baking dish.
column3: Cream the butter until soft and fluffy. Add the white sugar gradually, until light and fluffy. Beat in the egg yolks.
column4: Sift the cardamom, allspice and flour together. Gradually add it to the butter mixture and stir to combine well. Stir in the chopped pecans.
column5: Spoon 1/2 of the dough into the prepared pan, spreading evenly. Top with strawberry jam and cover with the remaining dough.
column6: Bake at 325 degrees F (165 degrees C) for 1 hour or until lightly browned. Cool then cut into 1 1/2 inch sized squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Cream the butter with 1/2 cup of the confectioners' sugar until light and fluffy. Stir in the flour, salt and nuts; mix well.
column4: Form the stiff dough into egg shapes about 1-1/2 inches long. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for about 15 minutes. Cool on rack.
column5: Spread half of cookie with confectioners' sugar glaze or melted chocolate. If desired, sprinkle with coconut, chopped nuts, colored sugar or decors. Let sit until glaze is dry.
column6: To Make Confectioners' Sugar Glaze: Combine 1 cup unsifted confectioners' with the water. Stir until smooth.
column7: To Make Chocolate Glaze: Melt the chocolate chips in a double-boiler or in microwave (stir every 15 second) until melted. Pour slightly cooled glaze in a quart size freezer ziploc, snip tip of bag and drizzle over cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column3: Cream butter with an electric mixer until light. Gradually add the fructose and beat thoroughly. Beat in the almond extract, vanilla extract and water.
column4: Combine the flour, salt and pecans. Add to the creamed mixture, a little at a time, beating well after each addition.
column5: Roll doll into date-sized balls and place on ungreased baking sheets. Bake at 325 degrees F (165 degrees C) for 13 to 14 minutes. Roll in confectioners' sugar while warm and then again once cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: In a large bow, with the mixer a low speed, beat the sugar and butter until combined. Increase speed to high and beat until light and fluffy (about 5 minutes). Reduce speed to medium and beat in the ricotta, vanilla and eggs.
column4: Reduce speed to low. Add flour, baking powder and salt; beat until dough forms.
column5: Drop dough by level tablespoons, about 2 inches apart; onto the prepared baking sheets. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for about 15 minutes or until cookies are very lightly golden (cookies will be soft). With spatula, remove cookies to wire rack to cool.
column6: When cookies are cool, prepare icing. In small bowl, stir confectioners' sugar and milk until smooth. With small spreader, spread icing on cookies; place a candied cherry piece on top of each cookie or sprinkle with colored sugar or candy sprinkles.

column2: In a small bowl mix the milk powder, peanut butter, honey and graham cracker crumbs until blended. Shape into 1 inch balls and roll in chopped nuts; chill.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch baking dish.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together 1 cup sugar and 1/2 cup of softened butter until smooth. Beat in eggs one at a time, then stir in the chocolate syrup. Stir in the flour until just blended. Spread the batter evenly into the prepared pan.
column4: Bake for 25 to 30 minutes in the preheated oven, or until top springs back when lightly touched. Cool completely in the pan.
column5: In a small bowl, beat the confectioners' sugar, 1/2 cup butter or margarine and creme de menthe until smooth. Spread evenly over the cooled brownies, then chill until set.
column6: In a small bowl over simmering water, or in the microwave, melt the remaining 6 tablespoons of butter and the chocolate chips, stirring occasionally until smooth. Allow to cool slightly, then spread over the top of the mint layer. Cover, and chill for at least 1 hour before cutting into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Arrange crackers in a single layer on the bottom of a 10x15 inch pan that has sides.
column4: Boil the butter and the brown sugar together for 3 minutes. Pour evenly over the crackers. Be careful it's extremely hot and sticky.
column5: Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 7 minutes.
column6: Remove from oven and immediately sprinkle chocolate chips over hot mixture. Wait a few minutes for them to melt, then spread evenly with the back of a spoon. While still hot spread finely chopped walnuts over the top. Break or cut into desired size pieces.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Place the raisins or chopped dates in a bowl and cover with white wine. Set aside to soak.
column4: Cream the shortening with the brown and white sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the eggs and lemon and or vanilla extracts.
column5: Stir the flour, cinnamon and salt together.
column6: Dissolve the baking soda in 1/3 cup of the wine and beat it into the shortening mixture. Stir in the flour. Drain the soaked raisins and stir them and the walnuts into the dough.
column7: Drop tablespoonfuls of the dough onto the prepared baking sheets. Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for about 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Cream 1 cup of the butter with the 1 teaspoon nutmeg and the white sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the egg, 1 tablespoon vanilla and 2 teaspoon rum flavoring. Gradually mix in the flour.
column4: On a lightly floured surface, shape pieces of the dough into long rolls 1/2 inch in diameter. Cut the rolls in 3 inch lengths (to look like small logs). Place cookies on ungreased baking sheets.
column5: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 12 to 15 minutes or until light golden brown. Let cookies cool then spread with frosting on tops and sides. Mark frosting with the tines of a fork to resemble bark on a log. Sprinkle lightly with nutmeg.
column6: To Make Frosting: Cream 3 tablespoons of the butter with 1 teaspoon of the vanilla and 1 teaspoon of the rum flavoring. Blend in 1/2 cup of the confectioners' sugar and beat well. Add the remainder of the confectioners' sugar alternately with the evaporated milk. Beat well after each addition and continue to beat until of spreading consistency.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease one 9x13 inch baking dish.
column3: Beat the white sugar with 1 cup of the butter or margarine until light and fluffy. Beat in the eggs. Then stir in the flour, salt, chocolate syrup and vanilla. Mix until combined.
column4: Pour batter into the prepared pan and bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 30 minutes. Let cool then frost with Creme de Menthe Frosting. Refrigerate until set. Then spread Melted Chocolate topping over top. Let sit until set and cut into bars.
column5: To Make Creme De Menthe Frosting: Combine the confectioners' sugar, 1/2 cup butter or margarine and creme de menthe. Mix until smooth.
column6: To Make Melted Chocolate Topping: Melt the chocolate chips and 6 tablespoons butter together. Stir until smooth and spread evenly over the top of the cooled filling.

column2: Combine the butter, flour and confectioners' sugar together. At first it will have a pie crust consistency. Roll into one large log and wrap in wax paper or plastic wrap. Chill for at least one hour.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column4: Slice chilled log into 1/4 inch thick slices. Place cookies on a baking sheet. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 10 minutes. Watch carefully so they don't burn.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column3: Sift together the flour, salt and baking powder. In a large bowl, beat the butter and sugar together until light and fluffy. Add the sifted dry ingredients and mix to combine. Chill until dough is easy to handle, about 10 minutes.
column4: On a lightly floured surface roll dough out to 1/4 inch thick. Cut into desired shapes and place on ungreased baking sheets.
column5: Bake at 325 degrees F (165 degrees C) for 10 to 15 minutes.

column2: Combine wafer crumbs, finely chopped pecans, 1 cup confectioners' sugar and cocoa.
column3: Blend the bourbon and the corn syrup together. Add the crumb mixture and mix well. Shape into 1 inch balls and roll in confectioners' sugar. Refrigerate.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Separate the eggs.
column4: Cream the butter or margarine with the sugar. Beat in the egg yolks and vanilla. Stir in the flour and the salt.
column5: Shape the dough into small balls and roll in the slightly beaten egg whites then in the chopped nuts. Press thumb in center of cookie to make an indentation.
column6: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 7 minutes or until lightly brown. Cool then fill with your favorite frosting or jam.

column2: Sift together the flour, baking powder and salt; set aside.
column3: Blend together the butter and the sugar, beat in the egg yolk, milk and vanilla. Add the flour mixture. Mix to combine.
column4: Divide dough into two parts. Leave one part buttery and yellow, the other half is to have melted chocolate chips added to it. (Melt in microwave or over boiling water in double boiler being very careful not to scorch or burn). Chill both halves of the dough.
column5: Roll out the black and white sections separately, each between two sheets of waxed paper. Roll into rectangles with 1/4 inch thickness. Place black on white roll together as tough rolling a jelly roll, removing center wax paper as you go. Shape into uniform roll, Chill dough for up to one hour.
column6: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (205 degrees C).
column7: Slice chilled dough into 1/8 inch thick slices. Bake on ungreased cookie sheets at 400 degrees F (205 degrees C) for 5 to 7 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease one 9x9 inch baking pan.
column3: Mix the brownie mix according to box directions, omitting 1/2 of the oil asked for. Stir in the sour cream and coconut pecan frosting. Spread evenly into the prepared pan.
column4: Bake for 20 to 30 minutes in preheated oven, or until done. Be careful not to overbake, or they will harden and be impossible to eat! About 5 minutes before brownies are done, remove from oven, and sprinkle chocolate chips over the top along with chopped pecans. Place back in the oven for 5 minutes. Remove pan from oven, and use a spatula to spread the melted chocolate chips over the top to frost the brownies.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: In a skillet over medium heat toast the pecans with 2 tablespoons of the butter, cooking for about 5 minutes. Sprinkle 1 1/2 tablespoons of the white sugar over the top.
column4: Cream 1/2 cup of the butter with the white and brown sugar. Beat in the egg and vanilla. Mix in the flour, baking soda and salt. Stir in the pecan mixture.
column5: Drop tablespoonfuls of dough onto the prepared baking sheets. Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes until golden brown. Let cool and devour.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Combine the graham cracker crumbs, sugar and melted butter or margarine. Mix and pat into the bottom of one 9x13 inch baking pan. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 15 minutes.
column4: Combine the condensed milk and flaked coconut. Spread over the crust and bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 15 minutes.
column5: Spread the melted chocolate chips over the top. Let cool and cut into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: In a large bowl, cream butter with brown sugar and 1/3 cup white sugar. Blend in the vanilla and milk. Mix in the flour and corn starch. Stir in the mini chocolate chips.
column4: Form the dough into 1 inch balls, and roll in the remaining white sugar. Place on the prepared cookie sheet, about 1 1/2 inches apart. Use your finger or thumb to press straight down into the center of each ball, making a well for the jam. Neatly fill each cookie with a small amount of jam.
column5: Bake in preheated oven for 13 to 15 minutes, or until cookies are just beginning to turn golden around the edges. Let cookies cool before eating.

column2: Heat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease bottom of one13x9 inch pan.
column3: In a small bowl blend the cream cheese, peanut butter, white sugar and 1 egg. Beat at medium speed until smooth. Stir in peanuts and set aside.
column4: In a large bowl combine the brownie mix, water, oil and 2 eggs. Beat for fifty strokes with a wooden spoon.
column5: Spread half of the batter into the prepared pan. Drop filling by tablespoonfuls over brownie batter. Spoon remaining batter over filling. Pull a knife through the batter in wide curves, turn pan and repeat for a marbled effect.
column6: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 30 minutes. Cool completely and cut into bars. Sore tightly covered in the refrigerator.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Combine the eggs and baking mix. Mix in the milk and oil. Stir in the pudding and the chocolate chips.
column4: Drop by teaspoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheet. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Combine peanut butter(including peanut butter from box mix), shortening, oil and water in a large mixing bowl, blend until smooth. Adding one at a time, blend in sugar, brown sugar , eggs and vanilla, mixing well.
column4: In a smaller bowl combine flour, salt, and baking soda. When those are combined, add dry mix from boxed cookie mix to flour mixture and stir using a whisk to break up any lumps.
column5: Combine dry mixture a little at a time into wet mixture and mix well. It may become necessary to finish mixing dough by hand.
column6: Roll dough into 1 1/2 to 2 inch balls and place a baking sheet leave 2 to 2 1/2 inches between cookies. Cross-hatch dough balls using a fork to flatten to 1/2 to 3/4 inch thickness. Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) about 7 to 10 minutes, until edges start to turn light brown. Remove from oven let stand for 5 minutes and transfer cookies to wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: In a large mixing bowl cream the butter. Add the flour, sugar and baking soda. Mix until the mixture forms coarse crumbs
column4: Pat 2/3 of the mixture into the bottom of one 9x13 inch baking pan. Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 10 minutes. Remove and let cool slightly.
column5: Spread the lemon curd over the baked layer. To the remaining 1/3 of crumb mixture add the coconut and the almonds. Sprinkle over the top of the lemon curd.
column6: Lower oven temperature to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Bake bars for 25 minutes or until lightly browned.

column2: Cream together the butter, confectioner's sugar and vanilla until light and fluffy. Stir in the flour and salt. Press and mold dough into a long smooth roll about 2 inches in diameter. Wrap in plastic wrap and chill for several hours or overnight.
column3: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (205 degrees C).
column4: Slice chilled roll into 1/8 to 1/16 inch thick slices. Place on ungreased baking sheets and bake at 400 degrees F (205 degrees C) for 8 to 10 minutes or until lightly browned.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together shortening and white sugar until smooth. Beat in eggs, vanilla extract, and banana. Combine flour, baking soda, and salt; blend thoroughly into the shortening mixture to make a sticky batter. Drop by rounded tablespoons onto the prepared baking sheets.
column4: Bake 10 to 15 minutes in the preheated oven, or until lightly browned.
column5: In a medium bowl, blend butter, confectioners' sugar, milk and vanilla extract. Adjust amount of milk as necessary to attain a drizzling consistency. Drizzle over warm cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Mix the cake mix, egg and whipped topping together. Beat with an electric mixer on medium speed until well blended (batter will be sticky).
column4: Drop batter by teaspoonfuls into the confectioners' sugar and roll to coat. Place cookies onto ungreased baking sheets and bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 8 to 10 minutes or until lightly browned.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Mix the flour, sugar and butter or margarine. Press into the batter of a 13x9 inch ungreased baking pan. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 15 minutes.
column4: Mix the raspberries, orange juice, and cornstarch in a 1 quart sauce pan. Heat to boiling, stirring constantly. Boil and stir for 1 minute. Let cool for 10 minutes.
column5: Sprinkle chocolate chips over baked crust and spoon the raspberry mixture over the top.
column6: Bake at 350 degrees F (1715 degrees C) for 20 minutes or until the raspberry mixture has set. Remove from oven and let cool. Drizzle with additional melted chocolate if desired. Cut into 2x1 inch squares.

column2: Butter a 9x13 inch baking dish. In a large saucepan, melt the butterscotch chips with the peanut butter, stirring frequently until smooth. Stir in the crisp rice cereal. Press half of the cereal mixture into the bottom of the prepared pan.
column3: In the top of a double boiler, melt chocolate chips and butter together, stirring occasionally. Mix in confectioners' sugar and water, and stir until smooth. Spread the chocolate mixture evenly over the cereal layer in the pan. Top with the remaining cereal mixture, and press down lightly. Cover, and chill for about 1 hour before cutting into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease one 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: Cream the butter and 1 cup of the dark brown sugar together until light and fluffy. Mix in 1 beaten egg then add the flour and until well combined. Pour batter into the prepared pan and spread evenly.
column4: Cover the batter with the remaining well-beaten egg. Sprinkle 1/2 cup of the dark brown sugar over the surface then sprinkle with the chopped pecans and top with the remaining 1/2 cup of dark brown sugar.
column5: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 35 minutes. Let cool for 30 minutes then cut into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease a baking sheet.
column3: In a medium sized bowl beat together the butter or margarine, sugar, eggs and vanilla. Stir in the flour, baking powder and cinnamon. Mix well then stir in the walnuts and raisins. Knead until dough comes together.
column4: Divide dough in half and shape into long loaves, 1 1/2 inches thick. Place loaves onto the prepared baking sheet and flatten slightly.
column5: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 18 to 20 minutes. Allow loaves to cool enough to handle (about 10 minutes). With a sharp knife cut loaves diagonally into 3/4 inch thick slices. Place cut sides down on baking sheets. Bake slices for an additional 10 minutes or until lightly browned.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
column3: Sift together flour, baking powder, salt, and orange zest.
column4: In a bowl of mixer, cream butter on medium speed, adding sugar gradually. Add vanilla and egg. Add flour mixture gradually, stopping frequently to push down from sides of bowl. When flour mixture is thoroughly combined, mix in chips.
column5: Drop dough by scant spoonful onto baking sheet, spacing 1 inch apart, flattening slightly with back of spoon. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) 10 to 12 minutes or until beginning to brown. Allow to cool completely on cooling rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheet.
column3: Cream together the butter or margarine and the pudding mix. Blend in the baking mix, egg and sugar and mix well.
column4: On a lightly floured surface roll out the dough to 3/8 inch thickness and cut into cookies with a shamrock cookie cutter.
column5: Place cookies on the prepared baking sheet and bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 9 to 10 minutes or until lightly browned on the edges. Let cookies cool on rack. Frost with green colored icing if desired.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Lightly grease or line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: In a medium sized bowl mix the shortening, applesauce, white sugar, brown sugar, egg and vanilla. Beat until well combined.
column4: In another bowl combine the infant cereal, flour, baking soda, salt and wheat germ. Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix well.
column5: Spoon tablespoonfuls of dough onto the prepared baking sheets. Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 8 to 10 minutes or until just set. Let cool on wire racks before storing.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease or line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: In a large bowl cream the shortening and the sugar together. Beat in the eggs, vanilla and lemon extract. Beat in the bananas and the nuts. Gradually add the flour, baking powder and salt.
column4: Drop the dough by spoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheets. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 12 to 15 minutes or until lightly colored. Transfer to wire racks to cool.

column2: In a saucepan combine the sugar, milk, cocoa, and margarine. Cook over medium high heat, stirring constantly, bring mixture to a boil and boil for 1 minute. Remove from the heat and stir in the vanilla, peanut butter, and quick cooking oats.
column3: Drop spoonfuls of batter onto sheets of greased waxed paper. Let cool. Store cookies in an airtight container.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease, or line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Cream the sugar and shortening together in a mixing bowl. Stir in the baking soda, eggs, and strawberries until just blended. Stir in the flour, salt, and pecans, and mix well. Drop dough by rounded tablespoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheets.
column4: Bake in preheated oven until tops set and are lightly browned, about 15 minutes.

column2: Boil unpeeled potato until soft. Let cool slightly then peel and mash.
column3: Stir in confectioners' sugar into the mashed potato and mix until stiff. On a piece of waxed paper or plastic wrap roll out potato mixture into 1/4 inch thick rectangle. Spread peanut butter over entire area (adjust thickness to suit taste). Roll up jellyroll-fashion wrap with plastic wrap and refrigerate for few hours. Cut into slices to serve.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees C (165 degrees C). Lightly grease one 8x8 inch baking pan.
column3: In large bowl beat the butter or margarine together until light and fluffy. Add the egg and beat well.
column4: Combine the flour, salt, baking soda, cinnamon and mace or nutmeg. Add the flour mixture to the sugar mixture and stir to combine. Mix in the vinegar and juice. Fold in the blackberries.
column5: Pour batter into the prepared pan and bake at 325 degrees F (165 degrees C) for 35 to 40 minutes. Let cool in pan and cut into squares.

column2: Place puffed wheat in a large bowl, and set aside. Grease one 9x9 inch pan.
column3: Grease the rim of a medium saucepan to prevent boil-over. Place the cocoa powder, corn syrup, brown sugar, and butter or margarine in the saucepan. Cook over medium heat, stirring often until mixture comes to a full boil. Allow to boil for 1 minute, and then remove from heat.
column4: Pour chocolate mixture over puffed wheat, and stir until puffed wheat is evenly coated. Using a buttered spatula, press mixture into the prepared pan. Allow to cool, then cut as desired. Wrap squares individually, or store in an airtight container.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: In a large bowl blend the shortening, salt, lemon zest and nutmeg together. Add the sugar and beat well. Beat in the eggs and milk and mix until well combined.
column4: Sift flour, baking powder and baking soda together. Add to the shortening mixture and blend until combined.
column5: Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto the baking sheets and flatten with a glass. Sprinkle tops with sugar. Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 8 to 12 minutes. Enjoy!

column2: Crush the graham crackers between two pieces of wax paper with a rolling pin or in a food processor.
column3: Combine graham cracker crumbs, peanut butter, honey and powdered milk in a large mixing bowl. Mix well.
column4: Make small balls with mixture and place on wax paper. Roll balls in shredded coconut.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: In a medium bowl, beat the butter, brown sugar, hone and egg on medium speed, scraping bowl constantly, until smooth.
column4: Stir in the flour, baking soda, salt and cinnamon. Mix until just combined.
column5: Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto an ungreased or parchment lined baking sheet. Bake until set and light brown around edges (surfaces of cookies will appear shiny), 7 to 9 minutes. Let stand 3 to 5 minutes before removing cookies to a wire rack to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Sift the flour, baking powder, ginger and salt into a large bowl.
column4: Beat the eggs, egg yolks and oil together. Pour the egg mixture into the flour and stir until combined.
column5: Turn dough out onto to a lightly floured surface and knead for a few turns.
column6: Divide dough into 8 equal-size pieces. Roll each piece into rope about 1/2 to 3/4 inch in diameter. Cut ropes into 1/2 inch long pieces. Place on baking sheets and bake at 350 degrees F(175 degrees C) for about 10 minutes. The bottoms should be lightly browned. Remove from oven and let cool.
column7: In a large heavy bottomed saucepan, combine the honey, sugar and ginger. Cook over low heat until sugar is dissolved. Raise heat to medium and bring mixture to a boil. Watch closely because it can boil over and make a big mess. Reduce heat to low and cook until the syrup reaches hard ball stage, 260 degrees F (127 degrees C).
column8: Stir in the cooked tayglach and optional chopped nuts and simmer over low heat, stirring occasionally for 10 minutes.
column9: Spoon mixture onto a parchment lined jelly-roll pan. Spread tayglach into one layer evenly over the surface. Let cool. Once cool, turn tayglach over onto a large surface and peel off parchment paper. Cut into 1 inch squares and place into little paper cups or candy foils. Store in an airtight container at room temperature.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column3: Mix together butter, flour, brown sugar, almonds and salt. Form the dough into marble-size balls. Place each ball on an ungreased cookie sheet 1-1/2 inches apart.
column4: Bake cookies for 15 minutes.

column2: In a medium bowl, cream together the shortening, sugar, eggs, and vanilla until smooth. Then stir in the sour cream. Sift together the flour, salt, baking powder, and baking soda; stir into the creamed mixture. Finally, stir in the pecans and raisins. Cover dough and refrigerate for 1/2 hour.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheet.
column4: Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto a cookie sheet. Bake for 15 to 20 minutes. When cooled ice the cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Cream the butter and sugar in a medium size mixing bowl. Mix flour, baking powder, salt, egg and vanilla extract into the butter-sugar mixture. Cool dough in the refrigerator for 1 hour.
column4: On a lightly floured surface roll dough out to 1/4 inch thick. Cut the dough into rounds with a round cookie cutter or glass. Using the tip of a teaspoon place a small drop of apricot preserves into the middle of the circle. Brush edges with water and fold the dough over so that the cookie is in the shape of a half moon; seal edges Arrange on ungreased cookie sheets.
column5: Bake for 8 to 12 minutes, or until golden brown. Dust the cookies with powdered sugar while still hot.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line cookie sheets with parchment paper, or grease cookie sheets.
column3: Mix flour, salt, baking soda and unsweetened cocoa powder in a medium size mixing bowl.
column4: Cream butter, white sugar, brown sugar, egg, vanilla and water in a mixing bowl until fluffy. Blend flour mixture into the egg mixture until mixed well. Stir white chocolate and chocolate chips into the dough. Drop tablespoon-size dough approximately 1 inch from each other on cookie sheet.
column5: Bake cookies for 9 minutes.

column2: Mix butter, powdered sugar and vanilla together. Add teaspoons of hot water until you reach your desired consistency for spreadable icing.
column3: Spread icing over the Sour Cream Cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x9 inch baking pan.
column3: Mix crunchy peanut butter, creamy peanut butter, powdered sugar, egg and baking powder together. Press dough into a 9x9 inch baking pan.
column4: Bake 8 to 10 minutes.

column2: Grease a 9x13 inch pan.
column3: Mix graham cracker crumbs, butter, peanut butter and powdered sugar together in a large mixing bowl. Press the mixture into the prepared pan.
column4: In a small pot melt chocolate chips and condensed milk together over a low heat. Stir until well mixed. Spread the chocolate mixture over the peanut butter mixture. Chill the cookie-bars for 4 hours. Cut and serve.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Place flour, baking powder, salt and sugar into an electric mixer's mixing bowl and mix well; blend eggs and 1/2 cup oil into mixture. Pour orange juice and orange zest into mixture; mix well. When the mixture becomes very thick take the mixing bowl out of the mixer and continue stirring with a wooden spoon (at this point the mixture is so thick that it could damage an electric mixer).
column4: Separate dough into thirds. Roll (or spread with your hands) each chunk of dough into a rectangular shape. Sprinkle the chocolate syrup onto the center of each rectangle. Fold the sides of each rectangle into the center to form a loaf shape. Work with the loaf until there is no longer a crease that could break open while baking. Each roll will be approximately 12 inches long. Brush the outside of each roll lightly with oil. Sprinkle cinnamon and sugar on top of the rolls.
column5: Bake on a nonstick cookie pan for 20 minutes. This is a firm, cake-like cookie. If you would rather a crispier cookie toast the cookie another 5 minutes. Cool on a wire rack. When cooled cut the loaves to form semi-circle shaped cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Mix butter or margarine, cottage cheese and flour together.
column4: Roll the dough into a circle about 1/4 inch thick. Cut the dough into triangular wedges. Sprinkle raisins into the broad end of the wedge along with cinnamon and sugar. Roll from the broad edge toward the pointed edge to form crescents. Sprinkle the crescents with cinnamon and sugar. Arrange the cookies on an ungreased baking sheet.
column5: Bake for 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease the bottom and sides of 9x13 inch pan.
column3: Combine flour, baking soda and salt in a small bowl; set aside.
column4: In a large mixing bowl blend butter, shortening, white sugar, brown sugar and vanilla together until creamed. Stir in the eggs, one at a time. Blend flour mixture into sugar mixture. Fold in chocolate chips.
column5: Spread 2/3 of the dough mixture evenly in pan. Cover top with 8 ounces raspberry preserves. Dot remaining dough randomly over the jam.
column6: Bake in the center of the oven for 30 minutes, or until done all the way through. Cool, cut, serve and enjoy!

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease the bottom of a 9x13 inch pan.
column3: Pour one cup of yellow cake mix into a medium size mixing bowl; set aside.
column4: Combine remaining cake mix, 1/2 cup melted butter and 1 egg; mix well. Press into the baking pan.
column5: Combine pumpkin pie filling, 2 eggs and milk in a medium size mixing bowl; mix until smooth. Pour evenly over the crust in the 9x13 inch pan.
column6: Pour the sugar and cinnamon into the mixing bowl containing the 1 cup of yellow cake mix. Cut in the butter until the mixture looks crumbly. Sprinkle this mixture over the pumpkin filling.
column7: Bake for 45 to 50 minutes or until a knife inserted into the bars come out clean. Let cool before cutting.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease a 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: Melt butterscotch morsels and margarine in a large bowl in microwave. Stir the mixture well and let it cool to lukewarm.
column4: While the liquid mixture is cooling, mix flour, brown sugar, baking powder, salt, vanilla, and eggs into the butterscotch mixture; mix well. Fold in marshmallows and chocolate morsels.
column5: Spread batter into a lightly greased 9x13 inch pan.
column6: Bake 25 minutes. Be careful not to overcook.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Mix together flour, baking powder, baking soda and salt. Stir 1/2 cup orange juice and 1 teaspoon rind into the flour mixture.
column4: Cream shortening and white sugar together. Mix egg into the sugar mixture thoroughly. Slowly blend flour mixture into the egg and sugar mixture. Drop by teaspoonful onto greased cookie sheet.
column5: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes.
column6: Make the icing: Mix confectioner's sugar and 2 tablespoons butter together until smooth. Pour 2 tablespoons orange juice and 1 teaspoon orange rind into the sugar and butter mixture, mix well. When the cookies have cooled spread the icing generously over the tops of the cookies.

column2: Combine almonds, almond extract, flour, and sugar until thoroughly mixed. Work in butter and egg yolk with hands; until well blended. Chill the dough for one hour.
column3: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column4: Pinch off pieces of dough about the size of your thumb and shape into crescents. Place on greased cookie sheets and bake for about 16 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Grease a cookie sheet.
column3: Beat shortening and sugar together. Blend eggs and fruit into the shortening and sugar mixture. Stir flour, salt, baking soda and nuts into the egg mixture; mix well.
column4: Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto the greased cookie sheet. The cookies will double in size while baking, so set the cookies far apart on the cookie sheet. Bake for 12 to 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column3: Sift together flour, baking soda and salt.
column4: Cream butter, peanut butter and white and brown sugars. Mix in egg and 1/2 teaspoon vanilla. Stir the flour mixture into creamed mixture. Shape the dough into 48 balls, 1 inch each. Place each ball in one compartment of a mini muffin tin.
column5: For filling, put chocolate chips in a double boiler over simmering water. Stir in milk and vanilla, mix well.
column6: Bake for 14 to 16 minutes or until lightly browned. Remove from oven and immediately make wells in the center of each using a melon baller. Cool in pan for 5 minutes. Then carefully remove to wire racks. Using a measuring cup fill each shell with the chocolate mixture. Top with a pecan half.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Toast almonds in oven for 10 minutes or until brown.
column4: Dissolve coffee in 2 tablespoons hot water. In a separate small mixing bowl mix flour, baking soda and salt.
column5: Beat butter and sugar in an electric mixer at a medium speed until fluffy. Pour coffee, vanilla and eggs into the butter mixture; mix well. Reduce mixer's speed to low and slowly pour flour mixture into the butter mixture.
column6: Fold chocolate chips and almonds into the dough. Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto an ungreased cookie sheet, 3 inches apart.
column7: Bake for 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Combine flour, sugar, baking powder and salt. Cut in margarine and cream cheese until mixture resembles coarse meal. Spoon in coconut and preserves, mix well. Drop dough by teaspoonful onto greased cookie sheet.
column4: Bake 15 to 18 minutes; until lightly browned. Cool before frosting.

column2: Mix together sugar, butter or margarine and apricot preserves until well blended.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Cream butter or margarine, sugar and vanilla until mixture is light and fluffy. Slowly blend in the flour.
column4: For each cookie, shape one level tablespoon of dough around a cherry. Form each cookie into a ball and place them on an ungreased cookie sheet 1 inch apart.
column5: Bake 12 to 15 minutes.

column2: In a small mixing bowl combine flour and baking powder.
column3: Beat oil, sugar, and cocoa together in a large mixing bowl. Add eggs to oil and cocoa mixture one egg at a time, beating well after each addition. Stir in vanilla. Mix in flour mixture. Fold in nuts if desired. Chill the dough overnight.
column4: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheet.
column5: Roll dough into walnut-size balls and roll each ball in confectioners' sugar.
column6: Bake cookies for 12 to 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets.
column3: Sift flour, soda, and salt together.
column4: In the top half of a double boiler, melt the chocolate over low heat.
column5: Cream together brown sugar, butter, and egg in a large mixing bowl. Slowly mix in the flour mixture and mix until well blended. Pour in melted chocolate, sour cream, and vanilla. Mix well and stir in nuts.
column6: Drop dough by teaspoonful onto greased cookie sheet about 1 inch apart. Bake for 10 minutes. Cool on wire racks. Cookies will be soft and about the size of a half dollar.
column7: When cooled top with Chocolate Frosting.

column2: Melt butter over a low heat. Stir cocoa, coffee and vanilla into the butter. Mix in powdered sugar and milk. Beat until smooth. Frost cookies and enjoy.
Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets.
column3: Combine white and brown sugar, butter and eggs. Stir in flour, baking soda and salt. The dough will be stiff.
column4: Stir in nuts, chocolate chips, rum and whiskey. Drop dough by tablespoonful onto cookie sheet. Bake 8 to 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 200 degrees F (100 degrees C).
column3: Trim crusts from bread. Cut bread slices into 1/2 inch wide sticks. Bake the bread sticks in the oven for 2 hours. Remove from pan to cool.
column4: Melt peanut butter and oil together until melted. Drizzle in honey, stirring until well blended.
column5: Dip each baked stick in the peanut butter mixture. Roll each stick in the cornflake crumbs. Place the coated breadsticks on wax paper to set. Layer the sticks on top of each other in a container, separating the layers with wax paper. Freeze the cookies. Serve them direct from the freezer.

column2: Spray a 9x9 inch baking pan with non-aerosol cooking spray.
column3: Combine sugar, cocoa, milk and butter in a saucepan. Bring mixture to a boil. Stop stirring after the mixture starts boiling; allow it to boil for 2 minutes.
column4: Remove mixture from heat and stir in oats, peanut butter and vanilla; mix well. Spread mixture into the prepared pan. Cool and store in refrigerator.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: In a small mixing bowl combine flour, cocoa, baking powder and salt.
column4: In a large bowl cream butter and sugar; beat in eggs and vanilla. Stir flour mixture into the creamed egg mixture. Spread batter into the greased 9x13 inch pan.
column5: Bake for 15 to 20 minutes.
column6: Sprinkle marshmallows over top of the baked bars; bake 3 minutes more. Cool.
column7: Place chocolate chips and peanut butter in a microwave safe bowl. Melt chocolate chips and peanut butter in a microwave on high until melted together. Cook one minute at a time, stirring after each minute.
column8: Stir cereal into the chocolate mixture. Spread the chocolate mixture over the cooled bars. Chill, cut into bars and refrigerate.

column2: Melt the chocolate and shortening together over medium-low heat. Stir until smooth. Remove the mixture from heat and stir in raisins and nuts. Drop cookies by tablespoon onto waxed paper. Chill and serve.
Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheet.
column3: Sift together flour, baking powder and salt.
column4: In a large bowl, cream butter or margarine with sugar. Beat in eggs and lemon flavoring. Mix in milk and flour mixture alternately in three parts, starting with the milk. Gently mix in blueberries.
column5: Drop batter by tablespoons onto prepared sheets 1 1/2 inches apart.
column6: Bake 12 to 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheet.
column3: Combine peanut butter, eggs, and sugar and mix until smooth. Mix in chocolate chips and nuts, if desired. Spoon dough by tablespoons onto a cookie sheet.
column4: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes or until lightly browned. Let the cookies cool on the cookie sheets for 5 to 10 minutes before removing.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease or line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
column3: In a large bowl cream the butter or margarine with the sugar. Beat in the egg and the Sweet Sourdough Starter. Stir in the flour, salt, baking soda, baking powder and vanilla. Mix until smooth.
column4: Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheets. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 10 to 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Combine baking soda, baking powder, salt, flour and instant coffee in a mixing bowl.
column4: Cream the butter with the brown and white sugar until fluffy. Beat in eggs, milk and vanilla extract. Gradually add flour mixture to the butter mixture and beat well. Stir in the chopped pecans and chocolate chips; mix well to blend. Drop cookies by tablespoon onto an ungreased cookie sheet.
column5: Bake for 15 minutes or until cookies are golden in color.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: Combine flour and sugar in a large mixing bowl. In a medium saucepan, over medium heat, bring margarine, cocoa and water to a fast boil. Pour over flour mixture and mix well. Mix buttermilk, eggs, baking soda, cinnamon and vanilla into the flour mixture; mixing well after each addition. spread evenly into the prepared pan.
column4: Bake for 35 minutes in the preheated oven, or until brownies begin to pull away from the sides of the pan.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets.
column3: Mix together coconut, flour, salt, syrup and vanilla. Drop the dough by rounded teaspoonfuls onto a lightly greased cookie sheet.
column4: Bake for 10 minutes or until slightly firm. Remove the cookies from cookie sheet immediately and cool completely before eating.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream shortening and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in egg and almond extract. Stir in flour, baking powder and salt. When the mixture is creamy, stir in chocolate chips, coconut and cherries. Drop the dough by teaspoonful onto a greased cookie sheet.
column4: Bake for 12 to 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat the over to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). Grease a cookie sheet.
column3: Stir flour, 2 tablespoons sugar, baking powder and salt in a medium bowl. Stir in milk and the 1/4 cup melted butter until dough forms.
column4: Turn dough onto a flat, floured surface. Knead dough 10 times. Roll dough with a rolling pin or pat with hands into a rectangle, 9x5 inches. Brush with remaining melted butter using a pastry brush; sprinkle with 3 tablespoons sugar and cinnamon. Roll dough up tightly, beginning at narrow end. Pinch edge of dough into roll to seal. Cut into 4 equal pieces with sharp knife. Place cuts sides up on cookie sheet; pat each into a 6-inch circle.
column5: Bake until golden brown, 8 to 10 minutes. Immediately remove from cookie sheet with a spatula. Let cool on wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets. Stir together the flour, baking soda, cream of tartar, and salt; set aside.
