column3: Melt the butter and white chocolate together over low heat in a saucepan. Remove from heat, and let cool slightly. Meanwhile beat eggs with sugar and vanilla extract in a mixing bowl; mix in the butter mixture, and stir in the flour and salt until thoroughly combined. Scoop the batter into the prepared baking pan; sprinkle with white chocolate chips.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick inserted into the center of the pan comes out clean, 30 to 35 minutes. Allow to cool in pan for about 10 minutes before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour an 11x17 inch baking pan.
column3: Melt vegetable oil, 3/4 cup margarine, and cocoa in a large pot over medium heat. Remove from heat, and stir 2 1/2 cups sugar and the salt into the chocolate. Allow the mixture to cool slightly. Beat in the eggs one at a time, mixing well after each, then add the vanilla. Stir 1 3/4 cup flour into the chocolate mixture. Spread the batter evenly into the prepared pan.
column4: Bake for 20 minutes in the preheated oven. Allow to cool completely.
column5: Beat 1 cup margarine, 1 cup brown sugar, and 1 cup white sugar with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Add milk and 2 teaspoons vanilla extract; beat well. Mix in the flour until just incorporated.
column6: Place chunks of the cookie dough over the cooled brownies; then place a piece of plastic wrap between your hand and the dough and squish it down into place. This gives an even layer of dough and helps "stick" it to the top of the brownies. Refrigerate until firm, about 30 minutes.
column7: Melt the chocolate chips with the shortening in a microwave-safe glass or ceramic bowl in 30-second intervals, stirring after each melting, until the chocolate is warm and smooth, 1 to 3 minutes (depending on your microwave). Do not overheat or chocolate will scorch. Spread over the chilled brownies. Refrigerate uncovered until set, about 30 minutes, before cutting into squares.

column2: Combine the graham cracker crumbs and melted butter in a mixing bowl. Mix until evenly moistened.
column3: Melt the chocolate chips in a microwave-safe glass or ceramic bowl in 30-second intervals, stirring after each melting, for 1 to 3 minutes (depending on your microwave). Do not overheat or chocolate will scorch. Stir the melted chocolate into the graham cracker mixture, you may need to use your hands to make sure it is evenly combined.
column4: Shape into 1 inch balls and roll them in the coconut. Store in an airtight container.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13-inch baking pan.
column3: Melt 1 12-ounce package of chocolate chips in a saucepan with 2/3 cup of butter over very low heat, stirring constantly, until smooth. Watch carefully to avoid scorching; Remove from heat, and scrape into a large bowl. Beat in the sugar, a couple of tablespoons at a time, then beat in the eggs 2 at a time until the mixture is well combined. Stir in flour and salt until blended, then stir in the vanilla extract. Gently fold in 1 more 12-ounce package of chocolate chips and the pecans. Spread batter into the prepared baking pan.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick inserted into the center of the brownies comes out with moist crumbs, about 35 minutes. Remove from oven and cool completely.
column5: Mix the cream and 1/4 cup of butter together in a saucepan over low heat until the butter has melted, stirring constantly; pour in remaining 1 12-ounce bag of chocolate chips and stir to melt completely. Pour the mixture into a mixing bowl, and beat on Medium speed with an electric mixer until combined, about 1 minute; chill the frosting thoroughly, stirring occasionally, about 45 minutes to 1 hour. Mixture should be the consistency of thick cream; beat the frosting again with electric mixer until it forms stiff peaks, 3 to 5 minutes. Spread frosting on cooled brownies.

column2: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly butter a 9x13-inch baking dish.
column3: Whisk together 1 1/2 cup flour and confectioners' sugar in a mixing bowl. Cut in the cold butter with a knife or pastry blender until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Press the crumbs into the bottom and up the sides of the prepared baking dish to form a crust.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, 15 to 18 minutes. Remove from oven, and set aside.
column5: Whisk together 4 eggs, 1 1/2 cup sugar, 1 tablespoon flour, lemon zest, and lemon juice in a bowl. Pour lemon mixture into the prepared crust. Skim off any bubbles from the surface of the filling. Mix the cream cheese and 1 cup sugar in a bowl until well blended. Whisk in 2 eggs, then spread over the lemon mixture. The mixtures will separate during baking.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until the filling is set, about 30 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 275 degrees F (135 degrees C). Spread the almonds onto a baking sheet, and toast until the nuts start to turn golden brown and become fragrant, about 45 minutes. Watch the nuts carefully as they bake, they burn quickly. Once toasted, set the nuts aside to cool to room temperature. Finely grind the almonds in a food processor.
column3: Raise oven temperature to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Oil a baking sheet with vegetable oil.
column4: In a bowl, mix together the ground almonds, oat flour, maple syrup, and almond extract. Form the mixture into 6 balls, then flatten the balls into cookies about 1/4 inch thick. Place cookies onto the prepared baking sheet.
column5: Bake until crisp and brown around the edges, 12 to 15 minutes; watch them carefully because they burn easily. Remove the cookies carefully, and allow to cool.

column2: Position racks in the upper and lower thirds of the oven. Preheat the oven to 325 degrees. Line two large baking sheets with foil, dull side up.
column3: Mix the flour, baking soda, and salt together thoroughly. Set aside.
column4: In a large bowl, combine the butter, both sugars, corn syrup, milk, and vanilla. Mix until smooth. Stir in the flour mixture. Stir in the nuts and chocolate chips. The dough will be very soft.
column5: Divide the dough in half. Divide one half of the dough into 10 equal pieces (each a scant 1/4 cup). Place 5 pieces of dough least 3 inches apart on each lined baking sheet. Use your fingers covered with a piece of plastic wrap to flatten each scoop until it is 3 inches in diameter. (Cookies will spread even more as they bake).
column6: Bake the two sheets for 8 minutes. Rotate the sheets from the top rack to the bottom and from front to back. Bake for 7-10 more minutes, watching closely, until the cookies are evenly dark golden brown all over. (Pale cookies will not be crispy). Let cool on pan for 5 minutes. Slide the foil with cookies onto racks. When the baking sheets are cool, repeat with the remaining dough. Cool cookies completely before stacking or storing. Cookies keep, in an airtight container for at least 5 days.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (325 degrees F for glass dish). In 13 x 9-inch baking pan, melt butter in oven. Sprinkle crumbs over butter; pour sweetened condensed milk evenly over crumbs. Top with remaining ingredients; press down firmly with fork. Bake 25 minutes or until lightly browned. Cool. Chill if desired. Cut into bars. Store covered at room temperature.
Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease a 9x13 inch baking dish with cooking spray.
column3: Combine the graham cracker crumbs, melted butter, sugar, and cinnamon in a mixing bowl. Mix until evenly moistened, then press into the bottom of the prepared baking dish. Bake in the preheated oven until the crust is lightly browned and smells toasted, about 5 minutes.
column4: Place the chocolate into a medium bowl. Heat the cream in a small sauce pan over medium heat. Bring just to a boil. When the cream has come to a boil, remove from the heat immediately and pour over the chocolate chips; whisk until smooth. Stir in the optional rum. Pour evenly over the graham cracker layer.
column5: Preheat the oven's broiler and set the oven rack about 6 inches from the heat source.
column6: Place an even layer of marshmallows on top of the chocolate. Broil until the marshmallows are lightly toasted, about 1 minute. Refrigerate until chocolate has hardened, about 45 minutes. Cut into bars using a pizza cutter sprayed with non-stick cooking spray.

column2: Line baking sheets with waxed paper. Mix the oats, coconut, and peanut butter in a bowl until thoroughly combined.
column3: Place sugar, cocoa powder, butter, and milk in a large saucepan, and bring to a boil over medium heat. Stir until the mixture is smooth and the sugar has dissolved, about 1 minute; remove from heat. Mix the oat mixture into the liquid mixture; stir in vanilla extract.
column4: Scoop up about 1 tablespoonful of the dough, roll it into a ball, and flatten. Place on waxed paper, and allow to cool.

column2: Whisk together flour, sugar, and salt in a large bowl; with a pastry cutter, chop in the butter until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Stir the rum extract and almond extract into the water in a small bowl. Mix into the dry ingredients, a little bit at a time, until the mixture holds together in a ball when you squeeze it.
column3: Place the dough onto a floured work surface, and sprinkle with flour; roll out into a sheet 1/4 inch thick. Cut into shapes with floured cookie cutters, and place 1 inch apart on ungreased baking sheets. Cover with a layer of plastic wrap, and refrigerate for 30 minutes.
column4: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column5: Bake the cookies just until the edges are lightly browned, 15 to 18 minutes. Allow to cool on sheets for 2 minutes before removing to wire racks to finish cooling. Cool completely before decorating.
column6: For frosting, whisk the confectioners' sugar and milk in a bowl until smooth. If desired, divide frosting into small bowls, and tint each bowl a desired shade with food coloring. Frost fully cooled cookies, and sprinkle with edible glitter before the frosting sets.

column2: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease an 11x17 1/2-inch jelly roll pan. Combine white sugar, flour, baking soda, and salt together in a bowl.
column3: Place 1/2 cup butter, shortening, 1/3 cup cocoa powder, and coffee in a microwave safe bowl. Heat in microwave for three minutes, stirring after each minute, until well blended. Whisk together the eggs and buttermilk in a bowl. Stir in the flour and cocoa mixtures, mixing until just combined. Pour mixture into the prepared pan.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until the top is dry and the edges have started to pull away from the sides of the pan, about 20 minutes.
column5: Heat the remaining 1/2 cup butter, 2 tablespoons cocoa, and milk in a saucepan over medium heat until combined, about 5 minutes, stirring often. Stir in the confectioners' sugar and vanilla extract until smooth. Pour the warm frosting over the hot brownies. Allow brownies to cool completely before slicing into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or a silicone liner. Whisk together the flour, cinnamon, ginger, cloves, baking soda, and salt in a bowl until thoroughly combined.
column3: In a large bowl, mash vegetable shortening and sugar together until smooth and creamy; mix in the egg and molasses. Stir the flour mixture into the molasses mixture to make a smooth dough, and mix in the chocolate chips. Drop by scant tablespoon or small dough scoop about 2 inches apart onto the prepared baking sheets.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until slightly golden brown, 10 to 12 minutes. Allow to cool on sheets 1 to 2 minutes before removing to finish cooling on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Whisk flour, baking soda, and salt together in a bowl.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, mash the butter with white sugar and brown sugar until the mixture is well combined. Beat in the eggs, one at a time, and stir in vanilla extract. Stir in the flour mixture, about 1 cup at a time, then mix in the chocolate chips. Drop the dough by rounded tablespoon onto baking sheets, about 2 inches apart.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, 12 to 15 minutes. Allow to cool for about 5 minutes on the baking sheets before removing cookies to finish cooling.

column2: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Mix the flour, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon together in a large bowl.
column3: Beat the butter and sugar with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Add the eggs one at a time, allowing each egg to blend into the butter mixture before adding the next. Mix in the flour mixture until just incorporated. Fold in the oats and raisins; mixing just enough to evenly combine. Drop spoonfuls of the dough 2 inches apart onto ungreased baking sheets.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, 10 to 12 minutes. Cool in the pans for 10 minutes before removing to cool completely on a wire rack.

column2: Butter a 9x13-inch pan. Melt butter in a saucepan over medium-low heat. Add the marshmallow creme and stir until melted. Stir in the corn chips, making sure they are well coated with the marshmallow mixture.
column3: Using buttered spatula or waxed paper, press mixture evenly and firmly into the prepared pan. Cut into squares when cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 250 degrees F (120 degrees C). Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Cut about 1/4 inch off a corner of a heavy gallon-size resealable plastic bag, and push a large-size cake decorating tip (such as a star tip) into the opening. The fit should be tight.
column4: In a small bowl, stir the gelatin mix with the sugar substitute. In a large bowl, using an electric mixer, beat the egg whites with cream of tartar and salt until stiff peaks form. As you beat the egg whites, gradually add the gelatin mixture, about 1 tablespoon at a time. Spoon the fluffy mixture into the prepared plastic bag, and gently squeeze and twist the bag to force the meringue mixture to the decorating tip. (Do not seal bag, so that air can escape.)
column5: Squeeze the bag to place golf-ball size dollops of meringue mixture onto the prepared baking sheets. For a decorative effect, twist and lift as you place the cookie on the sheet, to make a pretty shape.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until the cookies are set and dry, about 1 hour and 30 minutes. Do not open oven door while baking. At end of baking time, turn off oven, open oven door, and allow the cookies to slowly cool in the oven before removing from baking sheets. Store in airtight container.

column2: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a jelly roll pan.
column3: Sift flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, and salt together in a bowl.
column4: Beat the butter and 1 1/2 cups sugar with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Beat the first egg into the butter until completely blended, then beat in the vanilla extract with the last egg. Mix in the flour mixture until just incorporated. Fold in the zucchini; mixing just enough to evenly combine. Pour mixture into prepared pan. Sprinkle the remaining 2 tablespoons sugar, chocolate chips, and walnuts on top.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until the top is dry and the edges have started to pull away from the sides of the pan, 25 to 30 minutes.

column2: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Stir the flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, cinnamon, cloves, and salt together in a bowl.
column3: Beat the sugar and margarine with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Beat the first egg into the butter until completely blended; beat the vanilla into the mixture with the last egg. Stir the zucchini through the mixture until evenly distributed. Mix the flour mixture into the zucchini mixture until just incorporated. Fold in the chocolate chips, mixing just enough to evenly combine. Roll the dough into walnut-sized balls and place 2 inches apart onto ungreased baking sheets.
column4: Bake in batches in the preheated oven until the edges are golden, about 10 minutes. Allow the cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 1 minute before removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone mat.
column3: Combine the flour, coconut, pineapple, macadamia nuts, and salt in a large bowl. Stir in the sweetened condensed milk, rum extract, and vanilla extract. Drop golf ball-sized scoops of the dough 2 inches apart onto the prepared baking sheets.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until coconut is toasted, 12 to 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease baking sheets.
column3: Stir together the flour, baking soda, cinnamon, and cloves in a bowl; set aside. Beat the butter and brown sugar with an electric mixer in a large bowl until creamy. Add the egg and the vanilla extract. Mix in the flour mixture and oats until just incorporated.
column4: Wring the zucchini in a clean towel to remove any excess moisture. Stir the zucchini and raisins into the dough; mixing just enough to evenly combine. Drop batter by rounded teaspoonfuls 2-inches apart onto the prepared baking sheets. Bake for 14 to 16 minutes or until the bottom edges turn golden brown.

column2: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13-inch baking pan. Mix sweetened condensed milk, 1 egg, pecans, toffee bits, and vanilla extract in a bowl until well blended; set aside.
column3: Cut the butter and 1 egg into the yellow cake mix in a large bowl with a knife or pastry blender until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Press the crumbs into the prepared pan to form a bottom layer.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until firm, about 7 minutes. Spread pecan filling over the baked bottom layer, then continue baking until the filling has set, 22 to 30 minutes. Cool completely on a wire rack. Serve with whipped topping.

column2: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Arrange the graham crackers in a single layer on a baking sheet, making sure the crackers touch each other.
column3: Heat the butter, margarine, and white sugar in a saucepan over medium heat until the sugar is dissolved, about 2 minutes. Stir in the pecans. Spread the butter mixture over the graham crackers.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until butter mixture is absorbed, 8 to 10 minutes. Immediately transfer the crackers to cool on aluminum foil or wax paper. Once cooked, break crackers into bite-sized pieces.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: In a bowl, beat the cream cheese until soft and fluffy with an electric mixer, then beat in the egg until thoroughly combined. Mix in the cookie mix, then stir in the raspberry chips. Drop the dough about 2 inches apart onto the prepared baking sheets with a tablespoon or small scoop. Lightly pat the cookies to flatten.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until the edges of the cookies are lightly golden, 9 to 12 minutes. Cool before serving.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease baking sheets.
column3: With an electric mixer, cream together the sugar, vegetable shortening, egg, and vanilla extract in a bowl until light and fluffy. Sift 1 cup plus 2 tablespoons of flour together with the baking powder and salt in a bowl, and stir the flour mixture into the creamed mixture; mix in the coconut until thoroughly combined. Drop the dough by teaspoons onto the prepared baking sheets.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until very lightly browned, about 10 minutes; allow cookies to cool on sheets for about 1 minute before removing to finish cooling on baking racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with parchment.
column3: Spread oats out onto an unlined baking sheet in a thin layer, and toast until lightly browned, about 10 minutes; remove and allow to cool. Mix together the cooled oats, protein powder, whole wheat flour, and flax seed until thoroughly combined, and mix with peanut butter and honey. Mash the bananas into the mixture, and stir to combine. Press the dough down onto the parchment-lined baking sheet in a 1/2-inch layer.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until the edges of the dough are golden brown, about 15 minutes; cut into bars while warm, and allow the bars to cool. Wrap bars in plastic wrap, and refrigerate until ready to use.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Pulse the walnuts in a food processor several times to chop; continue processing until the walnuts are ground into flour; transfer to a bowl. Mix in the rolled oats, whole wheat flour, flax meal, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon until thoroughly combined.
column4: Combine the almond butter, canola oil, agave nectar, brown sugar, egg, and vanilla extract in the food processor and process a few seconds to blend the ingredients well; transfer the almond butter mixture to a large bowl and fold in the dried cherries and chocolate chips. Mix the walnut-oatmeal mixture into the almond butter mixture (dough will be very thick).
column5: Scoop up heaping teaspoons of dough, and form into balls; lay the dough balls onto the prepared baking sheets, about 2 inches apart.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until lightly browned, 8 to 10 minutes. Remove from oven and flatten the cookies with a spatula. Allow to cool for about 5 minutes on the baking sheets before removing to finish cooling on wire racks.

column2: In a bowl, whisk the flour, baking soda, and cinnamon together until evenly blended; set aside. Beat the margarine, white sugar, and brown sugar with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Add the eggs one at a time, allowing each egg to blend into the margarine mixture before adding the next. Mix in the flour mixture until just incorporated. Fold in the chopped nuts; mixing just enough to evenly combine.
column3: Scrape the dough onto a sheet of waxed paper, and form into a log. Roll tightly in the waxed paper, and refrigerate until firm, about 4 hours.
column4: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Spray baking sheets with cooking spray.
column5: Unwrap the dough, and cut into 1/4-inch slices. Place the cookies onto baking sheets, spaced 1-inch apart. Bake in the preheated oven until the edges are golden, 8 to 10 minutes. Allow the cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 1 minute before removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper.
column3: In a bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, salt, cinnamon, and cloves until well mixed. With an electric mixer on medium speed, beat the butter and sugar together in a separate large bowl until light and fluffy; beat in the eggs, one at a time. Mix in the vanilla extract. Stir in the flour mixture just until incorporated, and mix in the cinnamon chips and pistachio nuts.
column4: Divide the dough in half. With floured hands, shape each half into a log about 9 inches long, and place on the prepared baking sheet. Brush the logs with beaten egg white.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until the logs are golden brown, 30 to 35 minutes. Remove from oven and let cool until easy to handle. Reduce oven heat to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Remove parchment paper from baking sheet.
column6: Using a serrated knife with a light sawing motion, cut the logs apart into 1/2-inch thick biscotti. Place the biscotti onto the baking sheet, and return to oven.
column7: Bake in the oven until the biscotti are lightly toasted, about 10 minutes; remove from oven, turn the biscotti over, and toast the other sides for an additional 10 minutes. Allow to cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a bowl, cream together 1 cup butter and the flour until smooth and creamy. Stir in heavy cream. Scrape dough into a ball.
column4: Sprinkle the white sugar on a cutting board. Roll out the dough to about a 1/4-inch thickness on the sugared surface. Using a 3-inch round cookie cutter, cut dough into 24 circles. Using the rolling pin, roll each circle into a slightly oval shape. Place cookies on an ungreased cookie sheet about an inch apart.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until the edges of the cookies get very lightly brown, 10 to 12 minutes. Cool slightly on cookie sheet; then transfer them to cooling racks using a spatula.
column6: To make the filling, mix together 1/2 cup of butter, confectioners' sugar, egg yolk, and Swedish arrack punsch in a bowl. Beat until mixture is well blended and creamy.
column7: To assemble, spread about a rounded teaspoon of filling on the bottom of one cookie and place another cookie, bottom side down, on the filling to form a sandwich. Repeat with the rest of the cookies.

column2: Combine flour, baking powder, and salt in a bowl; set aside. Beat the butter and confectioners' sugar with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Stir in the vanilla and almond extracts and orange zest. Mix in the flour mixture until just incorporated. Fold in the cranberries; mixing just enough to evenly combine.
column3: Divide the dough into 2 equal portions, then roll into logs about 7 inches long. Wrap each log in wax paper or plastic wrap, and chill in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours.
column4: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column5: Remove wax paper, and cut the cookie dough into 1/2-inch slices. Arrange the slices on a baking sheet about 1 inch apart.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until firm but not browned, about 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat an oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the butter and 1/2 cup confectioners' sugar until smooth in a bowl. Stir in the poppy seeds and vanilla extract. Stir in the flour until just combined. Roll the dough into 1-inch balls, and place 1 inch apart onto ungreased baking sheets.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until lightly golden, 8 to 10 minutes. Remove from baking sheet to cool slightly, then roll warm cookies in the remaining 1/2 cup confectioners' sugar until coated. Cool completely on wire racks, then roll in sugar once more.

column2: Heat oven to 350 degrees F. Separate dough into 8 triangles.
column3: Place tablespoon of chocolate chips on wide end of each triangle. Roll up, starting at shortest side of triangle, rolling to opposite point. Place on ungreased cookie sheet.
column4: Bake at 350 degrees F. for 15 to 20 minutes or until golden brown. Sprinkle with powdered sugar.

column2: Place the bacon in a large, deep skillet, and cook over medium-high heat, turning occasionally, until evenly browned, about 10 minutes. Drain the bacon slices on a paper towel-lined plate. When cool, chop the bacon, and set aside.
column3: Beat the butter, white sugar, and brown sugar together in a large mixing bowl until fluffy with an electric mixer on medium speed, then mix in egg, and vanilla extract until thoroughly combined. Whisk the flour, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon together in a bowl, and stir the flour mixture into the butter mixture. Gradually stir in the oats and bacon, about 1/3 cup of oats at a time, and cover the dough. Refrigerate at least 1 hour.
column4: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Thoroughly grease baking sheets.
column5: Scoop about 1/3 cup of dough per cookie, roll into balls, and place the balls at least 3 inches apart on the greased baking sheets. Use a fork dipped in water to flatten the balls slightly.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until the cookies are golden brown with slightly browner edges, 10 to 12 minutes. Allow to cool on baking sheets 3 to 5 minutes before removing to finish cooling on racks.
column7: To make glaze, whisk confectioners' sugar, water, and maple syrup together in a bowl until smooth. Let the glaze stand about 5 minutes to slightly thicken; drizzle onto the tops of the cookies. Allow glazed cookies to stand about 20 minutes to set up before storing.

column2: In a bowl, mash the butter and flour together until smooth and creamy. Beat in the cream, 1 to 2 tablespoons at a time, until thoroughly combined.
column3: Scrape the dough onto a large sheet of plastic wrap, wrap tightly, and chill at least 1 hour to overnight.
column4: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column5: Roll the dough out 1/4 inch thick on a floured work surface, and cut into 2-inch circles with a cutter. Place sugar into a shallow bowl, and dip each cookie into the sugar on both sides. Place the cookies onto the prepared baking sheets.
column6: Bake cookies in the preheated oven until the edges turn light golden brown, 10 to 12 minutes. Allow to cool for about 5 minutes on sheets before removing to cool completely on racks.

column2: In a bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon; mix in the walnuts.
column3: In a separate large bowl, beat the butter and brown sugar together with an electric mixer until fluffy; stir in the honey, vanilla extract, and egg until thoroughly combined. Mix the flour mixture into the wet ingredients just until well combined (don't overmix), and chill the dough for at least 1 hour or overnight.
column4: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets, or line with parchment paper.
column5: Scoop up about 1 tablespoon of dough per cookie, and roll into a ball; place onto the prepared baking sheets.
column6: Bake until the cookies are just puffy (or a little bit flat in the middle for a gooey texture), 8 to 10 minutes. Allow the cookies to cool on baking sheets for about 5 minutes before removing them to finish cooling on racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Place an oven rack in the upper third of the oven. Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Place unsalted butter and light brown sugar into the work bowl of a stand mixer and mix on medium-slow speed until very fluffy, 3 to 4 minutes. Beat in the vanilla extract, followed by eggs, one at a time. Reduce mixer speed to lowest speed and leave running.
column4: In a separate bowl, whisk together the rolled oats, flour, baking powder, cinnamon, kosher salt, and nutmeg. Pour the dry ingredients into the slowly running mixer in thirds; mix in dried cranberries and nuts until just incorporated. Using a large cookie scoop, place dough on prepared baking sheet about 2 inches apart.
column5: Bake one batch at a time in the preheated oven just until the edges are brown, 17 to 18 minutes. Allow to cool on baking sheets for about 5 minutes before removing to finish cooling on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour a 9x13-inch baking pan.
column3: In a large bowl, beat the butter, brown sugar, and white sugar until thoroughly mixed and creamy. Beat in the eggs, one at a time, mixing well after each addition. Stir in the vanilla extract until well mixed, and mix in salt, baking soda, baking powder, flour, rolled oats, plus chocolate chips, raisins, and chopped nuts if desired. Mix well to moisten all ingredients, and spread into the prepared baking pan.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, 20 to 25 minutes. Let cool in the pan for about 5 minutes before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease baking sheets.
column3: In a bowl, sift the flour, baking soda, and salt together. In a separate large bowl, cream the butter, 1 cup of white sugar, and brown sugar until smooth, and beat in the eggs and vanilla extract until well combined. Stir in the flour mixture, and mix the pecans into the dough.
column4: Drop the dough by tablespoons onto the prepared baking sheets, about 2 inches apart. Place 1/2 cup of white sugar into a shallow bowl. Moisten the bottom of a drinking glass with a wet cloth, and dip the glass bottom into the sugar. Flatten cookies with the sugared glass, dipping into sugar for each cookie.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until lightly browned, 9 to 12 minutes. Allow to cool on sheets for a minute or two before removing to finish cooling on racks.

column2: In a heatproof bowl over a double boiler, melt chocolate and butter until smooth. Turn off the stove and let chocolate sit over warm water.
column3: Combine flour, baking powder and salt and mix to combine. In another bowl, mix together sugar and eggs, combine thoroughly with a whisk and slowly add the warm chocolate mixture. Stir to combine. Add vanilla extract and mix. Stir in flour mixture. Cool for a few minutes (if batter is warm, chocolate chips will melt). Stir in chocolate chips. Chill for 10-15 minutes.
column4: Pre-heat oven to 350 degrees. Scoop rounded tablespoons of batter and place on baking tray. Sprinkle each cookie lightly with a pinch of sea salt. Bake at 350 degrees for approximately 7-8 minutes until the outside looks slightly cracked. Be very careful not to over bake cookies because they will continue to bake as they cool once removed from the oven. Cookies should be soft and gooey in the center.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Line a 9 x 13 inch baking pan with foil and grease with pan spray.
column3: In a medium saucepan, bring 2 inches of water to a gentle simmer. Put the 60% chips and butter in a heatproof bowl and set it over (but not touching) the simmering water. Stir the mixture with a rubber spatula until the butter is melted and both ingredients are completely combined. Turn off the heat and leave the bowl over the warm water.
column4: Sift together the flour and baking powder and set aside. In a large bowl whisk together eggs, salt, sugar and vanilla. Add the egg mixture to the chocolate mixture and whisk together gently. With a spatula, fold in the flour. Immediately pour 1/2 the mixture into the prepared baking pan and spread it evenly. Next, sprinkle the chopped peppermint bark over the batter and then pour the remaining batter over this. Spread evenly.
column5: Bake for 15-20 minutes. The center should be fudgy but not dry. Remove from the oven and cool for 10 minutes. Place Peppermint Bark chunks on top of warm brownies and allow them to soften for 1 minute. Using a spatula, gently swirl the melting Peppermint Bark to create swirls of melted chocolate. Refrigerate for 1 hour. Trim the 4 edges of the brownies by 1/4 inch. And cut into 18 squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with a silicon mat or parchment paper.
column3: Mash the butter, white sugar, and brown sugar together in a large mixing bowl with a spatula until creamy and smooth, 2 to 3 minutes. Add the egg and vanilla; whisk vigorously for 20 to 30 seconds.
column4: Whisk the flour, salt, and baking soda together in a small bowl; dump into the butter mixture and mix until just combined. Fold the semi-sweet chocolate chips, white chocolate chips, and milk chocolate chips into the mixture. Arrange onto the prepared baking sheet using a small scoop or large spoon.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, about 10 minutes; remove from oven and allow to cool on the sheet for 10 minutes. Transfer to a wire rack to finish cooling completely.

column2: Place the chocolate chips into a microwave-safe bowl and cook on High for 30 seconds; stir and repeat several times, just until the chips are melted. Add peanut butter, cook for 20 more seconds to warm the peanut butter, and mix thoroughly. Mix in the toffee bits and chow mein noodles; stir to coat the ingredients with the chocolate mixture.
column3: Line a baking sheet with parchment or waxed paper; drop the mixture onto the lined sheets by the tablespoon. Refrigerate until set.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease two baking sheets.
column3: Cream together the butter, kiwi, brown sugar and white sugar in a large bowl, until light and fluffy. Add the eggs one at a time, beating well with each addition, then stir in the vanilla extract. Combine flour, baking soda, and toasted oat cereal in a bowl; gradually stir into the creamed mixture. Finally, fold in the chocolate chips. Drop by rounded spoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheets.
column4: Bake in preheated oven until light brown, about 8 to 10 minutes. Allow cookies to cool on baking sheet for 5 minutes before removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Cream together butter, sweetener, and sugar in a large bowl, until smooth. Beat in eggs and vanilla extract. Stir in flour and baking powder. Cover and chill dough for at least one hour or overnight.
column3: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column4: Roll out dough on floured surface 1/4- to 1/2-inch thick. Cut into shapes with any cookie cutter. Place cookies 1-inch apart on ungreased baking sheets.
column5: Bake in preheated oven until golden, about 6 to 8 minutes. Cool completely.

column2: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. In a large mixing bowl, cream the butter, peanut butter, brown sugar, and sugar until well blended. Beat in the egg, milk, and vanilla. In a separate bowl, combine the flour, baking powder, and salt. Gradually add the dry ingredients to the creamed mixture. Stir in the chocolate chips and peanuts. Chill the dough in the refrigerator for 15 minutes. Drop heaping tablespoons of dough onto an ungreased cookie sheet.
column3: Bake 12 to 14 minutes, or until the edges are golden brown. Cool 1 minute on cookie sheet, then transfer to wire cooling racks. Store tightly covered.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
column3: Whisk together the milk and lemon juice in a small bowl; set aside a few minutes to sour. Meanwhile, combine the flour, baking soda, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg in a bowl. Beat the margarine and sugar with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Beat the first egg into the margarine mixture until completely blended, then beat in the vanilla with the second egg. Mix into the flour, then stir in soured milk mixture until just incorporated. Wrap cookie dough in plastic, then freeze until firm, about 30 minutes.
column4: Roll dough out on a heavily floured surface, then cut with cookie cutters. Alternatively, the cookies can be rolled into balls, then pressed down with a fork. Arrange cookies onto prepared baking sheet.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until cookies are golden brown, about 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Cut and set aside 25 pieces of plastic wrap about 5 inches square.
column3: For cookies, beat 1/2 cup of vegetable shortening, 2 cups of milk, 2 cups of sugar, the eggs, and 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract together in a large mixing bowl until smooth and creamy. In a separate bowl, whisk the 4 cups of flour with both amounts of unsweetened cocoa, baking soda, and salt until thoroughly combined. Beat the flour mixture into the wet ingredients just until smooth.
column4: Scoop up the batter by teaspoons, and drop onto ungreased baking sheets in small round dollops about 2 inches apart. Recipe should make about 50 cookies. The cookies will rise and expand a lot.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until the cookies are set in the middle, 8 to 10 minutes. Allow to cool on baking sheets for several minutes before removing to finish cooling on racks.
column6: To make the filling, place 1 cup milk in a microwave-safe measuring cup, and cook in microwave until hot but not simmering, 1 to 2 minutes. Pour the heated milk into a large mixing bowl. Add the cup of room temperature butter, 1 cup of vegetable shortening, 2 cups of sugar, 2 tablespoons of flour, 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract, and the marshmallow creme. Beat the mixture on high speed until the frosting is fluffy, 5 to 10 minutes. At first the frosting will appear lumpy, but keep beating.
column7: To fill the cookies, choose 2 cookies that are about the same size, and spread about 1 1/2 tablespoon of the frosting onto the flat bottom of a cookie. Top with the other cookie, flat side down, and wrap the filled cookie in a sheet of plastic wrap. Place the filled cookie into the freezer. Repeat with remaining cookies and frosting, wrapping each whoopie pie in plastic wrap and freezing.
column8: To serve, remove whoopie pies from the freezer and allow to thaw until very cold but not frozen, 10 to 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: To make cookies, beat 2/3 cup of vegetable shortening with 2 cups of sugar in a large mixing bowl with an electric mixer until the mixture is creamy. Beat in eggs and 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract until thoroughly combined. Whisk together 4 cups of flour, the cocoa powder, and baking soda until thoroughly mixed, then beat the flour mixture into the vegetable shortening mixture in several additions, alternating with the milk. Beat dough just until smooth.
column4: Drop dough by tablespoon onto the prepared baking sheets, about 2 inches apart, making the cookies as round as possible. Recipe should yield about 48 cookies.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until the cookies are set in the middle, 15 to 20 minutes. Watch carefully to avoid burning the cookies. Allow cookies to cool for several minutes on baking sheets before removing to finish cooling on racks.
column6: To make the filling, pour 3 cups of milk into a large saucepan over low heat, and whisk in 9 tablespoons of flour until smooth. Allow the mixture to come to a simmer, whisking constantly, until as thick and smooth as pudding, about 3 minutes. Place the thickened mixture into the refrigerator to cool, about 30 minutes.
column7: In a large mixing bowl, beat 1 1/2 cup of vegetable shortening with the butter until thoroughly combined, then beat in 2 1/4 cup of sugar and 1 tablespoon vanilla extract until the mixture is thoroughly combined. Beat the cooled milk mixture into the butter mixture until smooth and fluffy, 1 to 2 minutes.
column8: Choose 2 cookies of the same size, and spread a thick layer of filling on the flat side of a cookie; top with remaining cookie. Repeat with remaining cookies and frosting.

column2: Preheat an oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Stir the sifted flour, baking soda, cream of tartar, and salt together in a bowl.
column4: Beat the margarine, butter and sugar together with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Add one egg, and continue beating until completely incorporated; add the remaining egg along with the vanilla extract, and beat on low speed until incorporated. Mix the flour mixture into the butter mixture until just incorporated. Gently mix the pecans into the dough with your hands.
column5: Roll the dough into 1-inch balls; arrange onto baking sheets about 2 inches apart.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until the edges are golden-brown, 8 to 9 minutes. Allow the cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 8 minutes. Place confectioners' sugar into a bowl, and lightly dip both sides of each warm cookie into the sugar. Tap of excess, and allow cookies to finish cooling.

column2: Mix the flour, the baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves together in a bowl.
column3: Cream the butter and brown sugar together with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth; beat the egg and vanilla extract into the butter mixture. Add the flour mixture in small amount to the butter mixture, beating each addition until blended. Form the dough into a ball, wrap with plastic wrap, and refrigerate at least 1 hour or up to 3 days.
column4: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease baking sheets.
column5: Roll the dough out on a floured work surface with a rolling pin to about 1/8-inch thickness. Cut with 2-inch cookie cutters. Arrange the cut cookies onto the prepared baking sheets.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until the edges begin to brown, 10 to 12 minutes. Allow the cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 1 minute before removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: In a bowl, mash the butter with the white and brown sugar until the mixture is creamy and well blended. Beat in eggs and vanilla extract. In a separate large mixing bowl, mix together the flour, baking soda, salt, rolled oats, rice cereal, coconut, pecans, toffee bits, pretzel pieces, and chocolate chips. Stir the butter mixture into the dry ingredients until evenly mixed.
column4: Drop the dough by tablespoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheets about 2 inches apart. Using a fork, flatten the cookies.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until the bottoms are just starting to brown, about 12 minutes. Allow cookies to cool on baking sheets for about 5 minutes before removing to finish cooling on racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: In a mixing bowl, beat the butter, brown sugar, white sugar, egg, and vanilla extract until well combined. Beat in flour, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, nutmeg, and rolled oats until thoroughly mixed. Stir in the butterscotch chips and coconut. Drop the dough by tablespoonfuls about 2 inches apart onto baking sheets.
column4: Bake the cookies in the preheated oven just until the bottoms are light brown, 7 to 8 minutes. If you prefer crunchier cookies, bake 9 to 10 minutes.

column2: Beat the butter, brown sugar, and white sugar with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Beat the first egg into the butter mixture until completely blended; beat the vanilla into the mixture with the last egg.
column3: Whisk the flour, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt together in a separate bowl. Beat the flour mixture into the butter mixture about 1/2 cup at a time. Fold the rolled oats and butterscotch chips into the resulting dough. If the dough isn't firm enough, mix in more rolled oats, about 1/4 cup at a time, until dough is of desired consistency.
column4: Refrigerate the dough for 1 to 2 hours before baking.
column5: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column6: Scoop up dough by heaping tablespoonful and roll into balls. Place cookies about 2 inches apart on baking sheets.
column7: Bake in the preheated oven until very lightly browned and cookies are set in the middle, 10 to 12 minutes. Allow cookies to cool for about 5 minutes before removing from baking sheets to finish cooling on wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease a 9x13-inch baking pan.
column3: In a bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.
column4: In a large mixing bowl, mash the butter, white sugar, and brown sugar together until smooth and creamy, and beat in the eggs to make a creamy mixture. Gradually beat in the flour mixture, rolled oats, and 1 1/2 cup of butterscotch chips.
column5: Press the dough into the prepared baking dish, and sprinkle the top with remaining 1/2 cup of butterscotch chips.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until the top is golden brown, 30 to 35 minutes. Allow to cool in the pan before cutting into bars and serving.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, combine Melt(R) and cocoa, blending with a spoon until smooth. Add baking powder and sugar, stirring until slightly mixed. Add flour and eggs; stir until completely integrated.
column4: Pour into a 9 x 13 baking pan, lightly coated with cooking spray. Sprinkle chocolate chips (and/or nuts) over top of brownie mixture.
column5: Bake in for 25-30 minutes, or until done. Cool, cut into squares, and enjoy!

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the butter, white sugar, and brown sugar until fluffy.
column4: Beat in the egg, vanilla extract, and coconut extract.
column5: Combine both amounts of flour, baking soda, and salt in a separate bowl; mix into the butter mixture until just combined.
column6: Fold in the chocolate chips, 1/2 cup almond candy pieces, and flaked coconut until evenly distributed.
column7: Roll the dough into walnut-sized balls and place 3 inches apart onto ungreased baking sheets.
column8: Bake in the preheated oven until the edges become golden brown, 9 to 11 minutes.
column9: Immediately after removing from the oven, press a few of the remaining 1/4 cup almond candy pieces into each cookie decoratively.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Whisk together the flour, white sugar, baking soda, and salt in a bowl.
column4: Beat honey, milk, butter, and vanilla extract together in a large bowl until smooth.
column5: Stir the flour mixture into the honey mixture until just combined.
column6: Fold in the chocolate and vanilla chips.
column7: Roll the dough into walnut-sized balls and place 2 inches apart onto nonstick baking sheets.
column8: Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, 15 to 18 minutes.
column9: Allow cookies to cool; dust with confectioners' sugar.

column2: Cream together the butter, sugar, egg, milk, vanilla extract, and almond extract in a large bowl.
column3: Stir in the flour and baking powder.
column4: Cover and refrigerate until firm, about 2 hours.
column5: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column6: Divide the dough into thirds. On a lightly floured surface, roll out each portion to 1/4-inch thick.
column7: Cut cookies out using a floured cookie cutter.
column8: Arrange cookies on an ungreased baking sheet about 1-inch apart.
column9: Bake until cookies are lightly golden, 6 to 9 minutes.
column10: Transfer cookies to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Sift the flour, baking powder, and salt together in a bowl; set aside.
column3: Beat the 1 cup butter with the sugar, egg, milk, and vanilla extract in another bowl until well mixed.
column4: Gradually mix the flour mixture into the butter mixture.
column5: Shape the dough into a disk; wrap with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 2 hours.
column6: Working with half the dough at a time, roll out dough to about 1/8-inch thick.
column7: Cut into cookies with a large heart shaped cookie cutter. Repeat with the remaining half of the dough.
column8: Cut the center of half of the cookies with a smaller heart shaped cookie cutter.
column9: Place an open centered cookie on top of a whole cookie to form a sandwich. Arrange cookies on an ungreased baking sheet; set aside.
column10: Preheat an oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column11: Place the raspberry jam in a microwave save bowl and heat on high until jam is runny, about 35 seconds.
column12: Fill the center of the cookies with the jam. Refrigerate cookies for 10 minutes.
column13: Bake in the preheated oven until the cookies are firm to the touch, 5 to 8 minutes. Cookies will be pale in color.
column14: Transfer cookies to a wire rack to cool completely.
column15: Melt the chocolate and 2 tablespoons butter in a microwave-safe glass or ceramic bowl in 30-second intervals, stirring after each melting until smooth, for 1 to 3 minutes, depending on your microwave.
column16: Spoon chocolate decoratively over half of each cookie.
column17: Place cookie on a waxed paper lined baking sheet and refrigerate until the chocolate has set, about 15 minutes.

column2: Butter a 9x12-inch baking dish.
column3: Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large nonstick pot over low heat.
column4: Mix in the marshmallows and cranberry gelatin mix until the marshmallows have melted and the mixture is smooth.
column5: Stir in the rice squares, oat cereal rings, mini candy-coated chocolate pieces, and dried cranberries until thoroughly combined.
column6: Working quickly, press the mixture into the prepared baking dish and allow to cool.
column7: Cut into 2-inch squares.

column2: Preheat an oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column3: Beat the butter, brown sugar, and white sugar with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth.
column4: Blend the egg and the almond flavoring into the creamed butter and sugar.
column5: Sift together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt into a bowl.
column6: Blend the flour mixture into the butter mixture.
column7: Fold the pineapple tidbits and coconut flakes into the dough.
column8: Drop teaspoonfuls of the dough 2 inches apart onto greased baking sheets.
column9: Bake in preheated oven until golden brown, 10 to 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
column4: Combine egg, peanut butter and sugar in a bowl. The dough should be slightly dry; add small amounts of sugar if it seems too wet.
column5: Place dough between two sheets of wax paper and roll to 1/2 inch thickness.
column6: Cut the dough with a heart-shaped cookie cutter.
column7: Place the hearts on the prepared baking sheet.
column8: Bake in the preheated oven until the edges are golden, 7 to 10 minutes.
column9: Cool completely on the baking sheet.
column10: Melt the chocolate chips in the microwave at 30 second intervals until fully melted, stirring between intervals.
column11: Dip the bottom and sides of each cookie in the melted chocolate.
column12: Place cookies on wax paper to dry.

column2: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper.
column4: Combine flour, cocoa powder, baking powder, and salt in a bowl.
column5: Beat the butter and sugar together in a large bowl with an electric mixer on medium-high speed, until light and fluffy.
column6: Beat the egg, coffee granules, and vanilla into the butter and sugar mixture until blended.
column7: Change the speed to low and pour in the flour mixture. Beat until just combined.
column8: Stir in semisweet chocolate chips, white chocolate chips, and dried cherries.
column9: Drop spoonfuls of the dough two inches apart onto the prepared baking sheets.
column10: Bake 10 to 12 minutes per batch in the preheated oven, until cookies are just becoming firm.
column11: Let cool on baking sheets for two minutes.
column12: Transfer cookies to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees.
column3: Butter a 9"x9" square baking pan.
column4: In a double boiler over low heat, melt butter and chocolate chips together and remove from heat.
column5: In a separate bowl, combine dry ingredients.
column6: When the chocolate/butter mixture has cooled a little whisk in the eggs and vanilla.
column7: Note: it is important to cool the chocolate/butter mixture or the eggs will cook.
column8: Add the dry ingredients and whisk to combine.
column9: Stir in the chopped walnuts.
column10: Pour batter into prepared baking pan.
column11: Bake for 40-45 minutes or until a knife inserted into center comes out clean.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper.
column4: Mix the milk and vanilla extract together in a small bowl; set aside.
column5: Combine the flour and baking powder in a separate bowl.
column6: Beat the peanut butter, brown sugar, and white sugar with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth.
column7: Add the eggs one at a time, allowing each egg to blend into the peanut butter mixture before adding the next.
column8: Pour in the flour mixture alternately with the milk, mixing until just incorporated.
column9: Fold in the peanut butter chips; mixing just enough to evenly combine.
column10: Divide the dough into 4 equal parts.
column11: Roll each section into a 4x5-inch rectangle about 1/2-inch thick.
column12: Transfer the dough pieces onto the prepared baking sheets.
column13: Bake in the preheated oven until firm to the touch, about 25 minutes.
column14: Place biscotti loaves on wire racks to cool.
column15: Reduce oven temperature to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C).
column17: Return the slices to the baking sheets with the cut sides up.
column18: Bake in the oven until biscotti are dry, about 10 minutes on each side.
column19: Cool in the pans for 10 minutes before removing to cool completely on a wire rack.
column20: Melt the chocolate chips in a microwave-safe glass or ceramic bowl in 30-second intervals, stirring after each interval, until melted and smooth, 1 to 3 minutes (depending on your microwave).
column21: Dip the cooled biscotti into the melted chocolate. Set the biscotti onto parchment paper, and allow to set, about 20 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Butter the heart-shaped molds.
column4: Beat brownie mix, vegetable oil, water, and 1 egg together in a bowl until smooth and well mixed.
column5: Pour the batter into the prepared heart molds.
column6: Beat cream cheese, sugar, and vanilla extract together with an electric mixer in a large bowl until light and fluffy. The mixture should be noticeably lighter in color. Beat in 1 egg until smooth.
column7: Spoon a dollop of the cream cheese mixture into each heart mold and mix slightly with a knife to make decorative swirls of cream cheese filling in the brownie batter.
column8: Bake in the preheated oven for 25 minutes.
column9: While brownies are baking, place chocolate chips into a microwave-safe bowl and microwave for 30-second intervals, stirring after each time, until the chocolate is warm, smooth, and melted.
column10: Stir heavy cream into the chocolate. Mixture will be clumpy.
column11: Remove hearts from oven, and immediately spread about 1 tablespoon of chocolate mixture over each heart.
column12: Return the hearts to the oven and bake until the chocolate topping spreads out, about 5 minutes. Cool before serving.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Line several baking sheets with parchment paper.
column4: Whisk together flour, baking soda, and salt in a bowl.
column5: In a separate large bowl, cream brown sugar, butter, and peanut butter together until evenly mixed and smooth.
column6: Beat in eggs.
column7: Stir the the flour mixture into the peanut butter mixture to make a smooth dough.
column8: Place white sugar into a shallow bowl.
column9: Roll dough into tablespoon-size balls, then roll in the white sugar to coat all sides.
column10: Place cookies onto the prepared baking sheets at least 1 inch apart.
column11: Press each cookie down flat with a fork, making a cross-cross pattern.
column12: Bake in the preheated oven until cookies are lightly browned on the bottom, about 12 minutes. Allow to cool on baking sheets about 5 minutes before removing to finish cooling on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column3: Beat cake mix and butter with an electric mixer on low speed in a bowl until crumbly, 3 to 5 minutes. Set aside 1 cup for topping.
column4: Press remaining crumb mixture into bottom of an ungreased 9x13 inch pan.
column5: Place in preheated oven and bake until edges begin to crisp, about 10 minutes. Remove from the oven and cool slightly.
column6: Beat cream cheese and frosting with an electric mixer on medium speed in a bowl until smooth, 3 to 5 minutes.
column7: Drop eggs one at a time into the cream cheese mixture and beat until blended, 2 to 3 minutes.
column8: Pour in 6 drops green food coloring, or more for a darker color; beat until color is blended, about 2 minutes.
column9: Beat in creme de menthe candy flavoring until thoroughly blended, about 2 minutes. Taste and add more flavoring if needed.
column10: Pour batter over the chocolate crust in the 9x13 pan.
column11: Sprinkle 1 cup reserved crumb mixture over cheesecake batter.
column12: Top with 1 cup chocolate and mint morsels; reserve remaining morsels for finishing touches.
column13: Place the pan in the preheated oven and bake until set, 42 to 45 minutes.
column14: Remove pan from oven and cool completely.
column15: Cover and refrigerate until chilled, at least 2 hours.
column16: Pour reserved chocolate and mint morsels into a small microwave-safe bowl. Microwave morsels in 45 second intervals; stir until completely melted and smooth.
column17: Pour melted chocolate into a resealable plastic bag.
column18: Clip a small bottom corner of the bag. Gently squeezing the bag, drizzle melted chocolate over the cooled cake through the clipped corner.
column19: Cut cake into bars to serve.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column3: Beat butter, brown sugar, and white sugar together in a bowl until creamy.
column4: Beat in eggs and vanilla extract until smooth.
column5: In a separate bowl, whisk together both amounts of flour, salt, baking soda, and baking powder. Mix flour mixture into the liquid ingredients.
column6: Gently mix rolled oats, corn flakes, and coconut into the dough until thoroughly combined.
column7: Drop the dough by tablespoons onto baking sheets.
column8: Bake in the preheated oven until the cookies are light golden brown, 10 to 12 minutes.
column9: Cool in the pans for 10 minutes before removing to cool completely on a wire rack.

column2: Beat butter, white sugar, brown sugar, peanut butter, salt, baking powder, and baking soda in a stand mixer until smooth.
column3: Scrape down the sides of the bowl and beater with a spatula. Add egg and mix for about 1 minute.
column4: Slowly mix in flour with the mixer on low. Scrape down the sides of the bowl and beater. Mix on medium until combined, about 30 seconds.
column5: Form dough into a ball, cover with plastic and refrigerate for 2-3 hours.
column6: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column7: Portion out cookie dough in equal-sized balls on a baking sheet covered with a silicone baking mat. Use damp hands to roll dough into smooth balls. Stamp each ball with a fork in a criss-cross pattern.
column8: Bake in the preheated oven for 10 minutes until golden.
column9: Leave on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring to a cooling rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Butter the bottom of a 10 1/2x15 1/2-inch jelly roll pan.
column4: Place fudge brownie mix into a large bowl; beat in 1 cup of Irish cream liqueur, vegetable oil, and eggs until the mixture forms a smooth batter.
column5: Spread the batter into the prepared jelly roll pan.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until the brownies are set and a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean, about 20 minutes. Remove pan from oven and allow to cool completely.
column7: Beat unsalted butter in a large bowl until smooth; beat in 5 tablespoons Irish cream liqueur until mixture is creamy.
column8: Slowly beat in confectioners' sugar, 1 cup at a time, until frosting is desired stiffness; spread frosting on brownies to serve.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Grease 18 muffin cups with coconut oil.
column4: Beat coconut oil, brown sugar, and white sugar with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Mix in the flour mixture until just incorporated.
column5: Beat 1 egg and vanilla extract into the coconut oil mixture.
column6: Whisk flour, baking soda, and coarse salt together in a bowl; beat into the coconut oil mixture until a dough forms.
column7: Fold oatmeal, raisins, and almonds into dough. Mix beaten egg into dough if needed for moisture.
column8: Spoon dough into prepared muffin cups to about half full.
column9: Bake in preheated oven until center is set and top is lightly browned, 12 to 14 minutes.

column2: Stir pistachios, flax seed, cocoa powder, and coffee beans together in a bowl.
column3: Blend figs, dates, cinnamon, agave nectar, and strawberry together in a food processor until thoroughly combined.
column4: Stir fruit mixture into pistachio mixture; mix to form a workable dough.
column5: Divide dough in half and pat each half into a flat cookie shape. Place cookies on a plate and refrigerate for 1 hour, flipping cookies after 30 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Place brownie mix, vegetable oil, water, and eggs in a bowl; stir 50 strokes with a spoon.
column4: Spoon the brownie batter into ice cream cones, filling them about 3/4 full. Place cones on an ungreased baking sheet.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick inserted into the middle of a brownie center comes out clean, about 20 minutes.

column2: Combine flour, butter, sugar, vanilla extract, and salt in a bowl to form a dough; stir in pecans.
column3: Shape dough into a large ball and refrigerate until firm, about 15 minutes.
column4: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column5: Roll dough into 1-inch balls and place on a baking sheet.
column6: Make an indentation with thumb in the middle of each ball, forming a 'nest'.
column7: Fill each nest with about 1 teaspoon chocolate chips.
column8: Bake nests in the preheated oven until edges are crisp (cookies will not brown), 10 to 12 minutes. Cool cookies on a wire rack, about 15 minutes.

column2: Place raisins, almonds, and cocoa powder in a food processor or blender. Blend until a 'dough' forms.
column3: Press dough into an 8x8 pan. Slice and serve.

column2: Spray a 9x13-inch baking dish with cooking spray.
column3: Mix crispy rice cereal, oat cereal rings, sunflower seeds, raisins, and chocolate chips together in a large bowl.
column4: Stir honey and brown sugar in a saucepan, place over high heat, and bring to a boil. Stir and boil for 1 minute. Remove from heat and stir in peanut butter and vanilla extract until smooth and well blended.
column5: Pour the hot peanut butter mixture into the dry ingredients and stir until all dry ingredients are moistened.
column6: Press the mixture into the prepared baking dish to make an even layer.
column7: Let cool and cut into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
column4: Blend coconut, sugar, flour, vanilla extract, almond extract, and salt in a food processor until combined, about 30 seconds.
column5: Beat egg whites in a bowl until soft peaks form.
column6: Fold coconut mixture into egg whites until just combined.
column7: Wet your hands. Roll spoonfuls of coconut mixture between palms to golf ball-size cookies; arrange on the prepared baking sheet.
column8: Bake cookies in the preheated oven until coconut is slightly golden and toasted, about 15 minutes. Transfer to a wire rack to cool, 30 minutes.
column9: Line baking sheet with new piece of parchment paper.
column10: Melt chocolate chips in the top of a double boiler over just-barely simmering water, stirring frequently and scraping down the sides with a rubber spatula to avoid scorching.
column11: Dip half of each cookie in the chocolate and place on the prepared baking sheet. Place in refrigerator until chocolate is set, about 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Spray a baking sheet with cooking spray.
column4: Combine coconut and flour in a large bowl.
column5: Puree cashews, water, sugar, salt, and almond extract together in a blender.
column6: Stir cashew mixture into coconut mixture until well blended.
column7: Form coconut mixture into 1-inch balls and flatten; arrange on the prepared baking sheet.
column8: Bake cookies in the preheated oven until edges are golden, 12 to 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column3: Grease two baking sheets.
column4: Whisk egg whites in a bowl until frothy; stir in almond extract.
column5: Combine coconut, sugar, flour, and salt in a large bowl.
column6: Lightly stir egg white mixture into coconut mixture to form a batter.
column7: Scoop batter by the tablespoon and drop onto prepared baking sheet.
column8: Bake cookies in the preheated oven until edges start to brown, about 20 minutes.
column9: Transfer cookies to wire racks to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C).
column3: Grease a baking sheet.
column4: Beat egg white in a bowl with an electric hand-mixer until stiff peaks form.
column5: Gradually beat sugar, 1 tablespoon at a time, into egg whites until fully incorporated. Stir salt and vanilla extract into egg whites until thoroughly mixed.
column6: Fold coconut and corn flakes into the mixture.
column7: Drop coconut mixture by the teaspoon onto the prepared baking sheet.
column8: Bake cookies in the preheated oven until lightly crisp, 20 minutes.
column9: Transfer cookies to wire rack to cool, at least 15 minutes.

column2: Place oven rack in the upper third of the oven.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column4: Spray 2 cushioned or heavy-duty baking sheets with cooking spray.
column5: Beat shortening and sugar together in a large mixing bowl with an electric mixer on medium speed until creamy and smooth.
column6: Beat egg into shortening mixture until well mixed.
column7: Place matzo cake meal, orange juice, potato starch, and salt into bowl with shortening mixture; beat on low speed until batter is well combined. Stir chocolate chips into batter.
column8: Drop batter by rounded tablespoons about 2 inches apart onto prepared baking sheets.
column9: Bake cookies in the preheated oven until pale golden brown, 14 to 17 minutes.
column10: Cool cookies on baking sheet for 2 minutes. Transfer to rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Grease baking sheets.
column4: Melt bittersweet chocolate and margarine together in the top of a double boiler over barely simmering water, stirring frequently and scraping down the sides with a rubber spatula, about 5 minutes. Remove from heat and cool.
column5: Combine potato starch and baking powder in a bowl.
column6: Beat eggs, sugar, and vanilla extract together in a separate large bowl with an electric mixer on medium speed until light and fluffy, about 5 minutes.
column7: Fold the cooled chocolate mixture, potato starch mixture, chocolate chips, and walnuts into egg mixture until just combined.
column8: Drop spoonfuls of batter onto the prepared baking sheet.
column9: Bake cookies in the preheated oven for 4 minutes, turn baking sheets the opposite way in the oven, and bake until cookies are crisp on the edges, about 6 more minutes.
column10: Let cookies cool on sheets for about 5 minutes; transfer to wire racks to finish cooling.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a baking sheet.
column3: Stir matzo cake meal, sugar, potato starch, eggs, chocolate chips, walnuts, and lemon juice together to make a dough.
column4: Divide the dough into thirds. Shape each piece of dough into a log and place on the prepared baking sheet.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until browned, about 30 minutes.
column6: Remove logs from oven and cut into slices.
column7: Arrange the slices on the baking sheet; sprinkle with cinnamon sugar.
column8: Return to oven and bake until the mandelbread are browned and crisp, about 10 more minutes. Turn the mandelbread after 5 minutes to crisp both sides.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Line two baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.
column4: Heat currants and coffee liqueur in a saucepan over low heat until it begins to simmer, about 2 minutes. Remove from heat and set aside.
column5: Combine unsweetened chocolate, bittersweet chocolate, and butter in bowl. Place bowl on top of a saucepan filled with 1-inch of water set over low heat. Stir chocolate mixture occasionally until melted, about 5 minutes. Remove from heat and set aside.
column6: Mix flour, black pepper, baking powder, salt, cinnamon, and cayenne pepper in large bowl and set aside.
column7: Whisk sugar and eggs in a small bowl until light, fluffy, and pale yellow, about 5 minutes. Slowly whisk in vanilla and melted chocolate mixture.
column8: Fold flour mixture into sugar and chocolate mixture until combined.
column9: Stir in dark chocolate chips and liqueur-soaked currants.
column10: Drop spoonfuls of cookie dough 2 inches apart onto prepared baking sheets.
column11: Bake in the preheated oven until cookies are almost set, about 12 minutes.
column12: Remove from the oven and leave on baking sheets to cool, 5 minutes.
column13: Transfer to cooling rack and allow to finish cooling, 5 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column3: Melt butter in a small saucepan over medium-low heat.
column4: Combine sugar and cocoa powder in a large bowl; stir in melted butter until mixture is smooth.
column5: Stir in 1 egg, vanilla, and salt. Mix in second egg.
column6: Fold in flour and transfer to ungreased 8x8-inch square baking dish.
column7: Bake in the preheated oven for about 35 minutes.
column8: Remove from oven and cool in the baking dish for 10 minutes before removing to cool completely on a wire rack.
column9: Mix powdered sugar, milk, and mint extract in a bowl until smooth.
column10: Pour icing over cooled brownies. Spread evenly and allow to set, about 30 minutes.
column11: Slice into 16 brownies.

column2: Cut licorice candy whips into 2-inch pieces, and pull them apart to make small strings. Set aside.
column3: Place a miniature peanut butter cup upside down on a work surface; top with a dab of frosting. Center a chocolate-covered graham cracker cookie onto the frosting to make a small cap with a mortarboard. Gently press the cookie onto the peanut butter cup.
column4: Place a small dab of frosting in the center of the graham cracker cookie and attach a red licorice string as a tassel, letting the tassel drape over the edge of the cookie. Place a candy-coated milk chocolate piece onto the center of the cookie over the end of the tassel to make a button.
column5: Repeat with remaining candies and cookies to make 50 graduation caps with tassels.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Spray baking sheets with cooking spray.
column4: Whisk egg whites and cream of tartar together in a bowl until foamy.
column5: Gradually whisk sugar into egg white mixture until blended.
column6: Whisk almond extract and flour into egg white mixture until stiff peaks have formed. The egg whites should form a sharp peak that holds its shape when whisk is held straight up.
column7: Fold coconut into egg white mixture until incorporated.
column8: Drop spoonfuls of batter onto prepared baking sheets.
column9: Bake in the preheated oven until just golden brown, 8 to 9 minutes. Cool on baking sheets for about 2 minutes; transfer to wire rack to completely cool.

column2: Heat oven to 350 degrees F. Coat large baking sheet with no-stick cooking spray. Microwave chocolate and butter in uncovered large microwave-safe bowl on HIGH for 2 minutes or until butter is melted. Stir until chocolate is completely melted and smooth. Stir in sweetened condensed milk. Stir in muffin mix until completely blended.
column3: Roll tablespoonfuls of dough into balls. Dip bottoms into pecans. Place on baking sheet with nut side up, 2 inches apart. Bake 7 to 8 minutes or just until cookies look slightly crackled and centers are still soft. Immediately press a caramel candy into center of each cookie. Remove to wire rack. Swirl caramel candy gently with knife while candy is warm, if desired. Cool completely.

column2: Cover almonds with boiling water in a bowl. Let stand for 1 to 2 minutes and drain. Rinse with cold water and drain again. Pat almonds dry and remove skin. Allow almonds to dry on paper towels.
column3: Place half the almonds in a food processor; pulse until finely chopped. Add apricots and dates; pulse until fruit is chopped. Reserve remaining 1 cup almonds.
column4: Combine flour, cinnamon, ginger, baking powder, cloves, cardamom, and salt in bowl. Beat eggs, brown sugar, honey, molasses, water, almond extract, orange zest, and 1 teaspoon lemon zest in a large bowl with an electric mixer until smooth. Add apricot mixture, blending until evenly distributed. Gradually stir in flour mixture on medium speed until dough comes together. Cover dough with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 8 hours to overnight.
column5: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column6: Turn dough onto a lightly floured surface and roll out to about 1/2-inch thick. Cut out cookies with a 2 1/2 to 3-inch diameter cookie cutter. Arrange cookies about 1 inch apart on ungreased baking sheets.
column7: Lightly press 3 almonds into each cookie with tips towards the center to create a star pattern.
column8: Bake in preheated oven until cookies begin to brown, about 12 minutes. Cool in the pans for 10 minutes before removing to cool on a wire rack.
column9: Meanwhile, whisk confectioners' sugar, milk, and 1 teaspoon lemon zest in a bowl until glaze is smooth. Brush warm cookies with glaze and allow cookies to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a baking sheet.
column3: Mix oats, coconut, flour, and sugar in a bowl. Dissolve baking powder in boiling water in another bowl; stir in butter and golden syrup. Stir butter mixture into oat mixture until dough is well mixed. Drop level tablespoonfuls of dough 2 inches apart onto prepared baking sheets. Flatten dough with a fork lightly coated with flour.
column4: Bake in preheated oven until golden brown, about 15 minutes.

column2: Place crumbled brownies in a bowl. Pour rum over brownies, let soak for 1 minute; stir until mixture forms a paste-like consistency.
column3: Using a 1-inch sorbet scoop or melon baller, scoop out balls of chocolate-rum mixture and transfer each to the plate lined with plastic wrap. Place the plate with chocolate balls in freezer for 15 to 20 minutes, or until firm enough to roll. Remove from freezer, roll each into a smooth ball; return plate to freezer.
column4: Melt 3 ounces chocolate in the top of a double boiler over simmering water, stirring frequently and scraping down the sides with a rubber spatula to avoid scorching. Remove from heat. Add remaining 1 ounce chocolate; stir until chocolate is melted and combined.
column5: Remove chocolate balls from freezer; place one ball in melted chocolate and gently move around with a fork to coat completely. Transfer to baking sheet lined with a silicone baking mat. Repeat for remaining chocolate balls.
column6: Dust chocolate rum balls with cocoa powder and serve.

column2: In a large bowl, cream together the sugar and shortening until smooth. Stir in the molasses and vanilla. Combine the flour, cinnamon, baking soda and salt; stir into the mixture alternately with the sour milk. Cover the dough and chill for at least one hour.
column3: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).Grease cookie sheets. On a lightly floured surface, roll out about 1/3 of the dough to 1/4 inch in thickness. Cut into circles about 3 inches in diameter using a cookie cutter or drinking glass. Place cookies 2 inches apart onto the prepared cookies sheets. Place a raisin onto the center of each cookie.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or until lightly browned. Allow cookies to cool on baking sheet for 5 minutes before removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Sift all-purpose flour, whole-wheat flour, baking soda, and salt.
column3: Beat butter, white sugar, brown sugar, and peanut butter with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Add egg allowing to blend into butter mixture. Beat in vanilla extract. Mix in flour mixture and milk until just incorporated.
