column3: Heat chocolate with canola oil in a large glass bowl in a microwave oven in 30 second increments, stirring between each round of heating, until completely melted, 2 to 3 minutes.
column4: Stir eggs and coffee granules into the melted chocolate. Sift sugar, cocoa powder, flour, and baking soda together into a bowl; add to chocolate mixture and stir to incorporate fully. Pour coffee liqueur and vanilla extract into the mixture; stir.
column5: Pour brownie batter into an 8-inch square baking dish.
column6: Bake in preheated oven until beginning to dry along the edges, 20 to 25 minutes.

column2: In a large mixing bowl, combine condensed milk and peppermint extract. Beat in enough confectioners' sugar, a little at a time, to form a stiff dough that is no longer sticky. Form into 1 inch balls, then place on waxed paper and flatten with fingers to form patties. Let patties dry at room temperature two hours, turning once.
column3: In a medium saucepan over low heat, melt chocolate with shortening, stirring often. Remove from heat. Dip patties, one at a time, into chocolate by laying them on the tines of a fork and lowering the fork into the liquid. Let cool on waxed paper until set.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Mix flour, baking soda, and salt together in a small bowl.
column4: Beat butter, white sugar, and vanilla extract together with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Add cashew butter, brown sugar, egg, and milk to the butter mixture; beat until smooth. Gradually add flour mixture and mix until just incorporated into a dough.
column5: Roll dough into 1 1/2-inch balls and arrange onto a baking sheet. Lightly press a fork into the top of the balls to make a crosshatch pattern.
column6: Bake in preheated oven until golden brown, 12 to 14 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Beat butter and 1 cup sugar together with an electric mixer in a large bowl until creamy. Add egg and beat until smooth. Stir molasses into the butter mixture until completely integrated.
column4: Sift flour, baking soda, ginger, cinnamon, salt, and cloves together in a separate bowl; add to the butter mixture and mix until you have a dough. Divide and shape the dough into 36 balls.
column5: Put 1/2 cup sugar in a wide, shallow bowl. Roll dough balls in sugar to coat and arrange onto a baking sheet.
column6: Bake in preheated oven until beginning to crisp around the edges, 13 to 15 minutes.

column2: Line a baking sheet with waxed paper or parchment paper.
column3: Melt white chocolate in the top of a double boiler over simmering water, stirring frequently and scraping down the sides with a rubber spatula to avoid scorching, 5 to 15 minutes.
column4: Insert a fork into the filling of each cookie and dip cookie into the melted chocolate, allowing excess chocolate to drip back into the bowl. Transfer coated cookies to the lined baking sheet.
column5: Immediately place 2 black sprinkles onto the top portion of the cookie for the "eyes" and 4 black sprinkles for the "smile" and 1 orange sprinkle for the "nose" while the chocolate is still warm on the cookie. Arrange 3 of the multicolored sprinkles down the center of the cookie for the "buttons". Cool cookies completely.
column6: Using the decorating gel, draw a thin line around the "neck" of each snowman creating a scarf. Allow gel to dry.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Beat butter and sugar together in a large bowl until creamy. Add egg and vanilla extract; mix well.
column4: Whisk flour, ginger, cinnamon, baking soda, baking powder, nutmeg, and cloves together in another bowl. Beat flour mixture into butter mixture until dough is just-combined. Stir vanilla chips into dough. Drop dough by the 1/8-cup full 2-inches apart on a baking sheet.
column5: Bake cookies in the preheated oven until golden and soft, 10 to 11 minutes. Cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Toss raisins and 1 teaspoon flour together in a saucepan until raisins are coated in flour. Stir 1/4 cup sugar, 1 teaspoon vanilla extract, and lemon juice into raisins. Pour 1 cup boiling water over raisin mixture; bring mixture to a boil. Cook, stirring constantly, until raisins start to break down and mixture thickens, 5 to 10 minutes. Remove from heat and cool to room temperature.
column4: Stir 2 3/4 cups flour, 3/4 cup sugar, and salt together in a bowl.
column5: Whisk melted shortening and molasses together in another bowl; stir in remaining vanilla extract. Dissolve baking soda in 1/3 cup boiling water. Stir soda water into molasses mixture until mixture foams and is well-combined. Stir flour mixture and molasses mixture together in a large bowl until a stiff dough forms.
column6: Divide dough into 2 balls; 1 dough ball for the bottom cookie rounds and 1 ball for the top cookie rounds. Cover 1 dough ball with a damp paper towel; roll remaining dough ball out to 1/8-inch thickness. Cut dough into rounds using the top of a glass or a round cookie cutter. Place these bottom rounds 2-inches apart on a baking sheet. Top each dough round with 1 tablespoon of raisin filling mixture.
column7: Roll out remaining dough ball to 1/8-inch thickness and cut into rounds using the same cutter. Moisten fingers slightly with water and carefully work each top round from the center outwards until each is about 1/4-inch larger around than the bottom round. Working from one edge, place top round over bottom round and filling, pressing firmly to seal the cookie. Lightly press down tops of cookies to settle filling in the pocket.
column8: Bake in the preheated oven until cookie is set, 10 to 12 minutes. Cool briefly on the baking sheet before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Combine water and amaranth together in a saucepan; bring to a boil, reduce heat to medium-low, and simmer until water is absorbed and amaranth grains are fluffy, about 20 minutes. Cool for 10 to 15 minutes.
column3: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column4: Beat cooked amaranth and peanut butter together in a large bowl until smooth. Beat in sugar until completely dissolved. Add butter to amaranth mixture and mix; stir in egg until smooth.
column5: Whisk all-purpose flour, pastry flour, oats, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together in a bowl. Gradually add flour mixture to amaranth mixture, stirring until the dough starts to come away from the sides of the bowl.
column6: Form dough into small balls and place 2-inches apart on a baking sheet. Dip a fork into flour and press dough balls with fork to flatten.
column7: Bake in the preheated oven until set, about 15 minutes. Cool on the baking sheet for 3 to 5 minutes before removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Butter a 9x13-inch baking dish.
column3: Melt butter in a large saucepan over low heat; add marshmallows and stir until melted. Cook and stir mixture for 2 minutes more. Remove saucepan from heat. Stir crushed cookies into marshmallow mixture until well coated.
column4: Press cookie mixture firmly into the prepared baking dish using a buttered spatula or waxed paper; cool. Cut into 2-inch squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Whisk coconut sugar, coconut milk, eggs, and almond extract together in a bowl. Combine almond flour, coconut flour, baking soda, and sea salt together in a separate bowl; beat into coconut milk mixture using an electric mixer on medium speed until batter is moist. Mix 1/2 cup chocolate chips and 1/4 cup shredded coconut into batter. Pour batter into a 9-inch square baking dish. Top batter with remaining chocolate chips and shredded coconut.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean, 30 minutes.

column2: Mix flour, butter, confectioners' sugar, and cornstarch together in a bowl until dough is just mixed; refrigerate until chilled, at least 30 minutes.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line 6 dozen miniature muffin cups with paper liners.
column4: Roll dough into small balls and press each ball into the bottom and up the sides of each muffin cup. Fill each cup 3/4-full with apricot preserves.
column5: Mix coconut, white sugar, and eggs together in a bowl; spoon over apricot filling, making sure to cover completely.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until topping is lightly browned, 25 to 30 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Form refrigerated cookie dough into cups, using about 1/2 cup dough to form about a 3-inch tall cup. Place cups on ungreased cookie sheet about 1-inch apart.
column4: Bake in preheated oven until golden brown, 10 to 15 minutes.
column5: Transfer cups to a wire cooling rack and allow to cool, 10 to 15 minute. Fill each cup with 1/2 cup ice cream and top with 1 tablespoon crushed chocolate sandwich cookies.

column2: Mix wheat germ, peanut butter, honey, and milk powder together in a bowl; shape into bite-size balls. Arrange balls on a plate.
column3: Place in the freezer until solid, at least 1 hour.

column2: Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Combine sugar, butter, and milk in a saucepan; bring to a boil and cook for 2 minutes. Remove saucepan from heat and stir in cinnamon chips and chocolate-hazelnut spread until melted. Fold oats into mixture.
column4: Drop mixture by walnut-size spoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheets.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Prepare a 12x8-inch baking dish with cooking spray.
column3: Pour entire contents of can of black beans into a blender bowl; add water and blend until very smooth.
column4: Stir blended black beans and brownie mix together in a bowl until the mix is completely moistened; pour into prepared baking dish.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean, about 40 minutes.

column2: Beat butter, sugar, eggs, and vanilla extract together in a bowl using an electric mixer until smooth and creamy. Sift flour, cream of tartar, baking soda, and salt together in a separate bowl; mix, 1 cup at a time, into creamed butter mixture until dough is just mixed. Form dough into 1-inch-thick disks and place on a plate; chill in refrigerator, 2 hours to overnight.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column4: Roll disks into desired thickness on a lightly floured work surface using a floured rolling pin. Arrange dough on a baking sheet.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until cookies are just starting to turn golden brown, 7 to 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Beat butter and 1 cup confectioners' sugar together in a bowl until light and fluffy. Stir in flour and walnuts until dough is just-combined. Roll dough into 1-inch balls and place 2-inches apart on a baking sheet.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until lightly browned on the bottom, about 10 minutes.
column5: Pour 1/2 cup confectioners' sugar in a shallow bowl. Roll hot cookies in confectioners' sugar to coat; cool cookies completely and roll again in confectioners' sugar to coat.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F. Line two cookie sheets with Reynolds(R) Parchment Paper.
column3: Beat butter in a large bowl with an electric mixer on medium to high speed for 30 seconds. Add sugar, baking powder, and salt. Beat until combined, scraping the sides of the bowl occasionally. Beat in the egg, milk, and vanilla until combined. Beat in as much of the flour as you can with the mixer. Using a wooden spoon, stir in any remaining flour. Divide dough in half. If necessary, cover and chill dough about 30 minutes or until easy to handle.
column4: Roll half the dough at a time between two sheets of parchment paper to 1/8- to 1/4-inch thickness. Using a 2 1/2-inch heart-shape cookie cutter, cut out cookie shapes, re rolling dough as needed until all the dough is cut out. Place shapes 1 inch apart on prepared cookie sheets.
column5: Bake 6 to 8 minutes or until edges are firm and bottoms are very light brown. Transfer the parchment paper with baked cookies to wire racks and let cool. Once cooled, slide the parchment paper onto a work surface.
column6: Tint frosting as desired with food coloring. Frost cookies with one color and use another color to pipe a message over the frosted cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
column3: Line cookie sheets with Reynolds(R) Parchment Paper; set aside. No need to add extra grease or spray your cookie sheets. Knead flour into sugar cookie dough until well blended. Roll out half of cookie dough at a time to 1/4-inch thickness between lightly floured sheets of Parchment Paper. Using Valentine cookie cutters, cut out cookies; place on parchment-lined cookie sheets.
column4: Bake 7 to 12 minutes, depending on the size of the cookies or until the edges begin to brown. Let stand one minute on cookie sheets. Slide Parchment Paper with cookies onto a wire racks to cool completely.
column5: Icing and Decorating: Beat powdered sugar, meringue powder, water and extract in a large bowl, with an electric mixer, on high speed until smooth and thick, about 1 minute.
column6: Divide icing into 3 small bowls. Leave one bowl of icing white. Stir food coloring in remaining 2 bowls to make pink and red icing of desired color. Cover icing tightly when not in use, icing dries quickly.
column7: Pipe outlines of cookies with contrasting colors of icing using a decorating bag with tip. Or, place icing in plastic zipper bags. Snip off one corner with scissors and use to pipe icing.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Beat 1 cup white sugar and shortening together in a large bowl until light and creamy. Add molasses and egg; beat until smooth.
column4: Whisk flour, baking soda, ginger, cinnamon, and salt together in a bowl. Gradually stir flour mixture into shortening mixture until dough is just-combined.
column5: Pour 1/2 cup white sugar into a shallow bowl. Roll dough into 1-inch balls and roll each ball in sugar to coat; place 2-inches apart on a baking sheet.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until set and lightly golden, 10 to 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Whisk brown sugar, shortening, butter, molasses, eggs, baking soda, cinnamon, ginger, salt, cloves, and cayenne pepper together in a large bowl until glossy; fold in flour until dough is just-combined.
column4: Pour coarse sugar into a shallow bowl. Roll dough into 48 balls. Roll balls in sugar and place 2-inches apart on a baking sheet.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until the tops of the cookies crack, about 9 minutes.

column2: Whisk flour, crystallized ginger, ground ginger, and salt together in a bowl.
column3: Beat shortening and sugar together in a bowl until smooth and creamy. Add egg yolks 1 at a time, beating well after each addition. Gradually beat flour mixture and cold water into egg mixture until dough is well-combined. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate until chilled, at least 2 hours.
column4: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column5: Press chilled dough into a 7x11-inch baking dish. Spread apricot preserves over the top.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown around the edges, 35 to 40 minutes. Cool for 1 hour before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Whisk flour, ginger, baking powder, cinnamon, and salt together in a bowl.
column4: Beat butter in a large bowl until creamy. Gradually beat in 2 cups sugar until light and fluffy. Add eggs, one at a time, beating well after each addition. Beat in molasses. Stir 1/2 of the flour mixture into butter mixture; add remaining flour mixture and stir until dough is just-combined.
column5: Pour 3/4 sugar into a shallow bowl. Roll dough into 2 inch balls and roll each ball in sugar to coat. Place sugar-coated dough balls 2 1/2-inches apart on a baking sheet.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until cookies are light brown and puffed, 12 to 14 minutes. Cool on the baking sheet for 2 minutes before transferring cookies to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Line an 8-inch square metal, ceramic, or glass baking pan with 2 long pieces of aluminum foil, layering the pieces across one another and crimping the overhang over the sides of the pan.
column3: Melt the butter and chocolate together in a small (1 1/2-quart) heavy-bottomed saucepan over low heat, stirring constantly to make sure the chocolate doesn't burn. When nearly all the chocolate is melted, remove the pan from the heat and continue stirring to melt completely.
column4: Scrape the melted chocolate into a large mixing bowl with a silicone spatula. Stir in the applesauce and vanilla extract, then stir in the sugar and salt until a grainy batter forms.
column5: Stir in the eggs one at a time, making sure the first egg is fully incorporated before adding the next.
column6: Gently stir in the almond flour 1/4 cup at a time, then stir in the almonds.
column7: Pour the batter into the prepared baking pan, spreading it evenly to reach all the corners of the pan.
column8: Make the almond butter swirl by beating the almond butter, sugar, and applesauce together with a silicone spatula or electric hand mixer on low speed.
column9: Drop the almond butter in spoonfuls over the brownie batter and use the tip of a butter knife to carefully swirl into the batter, making sure not to puncture the foil on the bottom of the pan.
column10: Bake for 45 minutes to 1 hour, or until a toothpick or small knife inserted into the center of the pan comes out with moist crumbs attached. (Baking time will be slightly longer for ceramic and glass pans than for metal pans.)
column11: Cool completely in the pan for at least an hour and preferably overnight.
column12: Use the long edges of the foil to carefully lift the bars out of the pan and onto a cutting board. Peel the foil off and cut the brownies into squares.
column13: Brownies taste best when baked the day before you plan to serve them. Leftover brownies can be stored in the refrigerator in an airtight container for up to 5 days.

column2: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Line an 8-inch square metal, ceramic, or glass baking pan with 2 long pieces of aluminum foil, layering the pieces across one another and crimping the overhang over the sides of the pan.
column3: Make the crust: Whisk the coconut flour, almond flour, sugar, and salt together in a medium mixing bowl. Stir in the coconut, poppy seeds and lemon zest.
column4: Whisk the butter, applesauce, and egg yolk together in a small bowl, then stir into the crust.
column5: Press the crust evenly across the bottom of the prepared baking pan.
column6: Bake the crust for 10-15 minutes, or until the edges just start to brown. (Baking time will be slightly longer for ceramic and glass pans than for metal pans.)
column7: While the crust bakes, make the filling: Whisk the eggs, lemon juice, lemon zest, and applesauce together in a medium mixing bowl until the eggs are well blended.
column8: Whisk in the sugar and cornstarch.
column9: Pour the filling over the baked crust and return the pan to the oven.
column10: Bake for 25-30 minutes more, until the filling is set.
column11: Cool in the pan on a wire rack for 5 minutes, then use the long edges of the foil to carefully lift the bars out of the pan and onto the rack.
column12: Cool to room temperature, then peel the foil off. Dust the bars with powdered sugar and sprinkle with poppy seeds, then cut into squares or longer bars.
column13: Bars can be made up to 3 days in advance and stored in the refrigerator in an airtight container.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Beat cake mix, butter and 1 egg in large bowl with mixer until crumbly. Stir in saltine crumbs. Set aside 2 cups of crumb mixture. Press remaining crumb mixture on bottom of greased 13x9-inch baking pan.
column3: Bake 15 to 20 minutes or until lightly golden. Beat 3 egg yolks, condensed milk and ReaLemon(R) with mixer or wire whisk. Spread over prepared crust. Top with reserved crumb mixture. Bake 25 minutes longer or until set and top is golden. Cool.
column4: Refrigerate within 2 hours. Cut into bars. Store leftovers covered in refrigerator.

column2: Combine all ingredients except egg white, flour, nuts and Lemon Cheese Filling. With mixer, beat until well blended. Beat in flour. Wrap dough in plastic wrap.
column3: Chill at least 1 hour.
column4: Shape into 1-inch balls. With mixer, beat egg white lightly. Dip balls in egg white; roll in nuts. Place 2 inches apart on ungreased baking sheets. Press thumb deep into center of each cookie; fill with Lemon Cheese Filling (recipe below).
column5: Bake in preheated 375 degrees oven 10 minutes or until filling is set. Cool slightly; remove from baking sheets. Store tightly covered in refrigerator.
column6: Lemon Cheese Filling Directions: Beat cream cheese, sugar, egg yolk, ReaLemon(R) and 1 drop of yellow food coloring, if desired, until well blended and smooth.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease an 8x8-inch baking pan.
column3: Whisk 1 1/3 cups flour and white sugar together in a bowl; cut in 1/2 cup butter with a pastry blender until mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Press flour mixture evenly into bottom of prepared pan.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until light golden, about 10 minutes; remove base from oven to cool slightly, leaving oven on, about 5 minutes. Sprinkle base evenly with raisins and walnuts.
column5: Beat eggs well in a bowl with an electric mixer; beat in brown sugar until creamy, about 2 minutes. Beat 1/4 cup butter, vinegar, 1 tablespoon flour, and vanilla extract into sugar mixture just until combined; pour over base, covering raisins and nuts.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until bubbly, about 30 minutes. Allow to cool completely, about 30 minutes; cut into squares.

column2: Prepare a baking dish and a large mixing bowl with non-stick cooking spray. Pour cereal into a large mixing bowl and set next to your stove.
column3: Heat caramel bits and butter together in a large saucepan over low heat until both are melted and the mixture is smooth, about 5 minutes; add marshmallows. Continue to cook the mixture, stirring regularly, until the marshmallows are melted and the mixture is smooth, about 5 minutes; pour immediately into the middle of the cereal in the bowl and quickly stir to coat cereal completely.
column4: Spread the coated cereal into the prepared baking dish. Spray the back of a spoon with cooking spray and use it to press the cereal into an even layer. Let cereal cool completely before cutting into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a 9x11-inch baking dish with aluminum foil.
column3: Whisk oats, flour, chocolate chips, ground cashews, sunflower seeds, flax meal, wheat germ, cinnamon, and sea salt together in a large shallow bowl.
column4: Stir warmed honey, almond butter, and vanilla extract together in a bowl until well-mixed. Pour honey mixture into oat mixture; stir until batter is well-combined. Turn batter out into prepared baking dish. Lay a sheet of waxed paper over batter and press firmly to evenly distribute in the baking dish. Remove and discard waxed paper.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until golden and fragrant, about 12 minutes. Pull aluminum foil from baking dish and cool bars in the aluminum foil for 10 minutes; remove and discard aluminum foil. Cut into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13-inch baking dish.
column3: Beat sugar, butter, and water together in a large bowl; add eggs 1 at a time, beating well after each addition. Stir in vanilla extract.
column4: Whisk flour, cocoa powder, pudding mix, baking powder, and salt together in another bowl. Add flour mixture, 1/2 cup at a time, to butter mixture, stirring batter well after each addition. Stir dark chocolate chips and mini chocolate chips into batter. Pour batter into prepared baking dish.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick inserted into the center of the brownies comes out slightly sticky with chocolate, 20 to 30 minutes. Cool in baking dish for 10 minutes before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a 9x13-inch baking pan with enough aluminum foil to hang over the edges. Spray the foil with cooking spray.
column3: Melt baking chocolate and butter together in a microwave-safe glass or ceramic bowl in 30-second intervals, stirring after each melting, for 1 to 3 minutes. Stir sugar into chocolate mixture until dissolved. Cool mixture slightly.
column4: Mix eggs into into chocolate mixture until well mixed; stir in vanilla extract. Stir flour into chocolate mixture just until batter is moistened.
column5: Process pecans and dried cherries in a food processor until chopped; fold into batter with chocolate chips. Spread batter into the prepared baking pan.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until brownies begin to pull away from the edges and are set in the middle, about 1 hour.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13-inch baking pan.
column3: Whisk flour, baking powder, and salt together in a bowl. Beat brown sugar, butter, eggs, and 1 tablespoon vanilla extract together in a bowl using an electric mixer until smooth and creamy. Stir flour mixture into creamed butter mixture until batter is well combined and thick; spread into the prepared baking pan.
column4: Combine white sugar, 2 tablespoons cinnamon, and ginger together in a bowl; sprinkle over batter.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until blondies are beginning to pull away from the sides of the pan and are set in the middle, 25 to 30 minutes. Allow blondies to cool, at least 30 minutes.
column6: Beat confectioners' sugar, cream, 1 tablespoon cinnamon, and 1 teaspoon vanilla extract together in a bowl until glaze is smooth; drizzle onto blondies.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line an 8-inch square baking dish with aluminum foil or baking parchment. Grease the lining.
column3: Mix rice flour, quinoa flakes, tapioca starch, coconut, baking powder, stevia powder, and salt together in a large bowl; add coconut oil and mix.
column4: Beat egg and agave nectar together; add to the flour mixture and mix into a dough. Spread dough into the prepared baking dish and flatten into an even layer.
column5: Spread jam to cover nearly to the edges of the dough.
column6: Bake in preheated oven until the edges are browned and the jam is bubbling, 20 to 25 minutes. Cool bars for 10 minutes in the dish before lifting from pan by aluminum foil or parchment paper; cut into 9 squares.

column2: Line a 9x13-inch baking pan with parchment paper.
column3: Blend quinoa, dates, honey, applesauce, coconut, sunflower seeds, coconut oil, and vanilla together in a food processor until smooth. Add enough of the oats to fill the processor bowl and and blend until combined.
column4: Stir the quinoa mixture with the remaining oats, flax seed, protein powder, sesame seeds, chia seeds, and salt in a large bowl until mixture is able to hold it's shape without sticking to you hands. Press mixture firmly into prepared baking pan and refrigerate until chilled, at least 1 hour.

column2: Beat butter in a large bowl with a hand mixer until fluffy; add vanilla extract, confectioners' sugar, ground cinnamon candies, and cornstarch and mix with hand mixer until combined.
column3: Incorporate flour 1/4 cup at a time, mixing with your hands until all flour is used and dough comes together.
column4: Divide dough into halves; roll each into an 8-inch cylinder. Wrap each cylinder in waxed paper and freeze until firm, at least 1 hour to overnight.
column5: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Remove dough from freezer and let thaw just until slightly softened.
column6: Cut dough into 1/4-inch slices and arrange onto baking sheets.
column7: Bake in preheated oven until firm along the edges but not yet browned, about 10 minutes. Cool cookies on racks for 5 minutes before moving to a rack to cool completely.

column2: In large saucepan melt butter over low heat. Add marshmallows and stir until completely melted. Remove from heat.
column3: Add KELLOGG'S RICE KRISPIES cereal. Stir until well coated.
column4: Using 1/4-cup measuring cup coated with cooking spray divide warm cereal mixture into portions. Using buttered hands shape each portion into 2 1/2- x 1 1/2-inch egg shapes. (Or, coat insides of plastic snap-apart Easter eggs with cooking spray. Press cereal mixture into eggs. Remove cereal mixture from plastic eggs.) Cool.
column5: In small saucepan combine chocolate morsels and shortening. Cook over low heat until melted, stirring constantly. Dip bottoms of cereal eggs into chocolate. Decorate with sprinkles. Place on wax-paper-lined baking sheet. Refrigerate until chocolate is firm. Individually wrap in plastic wrap. Best if served the same day.

column2: Whisk flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, baking powder, and salt together in a bowl.
column3: Beat butter with an electric mixer until fluffy, about 2 minutes; beat in brown sugar and white sugar until smooth, about 1 minute. Beat egg, milk, and vanilla extract into butter mixture; beat in food coloring until uniformly colored.
column4: Stir flour mixture into butter mixture gradually with electric mixer on low speed until combined; stir in 1 cup chocolate chips. Cover bowl with plastic wrap; place in the refrigerator for 1 hour or up to overnight.
column5: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column6: Roll dough into 2-inch balls; place on prepared baking sheets and flatten slightly.
column7: Bake in the preheated oven until edges are lightly browned, about 10 minutes. Sprinkle cookies with a few additional chocolate chips; allow to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line bottom and sides of an 11x7-inch glass baking pan with parchment paper; leave paper hanging over pan edges so that cookies can be lifted out after baking.
column3: Beat butter and brown sugar together with an electric mixer until light and fluffy, about 2 minutes. Stir flour into butter mixture until crumbly; stir in almonds and cherries. Press mixture evenly into the bottom of prepared pan.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until lightly golden at edges, about 20 minutes. Score with a sharp knife into bars while in the pan and still warm; allow cookies to cool about 30 minutes. Lift cookies from pan and slice to separate along scored marks.
column5: Melt white chocolate in a microwave-safe glass or ceramic bowl in 30-second intervals, stirring after each melting, for 1 to 3 minutes (depending on your microwave). Do not overheat or chocolate will scorch. Drizzle melted white chocolate over cookies or dip half of each cookie into melted white chocolate.

column2: Beat confectioners' sugar and margarine together in a bowl using an electric mixer until smooth and creamy. Add vanilla extract and beat until smooth.
column3: Whisk 2 1/2 cups flour, cornstarch, baking powder, and baking soda together in a separate bowl. Beat flour mixture into creamed butter mixture on medium-low speed just until dough is combined. Separate dough into 2 balls and refrigerate for at least 2 hours.
column4: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column5: Dust dough with flour and roll into 1/4-inch thick pieces on a work surface. Cut cookies into desired shapes using cookie cutters and arrange on a baking sheet.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until cookies are just beginning to turn brown, 10 to 14 minutes. Let cookies rest on baking sheet, 5 to 10 minutes; transfer to a wire rack to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Mix flour, sugar, baking soda, and salt together in a bowl.
column4: Beat vegetable oil, applesauce, almond milk, and vanilla extract together in a separate large bowl; add flour mixture and stir until combined.
column5: Divide dough into 14 portions and roll into balls. Spread cinnamon-sugar into a wide, shallow bowl. Roll dough balls in the cinnamon-sugar and arrange onto a baking sheet.
column6: Bake in preheated oven until golden brown, about 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease bottom of 9x13-inch baking dish.
column3: Stir brownie mix, oil, water, and eggs together in a bowl until well-blended. Spread mixture in prepared baking dish.
column4: Bake in preheated oven until a toothpick inserted 2 inches from the side of the dish comes out almost clean, about 25 minutes.
column5: Transfer baking dish from oven to wire cooking rack and while still hot, arrange mint candies across the top about 1/4- to 1/2-inch apart. Let sit until candies melt, about 3 minutes. Spread melted mints evenly over brownies with a spatula. Cool until top layer hardens, 4 to 5 hours.

column2: Mix peanut butter, confectioners' sugar, and vanilla extract together in a small bowl until smooth.
column3: Spread about 1 teaspoon peanut butter mixture atop each of 30 vanilla wafer cookie and top with another cookie to make 30 sandwiches.
column4: Mix chocolate chips and shortening together in the bowl a double-boiler, cooking and stirring until the chocolate is melted and the mixture is smooth, 5 to 7 minutes; remove from heat.
column5: Line baking sheets with waxed paper. Dip each cookie sandwich in melted chocolate to coat and place onto waxed paper.
column6: Refrigerate cookies until the chocolate hardens, 15 to 20 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease baking sheets.
column3: Beat butter and sugar together in a large bowl until light and fluffy; add eggs and vanilla extract and continue beating until smooth.
column4: Stir flour, cinnamon, baking soda, and salt together in a bowl. Gradually add flour mixture to butter mixture and stir until well-blended. Add zucchini, oats, pecans, and cinnamon chips, respectively, mixing well after each addition. Drop dough by heaping tablespoonfuls 2-inches apart onto prepared baking sheets.
column5: Bake in preheated oven until golden brown, about 12 minutes. Transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Spray a 9x13-inch baking dish with cooking spray.
column3: Process 2 cups flour, butter, and 1/2 cup confectioners' sugar in a food processor until mixture resembles coarse crumbs; press into the prepared baking dish.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until the edges of the crust are golden brown, 18 to 22 minutes. Cool crust to room temperature.
column5: Beat white sugar, eggs, 1/4 cup flour, lemon juice, baking powder, and lemon zest together in a bowl using an electric mixer until light and fluffy; pour onto the cooled crust.
column6: Bake in the oven until custard is set, 25 to 28 minutes. Cool lemon squares completely; dust the top with more confectioners' sugar.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Whisk almond butter, honey, egg, baking soda, vanilla extract, and salt together in a bowl; fold in chocolate chips. Drop batter, about 2 tablespoons per cookie, onto the prepared baking sheet about 1 1/2 inches apart.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until edges start to crisp, 8 to 10 minutes. Cool cookies on baking sheet for 10 minutes before removing.

column2: Preheat oven to 200 degrees F (95 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Line a large plate with waxed paper.
column3: Beat egg whites, coffee granules, vanilla extract, cream of tartar, and salt with an electric mixer at high speed until soft peaks form, 3 to 5 minutes. Add sugar, 1 tablespoon at a time, beating constantly, until stiff but still glossy peaks form, 3 to 5 minutes.
column4: Drop egg white mixture by rounded tablespoons 2 inches apart on prepared baking sheet (alternately, fill a pastry bag fitted with a star tip with egg white mixture and pipe out 1- to 1 1/2-inch stars).
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until kisses are firm and dry, about 2 hours. Cool on the baking sheet set on a wire rack for 1 hour.
column6: Melt chocolate in the top of a double boiler over simmering water, stirring frequently and scraping down the sides with a rubber spatula to avoid scorching. Remove from heat and cool slightly.
column7: Peel kisses from parchment paper. Dip the base of each kiss in melted chocolate and transfer to waxed paper-lined plate. Freeze kisses until chocolate hardens, 2 to 3 minutes.

column2: Blend all-purpose flour, almond flour, confectioners' sugar, and salt together in a food processor. Add butter; pulse until mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Add egg yolk, extracts, and ice water and pulse just until a smooth dough forms.
column3: Turn dough out onto a work surface, divide in half, form into disks, and dust each disk with flour. Wrap disks in plastic wrap and refrigerate until firm and cold, at least 1 hour to overnight.
column4: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper.
column5: Roll 1 dough disk out onto a floured surface with a floured rolling pin to 1/8-inch thickness. Use a floured 1 1/2-inch round cookie cutter to cut dough into rounds. Cut out the center of each round with a 1/2-inch floured round cookie cutter to form rings. Repeat with remaining dough disk.
column6: Cut through side of 1 dough ring and slip it around another to intertwine rings, pressing cut pieces together to seal ring. Place interlocked rings on prepared baking sheets.
column7: Beat egg white until frothy. Gently brush each "love knot" with egg white and sprinkle with turbinado sugar. Bake in the center of the preheated oven until lightly browned on edges, 15 to 18 minutes. Carefully transfer cookies to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Grease a 9x11-inch baking pan and line with parchment paper.
column3: Heat dates, orange juice, and lemon juice in a large saucepan over medium-low heat, stirring often, until dates are soft, about 6 minutes.
column4: Stir whole wheat flour, oats, brown sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together in a large bowl; stir in melted butter. Press half of the oat mixture evenly into the prepared pan.
column5: Spread date mixture evenly over oat mixture; sprinkle remaining oat mixture evenly over date mixture and press down lightly.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until golden, about 20 minutes. Allow to cool in the pan to room temperature, about 30 minutes. Refrigerate until chilled before cutting into squares, about 1 hour.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Heat dates, 2/3 cup brown sugar, orange juice, and orange zest in a saucepan over low heat; cook, stirring occasionally, until dates have softened, absorbed the liquid, and mixture is like a paste, about 10 minutes. Remove from heat; stir in vanilla extract.
column4: Stir oats, flour, 1 cup brown sugar, baking soda, and salt together in a bowl; cut in butter with a knife or pastry blender until mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
column5: Lightly press 2/3 of the crumb mixture into the bottom of a 9x9-inch pan. Spread date mixture evenly over the crumb crust; sprinkle remaining crumbs evenly over the top of date mixture.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until top is golden, about 30 minutes; cool on a wire rack for at least 1 hour before slicing into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Stir oats, flour, brown sugar, baking soda, and baking powder together in a bowl; cut in butter using a pastry blender until mixture is mealy and butter pieces are uniformly small.
column4: Press half of oat mixture evenly into the bottom of a 9x13-inch baking pan.
column5: Cook dates with water in a small saucepan over medium heat until they fall apart and are easily mashed with a wooden spoon, about 10 minutes; remove from heat and stir in vanilla extract.
column6: Spoon date mixture evenly over oat mixture in baking pan; sprinkle remaining oat mixture evenly over top and press into place.
column7: Bake in the preheated oven until crust is golden at the edges, about 30 minutes; remove to cool completely on a wire rack. Cut into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Line two cookie sheets with Reynolds(R) Parchment Paper; set aside.
column3: Beat the butter and sugar in a large bowl using an electric mixer about 2 minutes or until light and fluffy. Add the egg, orange peel, lemon peel, and vanilla and beat until well blended.
column4: Combine the flour, baking powder, and salt in a medium bowl. Add half of flour mixture to the butter mixture, beating until just combined. Add the milk. Beat about 10 seconds. Beat in the remaining flour mixture until just combined.
column5: Drop tablespoon-size mounds of dough on prepared cookie sheets.
column6: Bake 8 to 10 minutes or until set and the bottoms are browned. Transfer the cookies on the parchment paper to a wire rack; cool completely.
column7: Drizzle with Citrus Glaze to serve.
column8: Citrus Glaze: In a small bowl combine melted butter and orange juice. Add powdered sugar; beat until smooth. If necessary, add more orange juice, 1/2 teaspoon at a time, to make drizzling consistency. Drizzle over cookies.

column2: Butter a 9x13-inch pan.
column3: Heat brown sugar, butter, corn syrup, cocoa powder, cinnamon, and cloves in a saucepan over medium-high heat until butter is melted, stirring constantly. Bring cocoa mixture to a rolling boil; boil for 1 minute.
column4: Remove cocoa mixture from heat; stir in vanilla extract. Fold puffed wheat cereal into cocoa mixture. Pour cereal mixture into prepared pan; press evenly into the pan. Allow to cool completely before cutting into squares, about 30 minutes.

column2: Combine rhubarb, 1/2 cup (125 mL) brown sugar and the water in a heavy saucepan set over medium heat. Bring to a boil. Simmer, stirring often, for 10 to 12 minutes or until rhubarb is soft and thickened to an applesauce consistency. Cool to room temperature.
column3: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (160 degrees C).
column4: Toss cookie crumbs with melted Spreadables butter until well combined. Press into bottom of a parchment paper-lined, 9-inch (23 cm) baking dish.
column5: Whisk sour cream with remaining sugar and flour until well combined; whisk in eggs and vanilla just until smooth. Pour over prepared crust. Dollop rhubarb mixture over top and swirl with a knife until evenly marbled.
column6: Bake for 28 to 30 minutes or until centre is just slightly jiggly. Cool to room temperature, then chill thoroughly before slicing.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease baking sheets.
column3: Beat sugar, shortening, eggs, and vanilla extract together in a bowl until creamy. Sift flour, baking soda, baking powder, salt, cinnamon, ginger, and cloves together in another bowl. Add flour mixture to sugar mixture and stir until completely incorporated. Mix white chocolate chips and butterscotch chips into dough until evenly-combined. Drop dough by the teaspoonful onto prepared baking sheets.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until set, 10 to 15 minutes.

column2: In large mixing bowl beat peanut butter and butter on medium speed until combined. Add powdered sugar and milk. Beat until fluffy. Stir in KELLOGG'S RICE KRISPIES cereal, mixing until thoroughly combined. Press mixture evenly into 8 x 8 x 2-inch pan coated with cooking spray. Refrigerate until firm.
column3: Drizzle chocolate over cereal mixture. Refrigerate about 30 minutes or until chocolate is set and cereal mixture is firm. Cut into bars. Store in airtight container in refrigerator.

column2: Combine sugar, milk, and butter in a large saucepan; bring to a boil. Cook at a boil, stirring constantly, for 2 minutes. Remove saucepan from heat.
column3: Stir peanut butter and vanilla extract into sugar mixture until smooth; fold in oats until well blended. Drop mixture by spoonfuls onto aluminum foil or waxed paper. Cool until cookies are set.

column2: Beat butter, white sugar, and salt together in a bowl; add 2 cups flour and stir. Beat 1 cup flour into butter mixture; mix until a sticky dough forms.
column3: Whisk egg, vanilla extract, and milk together in a bowl. Beat remaining flour and egg mixture into dough. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes.
column4: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
column5: Break off a small portion of dough and roll it out on a lightly floured work surface into a 1/4-inch thick round. Place round on prepared baking sheet. Repeat with remaining dough.
column6: Bake cookies in the preheated oven until slightly golden and soft, 8 to 10 minutes. Transfer cookies to a wire rack to cool completely.
column7: Cook and stir coconut in a large skillet over medium heat until golden brown and toasted, 2 to 4 minutes.
column8: Melt caramel bits in a microwave-safe bowl, stirring every 30 seconds, until melted and smooth, about 2 minutes. Stir coconut into caramel. Press a spoonful of caramel-coconut mixture into the top of each cookie.
column9: Melt chocolate in a microwave-safe bowl, stirring every 30 seconds, until melted and smooth, about 60 seconds. Dip the base of each cookie into melted chocolate and place dipped cookies on parchment paper until chocolate sets. Drizzle chocolate over the top of each cookie.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Pour coconut into a shallow bowl. Press each cookie dough slice into coconut to coat both sides. Arrange coated slices on a baking sheet.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until lightly golden, 10 to 12 minutes. Cool completely.
column5: Drizzle caramel syrup over cooled cookies and top with hot fudge topping. Chill in the refrigerator until set, about 30 minutes.

column2: Combine corn syrup and brown sugar in a large saucepan; bring to a boil, cook at a boil for 1 minute, and remove from heat. Stir peanut butter and vanilla extract into sugar mixture. Add rice cereal, oats, cranberries, and coconut; stir well.
column3: Press peanut butter mixture into an 8-inch square baking dish. Cool completely before cutting into bars.

column2: Mix melted butter, white sugar, brown sugar, and vanilla together in a microwave-safe mug; add flour, baking powder, and salt and mix thoroughly. Stir chocolate chips into the doughy mixture until just combined.
column3: Cook in microwave oven until cookie-like, about 1 minute.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Place the bacon in a large skillet and cook over medium-high heat, turning occasionally, until evenly browned, about 10 minutes. Drain the bacon slices on paper towels.
column4: Mix flour, cocoa powder, and baking soda together in a bowl.
column5: Beat butter, brown sugar, and white sugar together with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Beat 1 egg into butter mixture. Beat second egg into mixture along with the vanilla extract; add flour mixture and mix well into a cookie dough. Crumble bacon and add to the dough with the chopped peanut butter cups; fold bacon and peanut butter cup chunks through the dough. Drop peanut butter in small amounts into the dough and swirl into the dough, but not mixing completely to integrate.
column6: Drop spoonfuls of dough onto baking sheets.
column7: Bake in the preheated oven until the edges are golden, about 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a 9x13-inch baking dish with parchment paper.
column3: Beat butter and 1/2 cup sugar together in a bowl with an electric mixer until creamy. Add 2 cups flour and cornstarch; beat until mixture forms a dough. Press dough into the bottom of the prepared baking dish.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until crust is light golden brown, 10 to 12 minutes.
column5: Beat 1 1/3 cups sugar, lemon juice, 2/3 cup flour, eggs, and lemon zest together in a bowl with an electric mixer until smooth. Pour lemon mixture over crust.
column6: Bake in the oven until lemon mixture is set, 25 to 30 minutes. Cool to room temperature before removing from baking dish. Cut into desired "Peep" shapes using shaped cookie cutters. Place 2 mini chocolate chips onto each "Peep" to create "eyes."

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column3: Combine flour, white sugar, brown sugar, cinnamon, and baking soda together in a bowl, breaking up any large lumps of brown sugar. Stir butter, egg, vanilla extract, and rum-flavored extract into flour mixture until dough forms; add chopped pecans and mix until well blended. Roll dough into 1-inch balls and place 2 inches apart on prepared baking sheets. Press a pecan half on top of each ball.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until edges of cookies are golden brown, 9 to 11 minutes. Sprinkle salt onto each cookie and gently press each with the back of a spatula to set the salt.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line 2 baking sheets with silicone mats or parchment paper.
column3: Mix confectioners' sugar, cocoa powder, and salt in a large bowl. Beat egg whites and vanilla extract into the sugar mixture until thick and batter-like; add chocolate chips and stir.
column4: Scoop batter by tablespoonful onto the prepared baking sheets.
column5: Bake in preheated oven until the tops are glossy and lightly cracked, 12 to 14 minutes. Let the cookies cool completely on the baking sheet and store in an airtight container for up to 3 days.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Beat butter, brown sugar, and white sugar together with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Add egg and vanilla extract and beat until smooth.
column4: Mix flour, salt, and baking soda together in a separate bowl; add to butter mixture and blend until just incorporated into a dough.
column5: Beat brownie mix, milk, water, and vegetable oil together in a separate bowl; add to dough and stir gently to keep the two batters distinct but somewhat evenly mixed.
column6: Drop dough onto ungreased baking sheets by heaping tablespoonful.
column7: Bake in preheated oven until set in the middle and crackling on top, 10 to 12 minutes. Cool cookies on sheets for 5 minutes before moving to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease an 8x8-inch baking dish.
column3: Stir cocoa powder and coconut oil together in a saucepan over low heat until coconut oil has melted, about 5 minutes. Remove from heat and let cool.
column4: Beat eggs, sugar, salt, and vanilla extract together in a bowl; stir in cocoa mixture. Whisk coconut flour into egg mixture until there are no lumps. Pour batter into prepared baking dish; sprinkle chocolate chips over top.
column5: Bake in preheated oven until a toothpick inserted into the center come out clean, about 35 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9-inch baking dish.
column3: Stir flour, powdered peanut butter, baking powder, and salt together in a bowl.
column4: Beat peanut butter and butter together in a bowl until creamy. Gradually add white sugar and brown sugar; beat until fluffy. Add eggs and vanilla extract; beat until smooth. Stir in flour mixture and chocolate chips until incorporated into batter. Spread batter into prepared baking dish.
column5: Bake in preheated oven until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean, 20 to 25 minutes. Cool on a wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Line 2 baking sheet with silicone baking mats.
column3: Beat cake mix, eggs, 1/2 cup flour, 3 tablespoons flour, and soybean oil together in a stand mixer until stiff.
column4: Divide and roll dough into 1-inch balls and arrange on prepared baking sheets and flatten to about 1/2-inch thick.
column5: Bake in preheated oven until somewhat firm in the center, 12 to 14 minutes. Remove from oven and let cookies sit undisturbed until set, about 5 minutes more.
column6: Spread a sheet of aluminum foil onto a countertop. Transfer cookies to foil to cool completely, at least 20 minutes.
column7: Beat confectioners' sugar, butter, shortening, half-and-half, and vanilla extract together with a hand mixer until smooth; spoon into a pastry bag and pipe onto cooled cookies or just spread onto cookies using a spatula.

column2: Beat sugar and butter together with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Add eggs one at a time, allowing each egg to blend into the butter mixture before adding the next. Beat sour cream and vanilla extract with the last egg.
column3: Mix 5 cups flour, baking soda, and baking powder together in a separate bowl; beat with the creamy mixture until just incorporated into a dough. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate 8 hours to overnight.
column4: Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column5: Turn dough out onto a floured sheet of waxed paper on a flat work surface. Sprinkle flour on top of dough and put another sheet of waxed paper atop the dough. Roll dough out to 1/4- to 3/8-inch thick, using additional flour to keep dough from sticking and to get the best consistency for rolling. Cut rolled dough with cookie cutters into desired shapes and arrange onto prepared baking sheets.
column6: Bake in preheated oven until set along the edges, about 8 minutes. Cool cookies on baking sheet for 10 minutes before moving to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Spray an 8-inch baking dish with cooking spray.
column3: Whisk flour, salt, baking powder, and baking soda together in a bowl. Beat sugar, oil, egg, lemon juice, and lemon zest together in another bowl. Add flour mixture to oil mixture and stir gently until batter is combined. Pour batter into prepared baking dish. Sprinkle cashews over the top.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until golden and set, 20 to 25 minutes. Cut into squares and garnish with strawberries.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease baking sheets.
column3: Melt margarine in a large saucepan over medium heat; remove from heat and stir in white sugar and brown sugar. Cool to room temperature, about 5 minutes.
column4: Beat eggs into butter mixture until smooth. Stir rice flour, xanthan gum, baking powder, cinnamon, baking soda, ginger, nutmeg, allspice, and salt into butter mixture. Add oats; stir until dough is thick and well-combined. Stir in chocolate chips. Drop dough by the tablespoonful onto prepared baking sheet.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until golden and soft, 7 to 9 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
column3: Beat butter and brown sugar together in a bowl using an electric mixer or in a food processor until smooth and creamy. Mix eggs and vanilla extract into creamed butter mixture. Add almond flour, coconut flour, salt, and baking soda to creamed butter mixture and stir until dough is well mixed; fold in chocolate chips. Drop dough by the rounded teaspoon onto the prepared baking sheet.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until edges of cookies are browned, 8 to 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
column3: Beat brown sugar, coconut sugar, butter, and coconut oil with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Beat the first egg into creamed butter mixture until completely blended; beat in vanilla extract with the last egg.
column4: Stir hot water and baking soda together in a small bowl until baking soda is dissolved; stir into butter mixture. Add cream of tartar and mix well.
column5: Mix flour into butter mixture until dough is smooth; fold in walnuts, chia seeds, flax seeds, cocoa nibs, and salt. Drop dough by rounded tablespoons onto prepared baking sheet.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until cookies are lightly browned around the edges, about 12 minutes. Transfer cookies to a wire rack to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Mix 1 cup rice flour, butter, confectioners' sugar, potato starch, and tapioca starch together in a bowl until crumbly and evenly combined; press into a 9x13-inch baking dish.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until crust is bubbling, about 18 minutes.
column5: Mix rhubarb, white sugar, eggs, 1/3 cup rice flour, and salt together in a bowl; spoon over crust.
column6: Bake in the oven until topping is bubbling, about 35 minutes.

column2: Stir sugar, milk, butter, and cocoa powder together in a saucepan over medium heat; bring to a boil and cook, stirring constantly, to dissolve sugar completely, 90 seconds to 2 minutes. Remove saucepan immediately from heat.
column3: Stir peanut butter and vanilla extract into the milk mixture until smooth; add oats and stir to coat. Spoon the mixture onto a sheet of baking parchment and let sit until the mixture holds together, about 15 minutes.

column2: Melt butter in a large saucepan over medium heat; add sugar, milk, and cocoa powder. Bring mixture to a boil, about 5 minutes; stir in peanut butter until melted, about 5 minutes. Return mixture to a boil and turn heat to low; simmer, stirring constantly, for 2 minutes. Remove saucepan from heat; stir in vanilla extract.
column3: Fold oats into mixture until thoroughly mixed. Drop mixture by spoonfuls onto a sheet of waxed paper; cool to room temperature.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Mix 2 cups flour, butter, and 1/2 cup white sugar together in a bowl until crumbly; press into the bottom of a 12x9-inch baking dish.
column4: Bake in preheated oven until crust is light brown, 25 to 30 minutes.
column5: Beat eggs, 1 cup sugar, and 6 tablespoons flour together in a bowl until smooth; add rhubarb, coconut, lemon juice, and vanilla extract and stir to coat. Pour the rhubarb mixture over the crust.
column6: Bake in preheated oven until the fruit layer is set, 35 to 40 minutes. Let bars cool completely before serving.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 13x9-inch baking dish.
column3: Mix 2 cups flour, 1/2 cup brown sugar, and 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon together in a bowl. Cut 1 cup unsalted butter into the flour mixture until crumbs form; press into bottom of prepared baking dish.
column4: Bake crust in preheated oven until golden brown, about 15 minutes.
column5: Blend eggs, white sugar, 1/2 cup flour, and salt in a blender until smooth; pour into a large bowl. Fold rhubarb, strawberries, and blueberries into the blended egg mixture. Spread the fruit mixture onto the baked crust.
column6: Mix 1/2 cup flour, 1/2 cup brown sugar, oats, melted butter, and 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon together in a bowl; sprinkle over the fruit mixture.
column7: Bake in preheated oven until lightly browned on top and the filling has set, 45 to 50 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Spray 2 baking sheets with cooking spray.
column3: Whisk oats, pastry flour, flax meal, cinnamon, salt, and baking soda together in a large bowl. Stir honey, egg whites, almond butter, and vanilla extract into oats mixture until dough is well-blended; mix in chocolate chips. Scoop dough into 36 balls and place on prepared baking sheets.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until lightly golden and set, 8 to 10 minutes. Cool on the baking sheet for 10 minutes, lightly loosen each cookie from the baking sheet, and continue cooling on the baking sheets for another 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with baking parchment paper.
column3: Mix flour, baking powder, and baking soda together in a bowl.
column4: Beat butter and brown sugar with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth. Beat 1 egg into butter mixture. Beat second egg into mixture along with the vanilla extract; add flour mixture and stir until it just forms a batter. Fold chocolate chips, quinoa flakes, oat bran, and cream through the batter to distribute throughout.
column5: Roll dough into small balls and arrange on prepared baking sheet with at least 2 inches between balls.
column6: Bake in preheated oven until lightly browned, about 10 minutes. Let cookies cool on pan for 10 minutes before removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease a baking sheet.
column3: Beat butter and sugar together in a bowl with an electric mixer until smooth and creamy; add eggs and vanilla extract and beat until smooth. Fold almond flour, baking soda, and salt into butter mixture until dough comes together. Stir in chocolate chips and cranberries. Drop dough by the teaspoonful onto prepared baking sheet.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until golden and set, about 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Mix cake mix, margarine, eggs, and vanilla extract together in a bowl until well combined; fold in white chocolate chips. Form dough into balls using a cookie scoop and arrange on a baking sheet.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until edges of cookies are lightly browned, about 12 minutes. Cool cookies on baking sheet 1 minute before transferring to a wire rack to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Mix almond flour, agave nectar, walnuts, eggs, cocoa powder, coconut oil, and vanilla extract together in a bowl; spread into an 8-inch square baking dish.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until edges of brownies begin to pull from sides of dish, about 30 minutes. Let brownies cool slightly before slicing, about 5 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 355 degrees F (180 degrees C). Grease a 9-inch square baking dish.
column3: Combine dates, water, 2 tablespoons sugar, and vanilla extract in a saucepan; cook and stir over medium heat until filling mixture forms a paste, about 5 minutes. Add more water if filling gets too thick. Remove saucepan from heat and cool.
column4: Place flour in a bowl and rub margarine into flour using your hands until mixture resembles bread crumbs; stir in oats and 3/4 cup sugar. Press 1/2 of the mixture into the prepared baking dish. Spoon filling over over crust, smoothing with the back of the spoon, leaving a thin border between the filling and the edge of the dish. Sprinkle the remaining crumble mixture over filling.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until top is golden brown, 40 to 45 minutes.

column2: Combine dates, sugar, and eggs in a skillet; place over medium heat. Cook and stir until mixture is cooked through and thickened, about 5 minutes. Remove skillet from heat and stir rice cereal, vanilla extract, and salt into egg mixture. Roll mixture into a log.
column3: Sprinkle coconut over a sheet of waxed paper. Roll date log in the coconut until coated. Cover date log with aluminum foil and refrigerate until set, about 1 hour. Cut log into 1/4-inch slices.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease a small baking dish.
column3: Beat eggs, vegetable oil, and vanilla extract together in a large bowl. Mix barley flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt together in a separate bowl; add to eggs mixture and stir to make a smooth batter. Pour batter into prepared baking dish.
column4: Bake in preheated oven until brown on top and set in the center, 20 to 30 minutes.

column2: Beat 1 1/2 cups sugar, butter, eggs, and vanilla extract together in a large bowl until smooth and creamy.
column3: Sift all-purpose flour, oat flour, cream of tartar, and baking soda together into a bowl. Beat 1/2 of the flour mixture into butter mixture; and remaining flour mixture and beat until dough is just combined. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate until chilled, about 30 minutes.
column4: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column5: Whisk 2 tablespoons sugar, cinnamon, and ginger together in a shallow bowl.
column6: Roll chilled dough into 1 1/2-inch balls and roll each ball in cinnamon-sugar mixture to coat. Place coated dough 2-inches apart on prepared baking sheets.
column7: Bake in the preheated oven until golden and set, 9 to 11 minutes. Cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Beat white sugar, brown sugar, and butter with an electric mixer in a large bowl until light and fluffy. Beat ice cream, egg, and vanilla extract into butter mixture until smooth.
column4: Whisk flour, malt powder, baking soda, and salt together in a bowl. Add flour mixture to butter mixture and stir until just combined. Drop spoonfuls of dough 2 inches apart onto baking sheet.
column5: Bake in preheated oven until lightly browned, about 8 minutes. Cool cookies on a wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease 2 baking sheets.
column3: Beat sugar and butter with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth and creamy. Beat eggs, 1 at a time, into creamed butter until smooth; add vanilla extract and beat well.
column4: Sift flour and baking powder together in a bowl. Gradually stir flour mixture into butter mixture, mixing well after each addition, until dough is smooth.
column5: Generously flour your hands. Make walnut-size balls from the dough and press into 4-inch circles on a floured surface, making the circles thicker in the center and thinner on the edges. Spoon about 1 1/2 teaspoons koshi an in the center of each dough circle. Gather the edges together and pinch dough around the filling until sealed. Place dough balls, pinched-side down, on the prepared baking sheets about 2 inches apart. Brush dough balls with evaporated milk.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until tops are lightly browned, about 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Place a sheet of parchment paper or plastic wrap on a work surface and dust with flour. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
column3: Beat butter in a bowl using an electric mixer until fluffy, about 3 minutes. Add 3/4 cup sugar and continue beating until mixture is lighter in color, about 2 minutes more.
column4: Mix flour, green tea powder, and salt together in a separate bowl; gradually add to creamed butter mixture, beating on low speed until dough sticks together. Roll dough to 1/4-inch thickness on the floured parchment paper; cut into 2-inch cookies or bars. Roll remaining dough and cut into more cookies until all the dough is used. Refrigerate for 10 minutes.
column5: Carefully transfer cookies to the prepared baking sheet. Sprinkle sugar over each cookie.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven until firm and barely starting to turn golden, about 15 minutes. Cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Process flour, butter, and 1/4 cup sugar together in a food processor until crumbly; press mixture into bottom of 9x9-inch baking pan.
column4: Bake in preheated oven until golden brown, about 15 minutes.
column5: Stir rhubarb, egg, 1/4 cup sugar, and almond meal together in a bowl until combined; spread mixture over crust.
column6: Bake in preheated oven until bubbling, about 30 minutes.
column7: Cool to room temperature on a wire rack before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Beat peanut butter, white sugar, and brown sugar together in a large bowl with an electric mixer until smooth. Stir egg, vanilla extract, and baking soda into peanut butter mixture; stir in chocolate chips.
column4: Drop mixture by small rounded spoonfuls onto a baking sheet about 2 inches apart.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until cookies are flattened and golden, about 8 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease a 9x13-inch baking pan.
column3: Mix cake mix, butterscotch chips, eggs, brown sugar, butter, and water together in a bowl; pour into the prepared baking dish.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until edges begin to pull away from sides of pan, 25 to 30 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
column3: Place cold butter, sugar, rosemary, salt, and vanilla extract in bowl. Combine with the back of a spatula or spoon, slowly incorporating ingredients together until butter has softened somewhat and ingredients come together.
column4: Pour flour into bowl with butter mixture. Flour your hands to then incorporate flour into the butter, using fingertips and rubbing mixture together until flour-y crumbs become buttery crumbs, 1 to 2 minutes. Press mixture together into a dough ball.
column5: Transfer dough to lightly floured work surface. Press dough into a disk, then into a 1/2-inch thick rectangle. Cover with a piece of plastic wrap. Flatten dough to 1/4-inch thick using a flat pan or rolling pin. Reshape into a rectangle.
column6: Cut dough lengthwise into 5 even strips about 1 inch wide, trimming extra dough if necessary. Cut each strip into 6 evenly sized squares. (You can roll out scraps to form more cookies if necessary). Transfer cookies to prepared baking sheet. Sprinkle each cookie with about a pinch of sugar. Using a fork, poke 4 rows of holes into each cookie.
column7: Bake in preheated oven until golden brown, about 50 minutes.
column8: Cool cookies 10 minutes on sheet; transfer cookies to rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Lightly grease a baking sheet, or line it with parchment.
column3: Combine the brown sugar, baking soda, salt, and butter, and mix until smooth.
column4: Mix in the vanilla, egg, and almond flour, stirring to combine. Scrape the bottom and sides of the bowl, then mix for 1 minute at medium speed.
column5: Stir in the chocolate chips.
column6: Scoop the dough one level tablespoon at a time onto the prepared baking sheet; a tablespoon cookie scoop works well here.
column7: Gently flatten the cookies to about 3/8-inch thick.
column8: Bake the cookies for 9 to 12 minutes, until golden brown.
column9: Remove the cookies from the oven. Allow them to cool on the pan for 2 minutes, then carefully transfer them to a rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F. Lightly grease a baking sheet, or line it with parchment.
column3: Mix all the ingredients, by hand or mixer, until a well-blended, cohesive dough forms; this will take about 2 minutes at medium-low speed in a stand mixer.
column4: Drop the cookie dough by teaspoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheet (a teaspoon cookie scoop works well here), leaving 1 inch between them; these cookies won't spread much when they bake.
column5: Use a fork to flatten each cookie to about 1/4 inch thick, making a cross-hatch design.
column6: Bake the cookies for 8 to 12 minutes, until just browned on the bottom. Allow the cookies to cool completely on the baking sheet.

column2: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Lightly grease an 8-inch square pan or 9-inch round pan.
column3: To make the crust: Combine the dry ingredients in a small bowl, whisking to blend. Add the cold butter, working it in with your fingers or a pastry blender until the mixture is evenly combined and crumbly.
column4: Pour the mixture into the prepared pan, shake to distribute, and press the crust into the bottom and about 1/2 inch up the sides of the pan.
column5: Bake the crust until it's light golden brown, about 8 to 10 minutes.
column6: While the crust is baking, whisk together the filling ingredients.
column7: Remove the crust from the oven, and pour the filling over the hot crust. Return the squares to the oven and bake them for 14 to 18 minutes, until the filling appears set.
column8: Remove the squares from the oven, and allow them to cool in the pan before cutting into 2-inch pieces. Cover the squares, and refrigerate until ready to serve.

column2: Beat butter, white sugar, and brown sugar together in a bowl until fluffy. Beat in eggs and vanilla.
column3: Combine flour, baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon, salt, and cayenne pepper in a separate bowl.
column4: Mix the dry ingredients into the butter mixture. Stir in cooked rice, chopped walnuts, and chopped chocolate.
column5: Cover bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 1 hour.
column6: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheet.
column7: Roll dough into walnut size balls; arrange on cookie sheets, about 12 per sheet.
column8: Bake in preheated oven until golden brown, about 15 minutes. Let cool on sheet 5 to 10 minutes; transfer to wire racks to cool completely.

column2: In a large bowl combine butter and peanut butter; beat until creamy. Add brown and white sugar and beat until fluffy. Beat in egg, vanilla extract and baking soda until well blended. With mixer on low, mix in flour just until blended. Cover and chill for 1 hour, or until firm.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column4: Shape 1 level tablespoon of dough into 1 inch balls. Taper each ball at one end into a teardrop shape. Press flat on one side. Place flat sides down, 2 inches apart on ungreased cookie sheets. Press the sides of the dough in to raise the 'backs' of the mice, as dough will spread slightly during baking.
column5: Gently push 2 peanut halves in each 'mouse' for ears, and 2 pieces of green candy for eyes. With a toothpick make a hole 1/2 inch deep in the tail ends.
column6: Bake in preheated oven for 8 to 10 minutes, or until firm.
column7: Transfer to a cooling rack and insert licorice pieces as tails.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: In a medium bowl combine graham cracker crumbs, flour and baking powder.
column4: In a separate, large bowl combine condensed milk and butter; beat until smooth. Stir in graham cracker mixture, mixing well. Stir in coconut and chocolates.
column5: Drop by rounded teaspoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column6: Bake in preheated oven for 7 to 9 minutes, or until lightly browned. Allow cookies to cool on baking sheet for 1 minute before removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch baking dish.
column3: In a medium bowl combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, flour, baking powder and salt; mix well. Spread 2/3 of mixture into prepared pan.
column4: Spread jam over mixture.
column5: Combine remaining mixture with oats and walnuts; sprinkle over jam layer.
column6: Bake in preheated oven for 30 minutes.

column2: In a large bowl combine crushed vanilla wafers, ground pecans, cocoa and chocolate chips. Stir in corn syrup and rum; mix well into a thick dough.
column3: Coat palms of hand with confectioners' sugar and roll dough into balls no larger than a quarter. Place on a cookie sheet, foil or wax paper to dry.
column4: Let balls dry for 1 hour. Roll in confectioners' sugar and seal in airtight containers.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a medium bowl beat eggs with an electric mixer. Beat in sugar. Stir in dates, coconut, walnuts, vanilla and almond extract. Spoon mixture into a 2-quart casserole dish.
column4: Bake in preheated oven for 30 minutes.
column5: Remove from oven, and while mixture is still hot, beat well with a wooden spoon.
column6: When mixture is cool enough to handle, form into small balls and roll in granulated sugar.

column2: In a large bowl combine oats, flour, brown sugar, cinnamon, baking powder, baking soda and salt. With a pastry blender cut in shortening until crumbly. Stir in raisins, coconut, chocolate chips and pecans.
column3: Refrigerate in an airtight container for up to 10 weeks.
column4: Attach a tag that reads: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease a baking sheet, or line with parchment paper. Measure 4 cups of the mix into a large bowl. Whisk together 1 egg, 2 tablespoons milk and 2 teaspoons vanilla; stir into the mix. Roll into 1 1/2 inch balls and place on prepared baking sheet. Flatten with a fork dipped in sugar. Bake in preheated oven for 15 to 18 minutes, or until golden. Allow cookies to cool on baking sheet for 5 minutes before removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter and brown sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the egg yolks then stir in the vanilla. Stir in the flour and mix well.
column4: In a shallow dish, such as a pie pan, beat egg whites until foamy. Spread walnuts on a plate or waxed paper.
column5: Roll 1 teaspoon of dough into a ball; roll in egg whites then in walnuts. Place 2 inches apart on a cookie sheet. Make a depression in each ball with your thumb.
column6: Bake in preheated oven for 12 minutes.
column7: Meanwhile, cream the remaining 2 tablespoons butter with corn syrup, blue and green food coloring and almond extract. Gradually stir in confectioners' sugar. Roll 1/2 teaspoon of fondant mixture into egg-shaped balls. Place fondant eggs into hollows of baked cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease a baking sheet.
column3: In a medium bowl combine coconut, crushed coconut cookies, candied fruit, dates and pecans. Mix well.
column4: To the sweetened condensed milk add the coconut extract and the food coloring; stir well to mix. Pour into coconut mixture; stir well.
column5: Drop by heaping tablespoonfuls onto prepared baking sheet.
column6: Bake in preheated oven for 12 minutes. Allow cookies to cool on baking sheet for 5 minutes before removing to waxed paper to cool completely.

column2: Gently separate each sandwich cookie and scrape the cream filling into a bowl.
column3: Melt the cream filling in a microwave until liquefied. Dip the chocolate cookies into the melted filling and place on a baking sheet; freeze until solid, about 2 hours.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13-inch baking dish.
column3: Blend black beans in a blender until smooth. Add bananas and vanilla extract; blend until smooth. Gradually add dates, a few at a time, and blend until evenly incorporated.
column4: Whisk oat flour, cocoa powder, flax seed, baking powder, and baking soda together in a bowl. Beat bean mixture into flour mixture on low to medium speed until batter is well blended; fold in walnuts. Spoon batter into prepared baking dish.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until edges of brownies begin to pull away from sides of dish, about 50 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Line 8x8-inch baking dish with parchment paper.
column3: Whisk egg white, coconut sugar, and almond extract together in a bowl. Fold almond flour into egg mixture until just combined; spread batter into baking dish. Sprinkle almonds over top of batter and press down lightly.
column4: Bake in preheated oven until golden brown, about 25 minutes. Transfer cookies to a cooling rack using the parchment to lift it out of baking dish. Cool to room temperature, about 1 hour.

column2: Place sugar into a jar with a tight fitting lid. Drip the food coloring onto the sugar, close the lid, and shake vigorously for about 1 minute. Adjust color with additional food coloring and repeat if the color is too light.
