column6: In large bowl, combine butter, sugars, and coffee. Beat until creamy. Add egg and melted morsels. Mix well. Gradually add flour mixture. Stir in remaining 1-1/2 cups chocolate morsels and walnuts. Form into walnut-sized balls and place on ungreased cookie sheets.
column7: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 10-12 minutes. Allow to stand 2-3 minutes before removing from cookie sheets.

column2: In a large bowl, combine the cocoa powder, rice cereal, oats, coconut, and sesame seeds. Set aside.
column3: In a saucepan over medium heat, stir together the peanut butter, brown sugar, honey, and vanilla. Cook and stir until melted and loose. Pour over the cereal mixture, and stir to coat evenly. Press lightly into a buttered 9x13 inch baking dish. Cool for about 1 hour to firm, then cut into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. In large bowl, beat cake mix, butter and 1 egg at medium speed until crumbly.
column3: Press evenly into greased 13x9-inch baking pan. Bake 15 minutes. Remove from oven; sprinkle with pecans and butterscotch chips.
column4: In small bowl, beat sweetened condensed milk, remaining 2 eggs and vanilla. Pour evenly over chips.
column5: Bake 25 to 30 minutes longer or until center is set. Cool thoroughly. Cut into bars. Store covered at room temperature.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (325 degrees F for glass baking pan). In small bowl, combine graham cracker crumbs and butter; mix well. Press crumb mixture firmly on bottom of 13x9-inch baking pan.
column3: Pour sweetened condensed milk evenly over crumb mixture. Layer evenly with remaining ingredients; press down firmly with fork.
column4: Bake 25 minutes or until lightly browned. Cool. Chill if desired. Cut into bars or diamonds. Store covered at room temperature.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease the sides and bottom of one 15x10 inch pan.
column3: In a large bowl combine the flour, 1/2 cup sugar, margarine or butter and salt until the mixture resemble coarse crumbs. Press firmly into the prepared pan.
column4: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 20 minutes.
column5: In a large bowl stir the eggs, corn syrup 1 1/2 cups white sugar, melted margarine and vanilla until blended. Stir in the chopped pecans.
column6: Spread the filling evenly over the hot crust. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 25 minutes or until set. Let cool before slicing.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch pan.
column3: Reserve 2/3 cup cake mix.
column4: Mix together remaining cake mix, margarine, and 1 egg. Pat in prepared pan.
column5: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 15-20 minutes or until golden brown.
column6: Beat together 3 eggs, vanilla, reserved 2/3 cup cake mix, corn syrup, and brown sugar. Pour on cake in pan. Sprinkle pecans on top.
column7: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 30-35 minutes.

column2: Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Grease one 9 inch square baking pan. Line the bottom of the pan with parchment paper and set aside.
column3: Chop 1/2 of the white chocolate into very small pieces. Chop the remaining white chocolate and the bittersweet chocolate into large chunks, set aside.
column4: Sift together the flour, baking powder and salt. Melt the butter in a small saucepan. Do not allow the butter to bubble or to color. Remove from the heat and add the finely chopped white chocolate. DO NOT STIR the chocolate in, set aside.
column5: Beat the sugar, eggs and vanilla together until thick and lemon colored, about 5 minutes. Lower the mixer speed and add the butter mixture. Mix just to blend. Add the flour mixture and mix just until the flour is mixed in. Use a rubber spatula to fold in the two chocolates and the nuts. Scrape the batter into the prepared pan.
column6: Bake at 325 degrees F (165 degrees C) until the brownies are just set, about 30 minutes. A toothpick inserted in the center should come out with moist crumbs still attached. As with all brownies it is better to underbake than to overbake. Allow to cool about 1 hour then cut into squares.

column2: Cream the butter and the sugar together until light beat in the flour, almond extract and salt. Stir in the chocolate chips. Wrap the dough in plastic wrap and chill for at least one hour.
column3: Preheat the oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Shape the dough into 1 1/2 inch long crescents. Bake on ungreased cookie sheets for 15 to 20 minutes, until cooked through but not browned at all about 10 minutes. Cool cookies on racks and store in an airtight container.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Cream the butter and the sugar together. Beat in the eggs.
column4: Combine the cherries, pecans, brazil nuts, almonds, dates, pineapple and walnuts. Toss to coat with 1/2 cup of the flour.
column5: Sift the remaining flour with cinnamon, salt and baking soda. Add the flour mixture to the butter mixture and mix well. Stir in the fruit and nut mixture. Drop by spoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheet.
column6: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 10 to 15 minutes.

column2: Spray a 9x13 inch baking pan with nonstick spray; set aside.
column3: Melt the peanut butter, butter, and marshmallows in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until smooth. Stir in the honey. Remove from heat; stir in the honey graham cereal. Press the mixture evenly into the prepared pan with a greased spatula. Allow to cool; cut into squares to serve.

column2: In a medium bowl, mix together the melted margarine, 1 cup sugar, and egg until smooth. Stir in the molasses. Combine the flour, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, cloves, and ginger; blend into the molasses mixture. Cover, and chill dough for 1 hour.
column3: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Roll dough into walnut sized balls, and roll them in the remaining white sugar. Place cookies 2 inches apart onto ungreased baking sheets.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven, until tops are cracked. Cool on wire racks.

column2: Grind the nuts, raisins, currants and citron. Boil the molasses and the sugar. Let cool then add the ground mixture, the eggs, salt, cinnamon, cloves, nutmeg, anise oil, sour milk and baking soda. Add enough flour to stiffen dough. Refrigerate dough for several days.
column3: When ready to bake preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Dough may be rolled out to 1/4 inch thick and cut with cookie cutters or you can shape dough into logs and slice. Place cookies on greased cookie sheets and bake for 10 to 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C).
column3: Cream butter and confectioners' sugar together. Add the cornstarch and flour and mix well. Stir in the chopped cherries. Drop teaspoonfuls of the dough onto a cookie sheet then press with tines of a floured fork.
column4: Bake at 300 degrees F (150 degrees C) until lightly golden, about 10 to 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the shortening and the sugar. Add the eggs and beat for 2 minutes. Beat in the vanilla, salt, sour milk, flour, cream of tartar, baking soda and cinnamon. Stir in the chopped walnuts. Drop cookies 3 inches apart on a baking sheet.
column4: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 12 minutes. Chopped dates can be added for extra flavor.

column2: Beat the sugar, molasses, butter or margarine, and oil together. Add 2 cups of the flour and the baking soda, cloves, ginger, and cinnamon. Mix in the remaining flour 1/2 cup at a time until the dough is stiff. Flatten into disks and cover with plastic wrap. Refrigerate for at least 1 hour.
column3: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column4: On a lightly floured surface roll the dough out to 1/4 inch thick and use cookie cutters to cut into desired shapes. Place cookies on a baking sheet and bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 8 minutes.

column2: In a medium bowl, cream together the dry butterscotch pudding mix, butter, and brown sugar until smooth. Stir in the egg. Combine the flour, baking soda, ginger, and cinnamon; stir into the pudding mixture. Cover, and chill dough until firm, about 1 hour.
column3: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease baking sheets. On a floured board, roll dough out to about 1/8 inch thickness, and cut into man shapes using a cookie cutter. Place cookies 2 inches apart on the prepared baking sheets.
column4: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, until cookies are golden at the edges. Cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a medium bowl, mix together the brown sugar, honey, butter and peanut butter until smooth. Stir in the banana and vanilla. Combine the whole wheat flour, oat bran, oats, baking soda, salt and pumpkin pie spice in a separate bowl. Stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients until it forms a smooth dough. Mix in the cranberries, chocolate chips and sunflower seeds. Drop by spoonfuls onto an ungreased baking sheet.
column4: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, until cookies are lightly browned at the edges.

column2: Melt the shortening in a large pan on the stove, and cool.
column3: Add sugar, eggs, and molasses, beat well.
column4: In a separate bowl, sift dry ingredients together and add to the pan. Mix well and chill 3 hours or overnight.
column5: Form into walnut-size balls. Roll in granulated sugar. Place on greased cookie sheet about 2 inches apart.
column6: Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 8-10 minutes.
column7: Store in an airtight container to keep from getting overly crisp. If they do lose their softness, an easy way to restore it is to place one slice of fresh bread in the container with the cookies for a couple of hours or overnight and they will be soft again!

column2: Melt butter in saucepan. Remove from heat. Add sugar and coconut. Mix well. Shape into balls.
column3: Make indent in center of each and place on cookie sheet. Place half a maraschino cherry in indent. Fill with melted chocolate. Chill until firm. Store in refrigerator.

column2: Cream together butter, sugar, and eggs. Beat in flour, cocoa, and cinnamon, mace, nutmeg, cloves, allspice, and soda.
column3: Meanwhile soak candied pineapple, orange peel, and lemon peel in bourbon.
column4: Add apples, raisins, dates, pecans, and soaked fruits, and mix well.
column5: On a greased cookie sheet spoon out half-dollar size cookies, spaced 1/2 inch apart.
column6: In a preheated 350 degree (175 degrees C) oven, bake 12-15 minutes.

column2: Cream together the butter and sugar in a bowl. Stir in the syrup and eggs. Sift together the flour, salt, cinnamon, ginger, allspice, and cloves in a separate bowl; add to the butter mixture; knead into a stiff dough. Pat into a flat circle, and wrap in waxed paper. Refrigerate at least 2 hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Roll the dough out onto a lightly-floured surface to about 1/2-inch thickness. Cut the dough using a star-shaped cookie cutter. Place cookies one inch apart on ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake in preheated oven until the edges are golden brown, about 10 minutes. Allow to cool to room temperature before serving.

column2: In a large bowl, combine crumbs, coconut, & nuts. Add sweetened condensed milk & rum; mix well. Chill 4 hours.
column3: Shape into 1- inch balls. Roll in sugar. Store in covered container in refrigerator 24 hours before serving.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column3: Sift together flour and cornstarch; set aside. Cream butter until smooth, then add white sugar, confectioner's sugar, vanilla, and salt; beat until fluffy. Slowly add flour mixture to butter mixture, beating on low until dough forms.
column4: On a floured surface, knead in 1/2 cup chocolate chips. Shape dough into two equal parts, pat each into a 6 inch round, and transfer to baking sheet. Cut into wedges.
column5: Bake 25 minutes. Remove immediately to cool on wire rack. Melt remaining chips and drizzle over wedges.

column2: Combine all-purpose flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. Set aside.
column3: In a 1 quart wide mouth canning jar, layer dark brown sugar, white sugar, cocoa, chopped pecans, and chocolate chips. Pack everything down firmly before you add flour mixture, it will be a snug fit.
column4: Attach a tag with the following instructions: Chocolate Cookie Mix in a Jar: 1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) 2. Empty cookie mix into large bowl. Thoroughly blend mixture with hands. Mix in 3/4 cup softened butter or margarine, 1 egg, slightly beaten, and 1 teaspoon vanilla. Shape into walnut size balls, and place 2 inches apart on a parchment lined baking sheet. 3. Bake for 11 to 13 minutes. Cool 5 minutes on baking sheet, then move to wire racks.

column2: In a medium bowl, mix vanilla wafer crumbs, ground pecans, cocoa, 1 cup confectioners' sugar, corn syrup, water, and rum flavoring together.
column3: Roll mixture into 1 inch balls, and then roll in remaining confectioners' sugar. Store, covered, about a week before serving.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F(175 degrees C).
column3: Sift all but 2 tablespoons of flour into a bowl, then add the sugar. Rub, or cut in butter until the mixture is crumbly. Divide in half. Work in the remaining 2 tablespoons of flour to one half, then the cocoa and ground chocolate to the other half. Knead each portion well with your fingers to form a smooth dough.
column4: Turn onto a lightly dusted with cornstarch surface, and roll out each portion to 1/4 inch thick circles. Using a 2 1/2 inch round cookie cutter, cut out 7 circles from each piece of rolled out dough. Out of these circles, cut two more circles, one 1 1/4 inch, and one 3/4 inch. Now you should have fourteen 2 1/2 inch rings, fourteen 1 1/2 inch rings and fourteen 3/4 inch circles.
column5: Construct wheels on greased baking sheets by starting with the largest rings, then alternating the colors to fill in. You should end up with 7 cookies that have a chocolate ring on the outside, a plain ring in the middle and a chocolate circle in the center; and 7 cookies that have a plain ring on the outside, a chocolate ring in the middle and a plain circle in the center.
column6: Bake for 12 minutes. Leave on sheets for 2 minutes, then remove with a flat knife. Cool completely on wire racks.

column2: Mix confectioners' sugar, butter or margarine, egg, vanilla, and almond extract. Stir in flour, baking soda, and cream of tartar. Cover and refrigerate for 2 hours.
column3: Heat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Divide dough into halves. On lightly floured cloth-covered board, roll each half out to 3/16 inch thick. on lightly floured cloth-covered board. Cut into Christmas shapes.
column4: Bake on parchment lined baking sheets for 7 to 8 minutes. Let cool on wire racks and decorate as desired.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C).
column3: Combine flour, baking powder, cinnamon and nutmeg.
column4: Cream sugar and butter until light. Add eggnog, vanilla, and egg yolks; beat at medium speed with mixer until smooth. Add flour mixture and beat at low speed until just combined. Do not overmix.
column5: Drop by teaspoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheet 1 inch apart. Sprinkle lightly with nutmeg. Bake 20 to 23 minutes until bottoms turn light brown.

column2: In a large bowl, mix together butter, sugar, eggs, and vanilla with an electric mixer until light and fluffy. Combine the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt; gradually stir flour mixture into butter mixture until well blended using a sturdy spoon. Chill dough for 2 hours.
column3: Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). On a lightly floured surface, roll out the dough to 1/4 inch thickness. Cut into desired shapes using cookie cutters. Place cookies 2 inches apart onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 4 to 6 minutes in the preheated oven. Remove cookies from pan and cool on wire racks.
column5: Using an electric mixer, beat shortening, confectioners sugar, water, salt, vanilla extract, and butter flavoring until fluffy. Frost cookies after they have cooled completely.

column2: First cut out in thin cardboard: a side wall, 4 1/2 x 8 inches; an end wall, 4 1/2x5 inches; a triangular gable, 4 1/2x3x3 inches; and a roof rectangle, 4 1/2x9 inches. Tape the rectangular end wall piece to the triangular gable piece: match the long side of the triangle, 4 1/2 inches, to one of the 4 1/2 inch sides of the end wall.
column3: In a large bowl, cream butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Stir in lemon zest, lemon juice, and molasses. Gradually beat in 2 eggs. Sift the flour, baking powder, and spices together; stir into creamed mixture. Wrap dough in parchment paper, and refrigerate for 1 hour.
column4: Turn out dough onto a lightly floured surface. Divide into 6 portions, 2 slightly larger than the others. On a lightly floured surface, roll out the 4 smaller pieces to approximately the size of the side wall and the end wall with gable templates; cut out two of each. Roll out remaining dough, and cut into two rectangular roof pieces. Transfer gingerbread onto greased baking trays.
column5: In a preheated 375 degree F (190 degrees C) oven, bake gingerbread for 10 minutes, or until crisp. When removing from the oven, leave the gingerbread on the baking trays for a few minutes to set, then transfer to wire racks. Leave out overnight to harden.
column6: In a large bowl, lightly whisk 2 egg whites. Gradually beat in approximately 5 cups confectioners' sugar. The icing should be smooth and stand in firm peaks. Spread or pipe a 9 inch line of icing onto a cake board, and press in one of the side walls so that it sticks firmly and stands upright. If necessary, spread or pipe a little extra icing along either side to help support it. Take an end wall and ice both the side edges. Spread or pipe a line of icing on the board at a right angle to the first wall, and press the end wall into position. Repeat this process with the other two walls until they are all in position. Leave the walls to harden together for at least two hours before putting on the roof. Spread or pipe a thick layer of icing on top of all the walls, and fix the roof pieces in position; the roof should overlap the walls to make the eaves. Pipe or spread a little icing along the crest of the roof to hold the two pieces firmly together. Leave overnight to set firmly.
column7: When ready to decorate, make the remaining icing. In a large bowl, lightly whisk 4 egg whites, and mix in remaining confectioners' sugar as before. Use this to make snow on the roof, and to stick various candies for decoration. Finish with a fine dusting of sifted confectioners' sugar.

column2: In a medium bowl, dredge candied fruit and raisins in 1 cup flour.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together brown sugar and butter. Beat in eggs. Gradually beat in bourbon and milk. Mix in remaining flour and spices. Stir in fruit and nuts. Refrigerate overnight.
column4: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Drop dough by teaspoonfuls, about 2 inches apart, onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column5: Bake for approximately 15 minutes. Remove from oven, and cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Sift together the flour, salt and baking soda; set aside.
column3: Cream together the butter, sugar, peanut butter and brown sugar until fluffy. Beat in the egg, vanilla and milk. Add the flour mixture; mix well. Shape into 40 balls and place each into an ungreased mini muffin pan.
column4: Bake at 375 degrees for about 8 minutes. Remove from oven and immediately press a mini peanut butter cup into each ball. Cool and carefully remove from pan.

column2: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease one cookie sheet.
column3: Mix together the molasses, brown sugar, water and shortening.
column4: Sift together the flour, baking soda, salt, allspice, ginger, cloves and cinnamon. Add to sugar mixture and mix well. Cover and refrigerate for 2 hours.
column5: Roll dough 1/4 inch thick on floured board. Cut with floured gingerbread cutter. Place about 2 inches apart on cookie sheet. Bake for 10-12 minutes. Cool and decorate with frosting.

column2: Blend together the peanut butter, sugar and melted butter. Allow to chill in refrigerator.
column3: Roll into 1 inch round balls and return to refrigerator.
column4: In a double boiler over medium heat, melt the chocolate and shortening. Whisk together until smooth.
column5: With a toothpick inserted in the balls, dip them into the chocolate so they look like buckeyes. Place on waxed paper and allow to set in refrigerator.

column2: In a saucepan over low heat, melt together the marshmallows, butter, vanilla, and food coloring. Mix in the cornflakes cereal.
column3: Drop by spoonfuls on wax paper, and decorate with red hots. Set aside, and allow to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease one 5x9 inch loaf pan.
column3: In a saucepan over medium heat, cook together the sugar, water, raisins, butter and salt. Remove from heat and allow to cool.
column4: Sift together the flour, soda, ginger and cinnamon. Stir into the cooled cooked mixture.
column5: Add the chopped dates, mixed peels, nuts and dried fruit.
column6: Pour into loaf pan and bake for 1 hour or drop by the teaspoon on a cookie sheet and bake for 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C).
column3: Combine the flour, baking powder, cinnamon and nutmeg. Mix well and set aside.
column4: Cream together the sugar and butter. Add eggnog, vanilla and egg yolks and beat until smooth.
column5: Add the flour mixture and mix until combined; be careful not to overmix.
column6: Drop by rounded teaspoonfuls onto ungreased baking sheets 1 inch apart. Sprinkle lightly with nutmeg. Bake for 23 to 25 minutes or until bottoms turn light brown. Transfer to cool, flat surface immediately with a spatula.

column2: Cream together the butter and cream cheese. Add sugar and vanilla; beat until light and fluffy.
column3: Combine the flour and salt; gradually add to creamed mixture, beating until well blended. Stir in chopped pecans. Cover bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 15 minutes.
column4: On four sheets of aluminum foil, shape dough into four 6 inch rolls, 1 1/2 inches in diameter. Wrap each roll tightly in foil and refrigerate over night.
column5: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Line cookie sheets with foil. Remove rolls of dough from refrigerator one at a time. Coat each roll with red or green sugar crystals; cut dough into 1/4 inch slices.
column6: Place on prepared cookie sheets; top each cookie with a pecan half. Bake for 15 to 18 minutes or until bottom of cookie is lightly browned when lifted.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, combine butter, flour, and confectioners' sugar. With an electric mixer, beat for 10 minutes, until light and fluffy. Spoon onto cookie sheets, spacing cookies 2 inches apart. Place a piece of maraschino cherry onto the middle of each cookie, alternating between red and green.
column4: Bake for 15 to 17 minutes in the preheated oven, or until the bottoms of the cookies are lightly browned. Remove from oven, and let cool on cookie sheet for 5 minutes, then transfer cookies on to wire rack to cool. Store in an airtight container, separating each layer with waxed paper.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column3: Combine flour, baking powder, cinnamon, and nutmeg. Mix well with a wire whisk and set aside.
column4: Cream sugar and butter until it forms a grainy paste. Stir in eggnog, vanilla, and egg yolks. Beat at medium speed until smooth. Add flour mixture and beat at low speed just until combined.
column5: Drop cookie dough by rounded teaspoonfuls onto ungreased baking sheets, 1 inch apart. Sprinkle lightly with nutmeg. Bake for 20 to 25 minutes, or until bottoms turn light brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the shortening and sugar. Add egg and vanilla; mix well.
column4: Sift together the flour, baking soda, baking powder, 1/4 teaspoon salt, cloves, cinnamon, and nutmeg. Stir flour mixture into creamed sugar mixture.
column5: Stir in the raisins, chopped nuts, 1/4 teaspoon salt and persimmon pulp; mix well.
column6: Drop by the teaspoonful on greased or parchment lined cookie sheet. Bake for 12 to 15 minutes. Transfer to wire racks to cool.

column2: In a medium saucepan, melt butterscotch chips over low heat, stirring constantly. Stir in chow mein noodles and peanuts.
column3: Drop by teaspoonfuls onto foil. Let stand until cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Melt the butter in a 7x11 inch baking dish, and tilt the pan to coat all of the sides; set aside.
column3: In a medium bowl, stir together the brown sugar, flour, and baking soda. Mix in the eggs and vanilla until smooth, then stir in the walnuts. Pour over the melted butter.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven for 20 minutes, or until the edges begin to brown. Cool, then cut into squares, and dust with confectioners sugar.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Stir together the peanuts, flour, corn flour, and confectioners' sugar in a large bowl until well-combined. Make a well in the center of the peanut mixture. Slowly pour in the vegetable oil and mix with the peanut mixture to make a wet, slightly sticky dough. Pinch off about 2 teaspoons of dough per cookie, and roll into balls about 1/2-inch in diameter. Place the balls on the prepared baking sheets, and brush each with egg yolk, if desired.
column4: Bake in the preheated oven until the cookies are golden brown, 6 to 8 minutes. Let cool on racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 F (175 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the butter, shortening, sugar and vanilla.
column4: Sift together the flour, baking soda and salt. Add to sugar mixture and mix well, being careful not to over mix.
column5: Drop heaping teaspoonfuls of dough on ungreased cookie sheet and flatten each with the tines of a fork (dip fork into small bowl of water so that dough doesn't stick to fork). Do this once or twice, depending on the size of cookie and fork.
column6: Bake for 13 to 15 minutes. After each pan is removed from oven, carefully place 5 or 6 chocolate chips on top of each cookie while they are still hot. When chocolate is glossy and soft, spread with knife.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C.) Lightly butter 2 baking sheets, or line with parchment paper.
column3: Cream the butter, sugar, and vanilla until light and fluffy. Sift together the flour and salt; mix into the butter mixture. Stir in the pecans. Dust your hands with a little of the confectioners' sugar and roll the dough into 1 inch balls.
column4: Place 2 inches apart on the baking sheets and bake for 25 minutes or just until brown. Put on racks to cool for 15 minutes, then roll in the confectioners sugar.

column2: Preheat the oven to 275 degrees F (135 degrees C). Grease a 10x15 inch jellyroll pan.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together 1cup of butter, white sugar and brown sugar until light and fluffy. Mix in the egg yolk and 1 tablespoon of vanilla. Combine the flour, cardamom and salt; stir into the batter until it forms a soft dough. Spread evenly in the prepared pan. Brush the top with egg white and sprinkle pecans over the top.
column4: Bake for 1 hour in the preheated oven. Prepare the frosting while the cookies bake.
column5: Melt the remaining butter in a saucepan over low heat until it starts to brown. Remove from the heat and stir in confectioners' sugar until smooth. Stir in enough milk to achieve a drizzling consistency. Drizzle frosting onto the bars when warm. Cool, then cut into bars.

column2: Melt margarine in a large pan over low heat. Add marshmallows and stir constantly until marshmallows melt and mixture is syrupy. Remove from heat. Stir in food coloring. Add corn flakes and stir until well coated.
column3: Drop mixture, by 1/4 cupful, onto cookie sheet. Using buttered fingers, quickly shape into individual wreaths. Dot with cinnamon candies

column2: Combine the chocolate chips, sugar, corn syrup, and water in a glass or metal bowl. Place the bowl over a pot of simmering water to melt the chocolate chips, stirring occasionally. Once the chips are melted, stir the orange flavoring into the mixture and remove from the heat.
column3: Meanwhile, mix together the vanilla wafers and hazelnuts in a bowl; set aside. Pour the chocolate mixture into the bowl; mix until evenly coated. Shape the mixture into small balls; decorate with the candy sprinkles.

column2: Melt butter in a large saucepan over low heat. Add marshmallows, and cook until melted, stirring constantly. Remove from heat, and stir in the food coloring, vanilla, and cornflakes.
column3: Quickly drop heaping tablespoonfuls of the mixture onto waxed paper, and form into a wreath shape with lightly greased fingers. Immediately decorate with red hot candies. Allow to cool to room temperature before removing from waxed paper, and storing in an airtight container.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Spray one 9x13 inch pan with non-stick coating .
column3: Combine the cake mix, butter and 1/3 cup evaporated milk. Mix well and pour 2/3 of the batter into pan.
column4: Press pecans into batter and bake for 8 to 10 minutes.
column5: In a saucepan over medium heat, combine the caramel and 1/3 cup evaporated milk. Stir until melted and smooth; pour over cooled cake mix.
column6: Sprinkle chocolate chips on top of caramel and top with spoonfuls of remaining cake mix. Bake for additional l5 to l8 minutes; cool and cut.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch pan. Set aside.
column3: Unwrap caramels and place in saucepan with 2 Tablespoons evaporated milk. Melt over medium to low heat, stirring constantly.
column4: In a large bowl, combine the remaining evaporated milk, dry cake mix, and melted butter. Stir until well blended. Spread half of this mixture in the prepared pan. Bake for 10 minutes.
column5: Remove brownies from oven. Sprinkle chocolate chips and drizzle melted caramels over the top. Drop remaining cake mixture by teaspoonfuls over all. Return to oven for 20 minutes. Garnish with whole pecans if you'd like.

column2: Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Coat a 9x13 inch baking pan with cooking spray.
column3: Mix the cake mix, melted butter, and half of the evaporated milk in a large bowl. Pat half of the mixture into the bottom of the prepared pan, reserve the remaining half for later use. Bake for 6 to 8 minutes. Remove baking pan from the oven; immediately sprinkle with toffee chips.
column4: Place the caramels and the remaining half of the evaporated milk in a microwave safe bowl. Microwave on High in 1 minute intervals, stirring after each minute, until caramels are melted. Top the toffee chips with the melted caramel. Crumble the reserved cake mixture over caramel layer.
column5: Return the baking pan to the oven; bake for 15 minutes. Allow to cool completely before cutting into 24 bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the butter, sugar, eggs and vanilla.
column4: Add the flour, baking soda and salt; mix well. Shape into 1 inch balls and roll in ground nuts.
column5: Place on ungreased baking sheet and bake for 10 minutes or until set. Press kiss in center of each cookie. Cool on wire rack.

column2: In a large bowl, dissolve the brown sugar in milk. Combine the flour, cloves, cinnamon, nutmeg, ginger, baking powder and salt. Stir the dry ingredients into the sugar and milk. Mix in 2 tablespoons of almonds and candied citron. Cut in the butter until it starts to form a dough, then knead on a lightly floured surface until smooth. Cover dough and chill for about 1 hour for easier handling.
column3: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Dust a wooden speculaas mold lightly with cornstarch. Firmly press the dough into the mold. Run a knife around the edges to trim off excess dough. Gently lift dough out of the mold or tap out onto a cookie sheet. Press remaining almond slivers into cookies to match the designs.
column4: Bake for 15 minutes in the preheated oven, just until the edges begin to darken. If your cookies are more than 1/2 inch thick, bake at 300 degrees F (150 degrees C) for up to 30 minutes. Cool cookies on wire racks to crisp. Store in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a month. The flavor will get better with age.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the butter, sugar, salt, nutmeg and egg yolk. Add the flour a little at a time until mixture is stiff.
column4: Place onto floured board and knead lightly until the dough begins to crack. Roll out 1/4 inch thickness and cut into desired shapes.
column5: Place on un-greased cookie sheet, decorate with colored sugar crystals and maraschino cherries.
column6: Bake for 10 minutes or until golden brown.

column2: Grease one 10x15 inch baking pan.
column3: In a large saucepan over medium heat, combine the sugar, corn syrup and water; bring to a boil, stirring constantly until sugar is dissolved.
column4: Continue to cook, without stirring until a candy thermometer reads 300 degrees F (150 degrees C).
column5: Remove from heat; stir in butter, vanilla and baking soda. Add cereal and cashews; pour into prepared pan and allow to cool. Break into pieces and store in air tight container.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease a 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: In 3-quart saucepan over very low heat, melt butter or margarine and chocolate, stirring the mixture constantly. Remove from heat, and stir the sugar into the chocolate. Allow the mixture to cool slightly. Beat in the eggs one at a time, mixing well after each, then stir in the vanilla. Combine the flour and salt; stir into the chocolate mixture. Fold in the walnuts. Spread the batter evenly into the prepared pan.
column4: Bake in oven 30 to 35 minutes. Brownies are done when toothpick inserted into center come out clean. Cool in pan on wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In large bowl mix all ingredients at medium speed, except walnuts and confectioners' sugar, occasionally scraping bowl with rubber spatula.
column4: Stir in walnuts.
column5: Drop mixture by rounded teaspoonfuls, 1/2 inch apart, onto cookie sheets.
column6: Bake 10 minutes. Remove cookies to wire racks; cool. Sprinkle with confectioners' sugar.

column2: In a medium bowl cream together the sugar and butter until smooth. Stir in the egg and vanilla. Combine the flour, baking powder and salt, gradually stir into the creamed mixture until all flour is absorbed. Shape dough into rolls about 1 1/2 inches in diameter. Wrap in waxed paper; refrigerate until firm, at least 4 hours or up to 1 week.
column3: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets. Unwrap chilled rolls and cut into 1/4 inch thick slices. Place cookies 1 inch apart onto the prepared cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven, until cookies are lightly browned. Remove from baking sheets immediately to cool on wire racks.

column2: In a medium bowl, cream together the butter and sugar. Stir in the eggs and vanilla. Combine the flour, baking powder, and salt; stir into the creamed mixture. Divide dough equally into three small bowls. Add almond extract and red food coloring to one portion; stir until thoroughly mixed. Mix chocolate into second bowl, and walnuts into the third bowl.
column3: Line a 9x5 inch loaf pan with waxed paper, and spread almond dough evenly in the bottom of the pan. Spread the walnut dough evenly over the almond layer, and top with chocolate dough layer. Cover layered dough with waxed paper, and place in the refrigerator until firm, about 4 hours.
column4: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Turn out chilled dough by inverting pan; peel off waxed paper. With sharp knife, cut dough lengthwise in half. Slice each half of dough crosswise into 1/4 inch slices. Place slices on cookie sheet one inch apart.
column5: Bake 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, until light brown. Remove to wire racks to cool.

column2: In a medium bowl, cream together the butter, white sugar and confectioners' sugar until light and fluffy. Mix in the lavender, mint and lemon zest. Combine the flour, cornstarch and salt; mix into the batter until well blended. Divide dough into two balls, wrap in plastic wrap and flatten to about 1inch thick. Refrigerate until firm, about 1hour.
column3: Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). On a lightly floured surface, roll the dough out to 1/4 inch thickness. Cut into shapes with cookie cutters. Cookie stamps will work well on these too. Place on cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 18 to 20 minutes in the preheated oven, just until cookies begin to brown at the edges. Cool for a few minutes on the baking sheets then transfer to wire racks to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together the butter, sugar and honey. Stir in the egg and peanut butter. Combine the flour and baking powder, mix into the peanut butter mixture. Shape dough into 1 1/2 inch balls. Place 3 inches apart on cookie sheets. Dip a fork into flour and press deeply across top of each cookie in a criss cross pattern.
column4: Bake for 15 minutes in the preheated oven, until cookies are lightly browned. Cool on wire racks. Store in tightly covered container.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a medium bowl, stir together the flour, baking powder, salt and confectioners' sugar. Stir in the butter and vanilla, and mix until a stiff dough forms. Pat dough into 9-inch round cake pan, and prick well with a fork. Sprinkle remaining sugar over dough.
column4: Bake for 30 to 35 minutes in the preheated oven, or until golden. Cut into wedges while warm. Cool on wire rack; separate cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together the butter, brown sugar and white sugar. Beat in the egg and vanilla. Combine the flour, salt and baking soda, stir into the creamed mixture. Finally, stir in the granola, raisins and peanuts. Drop dough by heaping teaspoonfuls onto greased cookie sheets, about 2 inches apart.
column4: Bake 12 to 15 minutes in the preheated oven, until cookies are lightly browned around edges. Remove from baking sheets to cool on wire racks.

column2: Combine sugar and shortening in a mixing bowl. Beat at low speed just until smooth. Mix in eggs, milk, and vanilla.
column3: In separate bowl, whisk flour, baking soda and salt. Pour into sugar mixture and blend until combined.
column4: Shape dough into a ball and wrap with waxed paper or plastic wrap. Refrigerate 2 to 3 hours until easy to handle.
column5: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets or line them with parchment paper.
column6: Roll out half of the dough at a time on a lightly floured surface. Keep the remaining dough refrigerated. For crisp cookies, roll paper-thin. For softer cookies, roll 1/8 to 1/4 inch thick.
column7: With floured cookie cutters, cut dough into various shapes. Re-roll dough trimmings into a ball, cover and refrigerate, and continue to cut shapes with chilled dough.
column8: Place cookies 1/2 inch apart on greased cookie sheets. To glaze, brush tops of cookies with heavy or whipping cream or with an egg white slightly beaten with 1 tablespoon of water.
column9: Sprinkle cookies with your choice of toppings; bake 8 minutes or until very light brown. Remove cookies and cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. In large bowl beat flour, oats, butter, wheat germ, orange peel and 1/2 cup of packed brown sugar at low speed until just mixed. Beat at medium speed for 2 minutes (mixture will look dry).
column3: With lightly floured hands, shape mixture into a ball, then pat into 8" by 8" baking pan.
column4: In a small bowl, beat eggs with a 1/4 cup of packed brown sugar, stir in almonds and coconut. Pour evenly over mixture in pan.
column5: Bake 35 minutes or until toothpick comes out clean. Cool in pan on rack. Cut into 12 pieces.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). In the microwave or over a double boiler, melt chocolate stirring frequently until smooth. Remove from heat.
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together the sugar and margarine until smooth. beat in the egg, melted chocolate and vanilla until well blended. Combine the flour, baking soda and salt; stir into the chocolate mixture alternately with the milk. Drop batter by heaping teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets, about 1 inch apart.
column4: Bake 8 to 10 minutes until cookies are puffy and slightly cracked on top. Let cool on wire racks.
column5: Top cookies with Chocolate Butter-Cream Frosting (see recipe) and garnish with pecans.

column2: In small bowl mix at medium speed, sugar, butter (softened), and salt until light and fluffy.
column3: Add melted chocolate, milk and vanilla extract, beating until well blended.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, mix together the shortening, white sugar and brown sugar until smooth. Stir in the egg and vanilla. Combine the flour, baking soda and salt; stir into the batter until blended. Mix in oats and walnuts. Drop by teaspoonfuls, 1 inch apart, onto greased cookie sheet.
column4: Bake for 12 minutes or until lightly browned. Immediately remove cookies to wire racks and allow to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease and flour cookie sheet. In 10-inch skillet over low heat, cook all ingredients. Stir until mixture is blended.
column3: Keep mixture warm over very low heat. Drop 4 heaping teaspoonfuls, 2 inches apart, on sheet. Bake 5 minutes.
column4: When cookies are golden, remove cookie sheet from oven. Loosen cookies from sheet with spatula.
column5: Roll each cookie around handle of wooden spoon and cool. If cookies get too hard, reheat in oven.
column6: Finish cooling on rack. Repeat steps 2-5, greasing and flouring cookie sheet each time.

column2: Preheat the oven to 250 degrees F (120 degrees C). Line cookie sheets with parchment paper.
column3: In a large bowl, whip egg whites with an electric mixer until stiff enough to make a mark through with a knife. Gradually sprinkle in the sugar, cinnamon and almond extract while continuing to mix on low speed. Fold in toasted coconut by hand. Spoon or scoop onto the prepared cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 20 to 25 minutes in the preheated oven, until cookies are dry and peel of the paper easily. Cool on wire racks and store in an airtight container at room temperature.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together the butter, brown sugar and white sugar. Beat in the egg and vanilla. Combine the flour, salt and baking soda, stir into the creamed mixture. Finally, stir in the granola, chocolate chips and peanuts. Drop dough by heaping teaspoonfuls onto greased cookie sheets, about 2 inches apart.
column4: Bake 12 to 15 minutes in the preheated oven, until cookies are lightly browned around edges. Remove cookies to wire racks and allow to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together the butter, brown sugar and white sugar. Beat in the egg and vanilla. Combine the flour, salt and baking soda, stir into the creamed mixture. Finally, stir in the granola, dates and peanuts. Drop dough by heaping teaspoonfuls onto greased cookie sheets, about 2 inches apart.
column4: Bake 12 to 15 minutes until cookies are lightly browned around edges. Remove cookies to wire racks and allow to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F. In large bowl, with mixer at medium speed, combine 1 cup flour and the next six ingredients until well mixed.
column3: In small bowl, mix 3 tablespoons of flour and the remaining ingredients until well mixed (mixture will be crumbly).
column4: Drop chocolate dough by teaspoonfuls, 1 inch apart, onto cookie sheet. Top each with 1/2 teaspoon of peanut-butter dough. Dip a fork into flour and press gently across top of each cookie.
column5: Bake 12 minutes or until firm. Move cookies to racks; cool.

column2: In a medium bowl, cream together the butter and sugar. Beat in the egg yolks, then stir in the milk. Combine the flour, cinnamon, baking powder and salt, stir into the wet ingredients until well blended. Wrap dough and chill for at least 2 hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column4: On a lightly floured surface, roll the dough out to 1/4 inch thickness. Cut out cookies using a 2 1/4 inch cookie cutter. Place cookies 1 inch apart onto a cookie sheet.
column5: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, until lightly browned. Remove cookies to wire racks and cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease an 11x7 inch baking pan.
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together the butter and sugar. Beat in the egg and lemon peel. In another bowl, stir together the flour, almonds, cinnamon and cloves. Gradually stir the dry ingredients into the creamed mixture. The dough will be stiff, so you may need to knead it by hand to get it to come together. Press half of the dough into the bottom of the prepared pan.
column4: Press half of the dough into the bottom of the prepared pan. Spread the preserves over the crust. On a lightly floured surface, roll the remaining dough into long rope about 1/2 inch in diameter. Place lengths of the rope across the top of the jam in a lattice pattern over the preserves.
column5: Bake 40 minutes or until top is golden. Cool in pan on wire rack. Cut into 2 inch by 1inch bars.

column2: In a large bowl, cream together the butter and brown sugar until smooth. Beat in the egg and molasses. Combine the flour, ground ginger, baking soda, and salt; stir into the molasses mixture using a wooden spoon. Mix in the fresh and crystallized gingers. Cover, and refrigerate dough for at least 2 hours, or overnight.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Shape dough into 1 inch balls, and place about 2 inches apart onto ungreased cookie sheet.
column4: Bake for 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or until lightly browned. Cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 275 degrees F(135 degrees C). Grease 15 1/2 by 10 1/2 inch jelly-roll pan.
column3: Sift the flour, set aside. In a medium bowl, cream the sugar and butter. Add the vanilla and egg yolk; mix well. Stir in the flour. Spread batter evenly into the prepared jellyroll pan.
column4: In a cup, beat egg white slightly; brush over top of dough and sprinkle with nuts.
column5: Bake one hour and 10 minutes or until golden. Immediately cut into 50 bars and remove from pan to cool on wire racks. Store in tightly covered container for at least 3 days before serving.

column2: In large bowl, mix all ingredients at medium speed until well mixed. Cover and refrigerate for about one hour.
column3: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F. Use part of dough at a time, keeping the rest refrigerated.
column4: Using a cookie press fitted with a bar-plate tip, press dough in long strips, about one inch apart down the length of the cookie sheets.
column5: With a sharp knife, cut each strip into 2 1/2 inch pieces. Leave pieces in place. Bake 8 minutes or until light golden. Do not to overbake.
column6: Remove from oven and immediately cut again between cookies to separate any cookies which are still joined together.
column7: Move cookies to wire rack, and allow cookies to cool completely. Store tightly covered.

column2: Cream shortening and sugar together. Add eggs and mix thoroughly.
column3: Stir in applesauce and coffee.
column4: In separate bowl, mix remaining ingredients together. Add to applesauce mixture and blend thoroughly. Chill at least 2 hours.
column5: Heat oven to 400 degrees F. Lightly grease cookie sheet. Drop rounded tablespoonfuls of dough onto cookie sheet about 2 inches apart.
column6: Bake 9 to 12 minutes. Cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F and grease cookie sheets.
column3: Cream butter.
column4: Add eggs, sugar and vanilla. Mix well.
column5: Add sifted dry ingredients. Stir until well blended.
column6: Cut dough into pieces about 2 inches by 2 inches. Dip in white sugar. Roll dough into palm of hand until round. Dip in brown sugar and place on greased cookie sheet about 2 inches apart.
column7: Bake at 400 degrees F for about 10 minutes or until light brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C.) Combine the flour, baking soda, and salt; set aside.
column3: In a medium bowl, cream the butter, brown sugar, and white sugar until smooth. Beat in the egg and vanilla until light and fluffy. Gradually blend in the flour mixture, then mix in the coconut. Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto an ungreased cookie sheet. Cookies should be about 3 inches apart.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or until lightly toasted. Cool on wire racks.

column2: Melt the butterscotch chips over low heat and add peanut butter.
column3: Stir in cornflakes.
column4: Drop on waxed paper and let cool.

column2: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a medium bowl, mix together 1/2 cup of brown sugar, butter, 1/2 cup of flour and oats until crumbly. Press into the bottom of a 9 inch square pan. Bake for 15 minutes in the preheated oven.
column4: In the same bowl, mix together the eggs, 1 cup of brown sugar, 1/2 cup flour, salt, baking powder and vanilla until well blended. Stir in the raisins, coconut and cherries, adding a little bit of the cherry juice to keep it from becoming stiff. Spread over the baked crust in the pan.
column5: Bake for 30 minutes in the preheated oven, or until firm and lightly browned. Cool and cut into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Mix all ingredients. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake until lightly brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Cream together the butter and sugar. Add eggs, molasses and vanilla.
column4: In a separate bowl, combine the flour, cinnamon, and baking soda. Gradually add to the cream mixture.
column5: Stir in oatmeal, raisins, nuts and chocolate chips.
column6: Drop by teaspoonfuls onto greased cookie sheet. Bake for 12 minutes or until light brown.

column2: Simmer raisins and water over medium heat until raisins are plump, about 15 minutes. Drain raisins, reserving the liquid. Add enough water to reserved liquid to measure 1/2 cup.
column3: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F.
column4: Mix the shortening, sugar, eggs and vanilla thoroughly. Stir in reserved liquid.
column5: Blend in the remaining ingredients.
column6: Drop by rounded teaspoons about 2 inches apart onto ungreased baking sheets. Bake 8 to 10 minutes or until light brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. In a large bowl, mix all ingredients until well blended.
column3: Drop on greased cookie sheets and bake for 12 to 15 minutes.

column2: Sift flour with soda and salt.
column3: In a separate bowl, cream margarine, peanut butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in egg and vanilla.
column4: Fold in flour mixture until just blended. Shape into rolls about 3 inches in diameter. Wrap in wax paper and chill in refrigerator overnight or until firm.
column5: Slice rolls 1/8" thick. Make Halloween faces using peanuts, raisins, chocolate or butterscotch chips, or red candies for eyes, nose and mouth. Use colored coconut or chocolate sprinkles for hair.
column6: Bake on an ungreased cookie sheet at 375 degrees F for about 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Blend flour, butter, sugar and cream cheese.
column3: Press into sandbakkel tins.
column4: Melt butter over low heat. Remove from heat and add eggs, chopped nuts, brown sugar, vanilla and salt, blending well.
column5: Fill tins about 3/4 full with mixture and bake until filling is well set and crust is brown.

column2: In a large bowl, beat the confectioners' sugar with butter until smooth. Stir in the egg and vanilla. Combine the flour, baking soda and cream of tartar; mix into the batter until well blended. Cover and refrigerate dough for 2 to 3 hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F. Divide dough in half and roll 3/16 inch thick on floured surface. Cut dough with cookie cutters and sprinkle with white sugar. Place cookies onto greased baking sheets.
column4: Bake for 7 to 8 minutes in the preheated oven, or until delicately golden.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour a 9x13 inch pan.
column3: In a medium bowl, stir together the flour, 2 tablespoons of sugar, and salt. Cut in the shortening until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Combine the egg yolks and 1/2 cup of milk, stir into the flour mixture.
column4: On a lightly floured surface, roll half of the dough out to the size of the prepared pan. Cover the inside of the pan with the dough. Spread dough with a light coating of egg white. Fill with sliced apples and sprinkle sugar and cinnamon on top. Roll out remaining dough and place on top of apples. Brush with a light coating of egg white.
column5: Bake for 35 to 40 minutes in the preheated oven, until the crust is golden. In a small bowl, beat together the confectioners' sugar, salt, vanilla and milk until smooth. Drizzle over cooled bars, cut into squares.

column2: Melt the butter or margarine and mix all ingredients in the order given.
column3: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 20 to 30 minutes in a 9 x 13 inch greased pan.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease and flour 13 x 9 x 2 inch pan.
column3: Mix sugar, nuts, melted butter and cinnamon until crumbly and set aside.
column4: In a separate bowl, cream together brown sugar, shortening and egg.
column5: Add flour, soda and salt to creamed mixture alternately with sour cream. Lastly, stir in rhubarb.
column6: Pour mixture into pan and sprinkle with reserved topping.
column7: Bake at 350 degrees F for 45 to 50 minutes. Cut in squares and serve warm or cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease two 9 x 13-inch pans.
column3: Combine the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon and set aside. In a separate bowl, mix the pumpkin, vegetable oil, eggs, and sugar. Add the flour mixture and stir just until combined. Mix in the walnuts.
column4: Spread the batter into the prepared pan and bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean, about 25 minutes. Cool on wire rack and frost bars with Cream Cheese Frosting.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Toast the almonds in a shallow pan for 12 to 15 minutes, shaking the pan a few times, until almonds are lightly colored. Set aside to cool.
column3: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line 2 or 3 cookie sheets with aluminum foil, shiny side up.
column4: In a large bowl, stir together the flour, baking soda, baking powder, salt and sugar. Place 1/2 cup of these dry ingredients into the bowl of a food processor. Add about a half cup of the toasted almonds and process for about 30 seconds.
column5: Return the mixture to the bowl of dry ingredients and stir in the remaining almonds and chocolate chips. In a large measuring cup, beat the eggs, vanilla and whiskey with a fork to blend. Stir into the dry ingredients until moistened. Wet your hands and divide the dough into four portions. Keeping hands wet, form each quarter into strips about 9 inches long, 2 inches wide and 1/2 inch high. Round the ends. Place two strips crosswise on each of the cookie sheets.
column6: Bake for 25 minutes in the preheated oven. If baking more that one sheet at a time, reverse the sheets top to bottom halfway through cooking time.
column7: Using a metal spatula remove the slabs from cookie sheets and let cool for 20 minutes on cutting board. Reduce oven temperature to 275 degrees F.
column8: With a serrated knife, carefully cut at an angle into slices about 1/2 inch wide. Place the slices, cut side down, onto cookie sheets.
column9: Bake 25 to 30 minutes in the preheated oven, until the biscotti is crispy and lightly toasted.
column10: Turn oven off and open the oven door, allowing the biscotti to cool in the oven. When cool, store in an airtight container.

column2: Mix flour, sugar and salt. Cut in butter, as for pastry.
column3: Soften yeast in water. Combine milk, egg yolk and softened yeast. Add to flour mixture and mix well.
column4: Cover dough and refrigerate for at least 2 hours.
column5: Place dough on a lightly floured cutting board and knead lightly. Cover with a cloth and allow to rest for 10 minutes.
column6: Roll dough into a rectangle, 10x18 inches, and brush with soft butter. Mix 1/2 cup sugar and 2 teaspoons cinnamon and sprinkle evenly over dough. Roll as for jelly roll, sealing the edge. The roll should be 18 inches long.
column7: Cut dough into 1-inch slices.
column8: Mix remaining sugar and cinnamon on a large square of waxed paper or aluminum foil. Place slices, one at a time, on sugar mixture and roll into 5-inch balls.
column9: Sprinkle nuts on top and press gently.
column10: Place dough on ungreased cookie sheets, brush with melted butter and sprinkle with about 1 teaspoon of the sugar-cinnamon mixture.
column11: Bake immediately in a preheated 400 degree oven about 12 minutes. Cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
column3: Melt butter over low heat.
column4: Pour butter into 13 x 9 inch pan. Sprinkle graham cracker crumbs over butter.
column5: Pour condensed milk over crumbs. Sprinkle chocolate and peanut butter chips over milk mixture and press down firmly.
column6: Bake 25 to 30 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease and flour 13 x 9 inch pan.
column3: Melt caramels with 1/3 cup condensed milk.
column4: In a separate bowl, combine cake mix with melted butter and 1/2 cup of condensed milk. Stir well.
column5: Spread 1/2 of the cake mix mixture in pan and bake for 6 to 8 minutes.
column6: Remove from oven and cover with caramel, chips and nuts. Put remaining cake mix on top. Bake for another 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease 13 x 9 inch baking pan.
column3: Melt shortening over low heat. Add eggs and sugar, mixing well.
column4: In a separate bowl, mix together flour, baking powder and salt until well blended. Add to the egg mixture.
column5: Spread batter into baking pan. Sprinkle thickly with cinnamon and chopped nuts. Bake until light brown, about 10 to 15 minutes. Cut into squares and remove from pan immediately.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Melt the chocolate squares and butter or margarine in a double boiler. Stir well and remove from heat.
column4: Cream sugar and eggs in medium sized bowl until thick and creamy. Mix in vanilla and melted chocolate.
column5: Mix in the flour, baking powder and salt until well blended. Stir in chocolate chips and nuts.
column6: Drop by teaspoonfuls about 1 1/2 inches apart on cookie sheet. Bake for 8 minutes or until tops crackle and look shiny. Cool 3 to 5 minutes. Remove to racks; cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F. Grease and flour a 16 x 11 x 1 inch pan.
column3: Cream butter or margarine and sugar. Separate egg, and set aside egg white. Add egg yolk and sifted dry ingredients.
column4: Pour batter into pan.
column5: Beat egg white until foamy and brush sparingly over batter (not all egg white will be used.) Sprinkle chopped nuts over top. Bake for 30 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, cream sugars, butter and shortening. Beat in eggs and vanilla until well blended.
column4: Mix in sifted flours, salt and baking soda and stir well.
column5: Stir in remaining ingredients.
column6: Drop in teaspoon size balls on greased baking sheet about 2 inches apart. Bake 8 minutes or until edges are brown.

column2: In a large bowl, cream the margarine, butter and both sugars until light and fluffy.
column3: Add the eggs, milk and vanilla and beat until well blended.
column4: Sift the flour, baking powder, baking soda and salt together and add to the butter mixture. Stir just until blended. Stir in the oats until well blended. Fold in the chocolate and walnuts.
column5: Cover and refrigerate the dough for at least 1 hour.
column6: Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Grease cookie sheets.
column7: Take a teaspoonful (for small cookies) or a tablespoonful (for large cookies) of dough and shape the dough into balls. Flatten slightly into rounded disks. Place 2 inches apart on the cookie sheets and bake until the edges are slightly browned, about 10 minutes.
column8: Remove from the oven and let cool on the sheets for about 10 minutes. Remove to wire racks to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F and grease cookie sheets.
column3: In separate bowl, sift together flour, baking powder, baking soda and salt. Set aside.
column4: In a large bowl, cream together shortening and both sugars until light and fluffy, using electric mixer at medium speed.
column5: Add eggs, one at a time, beating well after each. Blend in vanilla.
column6: Gradually add dry ingredients to creamed mixture, mixing well with spoon.
column7: Stir in oats, dates and walnuts.
column8: Drop dough by teaspoonfuls, about 2 inches apart, on cookie sheet.
column9: Bake for 8 minutes or until lightly browned. Remove from cookie sheets to cool on racks.

column2: Melt chocolate squares and cooking oil in a saucepan.
column3: Let cool and pour into mixing bowl. Add sugar, eggs and vanilla, mixing until well blended.
column4: Sift dry ingredients together and gradually add to chocolate/egg mixture, stirring well.
column5: Stir in nuts, cover and place in refrigerator overnight.
column6: Preheat oven to 375 degrees and grease cookie sheets.
column7: Shape dough into small balls, about an inch in diameter. Roll in powdered sugar and place about 2 inches apart on cookie sheet .
column8: Bake for 8 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In large mixing bowl, cream together eggs, butter and brown sugar. Mix baking soda with the milk and add to mixture. Stir in orange juice and bourbon. In a small bowl, lightly toss candied fruits with a small amount of flour until fruits separate easily. Add to mixture. Add flour, dates and pecans. Stir until well blended. Drop by teaspoons about 2 inches apart onto cookie sheet.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven. Allow cookies to cool on baking sheet for 5 minutes before removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, mash the bananas. Stir in oats, dates, oil, and vanilla. Mix well, and allow to sit for 15 minutes. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto an ungreased cookie sheet.
column4: Bake for 20 minutes in the preheated oven, or until lightly brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, beat together all ingredients.
column4: Drop by teaspoon on cookie sheets and flatten slightly with a fork.
column5: Bake for 10 minutes or until brown at the edges. Be careful to not overbake. Cool and store in an airtight container.

column2: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, mix together the butter, oil, white sugar, and confectioners' sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla. Combine the flour, baking soda, and cream of tartar. Stir into the sugar mixture until just combined. Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto the prepared cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in preheated oven, or until bottoms are lightly browned. Remove from baking sheets to cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Separate egg, reserving egg white. Cream butter or margarine, sugar, and egg yolk.
column4: Add vanilla, flour and salt, mixing well.
column5: Shape dough into balls. Roll in egg white, then walnuts. Place on cookie sheets about 2 inches apart. Bake for 5 minutes.
column6: Remove cookies from oven. With thumb, dent each cookie. Put jelly or preserves in each thumbprint. Bake for another 8 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, cream the shortening and sugar. Blend in peanut butter, salt, egg, vanilla and flour. Mix well.
column4: Shape dough into balls about 1 inch in diameter. Press your thumb into the center of each ball, creating a 1/2 inch depression.
column5: Bake for 12 to 15 minutes and cool on a rack. Fill the centers with a tart jelly/fruit preserve.

column2: Melt chocolate over low heat. Remove from heat and add cooking oil and granulated sugar.
column3: Add one egg at a time, mixing well.
column4: Add vanilla, flour, baking powder and salt; mixing well after each additional ingredient.
column5: Chill for several hours or overnight.
column6: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column7: Roll dough into balls about 1/2 inch in diameter. Roll balls in powdered sugar. Place about 2 inches apart on cookie sheets. Bake 10 to 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, combine pudding mix (dry), biscuit mix and sugar.
column4: Melt butter or margarine over low heat. Remove from heat and mix in eggs, milk, and vanilla until well blended. Add to dry mixture. Stir in coconut and mix well.
column5: Drop by rounded teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheet and bake 12 to 14 minutes. Remove from oven and let cool.

column2: In a large bowl, cream the butter. Add in cocoa, salt and boiling water, stirring until smooth.
column3: Add powdered sugar and beat until frosting reaches a spreadable consistency. If frosting seems too thick, add water. If it seems too thin, add powdered sugar.
column4: Spread on cooled cookies, such as Frosted Chocolate Walnut Goodies.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour an 8x8-inch baking pan.
column3: In a large bowl, mix melted butter with sugar and egg. Mix in flour, baking soda, and cinnamon, and then stir in apple and walnuts. Spread batter into prepared pan.
column4: Bake for approximately 40 minutes, or until a small knife inserted in the center comes out clean.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F.
column3: Mix together brown sugar and margarine until light and fluffy.
column4: Beat in eggs and vanilla.
column5: Mix in the rest of the ingredients, except for powdered sugar and milk. Stir until well blended.
column6: Drop on cookie sheet and bake 9 to 12 minutes.
column7: Mix powdered sugar and milk in small bowl and drizzle over cooled cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease and flour 9 x 13 inch pan.
column3: Cook first six ingredients over low heat until well blended. Set aside to cool.
column4: In a separate bowl, mix together brown sugar, oatmeal, baking soda, butter, flour and salt until crumbly. Press half of mixture into pan.
column5: Pour cooked mixture over crust and crumble the other half of crust over the top.
column6: Bake for 20 minutes.

column2: Cream butter and sugars in large bowl until light and fluffy. Stir in egg and vanilla and mix well.
column3: Sift dry ingredients and add to creamed mixture. Stir in undrained pineapple and nuts until well blended. Refrigerate dough for 2 hours.
column4: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column5: Drop dough by teaspoonfuls about 2 inches apart onto cookie sheets. Bake for 8 to 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Soak raisins in hot water and set aside.
column3: In large bowl, sift flour with soda, salt and spices. Blend in rolled oats, sugar and nuts. In a separate bowl, beat eggs with fork and add oil, vanilla, and raisins and water mixture. Pour into dry ingredients, stirring until well mixed. Drop by teaspoonfuls about two inches apart onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake 10 to 13 minutes in the preheated oven, until the edges are golden.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease an 11x7 inch pan.
column3: In large mixing bowl, mix shortening, brown sugar, vanilla, lemon juice and banana until well blended.
column4: Sift together the flour, baking powder and salt. Add to the banana mixture; stir until well blended. Stir in chopped nuts. Pour into the prepared pan.
column5: Bake for 30 to 35 minutes in the preheated oven.
column6: While warm, cut into bars and remove from pan. Combine powdered sugar and cinnamon. Gently roll warm bars in sugar-cinnamon mixture.

column2: Sift flour into large mixing bowl. Resift with salt, soda, baking powder and cinnamon. In a separate bowl, cream the butter or margarine with sugar until fluffy. Add eggs one at a time and mix well. Add butter mixture to dry ingredients alternately with sour cream, mixing until smooth after each addition. Add vanilla. Wrap dough in waxed paper and chill until firm enough to roll, about 2 hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F 150 degrees C. Roll dough on floured surface to about 1/4 inch thick. Cut with large cookie cutter; place on ungreased cookie sheet.
column4: Sprinkle with sugar and bake for 10 to 12 minutes or until lightly browned.

column2: Preheat oven to 275 degrees F (135 degrees C).
column3: Sift together the cake flour, all-purpose flour, and semolina and set aside. Beat the butter for at least 10 minutes until it is fluffy. Then beat 2 more minutes while sprinkling in the blossom water and confectioners' sugar. Fold in the flour mixture gradually. Then refrigerate the soft dough in covered bowl for about 10 minutes.
column4: On a lightly floured surface, roll or pat the dough out to 1/4 inch thickness, and cut into 1 inch sided diamonds and place them 1/2 inch apart on an ungreased baking sheet. Then place an almond in the center of each cookie.
column5: Back 35 to 40 minutes in the preheated oven. Do not over bake. Let the cookies cool for at least an hour. The are best served after they have cooled for several hours.

column2: Preheat oven 350 degrees F (150 degrees C).
column3: Mix the flour, sugar, salt, and nuts together in a medium bowl. Stir in the vanilla. Either with your hands (my favorite way) or with a pastry cutter, work the butter into the flour mixture until it becomes a ball. Shape the dough into 24 one inch flat circles, and place on a cookie sheet.
column4: Bake for 30 minutes or until they are lightly browned. After they have cooled on a rack, dust them heavily with confectioners' sugar.

column2: In a large bowl, cream the shortening, and sugar. Separate the eggs and refrigerate the whites. Mix in the egg yolks and almond extract. Dissolve the baking soda in the water, and stir into the mixture along with the milk. Combine the flour, cream of tartar and salt; gradually stir into the sugar mixture. Fold in the almonds.
column3: Roll the dough into a log about 2 inches in diameter. Wrap in waxed paper and refrigerate for at least 4 hours.
column4: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F. Cut the dough into 1/8 inch thick slices and place 2 inches apart on ungreased cookie sheets. Brush with egg whites and sprinkle with sugar.
column5: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes, or until lightly colored. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch pan.
column3: In a medium bowl, combine the flour, baking soda, baking powder and salt. In a separate bowl, cream the shortening and brown sugar. Mix in the egg, orange juice and zest until well blended. Gradually add the dry ingredients, stirring constantly. Stir in the butterscotch chips and coconut. Pour the dough into greased baking pan.
column4: Bake for 25 to 30 minutes, until top is golden brown. Let cool before cutting into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F.
column3: In a large bowl, cream the butter, and sugar. Mix well.
column4: In a separate bowl, beat eggs and add to the butter mixture. Stir in the caraway seeds and flour. Mix well.
column5: Roll out the dough on a floured surface to 1/4 inch thickness. Cut into 1 inch squares (or other shapes) and place at least 1 inch apart on cookie sheets.
column6: Bake for 12 to 15 minutes...watch closely...until lightly colored. Cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x9 inch baking pan.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, cream together the shortening, and sugar until smooth. Mix in 1 cup of flour. Spread into the bottom of the prepared pan. This is the crust.
column4: Bake for 15 minutes in the preheated oven, until firm.
column5: In a separate bowl, beat the eggs and brown sugar together until thick and pale. Add the brandy and mix well. Combine the remaining flour, baking powder and salt; stir into the egg mixture. Mix in apples and walnuts. Spread the filling over the hot crust.
column6: Bake for 30 minutes in the preheated oven, or until filling is set. Cool completely before cutting into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the shortening and sugar. Beat in the eggs until well blended. Combine the flour, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt; stir into the sugar mixture until well blended. Fold in the walnuts, oats and apples. Drop dough by spoonfuls about 2 inches onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 12 to 15 minutes in the preheated oven. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 13x9 inch baking pan.
column3: Melt chocolate in the microwave or in a bowl over a pan of simmering water. Stir frequently until smooth. Remove from heat, and let cool.
column4: Cream together the shortening and sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, stirring constantly until well blended. In a separate bowl, mix together applesauce, melted chocolate and vanilla. Add to the egg mixture, stirring until smooth.
column5: Combine the flour, baking powder, cinnamon and salt; gradually stir into the batter. Fold in chopped walnuts. Spread evenly into the prepared pan.
column6: Bake for 20 to 25 minutes in the preheated oven, or until a toothpick inserted in the middle of cake comes out clean. Let cool in pan before cutting.

column2: In large bowl, cream together the shortening, sugar, egg, milk, and vanilla. Stir until well blended. In a separate bowl, mix the flour, baking powder and salt. Add to egg mixture and mix well. Cover and chill for 4 hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease baking sheets.
column4: Roll out dough on a floured surface to a 1/4 inch thickness. Cut out cookies with round cookie cutter and place 1 inch apart on cookie sheets.
column5: Bake 18 to 20 minutes until lightly colored. Cool on wire racks.

column2: In a small bowl, combine raisins and rum. Use enough rum to completely cover raisins. Let stand for 30 minutes or up to overnight. Drain the raisins and transfer to another bowl. Add the flour and toss, thoroughly coating raisins.
column3: Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degree C).
column4: In a medium bowl, cream the shortening, and sugar. Add eggs one at a time, mixing well. Add the raisin/flour mixture and stir until well blended.
column5: Drop the dough by spoonfuls 2 inches apart onto cookie sheets and bake 4 to 6 minutes, until lightly colored. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: In a large bowl, combine the flours, baking soda, cream of tartar, cloves, nutmeg, cinnamon and salt. In another bowl, cream the shortening, and fructose. Beat in the eggs, lemon zest and dry ingredients. Mix until well blended. Cover dough and refrigerate for 24 hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets. Drop dough by spoonfuls 1 1/2 inches apart onto cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes until lightly colored. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease and flour a 9 inch square pan.
column3: Sift flour, baking powder and salt together. Set aside.
column4: In a medium size bowl, combine sugar, egg, butter, and vanilla. Beat until smooth. Stir in flour mixture. Stir in 1/2 cup nuts. Pour into jelly roll pan. Bake for 15 minutes.
column5: Remove from oven; while hot, arrange marshmallows and remaining nuts and chocolate chips on top of bars. Return to oven for 2 minutes or just until chocolate is softened. Swirl and cool until chocolate is set. Cut into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In large bowl, combine oil, bananas, and vanilla until smooth. Mix in oats, oat bran cereal and salt. Fold in apricots and almonds. Drop dough by spoonfuls 2 inches apart on cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 20 to 25 minutes in the preheated oven, until edges are light brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease 9 inch square baking pan.
column3: In large mixing bowl, cream shortening and brown sugar. Add eggs, pineapple and rum, mix well. In separate bowl, mix together the flour, baking powder and salt. Slowly add to egg mixture and beat until well blended. Blend in coconut and spread batter evenly in bottom of pan.
column4: Bake 25 to 30 minutes. Let cool on wire rack before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease 9 inch square baking pan.
column3: To make crust: In medium mixing bowl, combine flour and salt. Add in shortening until mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Press dough into baking pan and bake for 15 minutes.
column4: To make the filling: In large mixing bowl, beat sugar, eggs and bourbon. Slowly add in flour and salt, mixing well. Fold in coconut and pecans.
column5: Spread filling over hot crust. Bake 12 to 15 minutes, or until lightly browned. Let cool on wire racks before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Melt the butter over low heat. Pour 2 tablespoons of the butter into the bottom of a 9x13 inch baking pan. Layer 3 sheets of the phyllo dough in the pan. Trim dough to fit. Sprinkle 2 tablespoons of pecans over the phyllo dough. Layer 3 more sheets of dough, brush generously with the melted butter, and sprinkle with 2 tablespoons of pecans. Continue dough -butter- pecan layers until pan is 3/4 full.
column4: With a sharp knife, score phyllo dough to form diamonds. Press a clove at each end of the diamonds. Pour remaining butter over the dough.
column5: Bake 45 to 50 minutes in the preheated oven, until golden brown.
column6: Meanwhile, combine the sugar, water and cinnamon stick in a medium saucepan, and bring to boil, stirring constantly. Simmer for 10 minutes.
column7: Add the honey and simmer for 2 minutes longer. Remove from heat and discard cinnamon stick. Pour honey mixture over hot baklava. Let cool on wire racks. Cut into diamonds.
