column8: Pour honey mixture over hot baklava. Let cool on wire racks. Cut into diamonds.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease 8 inch square baking pan.
column3: To make the crust: In a large bowl, cream shortening and brown sugar. Gradually blend in flour and walnuts. Mixture will be crumbly.
column4: Set aside one cup of crust mixture. Press the rest of the mixture into the bottom of baking pan. Bake for 15 minutes.
column5: To make filling: in a large bowl, beat the cream cheese and sugar. Add in egg, milk, lemon juice and vanilla until well blended.
column6: Spread the filling over warm crust. Sprinkle top with remaining crust mixture. Bake for another 25 to 28 minutes. Let cool on wire racks before cutting.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease a 9 inch square baking pan.
column3: To make crust: In a large bowl, cream shortening, white sugar and brown sugar. Separate egg and beat in yolk and vanilla, stirring until well blended. Slowly add in the flour and blend well. Mixture will be stiff.
column4: Press dough evenly into baking pan. Bake for 18 to 20 minutes, or until top is golden brown.
column5: Melt the chocolate in a double boiler over low heat. Spread the melted chocolate over warm crust. Sprinkle top with almonds. Let cool on wire rack before cutting.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column3: In large bowl, cream together the butter and sugar. Beat in the egg, amaretto, and almonds. Gradually mix in the flour until well blended. Drop by teaspoonfuls 2 inches apart on ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake 5 to 8 minutes in the preheated oven, or until cookies are lightly colored.

column2: Grind apricots in food processor or blender.
column3: In small bowl, combine flour, baking powder, spices and salt.
column4: In a large bowl, cream the shortening and sugar. Dissolve baking soda in warm water and add to creamed mixture, beating until smooth. Beat in the egg.
column5: Slowly blend in the dry ingredients, mixing until well blended. Fold in the apricots, raisins and pecans. Cover and chill for one hour.
column6: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets.
column7: Drop dough by teaspoonfuls two inches apart. Bake for 18 to 20 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9-inch square baking pan.
column3: Melt shortening and cocoa in the top of a double boiler over low heat. Stir occasionally until shortening is melted. Remove from heat. Stir in sugar, eggs and vanilla until well blended. Slowly add in flour and mix well. Spread batter evenly in pan.
column4: Bake 18 to 20 minutes, until toothpick inserted in the center of brownies comes out clean. Let cool before cutting.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9 inch square baking dish.
column3: To make the crust: Cream shortening, sugar, one egg, milk and almond extract in a large bowl. Mix in flour and baking powder, stirring constantly. Spread crust evenly in baking pan. Top with blueberries.
column4: To make the topping: In a medium bowl, beat two eggs, and cream cheese until smooth. Stir in powdered sugar and almond extract. Spread over blueberries.
column5: Bake 55 to 60 minutes, or until firm to the touch. Cool in pan before cutting.

column2: In a large mixing bowl, cream the shortening, sugar, egg, milk, almond extract and lemon zest. Mix well after the addition of each ingredient. Combine the flour, baking powder and salt; blend into the sugar mixture. Fold in the blueberries. Cover and chill for 4 hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F. Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets, about 1 1/2 inches apart.
column4: Bake 12 to 15 minutes in the preheated oven. Let the cookies cool on the baking sheets for a few minutes before transferring to wire racks to cool completely.

column2: In a large mixing bowl, cream the butter and brown sugar. Beat in egg, heavy cream, and vanilla.
column3: Slowly add in flour, baking powder and salt. Mix until well blended. If dough seems too dry, add in water, 1/2 teaspoon at a time.
column4: Cover and refrigerate for 4 hours.
column5: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F.
column6: Roll out dough on a floured surface to a thickness of 1/8 of an inch. Cut with cookie cutters and place 1 1/2 inches apart on cookie sheets.
column7: Bake 8 to 10 minutes, until lightly colored.

column2: In a large bowl, cream butter, brown sugar and egg. Mix until well blended.
column3: Slowly add flour and salt and mix well. Cover and refrigerate for at least one hour.
column4: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F.
column5: Roll one inch pieces of dough into balls and place 2 inches apart on cookie sheets. Flatten balls with the bottom of a glass dipped in flour. Press a pecan into top of dough.
column6: Bake 10 to 12 minutes until lightly colored.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease an 8 inch square baking pan.
column3: In large bowl, cream the shortening, brown sugar, vanilla and eggs. In a separate bowl, mix together the flour, walnuts, baking powder and salt. Slowly add to egg mixture, stirring until well blended. Spread dough evenly into the prepared pan.
column4: Bake for 20 to 24 minutes, or until inserted toothpick comes out clean.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F(175 degrees C). Grease a 9 inch square baking pan.
column3: Mix shortening and cake mix until smooth. Stir in 1/3 cup of the milk and peanuts; mix well. Mixture will be crumbly.
column4: Press half of mixture into baking pan and bake for 8 minutes.
column5: Over low heat, melt caramels and remaining 1/3 cup evaporated milk in the top of a double boiler or in a glass bowl in the microwave. Stir frequently until melted and smooth. Sprinkle chocolate chips over warm dough. Spread the caramel mixture over the chips. Sprinkle the remaining cake mix mixture over the top.
column6: Bake for 18 to 20 minutes in the preheated oven, until the top is golden. Let cool before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: In large bowl, cream shortening, eggs and brown sugar. Add in milk and vanilla extract and mix well. Gradually add in flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. Mix until well blended.
column4: Fold in chocolate chips and stir until chips are evenly distributed in dough. Spread dough in pan and bake 25 to 30 minutes. Let cool before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9 inch square baking pan.
column3: In a large bowl, mix together the graham cracker crumbs, sweetened condensed milk, chocolate chips and coconut until well blended. Press dough evenly into the prepared baking pan.
column4: Bake for 30 minutes. Let cool before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
column3: Melt shortening over low heat. Pour into 9 inch baking pan. Layer bread crumbs evenly in bottom of pan.
column4: Layer coconut, chocolate chips, butterscotch chips and nuts over bread crumbs. Drizzle condensed milk over top.
column5: Bake 25 to 30 minutes. Let cool before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: In large bowl, cream the shortening, brown sugar, eggs and vanilla extract. Slowly blend in flour, baking powder, and salt. Mix until well blended. Fold in chocolate chips, walnuts and coconut. Spread the mixture evenly in pan.
column4: Bake 20 to 25 minutes. Let cool before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line 2 cookie sheets with parchment paper.
column3: In small bowl, combine sugar and cornstarch.
column4: In a large metal bowl, combine egg whites with almond extract. Place the bowl over a pan of simmering water. Stir in the sugar mixture. Whip with an electric mixer until thick and stiff, about 15 minutes. Fold in coconut. Remove from heat, and let cool for 5 minutes.
column5: Place mixture in a pastry bag fitted with a large star tip. Press out dough about 1 1/2 inches apart onto cookie sheets. Place 1/2 a cherry into the top of each cookie.
column6: Bake for 18 to 20 minutes or until lightly colored. Let cool on baking sheets for a minute before removing to wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease 2 baking sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, cream the shortening, brown sugar and eggs. Stir in the coffee. Gradually blend in flour, baking soda, cinnamon and salt. Stir in raisins if using. Drop by spoonfuls 2 inches apart on cookie sheets.
column4: Bake 10 to 12 minutes. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease 9 inch square baking pan.
column3: In top of a double boiler, melt chocolate chips and shortening, stirring frequently until smooth. Pour into a large bowl, and mix in sugar, cream cheese, and eggs. Stir in vanilla and almond extracts. Gradually mix in flour, baking powder and salt. Fold in almonds and pour the batter into pan.
column4: Bake for 35 to 40 minutes in the preheated oven, until toothpick inserted near the center comes out clean. Let cool in pan before cutting into bars.

column2: In a large bowl, cream shortening, white sugar and brown sugar. Beat in the egg and vanilla extract. Combine the flour, baking soda and salt; mix into the sugar mixture until well blended. Divide dough in half, cover and refrigerate for 4 hours.
column3: To make the filling: Combine dates, sugar, water, lemon juice and salt in saucepan. Cook over low heat until mixture thickens.
column4: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column5: Roll out dough on a floured surface to a thickness of 1/8 of an inch. Cut out an even number of 2 1/2 inch circles. Place half of the dough circles 2 inches apart on cookie sheets. Brush circles lightly with water and place a tablespoonful of filling in the center of each one. Place the remaining circles on top and crimp the edges with your fingers or a fork. Make two tiny slits at the top of each cookie and brush the tops with a beaten egg. Sprinkle with sugar.
column6: Bake 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, or until lightly colored. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Peel, pit and slice peaches. Place in small saucepan and add water until just covered. Sprinkle with 3 teaspoons of sugar and boil. Reduce heat and cook until peaches soften. Remove from heat and mash.
column3: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column4: In small saucepan, heat oil and honey over low heat. Pour into bowl and beat in egg, applesauce and mashed peaches. Mix in flour, cinnamon and salt until well blended. Fold in oats, raisins and pineapple, stirring well. If the dough seems too dry, add more applesauce 1 tablespoon at a time. Drop by spoonfuls 2 inches apart on cookie sheets.
column5: Bake for 15 to 20 minutes until lightly colored.

column2: In large bowl, cream shortening, sugar, egg and warmed molasses. Dissolve baking soda in warm water and add to egg mixture. Beat until smooth. Mix in flour, spices and salt until well blended. Cover and chill for 24 hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets. Roll out dough to a thickness of 1/4 inch on a floured surface. Cut out gingerbread men using cookie cutters and place 2 inches apart on cookie sheets. Use raisins to make eyes, noses and buttons.
column4: Bake 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, or until firm. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F. Grease 2 baking sheets.
column3: In large bowl, cream shortening, brown sugar, egg, and molasses. Slowly mix in flour, ginger, cinnamon, cloves and salt. Mix until well blended.
column4: Pinch off 1 inch sized pieces of dough and roll into balls. Roll in sugar and place 2 inches apart on cookie sheets. Flatten cookies slightly using the bottom of a glass. Bake for 10 to 12 minutes. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Mix together the flour, hazelnuts, baking powder, spices and salt. In a large bowl, cream the shortening and powered sugar. Beat in the lemon zest. Gradually stir in the dry ingredients. Press the dough into an ungreased 9-inch square baking pan.
column4: Bake for 18 to 20 minutes, until the top is golden. Let cool in the pan or on a wire rack.

column2: Combine flour, walnuts, baking soda, allspice, cinnamon, and salt.
column3: In small saucepan over low heat, melt shortening and honey, stirring constantly. Remove from heat and pour into large bowl. Stir in brown sugar, eggs and milk until well blended. Slowly add dry ingredients. Fold in raisins, currants and dates. Cover and chill for 4 hours.
column4: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets. Drop by spoonfuls 2 inches apart on cookie sheets.
column5: Bake 10 to 12 minutes, until lightly colored.

column2: In a large bowl, cream shortening, brown and white sugars, and eggs. Beat until well blended. Beat in vanilla extract and lemon juice. Stir in flour, baking soda and salt and mix well. Fold in macadamia nuts and oats. Cover and chill for 4 hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Lightly grease 2 baking sheets. Drop the dough by spoonfuls 2 inches apart on cookie sheets.
column4: Bake 15 to 18 minutes. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream the shortening, brown sugar and eggs. Stir in the flour and baking soda. Stir in the walnuts. Drop dough by spoonfuls 2 inches apart on cookie sheets.
column4: Bake 10 to 12 minutes. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line cookie sheets with aluminum foil or baking parchment.
column3: Steam raisins in a vegetable steamer over shallow water in a saucepan. Boil water for 3 minutes, until raisins are moist. Remove raisins and let dry on cloth.
column4: In a large bowl, cream together the butter, sugar and vanilla until smooth. Beat in eggs and sour cream until well blended. Sift together flour and baking soda; stir into the butter mixture. Mix in raisins, nuts and chocolate. Drop dough by tablespoons 2 inches apart on cookie sheets.
column5: Bake 13 to 15 minutes, until lightly colored. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Line cookie sheets with aluminum foil or baking parchment.
column3: Chop chocolates and mints. Place the chocolates and mints in the top part of a double boiler over medium heat. Stir occasionally until melted and set aside.
column4: In a large bowl, beat the butter until soft. Add vanilla and sugar and mix well. Beat in the eggs one at a time. Stir in the melted chocolate. Sift together the flour, cocoa, and baking soda. Add to mixture and stir until well blended. Drop by tablespoon at least 2 inches apart on cookie sheets.
column5: Bake 15 to 18 minutes until lightly colored. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line cookie sheets with aluminum foil or baking parchment.
column3: In a large saucepan, melt the butter over medium heat. Add peanut butter and sugar and stir until melted. Remove from heat.
column4: Transfer to large mixing bowl and stir in bran cereal. Stir in eggs and vanilla and mix well. Fold in raisins and oatmeal and stir until well blended.
column5: Sift together flour and baking soda and add to mixture. Mix thoroughly.
column6: Drop dough by tablespoonfuls onto cookie sheets. Dip a fork into water and press to flatten dough to 1/2 inch thickness.
column7: Bake for 15 minutes, or until cookies are lightly colored. Reverse sheet once during baking time. Let stand on wire racks to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (150 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Sift flour, baking powder, salt, sugar, and cocoa into a large mixing bowl. Chop chocolate into fine pieces and add to mixture. Cut the butter into small pieces and stir into the flour mixture. Add eggs and stir until the mixture forms a stiff dough. Wet hands with cold water and roll tablespoonfuls of dough into balls. Place on cookie sheets 3 inches apart.
column4: Bake for 13 to 15 minutes in the preheated oven, until centers look dry. Transfer to wire racks to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together butter, peanut butter and vanilla. Mix in sugar and egg until well blended. Combine the flour, cocoa and baking soda; Stir into the peanut butter mixture. Add the cut-up chocolate and peanuts. Stir well.
column4: Wet hands with cold water and roll teaspoon sized amounts of dough into balls. Flatten balls slightly and place 2 inches apart on cookie sheets.
column5: Bake for 12 minutes. Transfer to wire racks to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, beat butter until soft. Mix in the vanilla and sugar. Add the eggs and mix well. In a separate bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, ginger cinnamon and nutmeg. Gradually stir into the butter mixture. Stir in raisins and peanuts. Mixture will be stiff. Take tablespoon-sized pieces of dough and roll into a ball. Place onto cookie sheets and flatten slightly to 1/2 inch thickness.
column4: Bake for 15 to 18 minutes in the preheated oven. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: In a large bowl mix together the butter until soft. Add the peanut butter and sugar and beat well. Mix in the egg and milk. Sift together the flour, salt, and baking soda. Add to the egg mixture slowly and mix until just blended. Form dough into 2 logs, and wrap in plastic wrap. Freeze for at least 2 hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column4: Chop chocolate into small pieces and place in the top of a double boiler over medium heat. Stir frequently until melted. Add butter or margarine and stir until melted. Remove from heat and let cool to room temperature.
column5: Remove one package of the dough from the freezer and unwrap. With a sharp, serrated knife, cut a few slices of the dough 1/4 inch thick and place on cookie sheet about 2 inches apart.
column6: Quickly spoon a teaspoonful of the chocolate on each slice. Cut more slices, and top each with another slice of dough. If dough becomes too soft, rewrap it and return to freezer. Reheat chocolate if it becomes too hard.
column7: Bake 10 to 12 minutes until lightly colored.

column2: In a medium bowl, combine the almonds and the milk chocolate. Add half of the sugar, and mix well. Set aside.
column3: In a large bowl, beat the butter until soft. Stir in the vanilla and remaining sugar until well blended.
column4: Mix in the egg and apricot preserves. Sift together the flour, baking soda, baking powder, salt and cocoa powder. Stir into the egg mixture. Add the chocolate and nut mixture and stir until well blended. Mixture will be stiff.
column5: Spread two lengths of plastic wrap about 12 inches long on a counter. Spoon half of the dough down each length of the wrap, forming strips 8 to 9 inches long. Bring the two long sides of the wrap together on top of one of the strips of dough. Press together close to the dough and smooth into a strip about 9 inches long, 3 inches wide and 1 inch high. Repeat with second strip. Freeze for at least 1 1/2 hours, or as long as you'd like.
column6: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a cookie sheet with aluminum foil or baking parchment. Unwrap the frozen dough and cut 1/4 inch thick slices. Place on cookie sheets 2 inches apart.
column7: Bake for about 11 minutes. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F. Butter a cookie sheet. Write fortunes on strips of paper about 4 inches long and 1/2 inch wide. Generously grease 2 cookie sheets.
column3: Mix the egg white and vanilla until foamy but not stiff. Sift the flour, salt, and sugar and blend into the egg white mixture.
column4: Place teaspoonfuls of the batter at least 4 inches apart on one of the prepared cookie sheets. Tilt the sheet to move the batter into round shapes about 3 inches in diameter. Be careful to make batter as round and even as possible. Do not make too many, because the cookie have to be really hot to form them and once they cool it is too late. Start with 2 or 3 to a sheet and see how many you can do.
column5: Bake for 5 minutes or until cookie has turned a golden color 1/2 inch wide around the outer edge of the circle. The center will remain pale. While one sheet is baking, prepare the other.
column6: Remove from oven and quickly move cookie with a wide spatula and place upside down on a wooden board. Quickly place the fortune on the cookie, close to the middle and fold the cookie in half. Place the folded edge across the rim of a measuring cup and pull the pointed edges down, one on the inside of the cup and one on the outside. Place folded cookies into the cups of a muffin tin or egg carton to hold their shape until firm.

column2: Beat together butter and sugar. Finely grate the rind of the lemons and stir into mixture. Beat in one egg yolk and the egg. Sift together flour, pepper, and salt; stir into the butter mixture. Dough will be stiff. Knead on a smooth surface, and form into a log shape about 8 inches long with flat ends. Wrap in airtight plastic wrap and let stand at room temperature for one hour.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line cookie sheets with aluminum foil or baking parchment. Cut the dough into 12 even pieces. Cover with plastic wrap.
column4: On a floured surface, gently roll one piece of dough at a time into a 10 to 11 inch long roll, slightly tapered at the ends.
column5: Shape dough into a pretzel shape by crossing the two ends about 2 inches from the ends and bring them to the other side. Dab a bit of water under the ends where they cross the other side of the pretzel. Place pretzels 2 inches apart on cookie sheets.
column6: Mix the remaining egg yolk with 1/2 teaspoon of water. Brush the pretzels with the mixture, and sprinkle with crystal sugar (optional).
column7: Bake for 30 minutes, reversing cookie sheets top to bottom and front to back once during baking. Pretzels will turn golden brown. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Cream shortening, sugar and eggs together, then beat in vanilla. Sift the flour, salt and baking soda together, and add to shortening mixture. Mix until well blended. Stir in the nuts and mincemeat and mix well. Drop by teaspoonfuls on the cookie sheet.
column4: Bake 8 to 10 minutes until light brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Toast the almonds until golden brown.
column3: Let almonds cool, then chop into 1/4 inch pieces.
column4: Set oven temperature to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column5: Cream the butter and sugar until smooth and creamy. Beat in the eggs until smooth. Zest the orange, add to mixture and stir well. Add the orange-flavored liqueur and cinnamon. Mix in the flour, baking powder and salt. Beat until just mixed. Stir in the chopped almonds. Divide the dough in half on a lightly floured board and form into long rolls, about 2 inches in diameter and 10 inches long.
column6: Set the rolls on a cookie sheet and bake for about 25 minutes, or until they are brown on top.
column7: Let the rolls cool for 5 minutes, then slice diagonally 1/2 inch thick.
column8: Lay slices back flat on cookie sheet and cook for another 10 minutes. Flip biscotti over and cook for another 10 minutes. Let cool on wire racks. If you keep these in an airtight container, they will keep for months.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Hard boil the eggs and separate the yolks. Cream the butter and hard boiled egg yolks. Beat in the sugar and add the flour vanilla extract. Mix thoroughly. Put through a cookie press or arrange by teaspoonfuls on ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake 10 to 12 minutes, or until lightly browned.

column2: In a large bowl, cream together the butter, white sugar and brown sugar until smooth. Beat in the egg and vanilla. Combine the flour, cream of tartar, salt and nutmeg; stir into the creamed mixture until well blended. Divide dough and shape into rolls 2 inches in diameter. Wrap in aluminum foil and store in refrigerator for at least 2 hours and up to one week.
column3: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Slice the logs into rounds about 1/4-inch thick. Arrange the slices on a baking sheet.
column4: Bake the cookies until the edges are light brown, about 8 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a small saucepan over low heat, mix dates, sugar and 1/2 cup of water. Bring to a boil, and cook for 15 minutes, or until thick and smooth. Set aside to cool.
column4: Cream butter and brown sugar together until smooth. Gradually mix in flour, baking soda, and salt. Add the oatmeal and mix well. Stir in 2 to 4 tablespoons of water. Form the dough into a ball and refrigerate for 15 minutes.
column5: On a floured surface, roll dough to 1/8 inch thickness and cut into 2 inch rounds. Place 1/2 of the rounds on cookie sheets. Spoon date mixture in the center of each round and top with another round. Press edges firmly together.
column6: Bake 15 minutes in the preheated oven, or until browned.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F(190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Melt butter or margarine over low heat. In a separate bowl, beat together the eggs, sugar, sour cream, and vanilla. Mix in the melted butter and stir until well blended. Sift together the flour, baking soda, and nutmeg and add to egg mixture, stirring constantly. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets, about 1 inch apart.
column4: Bake for 10 minutes, or until lightly browned.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Combine milk and chocolate in double boiler over low heat. Stir frequently until chocolate has melted. Remove from heat and pour into mixing bowl. Stir in coconut, pecans, vanilla and salt. Mix well. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for about 15 minutes, or until firm.

column2: Cover cookie sheets with parchment paper or aluminum foil.
column3: In large mixing bowl, soften almond paste with your hands or food processor. Mix in white sugar and egg whites until well blended. Mix in the confectioners' sugar, flour, and salt until smooth and well blended.
column4: Force dough through a cookie press or drop by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets. Cover and let stand for 30 minutes. Preheat the oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C).
column5: Bake for 25 minutes. Remove foil or parchment from sheets and let cool. Peel off macaroons.

column2: Cover cookie sheets with parchment paper or aluminum foil, shiny side up.
column3: In large mixing bowl, mix almond paste and white sugar until well blended. Mix in egg whites one at a time. Combine the flour, confectioners' sugar and salt; blend into the almond paste mixture. Stir in cherries.
column4: Force dough through a cookie press or drop by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets. Cover and let stand for 30 minutes. Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C).
column5: Bake for 25 minutes. Remove parchment or foil from cookie sheets and let cool. Peel off macaroons.

column2: Cover cookie sheets with parchment or aluminum foil, shiny side up.
column3: Soften almond paste with your hands or food processor. In large mixing bowl, blend almond paste and sugar.
column4: Separate eggs and add whites to mixture. Mix in confectioners' sugar, flour and salt. Stir well.
column5: Force dough through a cookie press or drop by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets. Cover and let stand for 30 minutes.
column6: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Sprinkle cookies with chopped almonds and bake for 25 minutes. Remove parchment or foil from cookie sheets and let cool. Peel off macaroons.

column2: In a large mixing bowl, cream together the butter and sugar. Add the eggs and vanilla, and mix well. Sift together the flour, baking powder, baking soda and salt; add to mixture. Stir until well blended. Refrigerate dough until firm.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column4: Roll dough into 1-inch balls and roll in crushed corn flakes. Place on cookie sheets, about 2 inches apart. Indent the center of each ball with your thumb and fill with jam or jelly.
column5: Bake for 15 to 20 minutes in the preheated oven, or until firm.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (150 degrees C). Grease an 8-inch square baking pan.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, cream together the peanut butter and butter. Add the brown sugar, vanilla and eggs and beat until light and fluffy. Combine the flour, baking powder, and salt in a separate bowl. Add to the butter mixture and mix until well blended. Stir in the peanuts.
column4: Spread batter evenly into pan and bake for 25 to 30 minutes or until toothpick comes out clean. Let cool on wire rack and cut into 2-inch squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease an 8-inch square baking pan.
column3: Melt the butter or margarine over low heat. Pour into large mixing bowl and stir in carob powder, sugar, salt, flour, and vanilla. Mix in egg whites and walnuts. Spread the dough evenly into the baking pan.
column4: Bake for 30 minutes. Let cool in pan for 10-15 minutes before cutting.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Butter an 8-inch square cake pan.
column3: Melt the butter over low heat and pour into a large mixing bowl. Add the honey and eggs, and beat well. Mix in the flour, baking powder, and salt. Mix in the walnuts and dates. Spread batter in pan
column4: Bake for 25 minutes in the preheated oven, or until light brown. Let cool for 5 to 10 minutes. Cut into bars and roll in confectioners' sugar.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large mixing bowl, cream the butter and the sugar. Slowly add the flour and salt, mixing well. Roll out dough with a rolling pin until it is 1/4 inch thick. Cut into desired shapes using cookie cutters. Place on cookie sheet and prick with a fork.
column4: Bake for 5 to 8 minutes, or until light brown at the edges.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F. Grease and flour a 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: In double boiler over low heat, melt the chocolate and butter together, stirring frequently until smooth. Remove from heat and let cool.
column4: In a large mixing bowl, mix together eggs, vanilla, salt and sugar. Beat with an electric mixer for 8 to 10 minutes. Slowly pour in chocolate mixture and flour. Stir in the walnuts. Spread batter evenly in the prepared pan
column5: Bake for 17 to 20 minutes in the preheated oven, until the top is crackled. Let cool for 2 hours before cutting into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease an 8-inch square pan.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, cream the shortening with the sugar, vanilla, and almond extract. Stir in the egg and mix until well blended. In a separate bowl, mix together the flour, baking powder, cinnamon, cloves and salt. Add to the first mixture and mix well. Spread half of the dough into the pan. Cover with a layer of marmalade. Spread the remaining dough over the top
column4: Bake for 25 minutes. Let cool before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, cream the shortening and sugar. Add the egg and beat until light and fluffy, then stir in the molasses. In a separate bowl, mix together the flour, baking soda, salt, ginger and cinnamon. Add to the egg mixture and stir until well blended. Roll bits of dough into 1 inch balls. Dip each ball in sugar and place on cookie sheet, sugared side up about 2 inches apart.
column4: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes, until cookies have spread and tops have cracked. Let cool on wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Beat eggs and vanilla together in mixing bowl. Add in brown sugar, flour, baking soda, salt and walnuts. Mix until well blended.
column4: Melt the butter in a 9-inch square pan. Pour the batter into the pan and bake for 20 to 25 minutes, until firm to the touch.
column5: While bars are still hot, loosen with a spatula and turn out onto wax paper, buttered side up. Dust with confectioners' sugar while warm and cut into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour cookie sheets.
column3: Place sesame seeds in small saucepan and stir or shake them over moderate heat until slightly brown. Remove from heat and stir in butter, brown sugar, egg and vanilla. Mix in flour, egg and salt. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets about 2 inches apart.
column4: Bake until just brown, 4 to 6 minutes. Remove from cookie sheets while still warm. If cookies are hard to remove, reheat for 30 seconds.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease an 11x7 inch pan.
column3: In a medium bowl, cream the butter, sugar, egg and vanilla until well blended. Sift together the flour, baking powder, salt and nutmeg and slowly add to mixture, alternating with 1/3 cup orange juice and 2 teaspoons of rind. Stir in the coconut and carrots. Pour batter into baking pan.
column4: Bake for about 35 minutes in the preheated oven. Let cool on wire racks.
column5: Combine 1/2 cup of orange juice, 1 teaspoon of orange rind and 1 1/2 cups confectioners' sugar. Warm slightly and pour over cooled bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, cream butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in vanilla, egg and pumpkin. Sift together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt and cinnamon; stir into mixture until well blended. Cut the cranberries in half and stir into mixture along with the orange zest and walnuts. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: In a large mixing bowl, cream butter and sugars until fluffy. Beat in the eggs and squash. Sift together the flour, baking soda, baking powder, and spices; add to mixture, stirring until well blended. Stir in raisins and nuts. Spoon onto cookie sheets spacing cookies 2 inches apart.
column4: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, until edges are golden.

column2: Preheat 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a small saucepan over medium heat, melt butter till lightly browned. Pour into medium sized bowl. Stir in the egg white, sugar and vanilla. Combine the flour cocoa, and salt; mix into the butter mixture. Fold in chocolate. Drop by teaspoonfuls about 2 inches apart onto cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 12 to 15 minutes. Transfer to rack to cool and dust with confectioners' sugar.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Melt butter in a small saucepan over low heat. Add pistachios and stir until butter is lightly browned and pistachios toasted. Pour into mixing bowl.
column4: Whisk in sugar and egg white. Mix in the flour, cardamom or ginger and whisk until smooth.
column5: Drop by teaspoonfuls about 2 inches apart on baking sheets. Bake 12 to 15 minutes or until golden brown. Immediately transfer cookies to rack to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, stir together the molasses, brown sugar, vinegar, and egg. Sift together the flour, baking soda, ginger and salt; add to molasses mixture. Mix until well blended. Spoon the dough by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets, about 2 inches apart.
column4: Bake until edges are golden, 12 to 15 minutes. Let cool on pans for 5 minutes before removing.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease an 8 inch square baking pan.
column3: Sprinkle pecans on cookie sheet and toast in oven until lightly colored. Set aside to cool.
column4: In saucepan over low heat, melt unsweetened chocolate and butter, stirring occasionally. Let cool.
column5: In a large mixing bowl, beat the eggs, sugar and vanilla. Fold in the melted chocolate. Sift together the flour, and salt and add to mixture, stirring lightly. Chop the semisweet chocolate into coarse chunks and add to mixture, along with pecans. Mix until just blended. Pour batter into pan and smooth top.
column6: Bake about 25 minutes. Let cool before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: Mix the sugar, butter, eggs and cocoa until just blended. Slowly add flour and one teaspoon of the vanilla. Mix until just blended. Spread batter in pan and top with chopped pecans.
column4: Bake about 25 minutes. Let cool on wire rack.
column5: In saucepan over low heat, melt caramels, stirring until smooth. Remove from heat and stir in remaining vanilla. Drizzle over brownies in parallel rows and press pecan halves into the caramel in neat rows. Let set for at least 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Put nuts on a cookie sheet and bake for about 7 minutes, or until toasted. Grease an 8-inch square baking pan.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, beat the egg and brown sugar until light and fluffy, about 3 minutes with an electric mixer on medium speed. Melt the butter over low heat and add to egg mixture along with vanilla. Mix well. Sift the flour, baking soda and salt onto a piece of wax paper, and add to egg mixture beating slowly. Mix until just blended. Coarsely chop the white chocolate and fold into mixture. Stir in macadamia nuts.
column4: Pour batter into baking pan. Bake for 28 to 30 minutes, or until toothpick inserted in center comes out clean. Place on wire rack and let cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Add the egg and vanilla and beat until smooth. Sift together the flour and salt and slowly stir into butter mixture until just blended.
column4: Divide batter in half and place each half on in the center of two ungreased, flat-sided cookie sheets. Dip a spatula in warm water and spread batter to cover the entire baking sheet, making sure batter is spread evenly. Sprinkle almonds and press gently into dough.
column5: Bake each sheet about 12 minutes, or until edges are lightly browned. Cut hot cookies into 2-inch squares. Return to oven and bake until lightly golden... about 5 minutes. Watch carefully to prevent over baking.
column6: Remove from oven to a wire rack. Slide spatula under cookies to loosen. Cool completely on cookie sheets. Store in airtight containers with waxed paper between layers.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (160 degrees C). Grease cookies sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, beat egg whites until frothy. Add sugar and beat until mixture is thick and white. Stir in chopped almonds and chopped hazelnuts.
column4: Pour mixture into saucepan over low heat, stirring with a wooden spoon until thick and beige, about 10 minutes. Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets about 1 inch apart.
column5: Bake about 20 minutes, until cookies are dry to the touch. Let cool on wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Break almond paste into pieces and mix together with sugar, using your hands to crumble paste. In a separate bowl, separate the eggs and beat the whites into soft peaks. Slowly add to almond paste mixture and mix until just blended.
column4: Place pine nuts into bowl. Roll dough into 1-inch balls and press into nuts. Coat evenly and place on cookie sheets about 1 inch apart.
column5: Bake 15 to 17 minutes, until lightly golden. Let cool on cookie sheets for 5 minutes, then transfer to racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Toast sesame seeds on pan, stirring occasionally, until lightly golden (about 10 minutes). Set aside. Increase oven temperature to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In large mixing bowl, combine flour, baking powder, salt, brown sugar and white sugar. Melt butter over low heat and add to mixture. Separate two of the eggs and add egg yolks. Add the other two eggs and mix well. Mix in toasted sesame oil (optional) and vanilla. Stir until well blended. Add 1 1/2 cups of sesame seeds and mix with electric mixer at medium speed for 10 minutes. Let dough sit for 10 minutes.
column4: Place remaining sesame seeds in shallow pan. Drop level tablespoonful sized pieces of dough into pan. Gently roll in sesame seeds while forming 2-inch long log shape. Taper the ends and place on cookie sheet about 1-inch apart.
column5: Bake until golden, 11 to 13 minutes. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: In large mixing bowl, beat butter until light and fluffy. Add the sugar and beat for 10 minutes on medium speed. Add four of the eggs, one at a time, and beat well after each addition. Beat in the vanilla. Combine the flour, baking powder, and salt in a separate bowl. Add to the butter mixture and stir to form soft, cohesive dough. Add flour if dough is too soft to handle easily.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets
column4: Lightly flour a work surface. Break off 1 inch lumps of dough and roll on floured surface into ropes about 7 inches long and 1/4 inch in diameter. Cross the ends and twirl dough in a loop in the opposite direction, forming a braid. Place on cookie sheets about 1 inch apart.
column5: Beat remaining egg. Brush onto braids for glaze and sprinkle with sesame seeds. Bake 20 to 25 minutes. Let cool on cookie sheets for 10 minutes, then remove to racks to cool completely.

column2: To make Pastry: Combine flour, sugar, baking powder and salt in a large mixing bowl. Add the butter, eggs, vanilla and milk. Stir into a smooth dough. Remove dough from bowl and shape into a circle. Cut into 4 equal pieces, wrap in plastic and chill.
column3: To make the Filling: Use the zest and juice of the orange and place in large bowl. Mix in figs, raisins and nuts. Process in food processor until evenly chopped. Stir in honey, rum and cinnamon, and set aside.
column4: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column5: Remove dough from refrigerator. Roll one piece of dough at a time into an 8-inch wide strip about 1/4-inch thick. Cut lengthwise in half, forming two long strips, each about 4 inches wide. Lay strips on work surface. Brush top inch of each with cold water. About 1/3 of the way up from the bottom of the dough, place 1/4 of the filling in a 1-inch wide strip, running from end to end. Fold the moistened edge of the dough over the filling and press to seal edges. Cut each strip into 1-inch rectangles and place on cookie sheets. Repeat with remaining sections of dough.
column6: Bake 13 to 16 minutes, or until tops are golden. Let cool on cookie sheets for 10 minutes. Transfer to wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line 2 cookie sheets with aluminum foil. In small mixing bowl, sift the flour. Add the pecans and oats. Mix well.
column3: In saucepan over medium heat, combine the corn syrup, brown sugar, and butter. Bring to a boil, stirring constantly. Remove from heat. Stir in the vanilla and flour mixture. Stir until well blended. Mixture will turn opaque. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets about 3 inches apart.
column4: Bake for 9 minutes or until set and golden. When done, slide foil onto wire racks and allow cookies to cool. Re-line cookie sheets with new foil for next batch. Peel cookies off of foil when cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Lightly grease a 9" x 13" pan.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, cream the butter and sugar together.
column4: Mix in the vanilla, corn syrup and oats.
column5: Pat this dough into the greased pan. Bake for 15-16 minutes (don't overbake).
column6: Meanwhile, over low heat melt together the chocolate chips and peanut butter.
column7: Allow the cookie base to cool slightly, then spread the chocolate peanut butter mixture on top. Cool completely and cut into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease a 9" x 13" pan.
column3: In a saucepan over low heat, melt 1/2 cup butter and 1/2 cup chocolate chips.
column4: Remove from heat and add the four and sugar and mix well. Press this mixture firmly into the greased pan. Bake for 10 minutes.
column5: Meanwhile, combine the confectioners' sugar and baking powder in a mixing bowl.
column6: Add the eggs, remaining 1/4 cup butter, peanut butter, dates, walnuts and water, and mix thoroughly.
column7: Cool the baked crust for 5 minutes, then spread the date mixture over the crust. Bake for 15-20 minutes or until golden.
column8: Melt the remaining 1/2 cup chocolate chips with the 1 tablespoon of shortening and spread over the baked crust and filling. If desired, sprinkle with additional chopped nuts. Cool completely and cut into bars.

column2: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch pan.
column3: In a medium bowl, combine the sugar, brown sugar, flour, and butter; blend with a pastry blender until the mixture is in coarse crumbs. Remove 2 cups of the mixture to another bowl, and reserve the rest.
column4: Stir the coconut and walnuts into the 2 cups of the sugar mixture. Pat firmly into the greased pan. Stir the baking soda, salt, and cinnamon into the reserved mixture. Then mix in the egg, buttermilk and vanilla until well blended. Spread this over the crust in the pan.
column5: Bake for 35 to 45 minutes in the preheated oven, or until firm. Allow to cool. Make a glaze using confectioners' sugar and enough of the milk to give it a drizzling consistency. Drizzle over bars before cutting into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F.
column3: In a large bowl beat the butter or margarine until softened. Add the brown sugar and sugar and beat until fluffy. Add egg and 1 tablespoon of amaretto and mix well.
column4: Stir together flour and baking soda, and then add to the butter mixture and beat until well mixed. Stir in the oats, apricots, and almonds.
column5: Drop by rounded teaspoons onto an ungreased cookie sheet and bake for 8-10 minutes.
column6: Cool on cookie sheet for 1 minute, then remove and cool thoroughly on rack.
column7: Stir together powdered sugar and enough of the 2 to 3 tablespoons of amaretto to make an icing of drizzling consistency. Drizzle over the cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Line cookie sheets with greased foil, shiny side up.
column3: In a small saucepan, combine brown sugar, butter, and syrup. Cook and stir over medium heat until well blended. Remove from heat.
column4: Stir in the nuts, flour, and liqueur. Mix until well blended.
column5: Drop teaspoonfuls onto a greased, foil-lined cookie sheet about 5 inches apart (bake only 4-5 at a time; cookies spread when baked). Bake for 9-11 minutes; let stand 1 minute.
column6: Remove from cookie sheet. Pull up three sides to center to form a triangle, or roll around the greased handle of a wooden spoon. If cookies are difficult to remove from sheet, reheat them in oven about 30 seconds. Cool on rack.

column2: In a large mixing bowl, beat butter until softened. Add sugar and beat until fluffy. Add egg, vanilla and almond extract and beat well.
column3: Stir together flour, baking powder and salt. Add the flour mixture to the butter mixture and beat until well mixed.
column4: Divide the dough in half and stir food coloring into one half. Cover and chill at least 30 minutes.
column5: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F.
column6: On a lightly floured surface, roll about 1/2 tablespoon of plain dough into a 6-inch rope. Repeat with green dough.
column7: Place ropes side by side and twist together about 6 times. Form twisted ropes into a circle and gently pinch ends together.
column8: Place on an ungreased cookie sheet. Repeat with remaining dough, leaving 2 inches between cookies. Place small amount of chopped pistachios onto each wreath where ends are pinched together.
column9: Bake for about 10 minutes. Cool on cookie sheet for about 1 minute. Remove and cool thoroughly on rack.

column2: In a large mixing bowl, beat butter until softened. Beat in honey. Add egg yolk, orange peel and orange juice and mix well.
column3: In a separate bowl, stir together the flour, baking soda, nutmeg and salt. Add flour mixture to the butter mixture and beat until well mixed. Cover and chill at least 3 hours.
column4: Preheat oven to 325 degree F.
column5: Separate egg and slightly beat egg white. Shape dough into 1-inch balls. Roll in egg white and then in the nuts. Place 2 inches apart on an ungreased cookie sheet.
column6: Cut each cherry into 6-8 wedges. Place 4 or 5 wedges atop each ball so that it looks like a flower; press lightly. Bake for 15-18 minutes. Remove and cool on rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Lightly grease cookie sheet.
column3: Stirring constantly, melt 1 cup chocolate pieces, unsweetened chocolate, and butter in a saucepan. Transfer to a large mixing bowl and allow to cool slightly.
column4: In a separate bowl, combine the flour, baking powder, and a dash of salt.
column5: Add eggs, sugar, and vanilla to chocolate mixture and beat well. Add flour mixture and beat until well mixed. Stir in remaining chocolate pieces and nuts.
column6: Drop by heaping teaspoons onto the cookie sheet. Bake for 8-10 minutes or until the edges are firm and the surface is dull and cracked. Cool on cookie sheet 1 minute. Remove and cool completely on rack.

column2: In a food processor or with the fine blade of a food grinder, process or grind raisins, figs, dates and walnuts.
column3: In a large mixing bowl beat butter until softened. Add sugar and beat until fluffy. Add eggs and beat well.
column4: In a mixing bowl stir together flour, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, cloves, and nutmeg. Add flour mixture and beat until well mixed.
column5: Stir in ground fruit mixture. Divide dough in half; cover and chill several hours or overnight.
column6: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F. Grease cookie sheet.
column7: On a well floured surface roll dough 1/4 inch thick. Cut into rounds with a 2 1/2-inch cookie cutter. Place on cookie sheet and bake for 10-12 minute or until done. Cool on cookie sheet for 2-3 minutes, then remove and cool thoroughly on rack.
column8: Combine 1 1/2 cups sifted powdered sugar, 1 tablespoon softened butter or margarine, and 1/2 teaspoon vanilla and enough milk (4-5 tsp) to make icing of drizzling consistency.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together the butter and brown sugar. Add the eggs, one at a time, beating well after each addition. Beat in espresso and vanilla. Mix until well blended. Combine the whole wheat flour, baking soda and salt; stir into the creamed mixture until well blended. Melt chocolate in double boiler over low heat. Let cool to room temperature. Stir into mixture. Mix in nuts until well blended.
column4: Drop 3 inches apart on cookie sheets and bake for 12 minutes, or until crisp around edges.

column2: In a large bowl, combine fruits, honey, sherry, lemon juice, salt and walnuts. Cover and marinate overnight.
column3: Cream together with butter, brown sugar and white sugar until smooth. Add egg and mix well. Combine the flour, salt and cloves; gradually blend into the butter mixture. Blend in the fruit and nut mixture
column4: Lightly flour work surface and divide dough into 2 equal portions. Roll into logs and wrap in plastic wrap or waxed paper. Place dough in freezer for at least an hour.
column5: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Cut logs into thin rounds and place on cookie sheet spaced at least 1 inch apart.
column6: Bake 10 to 13 minutes in the preheated oven, or until golden brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (160 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch pan.
column3: To make crust: In a large mixing bowl, beat together the butter, 2 cups of the flour, and confectioners' sugar until fluffy. Scrape mixture into the pan and smooth. Bake 15 minutes.
column4: In a medium bowl, beat the eggs and sugar. Grate the rind of the lemon and add the rind, along with 6 tablespoons of lemon juice, to the egg mixture. Sprinkle 1 tablespoon of flour and the baking powder over the mixture. Fold in the nuts and mix until well blended. Pour the lemon mixture into the crust.
column5: Bake for another 35 minutes, until filling is set. Let cool before cutting.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C).
column3: Cream butter and sugar until smooth. Add the milk and eggs, stirring well. Set aside 1/4 cup of the flour. Sift the rest with baking soda, cinnamon, and nutmeg. Sprinkle on the grated orange rind. Stir into the butter mixture until well blended. In a separate bowl, mix together the currants, raisins, dates and nuts. Toss together with 1/4 cup of flour. Fold into the batter.
column4: Drop onto cookie sheets and bake for 23 to 25 minutes, until slightly golden. Let cool on rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Place 1/4 cup of sugar and the vanilla bean in a food processor fitted with a metal blade. Pulse to chop the bean, then add walnuts. Pulse again until finely chopped. Remove from food processor. Add the butter and flour. Mix until well blended.
column4: Pinch off 1 inch square pieces of dough and shape into balls. Shape the balls into crescents, about 2 inches long. Place about 1/2 inch apart on cookie sheets.
column5: Bake for 10 minutes, then reduce oven temperature to 300 degrees F and bake for additional 10 to 15 minutes, until cookies are dry. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: In a large mixing bowl, cream together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Mix in the egg yolk, vanilla extract and almond extract until well blended. Stir in the flour. Divide the dough in half. Roll each half into a log shape about 3 inches in diameter. Wrap in plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least three hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Remove dough from refrigerator and cut 1/8-inch thick slices and place on cookie sheets about 2 inches apart.
column4: Bake for about 10 minutes, or until cookies get a tinge of color. Let cool on wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 330 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Cream together butter or margarine and sugar until light and fluffy. Stir in eggs and vanilla.
column4: Sift together flour and salt and add to butter mixture. Stir well.
column5: Chop almonds to very fine pieces and stir into mixture.
column6: Drop by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets about 5 inches apart. Bake for 8 minutes, or until edges begin to brown.
column7: As soon as cookies are cool enough to handle, roll each one around the handle of a wooden spoon or pencil. If cookies become too brittle, reheat for a few seconds.

column2: Butter a small cake pan.
column3: To prepare Nougat: In a frying pan place 1/2 cup of sugar over medium heat and stir. Sugar will turn into liquid caramel. When syrup becomes dark brown, pour into cake pan and let harden.
column4: Crush nougat in a mortar or between waxed paper with a hammer into small pieces.
column5: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (175 degrees C). In a medium bowl, cream the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Separate the egg and add the yolk and water. Blend thoroughly. Stir in 1/2 cup of sifted flour and the nougat. Mix well. Sift in the rest of the flour.
column6: Knead the dough lightly on a board. Roll the dough into a 1-inch in diameter log. Slice into 1/2-inch thick cookies. Place on greased cookie sheets 3 inches apart and press down with a fork.
column7: Bake 10 to 12 minutes.

column2: Cream the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Whip the cream and vanilla and add to mixture.
column3: Sift the flour and baking powder and add, stirring well. Knead the dough lightly on a board. Cover and refrigerate for 2 hours.
column4: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column5: Roll the dough and cut into pencil sized strips 6 to 7 inches long. Double the strips and twirl together. Make into circles approximately 3 inches around. Bake 12 to 15 minutes, or until golden.

column2: Melt butter in a frying pan and let brown to a dark color. Do not burn. Remove from heat and pour into mixing bowl. Discard any residue and let cool to room temperature.
column3: Cream cooled butter with sugar, and stir in vanilla. Resift flour with baking soda and mix into the butter mixture until well blended. Knead dough lightly, cover and refrigerate for one hour.
column4: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets. Roll dough into a log 1 inch in diameter. Cut 1/2-inch thick slices. Shape slices into balls and place on cookie sheets. Press half an almond into top of each ball and
column5: Bake 25 to 30 minutes in the preheated oven, until the edges are golden. Remove from cookie sheets to cool on wire racks.

column2: Melt butter and let cool to room temperature. Cream with sugar until smooth and light yellow. Add almond extract and mix well. Sift flour and baking powder and add to mixture, mixing well. Knead dough lightly on board. Cover and refrigerate for one hour.
column3: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Roll dough into a log 1 inch in diameter. Cut off slices 1/3 to 1/2 inch thick. Roll slices into balls and place on cookie sheet 1 1/2 inches apart. Slightly dent the top of each with fingertip.
column4: Bake 25 to 30 minutes, or until light golden in color.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Cream butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Add sifted flour, and mix well. Shape dough into 1-inch balls and place on cookie sheets. Imprint your thumb in the center to make a 1/2-inch indentation. Fill with your favorite preserves.
column4: Bake 15 to 20 minutes or until golden brown at the edges.

column2: Set oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Whip egg whites until stiff. Add almonds, cocoa, cinnamon and sugar and stir to just blend.
column4: Drop by spoonfuls on cookie sheets and bake for 20 minutes, or until dry.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Chop almonds into 5 or 6 pieces each and set aside.
column4: Separate eggs and whip egg whites until stiff. Fold in brown sugar, flour and almonds. Stir lightly.
column5: Drop by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets and bake about 30 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column3: Cream the butter and 2 tablespoons of sugar until light and fluffy, then stir in the egg yolk. Add the flour and mix until well blended.
column4: Combine the 1/2 cup sugar with the cinnamon. Roll the dough into balls the size of small olives and roll in the sugar/cinnamon mixture. Place cookies on a cookie sheet and press criss-cross with a fork until cookies are 1/3 inch thick.
column5: Bake for 10 minutes, or until light brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Cream the sugar and butter until light and fluffy. Stir in the egg yolk and vanilla. Mix in flour just until incorporated. Knead dough lightly on a board. Place in a pastry bag using the star design. Cut off desired lengths and shape into rings or S's.
column4: Bake 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, or until edges are golden.

column2: Cream the butter and sugar. Beat in the egg, vanilla and almond extracts. Sift together the flour, baking powder and salt. Mix until well blended. Fold in the almonds and coconut. Cover dough and refrigerate for at least one hour.
column3: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C), and grease cookie sheets. Roll dough into 1/2 inch rolls and cut into 1 1/2 inch lengths.
column4: Bake 18 to 20 minutes, or until golden. Dip in confectioners' sugar and let cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Cream the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Separate the egg and reserve the egg white. Beat the egg yolk into the mixture. Mix in the flour. Beat the egg white until is stands in peaks. Cut it into the dough. Drop by teaspoonfuls 3 inches apart on cookie sheets.
column4: Bake 12 to 15 minutes, or until edges are golden.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease an 8x8-inch square pan.
column3: Place apricots and enough water to cover in a small saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, and boil for 10 minutes. Drain and cool, then chop coarsely.
column4: Cream together the butter, 1/4 cup sugar, and 1 cup flour until crumbly. Sprinkle the mixture into the prepared pan, and pack down. Bake in the preheated oven until firm and slightly golden, 20 to 25 minutes.
column5: In a large bowl, mix together the eggs and brown sugar until well blended. Combine 1/3 cup flour, baking powder, and salt. Stir into the egg mixture. Mix in vanilla, walnuts and apricots. Spread mixture over baked layer.
column6: Bake for 25 to 30 minutes in the preheated oven, or until firm. Let cool on wire racks. Cut into bars and dip in confectioners' sugar.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x9 inch baking pan.
column3: To prepare Pastry: In a large bowl, mix the eggs and both sugars together. Blend in the nuts and sift the flour with the baking powder and salt. Add to egg mixture and blend well. Press into the bottom of the greased pan.
column4: Bake for 20 to 25 minutes. While pastry bakes, mix 1/4 cup of brown sugar, cream and cashews into the melted butter.
column5: Spread over baked pastry and place under a broiler for about 1 minute, until topping bubbles and becomes brown. Cut into bars while warm. Let cool in pan.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a 9x13 inch baking pan with greased aluminum foil.
column3: To make the Crust: In a large bowl, mix together the butter, almond paste, and brown sugar until smooth. Beat in one egg and the almond extract. Mix in the flour and stir until well blended.
column4: Bake 20 to 25 minutes, or until golden. Cool slightly, and spread the raspberry preserves over the crust.
column5: In a large glass or metal bowl, whip egg whites until they form soft peaks. Gradually beat in 1/2 cup sugar until peaks become stiff. Spread the meringue over the jam and sprinkle with coconut.
column6: Bake 15 to 20 minutes, or until firm. Let cool on wire racks. Lift foil from pan and cut bars with a sharp knife.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: To make crust: In a medium-sized bowl, mix the flour, butter and two tablespoons of brown sugar. Knead into a light dough and press into an 8-inch square pan or an 11x7 inch pan. Bake for 10 minutes.
column4: To make Topping: Beat together the two eggs, brown sugar, baking powder, flour, vanilla, walnuts and coconut. Spread over warm crust.
column5: Bake another 25 to 30 minutes, until golden brown. Let cool on wire racks before cutting.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: To make Pastry: Cream together 2/3 cup butter and brown sugar. Stir in the flour, baking powder, salt, and baking soda until well blended.
column4: Separate the eggs and beat in the yolks. Add in 1/2 teaspoon vanilla and mix well.
column5: Press mixture into the bottom of a 9 x 13 inch pan. Bake for 12 minutes or until golden brown.
column6: To make the Topping: In a medium bowl, mix together the powdered sugar, chopped peanuts, peanut butter, egg whites, and 1/2 teaspoon of vanilla. Melt 1/4 cup of butter or margarine and stir into mixture.
column7: Turn off oven and remove pan. Let cool for about 2 minutes. Spread topping over pastry. Sprinkle chocolate chips over topping and return to warm oven for 2 or 3 minutes. Spread chocolate over topping, like a frosting. Let cool before cutting.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (160 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl cream together butter, sugar and spices. Beat in the eggs one at a time. Sift in the flour, baking soda and salt and stir until well blended. Stir in molasses and raisins.
column4: To make bar cookies: Spread mixture on cookie sheet and bake for 25 minutes. Cut into bars while warm and let cool on wire rack.
column5: To make drop cookies: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Drop batter about 2 inches apart on greased cookie sheet and bake 12 to 15 minutes. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: Melt the butter over low heat. In a large mixing bowl, combine the butter, honey and eggs. Beat well.
column4: Stir in the flour, salt and baking powder and mix well. Mix in zucchini, dates and walnuts until well blended.
column5: Spread mixture into baking pan and bake for 25 to 30 minutes, until lightly brown. Cut into 1 x 3 inch long pieces, and roll in confectioners' sugar while still warm.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9 inch square baking pan.
column3: In a double boiler, melt chocolate over low heat with 3 tablespoons of butter. Set aside to cool. In a medium bowl, mix together 2 of the eggs and sugar until thick. Stir in baking powder, salt and 1/2 cup of flour. Blend in cooled chocolate, nuts and vanilla extract. Set aside.
column4: In a separate bowl, cream 2 tablespoons of butter with the cream cheese. Gradually stir in 1/4 cup of sugar. Blend in one egg,1 tablespoon of flour, and 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract.
column5: Spread half of the chocolate batter in a pan. Layer on all of the cream cheese batter. Spoon on the remaining chocolate batter in spots. Zigzag through batter with a knife to create a marbling effect.
column6: Bake 35 to 40 minutes in the preheated oven. Let cool on wire rack before cutting into squares.

column2: To make Pastry: Combine 1/2 cup butter, white sugar, vanilla and the egg in a double boiler over low heat. Stir until thick. Add the graham cracker crumbs, coconut and nuts and mix well. Pour into baking pan and let cool.
column3: To prepare Filling: In medium-sized bowl, dissolve the instant coffee in the hot coffee. Mix in powdered sugar, cocoa, 1/4 cup of butter and milk. Spread filling over pastry and chill for 15 minutes.
column4: To prepare Topping: Melt white chocolate in double boiler over low heat. Spread over filling and cut into squares. Store in refrigerator.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (160 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: In a small saucepan, combine sugar, carrots, spices, raisins, water, orange juice and butter. Bring to a boil, reduce heat and simmer for 5 minutes. Pour mixture into a large bowl and cool to lukewarm. Add flour, baking soda, and salt to the carrot mixture. Mix well, and stir in walnuts.
column4: Bake for 35 to 40 minutes in the preheated oven, or until a toothpick comes out clean.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F. Grease a 9x13 inch pan.
column3: To make Filling: In a saucepan over low heat, combine dates, water, white sugar, and lemon juice. Heat for about 8 minutes, or until thick. Set aside to let cool.
column4: To make Pastry: In a large bowl, combine flour, brown sugar, oats and salt. Mix until well blended. Add in shortening until mixture forms into coarse crumbs.
column5: Press half of pastry mix into pan. Cover with date mixture and spread remaining pastry mix over the top.
column6: Bake 20 to 25 minutes until golden brown. Let cool on wire rack before cutting.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, beat together the butter, vanilla and sugar until light and fluffy. Sift together the salt and flour and mix into the butter mixture. Fold in the chocolate chips and nuts. Mix until well blended. Press batter into a 15x10 inch jelly roll pan.
column4: Bake 20 minutes or until golden brown. Cut into bars and let cool in pan on wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F(175 degrees C).
column3: To make Pastry: Cream together the butter and brown sugar until light and fluffy. Add in the flour and chopped nuts and stir until mixture becomes crumbly. Set aside 1/4 cup to use as a topping.
column4: Press pastry mixture into 8-inch square pan and bake for 12 to 15 minutes. Let cool on rack.
column5: To make Filling: Beat together the white sugar, and cream cheese until smooth. Stir in the egg, milk, lemon juice, and vanilla and mix well. Spread filling mixture over baked crust. Sprinkle reserved mixture on as a topping.
column6: Bake for 25 to 30 minutes. Let cool on wire rack and refrigerate. Serve with fruit.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F.
column3: Spread macadamia nuts on cookie sheet and bake until lightly browned. Set aside and let cool.
column4: In a large bowl, beat eggs until light and fluffy (this should take at least 5 minutes). Gradually add sugar and beat well. Sift together the flour, salt and baking powder and blend into egg mixture. Beat until smooth.
column5: Mix in the lemon zest, lemon juice and nuts. Mix until well blended.
column6: Drop by teaspoonfuls about 3 inches apart on parchment paper lined cookie sheets. Bake for 7 to 9 minutes until cookies are golden with dark edges. Let cool on wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In large bowl, cream together the brown sugar and butter. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla. Sift flour and baking soda together and mix into butter mixture. Stir in cashews and chocolate. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets
column4: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes, or until lightly brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the butter and salt while slowly adding the powdered sugar. Add the nuts, vanilla and flour and mix until well blended.
column4: On a lightly floured surface, roll out dough in the shape of logs about 1/2 inch in diameter. Cut into 1 1/2 inch pieces and bake for 15 to 18 minutes.
column5: Roll cookies in powdered sugar when they are still warm. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Beat shortening and brown sugar together until light and fluffy. Beat in egg and blend thoroughly.
column3: Stir together flour, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, cloves and nutmeg.
column4: Stir half the dry ingredients into creamed mixture. Stir in nuts, apple and raisins, then stir in remaining half of dry ingredients and milk. Mix well.
column5: Drop from tablespoon 1 1/2 inches apart onto lightly greased baking sheet. Bake in a preheated 400 degree oven for 10-12 minutes. Remove cookies to racks and while still warm, spread with glaze.
column6: To make Glaze: Combine powdered sugar, butter, vanilla and enough cream to make glaze of spreading consistency. Beat until smooth. Spread on warm cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, cream together the shortening, vanilla, and honey. Beat in the egg until well blended. Combine the flour, baking soda, baking powder and salt; stir into the honey mixture. Stir in the rolled oats, zucchini, pecans and raisins. Drop by teaspoonfuls on greased cookie sheet, and flatten slightly using a fork.
column4: Bake 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, until browned. Remove from cookie sheets to cool on a wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, cream together the butter and white and brown sugars. Add egg, almond and vanilla extracts and stir well. In a separate bowl, mix together the flour, salt and baking soda. Stir into butter mixture, and mix until well blended. Stir in chopped nuts and oats.
column4: Roll about 1 tablespoon of dough into a ball. Flatten dough on cookie sheet with a fork and bake for 8 to 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together the shortening, sugar and coffee. Beat in the egg, flour, vanilla and chopped nuts. Mix until well blended. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets
column4: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, or until edges are golden. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Melt chocolate over low heat and let cool.
column4: In a large glass or metal bowl, whip egg whites until foamy. Slowly add salt and sugar a little at a time, until mixture stands in peaks. Stir in vanilla. Fold in chocolate, coconut and nuts. Drop by teaspoonfuls about 2 inches apart on cookie sheets.
column5: Bake 10 to 12 minutes. Cookies should be soft in the center.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, cream the butter and brown sugar. Add the egg, syrup and vanilla. Mix until well blended. Sift together the flour, salt and baking soda. Stir into mixture until well blended. Shape into 1 inch balls and roll in sugar. Place on cookie sheets about 2 inches apart and flatten slightly.
column4: Bake 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven. Let cool on wire rack.

column2: In a large mixing bowl, cream the butter, white and dark sugars. Beat in the egg, water and vanilla. In a separate bowl, sift together the flour, baking soda, and salt. Blend flour mixture into the butter mixture, and stir well. Wrap dough in waxed paper and chill at least 2 hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets. Cover each thin mint with 1 tablespoon of dough. Place on cookie sheet and top with a pecan.
column4: Bake at 375 for 10 to 12 minutes. Let cool slightly on cookie sheet before removing to racks.

column2: In a large bowl, sprinkle the yeast on the warm water and stir until dissolved. Stir in the melted butter. Beat in the eggs and sugar until well blended. Gradually mix in flour. Place dough in an airtight container and refrigerate for at least 3 hours and up to 3 days.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Mix together the 1/2 cup sugar and cinnamon. Set aside. Divide dough into 6 equal parts. Sprinkle the cinnamon-sugar mixture into a shallow pan.
column4: Roll out dough into a circle on a flat surface to 1/8 inch thickness. Press dough into shallow pan and sprinkle again with cinnamon-sugar mixture. Cut dough into 8 wedges, as a pie. Sprinkle raisins on each wedge and roll each wedge, starting from widest to point, as a crescent roll. Place each roll on cookie sheets, about 2 inches apart. Let crescents stand 15 minutes before baking.
column5: Bake 15 minutes in the preheated oven, or until golden. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Mix together all ingredients until well-blended.
column4: Roll 2-inch sized pieces of dough into balls and place on cookie sheet. Flatten each with the back of a fork.
column5: Bake 13 to 15 minutes until light brown. Let cool on wire rack.

column2: In a medium sized bowl, mix together the vanilla wafers, cocoa and sugar. Stir in the chopped walnuts, corn syrup and rum. Mix until well blended.
column3: Form dough into 2 inch balls and roll in confectioners' sugar. Store in covered tin.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a small saucepan over low heat, combine butter, water, and dates. Bring to a boil, then remove from heat, and let stand for 10 minutes.
column4: Pour date mixture into a medium bowl. Mix in the brown sugar and chopped nuts.
column5: Whip egg whites in a small bowl until stiff. Fold egg whites into date mixture. Roll dough into 2 inch balls and roll in shredded coconut. Place on cookie sheets about 2 inches apart
column6: Bake for 12 to 15 minutes in the preheated oven. Let cool on wire racks.

column2: In a large mixing bowl beat shortening and butter until softened. Add the 3/4 cup sugar and beat until fluffy. Add milk, egg and 1 tsp of the vanilla and mix well.
column3: In a separate bowl combine flour, cocoa, baking powder and salt. Add to the butter mixture and beat until well mixed.
column4: Divide dough in half and chill 2-3 hours or until easy to handle.
column5: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets.
column6: Mix softened cream cheese, 1/3 cup sugar and 1 tsp vanilla until smooth. Stir in the coconut.
column7: Roll each half of the dough into a 10-inch square. Cut each square into sixteen 2 1/2-inch squares. Place 1/2 inch apart on an ungreased cookie sheet. Cut 1-inch slits from each corner to center of square. Drop a level tsp of the coconut mixture onto each center.
column8: Sprinkle chopped nuts in the center and firmly press to seal. Bake for 8-10 minutes or until edges are firm and cookies are slightly puffed. Cool on cookie sheet for 1 minute, then remove and cool thoroughly on rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F.
column3: Combine flour, 1/3 cup sugar, cocoa and salt. Cut in butter until mixture is crumbly.
column4: Sprinkle with cold water, 1 Tbsp at a time, mixing gently until all the mixture is moistened.
column5: Form this mixture into a ball. Shape dough into twenty-four 1-inch balls and press onto the bottom and up the sides of ungreased 1 3/4-inch muffin cups.
column6: In a small bowl beat cream cheese and 3 tablespoons sugar until fluffy. Separate the egg and beat in the egg yolk, sour cream and vanilla.
column7: Divide the cream cheese mixture evenly among the muffin cups. Top each with about 1/2 tsp of the chocolate chips.
column8: Bake for 5 minutes. Remove from oven.
column9: With a knife or chopstick, slightly swirl chocolate into mixture just to marble. Return to the oven and bake for 20-25 minutes more.
column10: Cool slightly in pan. Remove and cool on a rack.

column2: Grind the 1/2 cup pecans in a blender, food processor, or food grinder.
column3: Combine the nuts with the flour and baking powder.
column4: In a separate bowl beat butter and shortening with an electric mixer for 30 seconds.
column5: Add the sugar and beat until fluffy. Add egg, sour cream and vanilla and beat until well mixed.
column6: Stir in the flour, baking powder and the ground nuts.
column7: Divide dough in half. Cover and chill at least 3 hours.
column8: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F.
column9: Work half of the dough at a time. Keep the other half refrigerated. Roll dough to 1/8-inch thickness on a lightly floured surface. Cut with desired cookie cutter.
column10: Place on an ungreased cookie sheet and bake 7-8 minutes or until done. Remove from sheet and cool on a rack.
column11: To make lemon glaze: Beat 1 egg white until frothy. Add 1 1/2 cups sifted powdered sugar, 1 tablespoon lemon juice and a dash of salt. Beat well.
column12: Spread cookies with Lemon Glaze and sprinkle with nuts.

column2: Melt unsweetened chocolate squares in a heavy saucepan. Cool slightly.
column3: In a large bowl beat 1/2 cup shortening and butter or margarine with an electric mixer on medium speed until butter is softened. Add the sugar and brown sugar and beat until fluffy.
column4: Dissolve the instant coffee crystals in the water. Add the melted chocolate, egg and coffee to the butter mixture and beat well.
column5: Stir flour, cinnamon and salt together and add to the butter mixture. Cover and chill about 1 hour or until easy to handle.
