column6: Shape into two 7-inch long rolls. Wrap in plastic wrap and chill for at least 6 hours or overnight.
column7: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
column8: Cut into 1/4-inch slices and place on an ungreased cookie sheet. Bake for 10-12 minutes. Remove to a wire rack and cool.
column9: Melt the semisweet chocolate pieces and 3 tablespoons of shortening over low heat. Dip on half of each cookie into the chocolate mixture. Place on waxed paper until the chocolate is set.

column2: In mixing bowl beat butter or margarine until softened. Add the sugar and beat until fluffy. Add the milk and vanilla and mix well.
column3: Add the flour and beat until well mixed. Stir in the cherries and pecans.
column4: Shape into three 7-inch long rolls. Roll in the coconut to coat.
column5: Wrap in plastic wrap and chill for several hours or overnight.
column6: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F.
column7: Cut rolls into 1/4-inch slices and place on an ungreased cookie sheet. Bake about 12 minutes or until done. Remove to a wire rack and cool.

column2: In large bowl beat shortening and butter or margarine until butter is softened. Add the sugar and beat until fluffy.
column3: Add the egg, milk, orange peel, and vanilla and beat until well mixed. Add flour and baking powder and mix well.
column4: Cover and chill about 30 minutes or until easy to handle.
column5: Shape dough into two 8-inch long rolls. Wrap in plastic wrap and chill for several hours or overnight.
column6: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
column7: Cut rolls into 1/4-inch slices. Place on ungreased cookie sheet.
column8: On the bottom half of each slice, place a cherry for the bell clapper. Fold in the sides of the slice, overlapping at the top and slightly covering cherry. Pinch in the sides to form a bell shape.
column9: Bake for 12-14 minutes or until done. Remove and cool on wire rack.

column2: Stir together flour, sugar, salt, mace, and baking powder. Cut in butter or margarine until mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
column3: Combine 1 tablespoon water and lemon extract and sprinkle over the mixture. Toss gently with a fork.
column4: Repeat with the remaining cold water, 1 tablespoon at a time until all is moistened.
column5: Form into a ball, cover and chill for about 30 minutes or until easy to handle.
column6: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F.
column7: Divide the dough into quarters. Roll two of the quarters into 12 x 4-inch rectangles and spread with the preserves. Roll the remaining two quarters into 12 x 4-inch rectangles and carefully place over those spread with the preserves. Trim the edges.
column8: Cut each rectangle into twelve 4 x 1-inch strips. Twist each strip twice and pinch ends to seal. Place on an ungreased cookie sheet. Bake for 15 minutes.
column9: Remove from oven, brush with milk and sprinkle with additional sugar. Return to the oven and bake 5-8 minutes more or until done. Remove and cool on wire rack.

column2: In a large bowl beat butter or margarine until softened. Add 1 cup sugar and beat until fluffy. Add the egg and vanilla and beat well.
column3: Stir together the flour, baking soda, salt, and nutmeg. Add flour mixture and sour cream alternately to butter mixture. Beat until well mixed.
column4: Cover and chill at least 2 hours or until easy to handle.
column5: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
column6: Combine cinnamon and 2 tablespoons of sugar in a small bowl. Roll dough 1/8 inch thick. Cut into rings with a 2 1/2-inch doughnut cutter.
column7: Twist the rings once to form figure eights and place 2 inches apart on an ungreased cookie sheet. Spinkle with cinnamon-sugar mixture. Bake for 6-8 minutes or until done. Remove and cool on a wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F.
column3: Cut the 6 tablespoons of cold butter into the flour until it resembles coarse crumbs.
column4: Sprinkle 1 tablespoon of cream over the mixture and toss gently with a fork. Repeat with the remaining cream until all is moistened. Form into a ball.
column5: Roll the dough to slightly less than 1/8 inch thick. Cut into rounds with a 1 1/2-inch cookie cutter. Sprinkle one side of each round with sugar and place on an ungreased cookie sheet, sugar side up.
column6: Prick each round in four parallel rows with a fork.
column7: Bake for 8-10 minutes or until the edges just begin to brown. Remove to a rack and cool completely.
column8: Make filling as follows. Stir together the powdered sugar, 1 tablespoon softened butter, vanilla, food coloring, and enough of the 1 tablespoon cream to make it spreadable.
column9: Spread 1/2 teaspoon of the filling on the flat side of half of the cookies. Top with the remaining cookies, flat side down.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Line cookie sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Finely grind the almonds, sugar, cinnamon and salt in a food processor.
column4: Separate one of the eggs and add the white, the other egg, and almond extract and process until the mixture holds together. Transfer to a bowl and stir in the chocolate.
column5: Moisten hands and roll mixture into 1-inch balls. Place on prepared cookie sheet. Flatten to 1/3-inch thick rounds.
column6: Bake until tops puff and centers are still soft, about 12 minutes. Remove to a rack and cool completely. Replace parchment paper for next round of cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Line cookie sheet with parchment paper.
column3: In a mixing bowl beat sugar, vanilla, lemon peel and 6 tablespoons of butter with an electric mixer until well blended. Add eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition. Continue to beat for 1 minute.
column4: Stir in flour and baking powder (will be a soft, sticky dough). Spoon dough into a pastry bag fitted with a 3/8-inch round tip. Pipe 2-inch diameter rings onto the prepared cookie sheet.
column5: With moistened fingertips, press ends of each ring together to form a smooth ring.
column6: Bake about 20 minutes or until golden brown.
column7: To make icing: Melt 1 tablespoon of butter over low heat. Add sugar, water, lemon juice and vanilla and whisk until sugar melts and mixture is heated through. Thin with more water if icing is too thick to brush.
column8: Remove cookies from oven and immediately brush warm icing over hot cookies. Cool iced cookies on sheet for 2 minutes. Transfer to a rack and cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F. Grease cookie sheet.
column3: Beat butter until smooth. Add sugar and mix until fluffy. Mix in orange concentrate, orange peel and vanilla.
column4: Add flour and mix until dough comes together.
column5: Form 1 rounded tablespoon of dough into a ball. Place on prepared cookie sheet and flatten to a 2-inch round. Repeat with the remaining dough. Press 1 walnut half firmly onto each round.
column6: Bake about 12 minutes or until cookies just begin to brown. Remove to a rack and cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F.
column3: In a mixing bowl beat butter and both brown sugars until creamy. Add eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition. Stir in vanilla.
column4: Mix together the flour, baking soda and salt. Add to the butter mixture and stir just until combined.
column5: Mix in the chocolate chunks and pecans. Drop dough by rounded tablespoonfuls onto an ungreased cookie sheet. Flatten slightly with the back of the spoon.
column6: Bake about 15 minutes or until golden brown. Cool slightly on cookie sheet. Remove to a rack and cool completely.

column2: In a mixing bowl beat butter and 1/2 cup sugar with an electric mixer until smooth. Beat in lemon peel and vanilla.
column3: In a food processor, finely grind flour, nuts, salt and cinnamon. Add to butter mixture and mix just until dough holds together.
column4: Gather dough into a ball and flatten into a disk. Wrap in plastic and chill for about 1 hour or until firm.
column5: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F. Butter cookie sheet.
column6: Roll dough on a lightly floured surface to 1/4-inch thick. Cut out cookies with a 3-inch round cookie cutter. Gather scraps into a ball and re-roll to 1/4-inch thick. Cut out cookies, forming total of 12. Transfer cookies to the cookie sheet.
column7: Using a 1-inch round cookie butter, cut out the center of 6 cookies and remove. Bake about 20 minutes or until golden. Cool on rack for 5 minutes.
column8: Leaving a 1/8-inch border, spread 1 1/2 teaspoons of marmalade evenly over each cookie without a hole. Sift additional powdered sugar over cookies with holes. Place cookies with holes sugar side up atop jam-covered cookies.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Line 2 cookie sheets with parchment paper or foil.
column3: In large mixing bowl, beat sugar and butter until light and fluffy. Add eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition. Combine brandy, anise extract and vanilla in a small bowl or measuring cup. In a medium bowl, combine flour, baking powder and salt. Alternately add dry ingredients and brandy mixture to the butter mixture, beginning and ending with the dry ingredients. Stir in the almonds and aniseed.
column4: Drop dough by spoonfuls onto prepared sheet, forming two 2 x 13-inch long strips on each sheet. Smooth dough into logs with moistened fingertips.
column5: Bake about30 to 35 minutes or until golden and firm to the touch. Place cookie sheets on racks and cool completely. Reduce the oven temperature to 300 degrees F.
column6: Cut cooled logs on the diagonal into 3/4-inch thick slices using a serrated knife. Place slices on cookie sheets.
column7: Bake for about 20 minutes, turning after 10 minutes, until dry and slightly brown. Remove to a rack and cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F.
column3: Sprinkle sesame seeds onto a large baking sheet and bake about 20 minutes or until light gold, stirring occasionally. Let cool.
column4: Line cookie sheet with parchment paper.
column5: With an electric mixer, beat almond paste and sugar until only very small pieces of the paste remain. Separate the eggs and add the egg whites and mix on high speed until mixture is smooth. Mix in sesame seeds.
column6: Drop by rounded teaspoonfuls onto prepared cookie sheet, spacing 2 inches apart. Bake about 14 minutes or until cookies are puffed, pale golden and the edges begin to brown.
column7: Transfer cookies on the parchment paper to a rack and cool completely. Carefully peel cookies from parchment paper.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, sift together the flour and baking powder. Mix in the oatmeal. Cream together the butter and the sugar and add to mixture. Stir in the milk until mixture forms a thick paste.
column4: Knead dough on a floured surface until smooth. Roll out dough to approximately 1/8" thickness. Cut into rounds with cookie cutter about 2 1/2 inches in diameter. Transfer to cookie sheets and prick with a fork.
column5: Bake 15 to 18 minutes, or until golden. Let cool on wire rack. Store in an airtight tin.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F(190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Cream the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the egg yolk and vanilla extract. Sift together the flour, cornstarch, and salt; stir into the butter mixture. Shape dough into 20 to 24 small balls, about 1/2 inch in diameter. Roll each ball in the oats and place about 2 inches apart on cookie sheets.
column4: Bake 15 to 20 minutes until golden brown. Let cool on wire rack. Store in an airtight tin.

column2: Sift together the flour and salt into a large bowl. Cream in the butter until mixture resembles fine breadcrumbs. Mix in the sugar and Madeira, until mixture becomes stiff. Wrap dough in foil or plastic, and refrigerate for 30 minutes.
column3: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column4: On a lightly floured surface, knead dough lightly until smooth. Roll out to approximately 1/8" and prick all over with a fork. Cut dough into 36 fingers measuring 1 x 2 1/2 inches. Place on cookie sheets. In a small bowl, lightly beat the egg. Brush cookie fingers with the egg and sprinkle each with sugar.
column5: Bake for about 15 minutes or until light golden in color. Let cool on wire racks. Store in an airtight container.

column2: Sift together the flour, cinnamon and the salt into a large bowl. Cut in the butter with a fork until mixture becomes crumbly. Add sugar and vanilla extract, and mix to a stiff paste. Mix in egg. Knead dough on a floured surface until smooth. Wrap in foil or plastic wrap. Refrigerate for 30 minutes.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets. Roll out dough thinly and cut into 24 rounds.
column4: Bake 12 to 15 minutes, or until lightly gold in color. Let cool on wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Sift the flour into a bowl and cut in the butter or margarine. Mix in the sugar and almonds. Using a fork, mix in the egg until dough becomes stiff.
column4: Knead dough on a lightly floured surface until smooth. Roll out dough into a thin layer and cut into rounds, 2 inches wide. Re-roll trimmings and cut until you have 20 rounds. Place rounds on cookie sheets.
column5: Bake for 12 minutes in the preheated oven, or until light brown. Let cool on the sheet for about 3 minutes, then transfer to wire racks.
column6: When biscuits are completely cold, spread half of the rounds with a thin layer of preserves and sandwich together. Dust with confectioners' sugar.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Sift the flour and cinnamon and add to the butter mixture. Spread the mixture into an ungreased baking pan measuring 11x7 inches. Beat the egg and brush over the top of the dough. Prick dough all over with a fork. Sprinkle dough with almonds and sugar.
column4: Bake for 20 to 25 minutes, until golden brown. Let cool on wire rack for 5 minutes before cutting into 12 bars. Store in an airtight container.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets.
column3: Cream butter and peanut butter together. Add the sugars and stir until well mixed.
column4: Add eggs one at a time, then add vanilla.
column5: Mix oatmeal and baking soda separately, then stir into batter.
column6: Add chocolate chips last.
column7: Drop by heaping teaspoons onto cookie sheets. Bake for 12-15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together shortening and peanut butter; gradually add sugar and brown sugar, creaming well. Beat in the egg and vanilla.
column4: Sift together dry ingredients and add to creamy mixture.
column5: Shape dough into balls, using a rounded teaspoon for each ball. Roll balls in sugar and place on a greased cookie sheet.
column6: Bake at 350 degrees for 10 minutes. Remove from oven. Top each cookie with a candy kiss, pressing down firmly so cookie cracks around edges.
column7: Put back into oven for 2 to 5 minutes longer, until golden brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Measure oats into a blender or food processor, and then blend to a fine powder. Set aside.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together butter and sugars. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla. In a separate bowl, mix together flour, oats, salt, baking powder, and baking soda. Stir dry ingredients into creamed butter and sugar. Add chocolate chips, grated chocolate, and nuts.
column4: Drop by rounded teaspoons onto ungreased cookie sheets. Bake for 6 to 8 minutes in the preheated oven.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Lightly grease two baking sheets.
column3: In a large bowl beat the butter and sugar with an electric mixer until mixture is creamy and light.
column4: Add the egg, a little at a time, beating well between each addition. Add the lemon zest.
column5: Add the sifted flour and spices and, using a wooden spoon, stir well until the mixture forms a stiff dough.
column6: Knead dough lightly in the bowl and, using your hands, shape the dough into 25 small balls.
column7: Place the balls on the greased baking sheets, leaving room between each to spread during baking.
column8: Flatten each cookie slightly with the prongs of a fork dipped in flour. Press the fork in two directions to make a crisscross pattern.
column9: Bake for 10 minutes until golden. Remove from oven and let cool on a heatproof surface for five minutes. Then, with a spatula, transfer cookies to a cooling rack until cold.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
column3: Combine sugar, peanut butter, and egg.
column4: Shape into 1 inch balls and place on ungreased cookie sheet. NOTE: If dough is too sticky, refrigerate 1/2 hour or until easy to handle.
column5: Bake for 10 minutes. Remove cookies from oven. Press a chocolate kiss into the center of each warm cookie.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F.
column3: Lightly spoon flour into a measuring cup. Level off. In a bowl combine the flour and powered sugar.
column4: Cut in butter with a fork and mix well. Press mixture into a 9 inch square pan.
column5: Bake at 375 for 15 to 17 minutes until lightly brown.
column6: To make Filling: Spread jam evenly over baked crust . In a small bowl beat cream cheese and milk until smooth. Melt white chocolate chips over low heat and add to mixture. Beat until smooth. Drop cream cheese mixture by teaspoons evenly over jam. Spread carefully and refrigerate.
column7: To make Glaze Topping: Cut chocolate squares into small pieces and melt with shortening over low heat, stirring constantly. Spread over white chocolate layer. Cool completely. Cut into bars and store in refrigerator.

column2: In a large bowl, cream together the butter, 1 cup white sugar, and brown sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla. Combine the flour, cocoa, and baking soda; stir into the sugar mixture until well blended. Stir in 1/2 cup of the pecans. Cover, and refrigerate dough for 1 hour, or until firm.
column3: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). In a shallow bowl, combine the remaining 1/2 cup pecans and 1 tablespoon of sugar; set aside.
column4: Press 1 tablespoon of cookie dough around each chocolate coated caramel, forming a ball. Dip one side of each ball into the pecan mixture; and place pecan side up, 2 inches apart on ungreased baking sheets.
column5: Bake for 8 minutes in the preheated oven (the cookies will look soft). Cool on the pans for one minute before removing to wire racks to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the butter and sugar until fluffy. Add vanilla and tahini, mix until well combined. In a separate bowl, sift together the flour and baking powder, then stir into butter mixture. Drop onto an ungreased cookie sheet in tablespoon-sized pieces.
column4: Bake in preheated oven until they turn golden brown, about 15 minutes. Cool on the cookie sheet 10 to 15 minutes before removing to cool on a wire rack.

column2: Combine eggs, sugar and salt; beat well. Add remaining ingredients and beat until smooth.
column3: Heat a rosette iron in deep, hot oil (375 degrees) for 2 minutes.
column4: Drain excess oil from iron. Dip in batter to 1/4 inch from the top of the iron, then dip iron immediately into hot oil (375 degrees).
column5: Fry rosette until golden, about 30 seconds. Lift out; tip upside down to drain. With fork, push rosette off iron onto a rack placed over paper towels.
column6: Reheat iron 1 minute; make next rosette.
column7: Sprinkle rosettes with confectioners' sugar.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the margarine, white sugar, brown sugar, and peanut butter until smooth. Beat in the eggs, two at a time, then stir in the corn syrup and vanilla. Mix in baking soda and oats until well blended. Stir in the chocolate candies and chocolate chips. Roll dough into 2 inch balls, and place 3 inches apart on an ungreased cookie sheet. Flatten slightly with a fork.
column4: Bake for 12 to 15 minutes in the preheated oven. Cool on cookie sheets for a few minutes, before transferring to wire racks to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Lightly grease cookie sheets.
column3: Cream together the butter, sugar, eggs and vanilla.
column4: Mix in the flour and potato chips and stir well.
column5: Drop by teaspoon onto cookie sheets about 2 inches apart. Bake for 12 to 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the sugars and the butter. Add in the eggs and mix well.
column4: Mix in the vanilla, corn syrup, baking soda, and peanut butter. Stir until well blended.
column5: Add in the oatmeal one cup at a time and mix well. Lastly, stir in the chocolate chips and M & Ms by hand. Form dough into balls and place about 2 inches apart on cookie sheets. Bake 12 - 15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together butter and sugar until smooth. Stir in egg yolk and vanilla. Gradually stir in the flour until just blended, then mix in crushed potato chips and pecans. Drop by rounded spoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets. Criss-cross the top using a fork dipped in water.
column4: Bake 12 to 14 minutes in preheated oven, or until edges are lightly browned. Cool on baking sheets.

column2: Cream together the margarine and cream cheese in the bowl of an electric mixer. Blend in the vanilla. Mix in the flour. Chill the dough.
column3: To make the Filling: Mix together the chopped raisins, chopped walnuts, and cinnamon. If you have a food processor, place the whole walnuts and raisins into the bowl, sprinkle with the cinnamon, and chop them together by processing in short pulses.
column4: Divide the dough into 4 equal portions. Roll out each portion into a 10 - 12 inch circle 1/8 inch thick on a lightly floured board or between two sheets of waxed paper.
column5: Spread a light layer of preserves (approximately 2 tablespoons) onto each dough circle. Sprinkle each circle with approximately 1/4 cup of the chopped nut-raisin-cinnamon mixture.
column6: Cut each circle into 16 wedges using a pastry cutter or a pizza cutter. Roll each wedge from base to point. Place point down on a lightly greased or parchment lined baking sheets.
column7: Bake for 15-17 minutes at 375 degrees F (or until golden). Remove to racks to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Pour cake mix into a large bowl. Stir in the oil and eggs until well blended. Mix in chocolate chips. Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto the prepared cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven. Remove from pan to cool on wire racks.

column2: Mix oats, flour, sugar and coconut together.
column3: In a small saucepan over low heat, melt the syrup and butter together. Mix the soda and the boiling water and add to the melted butter and syrup.
column4: Add butter mixture to the dry ingredients. Drop by teaspoons on greased cookie sheets (or baking paper).
column5: Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 18 to 20 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 deg. F (180 deg. C).
column3: Cream together shortening and granulated sugar.
column4: Beat in 4 eggs, then stir in flour, salt and baking soda.
column5: Drop by heaping teaspoonfuls on to ungreased cookie sheets.
column6: Bake at 350 deg. F (180 deg. C) for 10 to 12 minutes.
column7: Prepare frosting by combining melted butter, vanilla, 1 egg, and powdered sugar in a medium bowl. Beat with electric mixer until smooth. Frost cookies when they are cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
column3: Combine cake mix, oil and eggs in a large bowl. Add butterscotch chips and mix well.
column4: Drop dough by tablespoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column5: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes until the center is just set. Let stand 2 minutes.
column6: Remove to wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F. Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Melt the butter in a sauce pan over low heat. Pour into bowl and combine with cake mix and egg. Beat on low with an electric mixer until blended.
column4: Stir in chocolate chips, pecans and 1/4 cup of almonds.
column5: Shape dough into balls. Press top of ball in remaining almonds.
column6: Bake for 9-11 minutes or until lightly browned.

column2: In a large bowl, cream butter and shortening; gradually add sugars, beating well at medium speed with an electric mixer. Beat in egg and vanilla. Combine flour, soda, and salt; stir into creamed mixture. Stir in white chocolate and macadamia nuts. Chill dough for 1 hour.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets. Drop dough by heaping tablespoonfuls 3 inches apart onto prepared cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 12 to 14 minutes in preheated oven. Cookies will be soft. Cool slightly on cookie sheets; transfer to wire racks to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
column3: Combine dry ingredients and set aside.
column4: In a separate bowl, beat butter and sugar together until light. Add eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition.
column5: Stir in dry ingredients 1/2 cup at a time. Add almonds, if desired.
column6: Roll into one inch balls and arrange 1 inch apart on ungreased baking sheet. Bake 11 to 14 minutes.
column7: Cool and store in airtight containers for 3 days to mellow flavors.

column2: Preheat your oven to 375 degrees F. Spray a large cookie sheet with non-stick spray.
column3: In a large bowl, with a mixer set on low speed, beat corn-oil spread and brown sugar until blended. Increase speed to high; beat until well combined, about 3 minutes. At low speed, add egg whites, egg, and vanilla; beat until smooth.
column4: With spoon, stir in flour, oats, raisins, baking powder, and salt until combined.
column5: Drop dough by heaping tablespoons, about 2 inches apart, on cookie sheet. Flatten dough into 3-inch circles. Bake cookies 16-18 minutes or until golden brown. With a pancake turner, remove cookies to wire racks to cool for 15 minutes. Store cookies in tightly covered container.

column2: Bring margarine, sugar, milk and cocoa to boil. Let boil for exactly 1 minute and 30 seconds.
column3: Remove from heat, stir in vanilla and peanut butter. Then stir in oats.
column4: Quickly drop by large tablespoon onto wax paper laid on top of newpaper. Let cool, peel from paper and turn over to finish drying.
column5: Store in closed container.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
column3: Mix in the order given. Spoon onto cookie sheet and gently press into cookie shape. Bake for 10 to 15 minutes until golden. NOTE: You can add choclate chips to half the recipe for an awesome taste.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter and sugar until smooth. Mix in the egg and vanilla. Combine the flour and baking powder; stir into the creamed mixture until blended. Divide dough into walnut sized portions. Roll each piece into a rope and then shape into a loop. Place cookies 2 inches apart on the prepared cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven, until firm and golden at the edges.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In large bowl, beat butter, sugar, eggs, and vanilla until light and fluffy. Combine the flour, cocoa, baking soda, and salt; stir into the butter mixture until well blended. Mix in the chocolate chips and walnuts. Drop by rounded teaspoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or just until set. Cool slightly on the cookie sheets before transferring to wire racks to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Mix dry ingredients, then add remaining ingredients. Dough will be thin.
column4: Drop by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheet. Bake for 10 to 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream together butter and brown sugar. Beat in eggs, peanut butter and vanilla.
column4: Add flour, cornstarch, salt, baking soda and baking powder. Stir in chocolate chips.
column5: Roll into balls about 1 1/2 teaspoonfuls (or use cookie scoop) and place onto ungreased cookie sheets about 2 inches apart. Flatten slightly because they do not flatten much while cooking.
column6: Bake for 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Grease and flour a 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: Melt the butter over medium heat. Remove from heat and stir in the chocolate until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the sugar and vanilla. Combine the flour and salt, gently stir into the mixture until just blended. Spread evenly into the prepared pan.
column4: Bake for 25 to 30 minutes in the preheated oven, until brownies begin to pull away from the sides of the pan.

column2: In a medium saucepan, combine sugar, milk, butter, and cocoa. Bring to a boil, and cook for 1 1/2 minutes. Remove from heat, and stir in peanut butter, oats, and vanilla. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto wax paper. Let cool until hardened.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: In a large mixer bowl, beat butter and sugar until creamy. Add eggs and vanilla extract; beat until light and fluffy.
column4: In a separate bowl, stir together flour, baking soda and salt; gradually blend into butter mixture.
column5: Stir in vanilla chips, and macadamia nuts. Drop by rounded tablespoonfuls onto an ungreased cookie sheet.
column6: Bake for 9 minutes. (Do not overbake; cookies will be soft. They will puff while baking; flatten upon cooling.) Cool slightly, remove from cookie sheet to wire rack. Cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Spray cookie sheets with non-stick cooking spray.
column3: Mix ingredients in the order given. Drop by tablespoons onto cookie sheets about 2 inches apart.
column4: Bake for 3 1/2 to 4 minutes, then switch racks and bake another 3 1/2 to 4 minutes. Remove from oven and let cool on racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C). Lightly grease baking sheets.
column3: Beat butter, sugars, egg, and vanilla at medium speed of electric mixer until fluffy.
column4: At low speed, gradually beat in flour, just until blended. By hand, stir in nuts and chocolate.
column5: Drop by heaping tablespoonfuls, 2 1/2 inches apart, onto lightly greased cookie sheets.
column6: Bake for 17 minutes or until edges of cookies are lightly browned and tops look dry. Allow to cool on baking sheets five minutes, then remove to racks to cool completely.

column2: In a medium-sized bowl, mix the flour with spices, baking powder and salt.
column3: In a large bowl, beat butter and sugar at high speed until light and fluffy. Beat in the egg and mix well.
column4: Stir in by hand half the flour mixture, then add the remaining flour and almonds. Mix with a wooden spoon or knead with hands.
column5: Divide dough into four parts, wrap in plastic and refrigerate for several hours. (If you are using a mold, chill it as well.)
column6: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C) and grease two cookie sheets.
column7: Remove one quarter of the dough from the refrigerator and flatten it with your hands. Oil your mold and lightly flour it. Using your fingers, press dough firmly into the mold. Trim any excess dough from the mold with a knife.
column8: Transfer the cookies onto greased cookie sheets with a spatula, spacing about one inch apart.
column9: Refrigerate dough trimming to be rerolled later. Lightly flour but do not re-oil cookie mold.
column10: Repeat process with remaining dough. When cookie sheets are full, bake cookies for 20 - 25 minutes or until golden brown around the edges. Store in a covered tin.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Cream shortening, sugar and egg. Add half of the dry ingredients.
column4: Blend in milk and remaining dry ingredients.
column5: Add nuts, raisins, apples and mix.
column6: Drop on greased cookie sheet. Bake for 10 to 12 minutes. Let cool and spread with Vanilla Glaze (see recipe).

column2: Combine milk with vinegar to make sour milk. Let stand for 5 minutes.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, combine sugars, shortening, eggs, and vanilla. Add flour, soda, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
column4: Stir in sour milk and mix well. NOTE: Dough will be very sticky and hard to handle. You could refrigerate it for a few hours, or just use plenty of flour when rolling out.
column5: Roll on well floured board to 1/2 inch thickness. Cut with cookie cutters to desired shapes (large cutters work best).
column6: Bake at 350 degrees F (180 degrees C) for 8 to 10 minutes or until lightly brown on bottom.
column7: Frost with Sugar Cookie Frosting (see recipe) and decorate.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Cream together shortening and sugar replacement. Add egg and blend well.
column4: Sift all dry ingredients together and add alternately with applesauce and water to creamed mixture. Be sure to add flour first and last.
column5: Drop by teaspoonfuls onto greased cookie sheets. Bake at 375 degrees F for 12-15 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: To make Bottom Layer: Mix one cup flour and 1/4 cup confectioners sugar. Melt the butter and stir into flour mixture.
column4: Press flat and even into an 8x8 inch baking dish. Bake for 20 minutes.
column5: While baking, make the top layer: Mix 1 cup sugar, 2 tablespoons flour, and the baking powder.
column6: Beat eggs and add to mixture, stirring well. Add lemon juice and rind, mix again.
column7: Pour over bottom layer; Bake at 350 for 25 minutes. Cool a little, cut into squares while warm; dust with confectioners sugar.

column2: In a large bowl, cream the butter and 1/3 cup confectioner's sugar until light and fluffy. Add the vanilla extract.
column3: In a separate bowl, combine the flour, ground pecans, 1/2 cup ground chocolate, cinnamon and salt; mix well.
column4: Gradually add the dry ingredients to the creamed mixture.
column5: Wrap dough in plastic wrap and chill 1 to 2 hours, or until firm.
column6: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column7: Shape the dough into 1-inch balls. Place balls 1 inch apart on an ungreased baking sheet. Bake 15 to 18 minutes, or until the cookies are firm to the touch. Cool 1 minute on the baking sheet, then transfer to a wire rack.
column8: For the coating, sift 1/2 cup of the confectioner's sugar and 1/4 cup of the ground cocoa into a shallow bowl. While cookies are still warm, roll them in the coating.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (or 190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Put all ingredients except raisins (or chips) and walnuts in food processor. Mix well.
column4: Put in bowl and add raisins and walnuts, stir.
column5: Drop by teaspoons onto greased cookie sheets. Bake for 12-15 minutes. NOTE: Can use parchment paper instead of grease on cookie sheet.

column2: Combine 1 cup of sugar and corn syrup; bring to a boil but do not cook.
column3: Add peanut butter and cereal.
column4: Put in 8 x 4 inch pan and pack down. Cool and frost if desired.
column5: To make Frosting: Combine last 4 ingredients and boil 1 minute; beating well. Frost and cut into bars.

column2: Wipe 1" wide band of butter around the rim of a 3 quart pan to prevent boil-over.
column3: Combine milk, sugar, cocoa, butter and peanut butter.
column4: Stir and bring to boil over medium heat. Let boil for 1 1/2 minutes, do not stir.
column5: Remove from heat. Stir in oats and vanilla. Stir until oats evenly distributed.
column6: Drop by teaspoon onto waxed paper. Cool. Makes 4 to 5 dozen.

column2: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). To prevent burning you can bake on an air cushion baking sheet or put parchment paper on a regular cookie sheet.
column3: Beat egg whites, salt, cream of tartar, and vanilla until very firm. Gradually add sugar and mix. Fold in chocolate chips.
column4: Drop by teaspoonfuls on pan. Bake 300 degrees for 25 minutes. They should only be lightly browned.

column2: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, combine the cake mix, oil, and eggs Beat with an electric beater for 3 to 4 minutes, until well blended. With a spoon, stir in the chopped candy.
column4: Drop by teaspoonfuls 2 inches apart on to cookie sheets that have been coated with nonstick baking spray. Bake for 9 to 11 minutes, or until the cookies are firm. Remove the cookies to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column3: Beat egg whites with the salt until foamy. Slowly add sugar, one tablespoonful at a time, beating after each addition until the meringue stands in stiff peaks.
column4: Stir in vanilla and fold in chocolate chips. Drop by teaspoonfuls on a lined baking sheet and place in preheated oven.
column5: After 2 minutes, turn off oven. Leave meringues in oven overnight. Remove from pan and store in cookie tin lined with paper towel.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line baking sheet with parchment paper; set aside.
column3: In medium bowl, with electric mixer on medium speed, beat egg whites until frothy; add cream of tartar and salt. Beat on high speed until stiff.
column4: Beat in sugar 1 tablespoon at a time. Add vanilla and fold in chocolate chips.
column5: Drop batter by heaping teaspoonfuls onto prepared baking sheet. Place in oven. Turn oven off; leave cookies in oven 5 hours. Variation: Add food coloring for festive holiday touch: green for Christmas; pink and yellow for Easter, etc.

column2: Stir together flour, sugar, baking soda, spices, and dash black pepper.
column3: In large saucepan, combine molasses and butter; heat and stir until butter melts. Cool to room temperature.
column4: Stir in eggs. Add dry ingredients to molasses mixture; mix well. Cover. Chill several hours or overnight.
column5: Shape into 1" balls. Place on greased cookie sheet.
column6: Bake at 350 degrees F (180 degrees C) for 12 to 14 minutes or until cookies are done. Remove. Cool. Roll in powdered sugar.

column2: Bring sugar and syrup to a boil. Add peanut butter and stir well. Remove from heat. Stir in cereal (see Cook's Note).
column3: Pat into a lightly greased 9x13-inch pan, or drop by spoonfuls onto waxed paper.
column4: Allow to cool before slicing bars.

column2: Melt butter and chocolate either in a microwave or over low heat on the stove. Allow to cool slightly.
column3: Stir in remaining ingredients, except powdered sugar. Mix well.
column4: Cover dough and chill for 30 minutes.
column5: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C).
column6: Shape dough into 1 inch balls. Roll in powdered sugar to coat heavily. Place 2 inches apart on an ungreased cookie sheet. Bake for 15 to 18 minutes or until edges are set. Remove from cookie sheet and cool on rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets.
column3: Beat butter and shortening until soft and creamy. Gradually add the sugars and beat well.
column4: Add egg and vanilla and beat well.
column5: Combine flour, soda and salt; gradually add to butter mixture beating well after each addition. Stir in chips and nuts.
column6: Drop dough by rounded teaspoonfuls onto lightly greased cookie sheets. Bake for 10-12 minutes or until done. Remove to wire racks to cool.

column2: Blend syrup, sugar, vanilla and salt in a 2 quart microwave-safe dish. Cook on high 4 minutes, or until mixture boils and sugar dissolves.
column3: Stir in peanut butter, then add the cereal.
column4: Drop by teaspoonfuls onto waxed paper. Let cool before storing.

column2: Preheat oven to 225 degrees F (110 degrees C). Line 2 cookie sheets with foil.
column3: In a large glass or metal mixing bowl, beat egg whites, salt, and cream of tartar to soft peaks. Gradually add sugar, continuing to beat until whites form stiff peaks. Drop by spoonfuls 1 inch apart on the prepared cookie sheets. Sprinkle crushed peppermint candy over the cookies.
column4: Bake for 1 1/2 hours in preheated oven. Meringues should be completely dry on the inside. Do not allow them to brown. Turn off oven. Keep oven door ajar, and let meringues sit in the oven until completely cool. Loosen from foil with metal spatula. Store loosely covered in cool dry place for up to 2 months.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Beat egg whites until stiff.
column4: Add cream of tartar and salt. Beat until stiff.
column5: Add sugar and beat until glossy. Add vanilla (or any flavoring) and any coloring, if desired. Add chocolate chips, nuts or raisins if desired.
column6: Drop on greased sheet. Place in preheated oven and turn heat off. Leave for 4-6 hours or over night. Do not double recipe as oven will not hold the cookies.

column2: Cook butter or margarine, milk and sugar in kettle and boil for 1 and 1/2 minutes.
column3: Add peanut butter, oatmeal, cocoa powder and any one of the optional ingredients.
column4: Drop on waxed paper and allow to cool before serving.

column2: Butter a 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: In a saucepan over medium heat, combine the sugar and corn syrup, and bring to a rolling boil. Remove from heat, and stir in peanut butter. Mix in the rice cereal until evenly coated. Press the mixture into the prepared pan.
column4: In a glass bowl in the microwave, melt the chocolate and butterscotch chips, stirring occasionally until smooth and well blended. Spread over the top of the bars. Chill until set, then cut into bars.

column2: In a medium bowl, mix together cocoa, white sugar, and vegetable oil. Beat in eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla. Combine the flour, baking powder, and salt; stir into the cocoa mixture. Cover dough, and chill for at least 4 hours.
column3: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line cookie sheets with parchment paper. Roll dough into one inch balls. I like to use a number 50 size scoop. Coat each ball in confectioners' sugar before placing onto prepared cookie sheets.
column4: Bake in preheated oven for 10 to 12 minutes. Let stand on the cookie sheet for a minute before transferring to wire racks to cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter and sugar. Stir in vanilla and eggs.
column4: In another bowl, sift together flour, baking powder and salt; add to egg mixture alternately with milk.
column5: On a lightly floured surface, roll the dough 1/4 inch thick. Cut into 1/4 to 1/2 inch wide strips and, on a well-buttered baking sheet, form into window frames.
column6: Keeping the colors separate, place candy in plastic bags and crush with a meat mallet. Place crushed candies inside window frames.
column7: Bake for six minutes, or until candy is just melted. Cool on baking sheet for 5 minutes, until candy is hard. Carefully lift cookies off baking sheet with spatula.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets or line with parchment paper.
column3: Cream butter, sugars, eggs and vanilla until very smooth and fluffy.
column4: In a separate bowl, mix together flour, salt, baking powder, and baking soda. In a food processor, blend oatmeal until fine. Add to flour mixture.
column5: Stir butter mixture into flour/oatmeal mixture. Blend well.
column6: Add chocolate chips and walnuts. Stir until blended. Roll into golf balls size and bake for 8-10 minutes. You do not want to over bake these.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Lightly grease 2 cookie sheets.
column3: Cream together sugar and butter. Beat in egg yolks and vanilla.
column4: Add flour, baking soda, and cream of tartar. Stir.
column5: Form dough into walnut size balls and place 2 inches apart on cookie sheet. Don't flatten. Bake 10 to 11 minutes, until tops are cracked and just turning color.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: In large bowl of an electric mixer, beat butter and sugar until creamy. Beat in 2 of the egg yolks, one at a time. Mix in 3 tablespoons of the half and half.
column4: In another bowl, stir together flour, baking powder, and salt; gradually add to butter mix and blend.
column5: To shape cookies, pinch of 1 inch balls of dough and roll each into a 7 inch strand. Bring ends together and twist, to form a twirled look to each one.
column6: Beat remaining egg yolk with remaining half and half and brush lightly over cookies and sprinkle with sesame seeds. Bake for about 15 minutes or until golden.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets.
column3: Mix shortening, sugar, eggs, and carrots.
column4: Blend in flour, baking powder and salt. Stir in coconut.
column5: Drop dough by teaspoonfuls about 2 inches apart onto lightly greased baking sheet.
column6: Bake 8 to 10 minutes or until no imprint remains when touched lightly. Immediately remove baking sheet. Let cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter and sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the sour cream and vanilla. Stir in baking soda, baking powder and salt; gradually mix in flour to form a dough that is stiff enough to roll out. More or less flour may be necessary.
column4: Roll out dough on a lightly floured surface and cut into shapes using cookie cutters. Place cookies 2 inches apart on ungreased cookie sheets.
column5: Bake for 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or until firm and the center appears dry. Cookies will stay white, so be careful not to overbake.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Beat oil, sugar and eggs. Add molasses, vanilla, and water.
column4: Stir in dry ingredients.
column5: Drop by teaspoons on cookie sheets sprayed with non stick spray.
column6: Bake for 15 minutes. Cool tray slightly before removing.

column2: Cook syrup and sugar until mixture comes to a boil. Stir constantly; do not overcook.
column3: Remove from heat, add peanut butter, and stir until smooth. Pour mixture over cornflakes in a large bowl. Mix until cereal is thoroughly coated.
column4: Spread in a buttered 9 x 13 inch pan and press down lightly with buttered hands. When cool, cut into squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). In a small bowl, stir together flour, baking soda, and baking powder. Set aside.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter and sugar until smooth. Beat in egg and vanilla. Gradually blend in the dry ingredients. Roll rounded teaspoonfuls of dough into balls, and place onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or until golden. Let stand on cookie sheet two minutes before removing to cool on wire racks.

column2: In a medium saucepan, combine caramel topping and pecans over medium heat.
column3: Stirring constantly, bring to a boil and cook 3 to 5 minutes longer or until mixture thickens. Remove from heat and allow to cool 5 minutes.
column4: Spoon about 1 1/2 teaspoons caramel mixture on top of each cracker. Refrigerate 1 hour or until firm
column5: In a small saucepan, melt chocolate chips over low heat, stirring constantly. Remove from heat.
column6: Using tongs, dip bottom of each cracker in chocolate. Transfer to waxed paper and refrigerate 1 hour or until chocolate is firm. Can be stored in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the shortening and sugar. Mix in eggs and beat well.
column4: In a separate bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, baking soda and salt. Add flour mixture to shortening mixture in thirds. After each third, add 1/4 cup of the milk and mix well. Dough will be soft.
column5: Put dough on well-floured surface and knead in just enough additional flour so it can be rolled. Cut with your favorite cookie cutter.
column6: Transfer to parchment-lined baking sheet and bake for 10 minutes. I rotate my sheets, baking each sheet 5 minutes on middle, then 5 minutes on top rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: To make crust: Mix together the butter, 1 1/3 cups flour and 1/4 cup sugar with a fork until crumbly. Press into an 8 inch square pan and bake for 20 minutes. Crust will look white. Do not brown!
column4: Combine the eggs, 3/4 cup of sugar, 2 tablespoons flour, baking powder and lemon juice in a blender. Blend until well mixed. Pour over pre-baked crust.
column5: Return to oven and bake an additional 20 minutes. Remove from oven and sprinkle with powdered sugar. Let bars cool before cutting.

column2: Preheat an oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease the bottom of a 9 inch square baking dish.
column3: Mix the flour, oats, white sugar, and brown sugar in a large bowl. Cut the butter into the flour mixture until the mixture is crumbly. Set aside 3/4 cup of the mixture and press the rest into the bottom of the prepared dish. Spread the top with the apple jelly.
column4: Stir the reserved flour mixture and the cashews together in a bowl; sprinkle over the apple jelly. Scatter the butterscotch chips over the cashew mixture.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown; 30 to 35 minutes. Allow to cool completely before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch baking pan.
column3: In a large bowl, mix together 1 cup of white sugar and 1/2 cup of butter until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla and chocolate syrup. Combine the salt and flour; mix into the batter just until blended. Spread the batter evenly in the prepared pan.
column4: Bake for 25 minutes in the preheated oven, until the brownies begin to pull away from the sides of the pan. Let cool.
column5: In a medium bowl, mix together 1/2 cup melted butter and confectioners' sugar until smooth. Stir in creme de menthe liqueur. Spread over the cooled brownies and allow to cool completely.
column6: Combine the chocolate chips and remaining butter in a microwave safe dish. Heat for 1 minute in the microwave, stir, then continue to heat at 30 second intervals, stirring each time, until melted and smooth. Spread over the top of the brownies. Allow to cool completely before cutting into 2 inch squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Using a mixer, cream shortening and sugars until fluffy. Add egg and extracts and beat well.
column4: Add flour, baking powder, salt, nuts and mix well.
column5: Form into 1 inch balls. Press each ball around a kiss so kiss is completely covered (like a chocolate covered cherry).
column6: Bake 12 minutes on ungreased cookie sheet (do not overbake). Cool on wire rack. Frost or decorate as desired.

column2: Heat mold by letting sit in hot oil. Remove mold and let excess shortening drain off. Dip mold into batter. Do not go over the top.
column3: Hold in the hot oil about 45 seconds or until lightly browned. Remove and drain on paper towels or brown bags.
column4: Dust with confectioners sugar if desired. When you make the first one it's usually a waste cookie because it sticks. But after that they usually fall off the mold as they're cooking, just scoop out with a slotted spoon.

column2: In a large bowl, mix chocolate wafer crumbs, ground blanched almonds, unsweetened cocoa powder, and 1/4 cup sugar.
column3: Dissolve instant coffee in coffee liqueur and stir into crumb mixture with corn syrup.
column4: Shape into 1/4 inch balls and roll in cinnamon sugar. To make cinnamon sugar, combine 1/4 cup sugar with 2 teaspoons cinnamon. Store in refrigerator.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Mix dry ingredients except confectioner's sugar. Add nuts and dates.
column4: Then add eggs which have been lightly beaten. Mix well.
column5: Press mixture into ungreased cookie sheet as thin as possible. Bake for 15-20 minutes.
column6: Cut into 1 -2 inch squares while hot. Roll into balls as soon as the squares are cool enough to handle then roll in confectioner's sugar. Allow to cool completely before eating.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Combine flour and sugar. Cut butter into flour as for pie crust.
column4: Press mixture into an 8 x 8 inch pan. Bake for 20 minutes.
column5: While warm, cut into 36 squares. Place squares in pan lined with wax paper. Let cool.
column6: Place a cherry half on center of each, cut side down. Melt chocolate over low heat. Cover cherry with a spoonful of melted chocolate. Chill for a few minutes in refrigerator until chocolate is firm.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Cream butter to consistency of mayonnaise. Add sugar gradually, while continuing to cream.
column4: Add eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition. Add vanilla and beat until light and fluffy.
column5: In a separate bowl, mix and sift flour, salt, baking powder and baking soda.
column6: Add dry ingredients alternately with sour cream; beginning and ending with dry ingredients.
column7: Drop by teaspoons or tablespoons depending on the size cookie you want. Sprinkle cinnamon-sugar mixture over the tops of the cookies. Bake for 8 to 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, mix together the shortening and 1 1/2 cups of white sugar until smooth. Stir in the eggs one at a time, blending well after each. Combine the flour, baking soda, cream of tartar and salt; stir into the batter until blended.
column4: Roll the dough into balls the size of small walnuts. Roll in a mixture of 2 tablespoons sugar and 2 teaspoons cinnamon. Place 2 inches apart on an ungreased cookie sheet.
column5: Bake in the preheated oven for 8 to 10 minutes or until lightly browned, but still soft.

column2: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease and flour four 8x8-inch baking pans.
column3: Place the chocolate chips and the coffee granules in a double boiler over simmering water. Cook over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until melted and smooth. Set aside.
column4: In a large bowl, cream the butter and sugar together until light and fluffy. Beat in the eggs two at a time, mixing well after each addition. Stir in vanilla, cinnamon, and salt, then mix in the melted chocolate. Mix in flour until just blended. Divide the batter equally into the prepared pans, and spread smooth.
column5: Bake for 35 minutes in preheated oven, or until the edges pull from the sides of the pans. Cool on a wire rack. Cover, and refrigerate for 8 hours. Cut the cold brownies into bars to serve.

column2: Beat together margarine (or butter), sugar, egg, and cocoa.
column3: Add flour, baking powder, baking soda, and water. Mix well. Stir in pecans.
column4: Shape dough into a log 2 inches in diameter. Wrap in plastic wrap and refrigerate at least for 2 hours or overnight.
column5: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column6: Slice dough into 1/2 inch-thick rounds and place on lightly oiled baking sheet. Bake for 8-10 minutes. Cool thoroughly.

column2: Mix oatmeal and coconut together in a large bowl.
column3: Put other ingredients in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring constantly. When mixture comes to a boil, let it boil for 2 minutes.(any longer your cookies will be crumbly, any shorter, your cookies will be gooey)
column4: Remove from heat and pour over the oatmeal-coconut mixture. Working quickly now, mix well and drop by spoon onto waxed paper. Let sit until firm and cool. Excellent for freezing.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Butter a 9x9 inch baking pan.
column3: In a medium bowl, combine flour and 2 tablespoons brown sugar. Cut in butter until mixture is crumbly. Press into the bottom of the prepared pan.
column4: Bake for 15 minutes in preheated oven. Crust should not be fully cooked.
column5: In a large bowl, mix together the eggs and remaining brown sugar. Combine the oats, salt, and baking powder; stir into the egg mixture along with the vanilla. Mix in raisins and coconut, if desired. Spread the mixture evenly over the partially baked crumb layer in pan.
column6: Bake 20 minutes more. Cool, and cut into squares.

column2: In saucepan, over medium heat, melt corn syrup, peanut butter and brown sugar.
column3: Remove from heat and add cereal. Mix well and press into buttered 9 x 9 inch square pan.
column4: To make icing: Combine the rest of the ingredients. Add more milk, if necessary, until smooth and spreadable.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Place butter in 13 x 9 inch pan and melt in oven. Swirl to coat bottom and sides with butter.
column4: Spread graham cracker crumbs evenly over bottom of pan. Layer chocolate chips, butterscotch chips, and nuts over crumbs. Pour condensed milk over nuts. Sprinkle coconut over condensed milk.
column5: Bake until edges are golden brown, about 25 minutes. Let cool before cutting into bars.

column2: In a saucepan bring sugar, cocoa, milk and butter or margarine to a boil. Remove from heat.
column3: Stir in oats, coconut, nuts and salt. Drop quickly from teaspoon on wax paper. Let cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Grease and line a 9 x 13 inch pan.
column4: Combine first 4 ingredients. Take 1/2 cup of flour mixture and dredge the dates.
column5: Cream butter and sugars until light and fluffy. Add eggs, one at a time, and beat well after every addition. Gradually stir in flour mixture.
column6: Add dates and walnuts and stir until completely combined.
column7: Pour batter into prepared pan and bake for 10 minutes. Lower heat to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C) and bake for 30-40 minutes or until done.
column8: Cool on a wire rack for 20 minutes and cut into bars. Wrap individually with foil or colored cellophane wrap.

column2: In a large bowl, cream shortening and sugar together. Mix in molasses and water. Sift together flour, salt, baking soda, ginger, cloves, nutmeg, and allspice in a bowl; blend into the shortening mixture. Cover and chill overnight.
column3: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets. Roll out cookie dough 1/4 inch thick on floured surface. Cut with 3-inch cookie cutter and arrange on prepared cookie sheets. Sprinkle cookies with additional sugar (optional).
column4: Bake until cookies are set up and very lightly browned, 10 to 12 minutes. You need to leave cookies on cookie sheet for 2 minutes after baking to keep them from breaking.

column2: Cream together shortening, margarine, and sugars.
column3: Beat in eggs and vanilla.
column4: Mix in flour, salt, and baking soda. Add oats and walnuts. Mix well.
column5: Shape into long rolls and roll in wax paper. Chill until firm.
column6: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column7: Slice 1/4 inch slices and place on ungreased cookie sheet. Press with fork dipped in milk.
column8: Bake for 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream the margarine and sugar well. Add the eggs, one at a time, beating well after each. Add the buttermilk.
column4: Sift together the flour, baking soda, salt, and baking powder and add to the creamed mixture.
column5: Add 1/4 cup of vanilla (yes, this is correct) and nutmeg, and blend well. Let dough rest for 10 minutes.
column6: Drop by tablespoonfuls onto greased cookie sheet. Sprinkle with additional sugar.
column7: Bake for 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Cream shortening with vanilla. Add sugars gradually, creaming well. Add eggs and beat thoroughly.
column4: Sift flour, soda, and salt together; add to creamed mixture and mix well. Stir in oats.
column5: Shape dough into balls and put on greased cookie sheets. Make a hollow in each ball and place a gumdrop in each hollow.
column6: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the first 5 ingredients.
column4: Add the remaining ingredients and mix well. Fold in gumdrops.
column5: Drop by teaspoonfuls onto cookie sheets. Bake for 10 to 12 minutes or just until golden brown

column2: Combine the dry ingredients in a mixing bowl.
column3: In a blender, combine the juice concentrate and the raisins. Mix on high until raisins are chopped. Add the egg whites and beat on slow speed just until combined.
column4: Slowly add the juice mixture and the oil to the dry ingredients and mix until combined.
column5: Wrap the somewhat soft dough in waxed paper and chill for 2 hours.
column6: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column7: Wet your hands and shape dough into balls 1 1/2 inches in diameter. Place on nonstick cookie sheet and flatten with fork. Bake 8 to 10 minutes until just done. Don't overbake! Cool on wire rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column3: Mix shortening and sugar well. Add eggs. Mix dry ingredients together and add to shortening mixture until dough is stiff and doesn't seem sticky (you may not need to add all of the flour).
column4: Roll out on a floured board. Cut into shapes. Decorate with sprinkles or colored sugar. Re-roll trimmings and cut into shapes until all of the dough has been used.
column5: Bake on lightly greased cookie sheets for 8 to 9 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: In large bowl, combine brownie mix, oil and eggs. By hand, stir until well-blended. Stir in chips.
column4: Drop dough by rounded teaspoonfuls about 2 inches apart on ungreased baking sheets.
column5: Bake in heated oven for 8-12 minutes or until set. Cool 1 minute; remove from baking sheets.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Cover cookie sheet with foil. Spray foil with cooking oil spray.
column3: Place crackers on foil in 5 x 7 inch rows.
column4: Microwave butter on high for 2 minutes. Add brown sugar and stir. Microwave on high for 2 more minutes, stirring every 30 seconds.
column5: Pour over crackers. Bake 17 - 20 minutes (should bubble but not burn).
column6: Sprinkle chocolate chips over hot crackers. Spread after 2 minutes (chips have softened). Sprinkle nuts on top.
column7: Refrigerate 1 hour. Break into pieces. Can be frozen.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch pan.
column3: In large bowl, mix together the cake mix, butter and 1 egg. Mixture will be crumbly. Press into the prepared pan.
column4: In another bowl, mix together the sweetened condensed milk, vanilla and 1 egg until smooth. Stir in 1 cup of the coconut and pecans. Spread the mixture evenly over the prepared crust. Sprinkle remaining 1/4 cup coconut over top.
column5: Bake for 30 to 35 minutes in the preheated oven, or until golden brown. Cool on a wire rack before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla. Sift together the flour, cocoa, baking soda, and salt; stir into the creamed mixture. Mix in the chocolate chips. Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake 8 to 9 minutes in the preheated oven. Cookies will be soft. Cool slightly on cookie sheet; remove from sheet onto wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a medium bowl, mix together graham cracker crumbs, 1/4 cup brown sugar, and 1/3 cup melted butter. Press into the bottom of an ungreased 9x13 inch pan.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in preheated oven. In a saucepan, combine 1/2 cup butter and 1/2 cup brown sugar. Cook over moderate heat, stirring constantly, until mixture comes to a boil; boil for 1 minute. Pour immediately over baked cookie base.
column5: Bake for 10 more minutes. Remove from oven, and sprinkle with chocolate chips. Let stand for 2 to 3 minutes, until chips are shiny and soft. Spread the softened chocolate evenly over the top. Sprinkle with chopped nuts. Cool before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Melt the margarine and add soda crackers; spread in a 13 x 9 inch cake pan.
column4: Sprinkle coconut, chocolate chips and nuts evenly over soda cracker mixture. Pour milk over nuts and bake for 20 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Combine margarine or butter, salt, and vanilla; blend well. Add sugar and cream well. Beat eggs and blend into mixture.
column4: Sift flour with soda and add to the creamed mixture, alternately with the milk. Mix thoroughly.
column5: Stir in dates and nuts.
column6: Drop from teaspoon and flatten with glass covered with damp cloth. Sprinkle with sugar.
column7: Bake at 350 degrees for 12 to 15 minutes. Cool and enjoy.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl cream shortening, brown sugar and granulated sugar. Add eggs and mix thoroughly.
column4: Combine the baking soda, salt and flour and stir into creamed mixture
column5: Add oatmeal and chocolate chips and stir until well blended.
column6: Drop by teaspoonfuls onto greased cookie sheet. Bake for 15 minutes.

column2: Melt chocolate over low heat. Cream together sugar and butter or margarine. Add chocolate and mix well.
column3: Add eggs and dry ingredients. Mix well.
column4: Heat waffle iorn. Non stick spray can be used to prepare iron.
column5: Drop about 1 Tablespoon of dough in each section of preheated iron.
column6: Bake until cookies start to turn brown. Be careful because they can burn easily.
column7: Cool and frost with a white powdered sugar frosting. (See recipe for Vanilla Glaze.)

column2: In a large bowl, mix together the peanut butter, butter, vanilla and confectioners' sugar. The dough will look dry. Roll into 1 inch balls and place on a waxed paper-lined cookie sheet.
column3: Press a toothpick into the top of each ball (to be used later as the handle for dipping) and chill in freezer until firm, about 30 minutes.
column4: Melt chocolate chips in a double boiler or in a bowl set over a pan of barely simmering water. Stir frequently until smooth.
column5: Dip frozen peanut butter balls in chocolate holding onto the toothpick. Leave a small portion of peanut butter showing at the top to make them look like Buckeyes. Put back on the cookie sheet and refrigerate until serving.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Microwave chocolate and butter or margarine in large bowl at HIGH for 2 minutes or until butter or margarine is melted.
column4: Stir until chocolate is melted. Stir in sugar. Mix in eggs and vanilla. Stir in flour and nuts.
column5: Spread in greased 13 x 9 inch pan. Bake for 35 minutes (do not overbake).

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column3: Mix thoroughly shortening, sugar, gelatin, eggs and vanilla. Blend in dry ingredients.
column4: Roll dough into 3/4 inch balls. Place 3 inches apart on ungreased cookie sheet. Flatten each with the bottom of a glass dipped in sugar. Bake for 6 to 8 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 250 degrees F (120 degrees C). Grease an 8x8 inch baking pan.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter, brown sugar, and eggs until light and fluffy. Stir in the unsweetened chocolate and vanilla until well blended. Mix in the flour, and then the walnuts. Spread batter evenly into the prepared pan.
column4: Bake for 1 hour in the preheated oven, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. Cool in the pan on a wire rack before cutting into bars.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a medium bowl, beat the butter and sugar with an electric mixer until light and fluffy. Stir in flour by hand until the dough is smooth. Extra flour can be added if the dough is not stiff enough to roll out.
column4: On a floured surface, roll dough to 1/4 inch thickness and cut into desired shapes with cookie cutters. Place 1 inch apart onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column5: Bake for 12 to 15 minutes in the preheated oven, until the edges are lightly browned. Cool on cookie sheets for a few minutes before transferring to wire cooling racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column3: To make Crust: Mix together first three ingredients and pack into the bottom of an 8 x 8 inch pan. Dot with strawberry jam.
column4: To make Topping: Beat together the rest of the ingredients and pour over the crust.
column5: Bake till firm for 30-35 minutes.

column2: In a heavy saucepan, combine chocolate and butterscotch chips. Melt, stirring constantly over low heat.
column3: Remove when melted and add chow mein noodles. Add cashews or peanuts. Mix quickly to coat Dip out tablespoons onto wax paper. Cool. (Can also melt chips in the microwave.)

column2: Cream butter or margarine with powdered sugar until light.
column3: Mix in brandy and water.
column4: Chop almonds and set 1/2 cup aside. Add the rest of the almonds to mixture. Stir in flour and mix well.
column5: Chill dough until stiff enough to mold.
column6: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column7: Shape dough into crescent shapes (Use about 1 teaspoon per cookie.)
column8: Dip into additional chopped almonds
column9: Bake on ungreased cookie sheet 12 - 15 minutes.
column10: Cool on wire racks about 5 minutes. Option: Roll gently in additional powdered sugar after cooling.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Grease a 9 x 13 inch pan.
column3: Sift dry ingredients and set aside
column4: Beat eggs in large bowl until foamy.
column5: Beat in sugar gradually.
column6: Add vanilla.
column7: Blend in sifted dry ingredients.
column8: Mix in gumdrops and walnuts.
column9: Pour into pan and spread evenly with a spatula.
column10: Bake for 30-35 minutes or until toothpick inserted in center comes out clean. Cut into bars while still warm.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Beat brown sugar, peanut butter and margarine until fluffy.
column4: Blend in water, egg, and vanilla.
column5: Add combined oats, flour and baking soda; mix well
column6: Cover; chill 1 hour.
column7: Shape into 1 inch balls. Place on ungreased cookie sheet. Using bottom of glass dipped in sugar, press into 1/4 inch thick circles.
column8: Bake 8-10 minutes or until edges are golden brown. Remove to wire rack; cool completely.
column9: To make Frosting: Melt chocolate pieces in saucepan over low heat. Stir in vegetable shortening, mixing until smooth.
column10: Top each cookie with 1/2 teaspoon melted chocolate. Sprinkle with chopped peanuts. Chill until set. Store tightly covered.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the shortening, peanut butter, brown sugar, and 1 cup white sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, and stir in the milk and vanilla. Combine the flour, baking soda, and salt; stir into the peanut butter mixture until well blended. Shape tablespoonfuls of dough into balls, and roll in remaining white sugar. Place cookies 2 inches apart on the prepared cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 10 to12 minutes in the preheated oven. Remove from oven, and immediately press a chocolate kiss into each cookie. Allow to cool completely; the kiss will harden as it cools.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column3: Combine coconut, milk, rum extract, and ginger. Stir until well blended.
column4: Drop by teaspoon onto foil-lined sheet. Garnish each with 1/2 candied cherry placed upside down in center.
column5: Bake 15 minutes or until firm.
column6: Remove from cookie sheet to wire racks. Cool completely before storing.

column2: Beat eggs in large mixing bowl until very light.
column3: Add sugar and butter. Cream together until light and fluffy.
column4: Sift flour, baking powder, and salt. Add dry ingredients and combine.
column5: Knead dough until smooth ... add more flour to get a smooth dough if necessary.
column6: Cover dough and allow to chill in refrigerator for at least 2 hours.
column7: Roll onto slightly floured board to 1/2 inch thickness. Then roll again with springerle roller to make designs. Cut at border. Sprinkle anise seed on clean tea towel and place cookies on this. Allow to stand overnight (don't cover) to dry.
column8: Bake 12 to 15 minutes at 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column9: Cool completely. Store in tight tin container ... the longer they are stored, the more anise flavor they take up.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Spray cookie sheets with non-stick spray.
column3: Beat egg whites until frothy. Add cream of tartar and salt. Beat until very stiff.
column4: Add sugar slowly by teaspoonful. Beat until glossy.
column5: Fold in vanilla, food coloring, and chips.
column6: Drop by spoonfuls onto greased sheet. Place in oven. turn OFF the oven. Leave til oven is cold. DO NOT OPEN THE DOOR TO PEEK ... THE COOKIES WILL TURN GUMMY!!!

column2: Beat eggs until light and fluffy, gradually adding sugar ( approx. 15 minutes) This is important, do not underbeat.
column3: Fold in extract and flour.
column4: Roll dough out on lightly floured surface to about 3/8 inch. Use rolling pin to firmly "imprint" the design onto dough.
column5: Cut cookies apart and on greased baking sheet, sprinkle with anise seeds. Let cookies sit out overnight, covered, to "dry".
column6: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column7: Place cookies into oven and reduce temp to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Bake until light yellow only, approx. 15 minutes. They are not supposed to get brown!
column8: These cookies are a hard cookie, need to be stored for at least 2-3 weeks. You can add a slice of apple to "soften" back up or a slice of bread works, too. Replace bread or apple every 2-3 days.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Mix sugar and shortening until smooth and fluffy. Beat eggs and add baking soda which has been dissolved in 1 tablespoon hot water.
column4: Sift flour and salt together and add to the creamed mixture. Add vanilla and fold in nuts and chocolate chips.
column5: Drop by spoonfuls onto lightly greased cookie sheets. Bake for 9 to 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Place 40 - 45 small graham crackers on cookie sheet.
column4: Combine margarine, butter (yes... 1 stick of each!) sugar, and nuts in a saucepan over medium heat. Let boil for 2 minutes.
column5: Spread over crackers. Bake 10 minutes. Remove and immediately transfer to foil with spatula.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Brush baking sheets lightly with vegetable oil.
column3: Combine flour, salt and baking soda on waxed paper.
column4: Beat together shortening, sugars and vanilla in large bowl with electric mixer until creamy. Add eggs and beat until light and fluffy.
column5: Gradually beat in flour mixture. Stir in rolled oats and then chocolate chips.
column6: Drop batter by rounded teaspoonsfuls onto baking sheets. Bake for 8-10 minutes or till golden. Cool cookies on sheets for 2 minutes. Remove to wire racks to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream sugar and shortening and add beaten egg.
column4: Sift dry ingredients and blend with creamed mixture. Fold in figs and nuts.
column5: Drop by spoonfuls on greased sheet. Bake for 15 to 20 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Melt butter or margarine over low heat.
column4: Stir together all ingredients, including butter or margarine, and mix well.
column5: Shape dough into 1-inch balls and place them about 2 inches apart on ungreased cookie sheets. Press flat with thumb.
column6: Bake for 9 minutes or until edges are golden. Cool on cookie sheets one minute. Remove to wire racks to cool.

column2: Combine butter and sugar and egg yolk. Add dry ingredients and milk alternately.
column3: Divide dough into 2 equal parts. Melt chocolate over low heat and add to one half of the dough.
column4: Use a rolling pin and roll each half into a rectangle. Put the chocolate rectangle on top of the vanilla one. Roll up like a jelly roll in wax paper.
column5: Chill several hours, best if chilled overnight.
column6: Slice them and bake at 400 degrees (200 degrees C) for about 5 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Line a baking sheet with aluminum foil and cover bottom of pan with graham crackers.
column4: Bring butter, margarine, and brown sugar to a boil for 2 minutes. Add pecans and vanilla.
column5: Pour brown sugar-pecan mixture over crackers; spread evenly.
column6: Bake in the preheated oven for 10 minutes. Cut while warm or break into small pieces.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream together shortening, white sugar, and brown sugar until smooth. Beat in egg, then stir in vanilla. Combine flour and baking soda, and mix into the batter. Mix in oats and chocolate and butterscotch chips. Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 9 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, or until the edges are toasted. Cool on wire racks.

column2: Beat egg whites. Add sifted powdered sugar and beaten egg yolks. Beat for 15 minutes (!)
column3: Sift cake flour with baking powder and salt.
column4: When you roll them out, use just enough flour to roll easily. Roll lightly to 1/4 or 1/2 inch thickness and press design into dough with a well-floured 'Springerle' rolling pin - but don't go all the way through the dough. (The rolling pin has designs cut into it. They sell them in specialty stores.)
column5: Butter a cookie sheet and then sprinkle it with anise seed. Cut each section apart carefully and transfer the cookies to the sheet.
column6: Let stand overnight to set the design. Otherwise, they sort of melt into themselves.
column7: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column8: Bake for 15 minutes. Do not brown. Springerles are hard at first, but if you store them in a bread box they become tender.

column2: Cream shortening and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in peanut butter, egg and milk.
column3: Sift together flour, soda and salt. Stir into creamed mixture.
column4: Place dough on floured waxed paper. Roll into 15 x 18 inch rectangle (just pat it out and don't measure).
column5: Melt chocolate chips over hot water; cool slightly. Spread over cookie dough.
column6: Roll up like jelly roll, rolling the long side, lifting wax paper off with each turn. Chill about 15-20 minutes.
column7: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column8: Dough should be fine, but chocolate should be hard. Slice cookies 1/4 inch thick. Place on ungreased cookie sheet. Bake for 8-10 minutes.

column2: Mix cream cheese and butter well in large bowl until well blended and creamy.
column3: Add in flour slowly, beating well after each addition. Roll dough into 1-inch balls and wrap well in cellophane. Store in fridge overnight.
column4: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column5: Roll out dough balls flat and place a 1/2 teaspoon full of the jam in the center. Fold sides over and place on ungreased cookie sheet.
