column6: Bake for 13-15 minutes until brown and the jam starts to bubble hard. Cool for 3 minutes and place on cooling rack. Sprinkle with powdered sugar if desired.

column2: Cream together butter or margarine with the cream cheese. Then stir in vanilla.
column3: Next, add the powdered sugar, slowly, keep beating until mixture is smooth.

column2: Spray bottom and sides of a 10 x15 inch glass pan with a non-stick spray. Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column3: In a 2 cup glass measuring cup, heat the honey and 1/3 cup sugar in a microwave for 1 minute. Pour this mixture into a medium mixing bowl.
column4: Sift together the flour, baking powder, and baking soda. Add to the honey mixture. Stir well.
column5: Add and mix in by hand the candied fruit, oil, and spices.
column6: Add 1 1/2 to 2 cups more flour. Knead dough to mix (dough will be stiff). Spread into pan. Bake for 20 minutes until inserted toothpick comes out clean.
column7: Cut into squares. May be frosted with sugar glaze or eaten plain. Best if stored for 2 weeks.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Melt shortening, stir in brown sugar. Let cool.
column4: Beat in the eggs.
column5: Add dry ingredients.
column6: Add chocolate chips, nuts and vanilla.
column7: Pour in 10 x 15-inch pan and bake for 30 minutes. Cool and cut into squares.

column2: Melt butter or margarine in heavy skillet. Add slightly beaten eggs. Stir in dates, sugar, salt and vanilla. Cook over low heat stirring constantly until thick and well blended.
column3: Have ready crisp rice cereal and chopped nuts in large bowl. Stir cooked mixture into them until coated.
column4: Chill. Put by teaspoonful on cookie sheet. Chill again. When cold roll in crisp rice crumb and coconut mixture or powdered sugar.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column3: Beat egg whites until stiff (the egg whites not your arm).
column4: Stir in sugar, salt and vanilla.
column5: Blend coconut and corn flakes and add to egg white mixture.
column6: Drop on ungreased parchment paper. Bake for 15-18 minutes.

column2: Melt chocolate over hot, not boiling water. (Or 30 seconds on High in microwave, stir then another 30 seconds.)
column3: Beat egg whites with a dash of salt until foamy. Gradually add sugar, beating well, then beat until stiff peaks form.
column4: Beat in vanilla and vinegar. Fold in melted chocolate and nuts.
column5: Drop by teaspoonfuls on well greased cookie sheet. Bake at 350 degrees F (180 degrees C) for 10+ minutes. Remove from pan *immediately*. Decorate with nuts if desired.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Blend all ingredients well. Dough will be stiff.
column4: Press into a 9 x 9 inch buttered dish. Prick top with a fork.
column5: Bake until pale golden brown on the edges. Cool and cut into squares.

column2: Beat eggs and sugar with an electric mixer until fluffy. Stir in the melted margarine and anise extract. Combine the flour and baking powder; stir in gradually. Dough will be sticky.
column3: Preheat your pizzelle iron according to the manufacturer's instructions. Drop batter by rounded spoonfuls onto the iron. Close and cook for about 90 seconds, or until steam stops coming out of the iron. Carefully remove and cool. Store in an airtight tin at room temperature.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together shortening, brown sugar and white sugar. Mix in the egg and vanilla. Combine the flour, baking soda and salt; stir into the batter until moistened. Mix in the walnuts and chocolate chips. Drop by heaping spoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 8 minutes in the preheated oven, until the edges are light brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a medium bowl, bowl, beat together the white sugar, brown sugar, oil and shortening until smooth. Stir in eggs and vanilla, beating well after each addition. Combine the flour, cream of tartar, baking soda and salt, stir into the sugar mixture. Finally , fold in the chocolate chips. Drop by heaping spoonfuls onto an unprepared cookie sheet.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven. Remove from baking sheet to cool on wire racks.

column2: Mix together the sugars, oil, butter and egg.
column3: Sift together the flour, baking soda, salt, cream of tartar and vanilla. Stir into butter mixture. Stir in vanilla
column4: Stir in cereal, coconut, oatmeal, and chocolate chips.
column5: Chill for at least an hour.
column6: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column7: Make into balls the size of walnuts. Mix and flatten with a glass dipped in sugar and bake for 8-10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column3: Mix butter in a mixer until light, add remaining ingredients.
column4: Knead until velvety. Roll one-half of the dough at a time to about 1/4 inch thickness using the smallest amount of flour possible.
column5: Cut out and bake on a lightly greased pan for 12 minutes. Cookies will be almost white when cooked.

column2: Preheat oven 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter, oil, confectioners' sugar, and 1 cup white sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in eggs one at a time, and stir in the vanilla. Combine the flour, baking soda, and cream of tartar; stir into the creamed mixture. Roll dough into 1 inch balls, and then roll the balls in remaining white sugar. Place onto ungreased cookie sheets, and flatten with a fork.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or until the edges begin to brown. Cool on wire racks.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C). Grease a 9 X 13 inch baking pan; set aside.
column3: In a large mixing bowl, beat butter, 1 cup brown sugar, instant coffee powder, 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon and 1/4 teaspoon salt until light and fluffy.
column4: Stir in flour 1/2 cup at a time, blending well after each addition. Spread evenly in prepared pan.
column5: Bake 20 minutes. Cool in pan on rack 15 minutes.
column6: In a large bowl, beat eggs and vanilla with remaining 1 cup brown sugar, 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon and 1/4 teaspoon salt. Stir in coconut and macadamias.
column7: Spread evenly over cooled baked layer. Bake 40 to 50 minutes, or until golden brown and firm to the touch.
column8: Use a knife to loosen cookies around edges while warm. Cool completely in pan on rack. Cut into 48 (about 1 1/2 inch) squares, cutting 6 strips one way and 8 strips the other way. Store in an airtight container at room temperature 1 week; freeze for longer storage.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Butter and flour 12 (3 inch) madeleine molds; set aside.
column3: Melt butter and let cool to room temperature.
column4: In a small mixing bowl, beat eggs, vanilla and salt at high speed until light.
column5: Beating constantly, gradually add sugar; and continue beating at high speed until mixture is thick and pale and ribbons form in bowl when beaters are lifted, 5 to 10 minutes.
column6: Sift flour into egg mixture 1/3 at a time, gently folding after each addition.
column7: Add lemon zest and pour melted butter around edge of batter. Quickly but gently fold butter into batter. Spoon batter into molds; it will mound slightly above tops.
column8: Bake 14 to 17 minutes, or until cakes are golden and the tops spring back when gently pressed with your fingertip.
column9: Use the tip of the knife to loosen madeleines from pan; invert onto rack. Immediately sprinkle warm cookies with granulated sugar. Madeleines are best eaten the day they're baked. Leftover madeleines are wonderful when dunked into coffee or tea.
column10: Variation: Chocolate Madeleines: Omit lemon zest. Increase sugar to 1/2 cup. Substitute 1/4 cup unsweetened cocoa powder for 2 tablespoons of the flour; sift into batter with flour.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease 10 X 15 inch jelly roll pan. Place a 22 inch length of waxed paper lengthwise in pan. Smooth paper so it conforms to pan, allowing excess to hang over ends of pan. Butter the waxed paper.
column3: In a medium bowl, combine flour, baking powder and salt, set aside.
column4: In a large mixing bowl, beat butter, sugar and vanilla until light and fluffy. Add eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition.
column5: Stir in flour mixture 1/2 cup at a time, blending well after each addition. Stir in chopped nuts. Spread evenly in prepared pan.
column6: Bake 10 - 15 minutes, or just until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Holding ends of waxed paper, lift cookie base out of pan and place on rack. Cool.
column7: To prepare Glaze: In a large bowl, whisk together powered sugar and cocoa until no lumps remain. Add vanilla and 4 tablespoons milk. Add enough of the remaining milk to make a smooth, creamy glaze of medium consistency.
column8: Line a large baking sheet with waxed paper. Place coconut on a large plate. Cut cookie base in 48 (1 1/4 X 2 1/2 inch) strips.
column9: Use a fork to spear cookie rectangles; dip into chocolate glaze, allowing excess to drip back into bowl. Place chocolate dipped cookie on plate of coconut; use 2 forks to turn cookie so that all sides are coated. Place on prepared baking sheet and refrigerate until glaze is set. Store in airtight container at room temperature one week; freeze for longer storage.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Butter 2 baking sheets.
column3: In a medium bowl, cream together butter and sugar until smooth. Beat in eggs one at a time, then stir in the milk, vanilla, and lemon extract. Combine cake flour and all-purpose flour, baking powder, and salt; gradually blend into the creamed mixture. Drop tablespoonfuls of the dough 2 inches apart on prepared baking sheets.
column4: Bake until edges begin to brown, about 20 to 30 minutes. Cool completely.
column5: Place confectioners sugar in large bowl. Mix in boiling water one tablespoon at a time until mixture is thick and spreadable. (Add more than the indicated amount if you need to).
column6: Transfer half of the frosting to the top of a double boiler set over simmering water. Stir in the chocolate. Warm mixture, stirring frequently, until the chocolate melts. Remove from heat.
column7: With a brush, coat half the cookie with chocolate frosting and the other half with the white frosting. Set on waxed paper until frosting hardens.

column2: Melt the chips in a saucepan on low heat. Stir in the nuts and the noodles.
column3: Then drop by teaspoonfuls onto waxed paper-lined cookie sheet. Cool and then store covered in the refrigerator.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C).
column3: Cream together the butter or margarine and sugars.
column4: Stir in egg, oil, vanilla, baking soda and flour. Mix until well blended.
column5: Stir in the rest of the ingredients. Drop on cookie sheets. If desired, sprinkle with sugar before baking. Bake for 12 - 15 minutes.

column2: Melt butter in large sauce pan over low heat. Add marshmallows and stir until melted and well-blended. Cook 2 minutes longer, stirring constantly. Remove from heat.
column3: Add cereal. Stir until well coated.
column4: Using buttered spatula or waxed paper, press mixture evenly and firmly in buttered 13 x 9 inch pan. Cut into 2 x 2 inch squares when cool.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream together butter and sugar.
column4: Mix in egg and molasses, blending well.
column5: Mix flour, baking soda and cinnamon; add to creamed mixture, mixing well.
column6: Drop by teaspoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheet.
column7: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes.

column2: In a medium size bowl, combine the flour, walnuts, baking powder, and spices. Set aside.
column3: In a large bowl, cream the vegetable shortening with the sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the egg. Gradually blend in the dry ingredients. Cover and chill for 8 hours or overnight.
column4: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column5: On a floured surface, roll out the dough to a thickness of 1/4 inch. Cut into rounds using a 2-inch round cookie cutter and place 1-1/2 inches apart on ungreased cookie sheet.
column6: Bake for 15 to 18 minutes, until golden. Transfer to a wire rack to cool.
column7: Melt chocolate over low heat and drizzle over cooled cookies.

column2: Butter a 9x13 inch pan.
column3: Pour the sugar, syrup, and peanut butter into a large microwave bowl. Microwave on high until it begins to bubble, two to three minutes. Once the mixture is boiling, remove from the microwave oven, and stir in the cereal and chocolate chips until coated.
column4: Pour the mixture into the prepared pan. Wet hands, sling off the excess water, and press down the treats until smoothed. Let cool, and cut into squares.

column2: Preheat oven 300 degrees F (150 degrees C).
column3: Stir together sifted flour, salt, cornstarch and sugar.
column4: Add salad oil and egg whites and stir until smooth.
column5: Gradually stir in water just until blended.
column6: Foil cover the cookie sheet. Drop level tablespoon of batter for each of 6 cookies. Use back of spoon to spread batter evenly into 4 inch circle.
column7: Bake for about 20 minutes.
column8: Remove one cookie at a time from the oven with a wide spatula; working quickly follow these four steps: 1. Flip cookie onto cotton gloved hand 2. Hold fortune in center of pliable cookie while folding cookie in half 3. Grasp ends of cookie and draw gently down over edge of muffin pan to crease at center of cookie 4. Fit cookie in muffin pan (points down) to hold shape as it cools If cookie hardens too quickly, return to oven for about 1 minute. Store in airtight container.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Mix all the ingredients together with a mixer until well blended. Roll dough into round small balls.
column4: Bake for 10-12 minutes.
column5: Cool completely then roll in additional confectionary sugar.

column2: Preheat over to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Spray 11 x 15 inch jelly roll pan with non-stick spray.
column3: Completely cover with a single layer of graham crackers. Sprinkle with almonds.
column4: Combine butter, vanilla, and brown sugar in a heavy saucepan. Place over medium heat and bring to a full boil, stirring constantly. Boil for 1 minute.
column5: Carefully pour evenly over crackers (this mixture is hot!). Bake for 8 minutes. Let cool for 3 to 4 minutes.
column6: Evenly space chocolate bars over cracker/toffee mixture. Wait 1 minute and spread chocolate to cover. When completely cool, cut into 2 inch squares or break into pieces.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: Cream together shortening, brown sugar, and white sugar until smooth. Beat in egg. Combine the flour, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves; stir into the creamed mixture. Mix in zucchini, raisins, and walnuts. Drop by rounded tablespoons onto the prepared baking sheets.
column4: Bake 15 minutes in the preheated oven, or until lightly browned. Cool on the cookie sheets for a few minutes before removing to wire racks to cool completely.

column2: Mix 1/4 pound of the butter with 3 cups of flour, 2 tablespoons white sugar, egg yolks, and water. (Done like making pie dough with a pastry blender.)
column3: Chill for 1 hour then roll out like pie dough on a floured pastry sheet. Spread another 1/4 pound of the butter over dough. Fold dough together and refrigerate 1 hour. Repeat this procedure until all of the butter is used.
column4: Cut dough into fourths. Wrap each quarter in plastic wrap. Chill.
column5: Take out one quarter at a time and allow to stand at room temperature long enough that it softens enough that the dough can be rolled.
column6: Roll dough out on floured pastry sheet/ board. Cut dough into 1/2 inch wide X 4-5 inch long strips. Wrap around clothes pins or dowel pins pinching ends.
column7: Bake at 400 degrees F (200 degrees C) for 12-15 minutes until lightly browned. Slide off sticks while still very warm and then cool completely.
column8: To Make Filling: In a saucepan over medium heat, cook 1 cup milk and 1/2 cup flour until thick stirring constantly. Let cool.
column9: Cream together shortening, confectioners' sugar, marshmallow cream, and vanilla. Add cooked mixture to creamed mixture and beat till fluffy. Fill cooled pastry curls with filling.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream together butter and sugar. Add eggs, vanilla and food coloring of your choice. Add dry ingredients and mix well.
column4: Place dough in a pastry bag fitted with a number 4-S tip (the S means 'star'), and pipe out in 2 inch bars on greased baking pan. (Can also be piped into rosettes or other shapes)
column5: Bake for about 5 to 7 minutes. Put baked cookies together with jam, frosting or melted chocolate.

column2: In heavy small saucepan over low heat, heat chocolate chips, stirring occasionally, until melted and smooth.
column3: Pour melted chocolate into bowl and add flour, butter, corn syrup, baking soda, salt, egg and 1/2 cup sugar. Mix with electric mixer at low speed until blended. Increase speed to medium; beat until well mixed, scraping bowl frequently with rubber spatula.
column4: Wrap dough with plastic wrap and refrigerate until easy to handle, about 2 hours.
column5: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column6: Measure 1/3 cup sugar into small bowl. Shape dough into 96 balls; roll balls in sugar to coat. Place in even number of balls, about 2 inches apart, on ungreased large cookie sheet.
column7: Bake cookies 12 to 15 minutes until set. Immediately remove half of cookies from cookie sheet and invert onto work surface. While still hot, place chocolate-covered mint patties on remaining cookies, top side up. Press cookies together slightly so mint patty spreads out to cookie edges as it melts. With pancake turner, remove cookies to wire racks to cool. Repeat with remaining dough and mints.

column2: Place chocolate chips into a microwave-safe medium bowl. Heat in the microwave for 1 minute, stir and then continue to heat at 20 second intervals, stirring between each, until melted and smooth. Stir in sugar and corn syrup. Blend in rum. Add crushed vanilla wafers and chopped nuts. Mix until evenly distributed. Cover and refrigerate until firm.
column3: Roll the chilled chocolate mixture into bite-size balls. Roll balls in a mixture of ground nuts and confectioner's sugar, or just plain confectioner's sugar. Store in a covered container for a week before serving to blend the flavors.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: Sift together flour, salt, baking soda and baking powder and set aside.
column4: Cream together shortening, brown sugar and white sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in eggs, vanilla and coconut.
column5: Add sifted ingredients and mix well. Stir in oatmeal, chocolate chips and nuts. Mix thoroughly.
column6: Drop by teaspoonful onto ungreased baking sheets. Bake for 8--12 minutes until golden brown.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Beat egg whites until glossy. Add cream of tartar, vanilla, salt, mint extract and few drops of food coloring. Add sugar and beat until stiff. Fold in chocolate chips and nuts.
column4: Line cookie sheets with foil. Grease with oil. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto foil. Put cookie sheets in oven and TURN OFF OVEN. Leave in oven overnight.

column2: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, mix 1/2 cup margarine (NOT butter) and 1/2 cup sugar. Stir in egg yolks, almond extract, and sifted flour.
column4: Spray tiny muffin cups with non-stick spray. Press mixture evenly into tiny muffin cups. Bake for 8 to 10 minutes.
column5: To make Filling: Bring to a boil 1/2 cup margarine, corn syrup, and confectioner's sugar. Stir in chopped pecans.
column6: Spoon into shells no more than 1/2 way. Top with pecan halves. Bake in a 350 degrees F (180 degrees C) oven for 5 minutes.

column2: Mix the salt and baking soda with the flour, then layer the ingredients into a 1 quart, wide mouth jar. Use scissors to cut a 9 inch-diameter circle from calico. Place over lid, and secure with rubber band. Tie on a raffia or ribbon bow to cover rubber band.
column3: Enclose a card with the following mixing and baking directions: Chocolate Chip Cookies 1. Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). 2. In a large bowl, cream 1 cup of unsalted butter or margarine until light and fluffy. Beat in 1 egg and 1 teaspoon of vanilla. Mix in cookie mix. Drop teaspoonfuls of dough, spaced well apart, onto a greased cookie sheet. 3. Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in preheated oven, or until lightly browned. Cool on wire racks.

column2: Mix all ingredients together. Form into one inch balls.
column3: Roll balls in a mix of cocoa power and confectioner's sugar. Store covered several days before serving. Cookie can be stored for several weeks in a covered container.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Mix flour, baking soda and salt; set aside.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the egg, then stir in the vanilla. Mix in the dry ingredients until well blended. Stir in the chocolate chips and walnuts. Roll the dough into 2 inch balls and place them 3 inches apart onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 20 to 23 minutes in the preheated oven. Allow cookies to cool for a few minutes on the baking sheet before removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Beat the butter and sugar together in a bowl. Add egg and vanilla and beat well. Add the flour, cocoa powder, salt, baking soda, and baking powder and stir until smooth. Roll the mixture into 1-inch balls about the size of a walnut (larger if desired). Place on ungreased cookie sheet. Press center of each ball with thumb.
column4: Drain cherries and reserve juice. Place a cherry in indentation of each cookie ball.
column5: In a saucepan, heat condensed milk and chocolate chips until chips are melted. Stir in 4 teaspoons of cherry juice. Spoon about 1 teaspoon of mixture over each cherry and spread to cover cherry. (More cherry juice may be added to keep frosting of spreading consistency.)
column6: Bake in preheated oven for 10 minutes.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: In a mixing bowl, cream the shortening and peanut butter. Add the brown sugar, eggs, and vanilla; mix well.
column4: Combine oats, flour, baking soda, and salt; add to the creamed mixture and mix well.
column5: Drop by the rounded teaspoonfuls onto ungreased baking sheet. Flatten with fork. Bake for 12 minutes or until done.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the shortening, white sugar and brown sugar. Mix in the egg and vanilla until well blended. Combine the flour, baking powder, baking soda and salt; stir into the batter until well blended. Mix in the oats, coconut and chocolate chips until evenly distributed. Roll dough into walnut sized balls and place 2 inches apart onto prepared cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 12 minutes in the preheated oven, or until edges are lightly browned.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Line cookie sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Melt butter over low heat. Pour into bowl and stir in the rest of the ingredients. Mix well.
column4: Drop on one inch apart by the teaspoonful onto parchment paper. Bake 10 to 12 minutes until light golden brown. Let cool on rack.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream the cheese and oleo together. Add the flour, sugar and nuts. Mix well.
column4: Drop dough by teaspoon onto ungreased cookie sheet. Flatten thin with wet fingers. Bake for 10 minutes. Let cool before removing from pan.

column2: Preheat oven to 250 degrees F (130 degrees C). Cover cookie sheets with parchment paper.
column3: Beat egg whites until very stiff and dry. Add 1/4 cup granulated sugar slowly and continue beating until mixture holds its shape.
column4: Add flavoring extract. Fold in another 1/4 cup sugar and 1/3 cup finely crushed nut brittle or other crushed candy.
column5: Drop or form into desired shapes on parchment covered cookie sheet. You can sprinkle lightly with either more crushed candy or powdered confectioner sugar, if desired. Place in oven for 30-35 minutes until set and delicately brown.
column6: To remove baked kisses from paper if you have a problem, lay out a hot, wet towel and place paper with kisses on towel. Let stand about 1 minute and steam will loosen kisses. Slip them off the paper with a spatula.

column2: Mix 1/2 cup corn flakes, coconut, peanut butter and honey together.
column3: Shape into small balls and roll them in the remaining cornflakes. These cookies can be put in the fridge to firm up. They also freeze well.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter, peanut butter, white sugar, and brown sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla. Combine the flour, cocoa, and baking soda; stir into the peanut butter mixture. Mix in the chocolate chips, peanut butter chips, and peanut butter cups. Drop by tablespoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets.
column4: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes in the preheated oven. Let cool for 1 or 2 minutes on sheet before removing, or they will fall apart.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Beat margarine and sugars until creamy. Add eggs and vanilla: beat well.
column4: Combine flour, baking soda, cinnamon and salt; add to margarine mixture and mix well.
column5: Stir in oats and chocolate morsels. Mix well.
column6: Drop by rounded tablespoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheet.
column7: Bake 10 to 12 minutes or until light golden brown.
column8: Cool 1 minute on cookie sheet; remove to wire rack. Store in airtight container.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease and flour baking sheets.
column3: Melt butter in medium saucepan. Add rest of ingredients and cook, stirring constantly, until mixture starts to bubble.
column4: Remove from heat and stir briskly for a few strokes. Drop by rounded teaspoonfuls about 4 inches apart on well-greased and floured baking sheet.
column5: Bake only 5-6 cookies at a time. Bake for about 5-6 minutes until golden brown.
column6: Cool wafers for 2 minutes on baking sheet. Remove carefully with spatula and place over rolling pin, glass, or mug so they curl and become firm. If cookies harden before they can be removed from cookie sheet, reheat in oven again a few seconds to soften.
column7: Note: Do one test to check oven temp and quantity of batter. The bigger the cookie, the more fragile. Use 1/2 tsp for test.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Lightly grease cookie sheets.
column3: Mix sugar, shortening, egg, honey, and lemon extract.
column4: Stir in remaining ingredients and mix well.
column5: Roll dough 1/4 inch thick. Use cookie cutters to cut into desired shapes. Place 1 inch apart on lightly greased cookie sheet. Bake 7 to 8 minutes or until no indentation remains when touched. Cool and decorate.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Blend the above ingredients together with a pastry blender until mixed.
column4: Roll in balls about the size of a quarter and place on ungreased baking sheets. Make an even number of balls.
column5: Bake for 10 minutes. Let cookies stand on cookie sheet for 5-6 minutes before removing them to cooling rack. After cookies have cooled, put Cream Cheese Frosting (see recipe or use one can of pre-made frosting) between two cookies, putting bottom sides together.
column6: NOTE: Adding chopped pecans to the cookies without making them into sandwiches is also very good. Spice cake mix can be used in place of Devil's food.

column2: Mix together all of the ingredients and spread on cookies.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Cream brown sugar, shortening, melted chocolate, egg and buttermilk.
column4: Add dry ingredients and beat until smooth.
column5: Drop onto greased cookie sheet and bake for 12 to 15 minutes. Ice with Chocolate Cookie Buttercream Frosting when still warm but not hot.

column2: Mix together all ingredients. May need to add more milk (slowly) until frosting reaches a spreadable consistency. Spread on Chocolate Cookies or other cookies or bars of your choice. Enjoy!
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C). Lightly oil an 8-inch square baking pan.
column3: Combine flour, brown sugar, chopped walnuts, cinnamon, cardamom, salt, baking powder, and dates; mix well.
column4: Add eggs (see Cook's Note) and stir until dry ingredients are moistened.
column5: Spoon batter into prepared pan. Bake in preheated oven until toothpick inserted into center comes out clean, about 25 minutes. Cool slightly before cutting into bars or squares.

column2: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
column3: In a large bowl, cream together the butter, peanut butter, brown sugar, and white sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the corn syrup, water, and vanilla. Combine the flour, baking soda, and salt; stir into the peanut butter mixture. Fold in chocolate chunks. Drop by 1/4 cupfuls 3 inches apart onto ungreased baking sheets.
column4: Bake for 12 to 14 minutes in the preheated oven, or until edges are golden. Allow cookies to cool for 1 minute on the cookie sheet before removing to wire racks to cool completely.

column2: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (170 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
column3: Combine flour, 1/3 cup sugar, and ground almonds. Cut in butter with pastry blender, then quickly knead into a dough.
column4: Shape dough into logs and cut off 1/2-inch pieces. Shape each piece into a crescent and place on prepared baking sheet.
column5: Bake in preheated oven until edges are golden brown, 8 to 10 minutes. Cool 1 minute and carefully roll in vanilla sugar mixture.

column2: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (180 degrees C).
column3: Combine ingredients and drop by teaspoonfuls on cookie sheet. Bake for 8 minutes. Let cool. Recipe doesn't make very many, so you could double recipe as you desire.

column2: In a medium bowl, mix together the butter or margarine, graham cracker crumbs, confectioners' sugar, and 1 cup peanut butter until well blended. Press evenly into the bottom of an ungreased 9x13 inch pan.
column3: In a metal bowl over simmering water, or in the microwave, melt the chocolate chips with the peanut butter, stirring occasionally until smooth. Spread over the prepared crust. Refrigerate for at least one hour before cutting into squares.
